AMST.title: Race and Class in Los Angeles
AMST.description: Analysis of race and the economic, political, gender, and social dimensions of contemporary Los Angeles including topics such as residential segregation, economic inequality, and city politics.

AMST.title: Peoples and Cultures of the Americas
AMST.description: An introduction to cultures and people in the Americas; the social, historical, economic and cultural formations that together make up the Latino/a American imaginary.

AMST.title: Introduction to American Studies and Ethnicity
AMST.description: Introduction to American studies and ethnic studies. Provides an overview of major theories, concepts, and issues.

AMST.title: Introduction to Native Studies
AMST.description: Overview of Native American studies, including Indigenous intellectualism and resistance through language revitalization, film-making, and the recognition of one another.

AMST.title: Introduction to American Popular Culture
AMST.description: Examines the relation between U.S. national culture, race, and popular culture.

AMST.title: Sex in America
AMST.description: Explores how the proliferation of sexual cultures, identities, politics shape everyday lives in the United States and beyond.

AMST.title: The Making of Asian America
AMST.description: Historical, social, and cultural analysis of (East, South, and Southeast) Asians in the United States. Theme examined: immigration, race and gender relations, ethnic culture, community, and identity.

AMST.title: Introduction to African American Studies
AMST.description: Examines the socio-historical and political imperatives of multi-disciplinary scholarship foundational to the study of African Americans.

AMST.title: The African Diaspora
AMST.description: History, political-economy and aesthetics of the African Diaspora with emphasis on Latin America, the Caribbean, Europe and Africa.

AMST.title: Exploring Ethnicity through Film
AMST.description: Examination of the constructions of American ethnicity/race in film.

AMST.title: America, the Frontier, and the New West
AMST.description: Introduction to an interdisciplinary study of American political, cultural and social life with a particular emphasis on the Western United States as a region. Recommended preparation: HIST 200, ENGL 263

AMST.title: Documenting Latinx Los Angeles Food Cultures
AMST.description: Explores Latinx food in Los Angeles through an anthropological lens. Students experience, document and analyze local food knowledge and traditions through active field study.

AMST.title: The Middle East in Hollywood
AMST.description: An examination of how Hollywood representations of the Middle East have changed over the last 100 years, focusing on how representations influence perceptions and policies.

AMST.title: Black Music and the Political Imagination
AMST.description: Explores the changing political meanings of black music throughout the 20th century, from freedom to a threat to civil order, from racial integration to Black liberation.

AMST.title: Junior Seminar in American Studies and Ethnicity: Theories and Methods
AMST.description: Advanced study in interdisciplinary theories and methods for  analyzing race and ethnicity in the United Stes, including a  comparative study of topics such as inequality, gender, and class.

AMST.title: African American Art
AMST.description: A survey of the fine arts produced by people of African descent in  the United States from the nation's inception in the late 18th  century until the contemporary moment.

AMST.title: Leadership in the Community -- Internship
AMST.description: 8-10 hours per week in a community-based internship plus 2 hour  class discussion.  Theoretical and practical issues associated  with community leadership.

AMST.title: History of the Mexican American
AMST.description: Racial and cultural background of Mexico; immigration and  conquest; the Mexican in California and the southwest; the rise of  contemporary Mexican-American consciousness.

AMST.title: Introduction to Asian American History
AMST.description: Comparative examination of the social, economic, and political     experiences of Asian immigrants and their descendants in the U.S., 1840s-present.

AMST.title: Carceral Geographies
AMST.description: Focusing on California, interdisciplinary research teams will  study why there are so many new US prisons. What is their  relationship to shopping malls, gated communities, globalization?

AMST.title: African American Humor and Culture
AMST.description: Examination of one of several traditions of African American humor  for insights into shifting notions of race, culture, language, and  identity in and beyond Black America.

AMST.title: Latino Politics
AMST.description: Analysis of the historic and contemporary roles of Latinos in the  American political system; patterns of political participation and  representation are examined.

AMST.title: Native American Literature
AMST.description: Survey of Native American literature, including oral traditions  and print genres, such as short story, poetry, novel, and  autobiography, from 1700 to the present.  Recommended preparation:  ENGL 263.

AMST.title: Directed Research
AMST.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

AMST.title: Senior Capstone Experience in American Studies and Ethnicity
AMST.description: Writing the senior thesis for students in American Studies and Ethnicity, American Popular Culture or related fields.

AMST.title: Senior Seminar in American Studies and Ethnicity
AMST.description: Capstone course for majors, highlighting interdisciplinary study  of race and ethnicity in a comparative context.

AMST.title: Readings in Caribbean Studies
AMST.description: Surveys interdisciplinary theories and methodologies in Caribbean studies, focusing on the Circum-Caribbean and diasporic roots/routes of cultural studies (including ethnography, popular culture, performance).

AMST.title: Readings in African American Studies
AMST.description: Seminar exploring crucial theoretical, methodological and  historical issues in the development of African American Studies.

AMST.title: Critical (Dis)ability Studies
AMST.description: Analyzes works in critical (dis)ability theory and its intersections with decolonial studies, critical race studies, feminist studies.

AMST.title: Directed Research
AMST.description: Research leading to the master's degree.  Maximum units which may  be applied to the degree to be determined by the program.  Graded  CR/NC.

AMST.title: Interdisciplinary Research Seminar in Chicano/Latino Studies
AMST.description: Exploration of issues involved in conducting research in the  interdisciplinary field of Chicano/Latino Studies and guides  students through the design and completion of a journal-quality  research paper.

AMST.title: Critical Theories of Race and Culture
AMST.description: Examines the historical emergence of ideas about race, modernity and colonialism and the role of culture in shaping how we understand race today.

AMST.title: Research Seminar in Comparative Ethnic Studies
AMST.description: Examination of the historical evolution and current status of comparative and relational ethnic studies. Original research project required.

AMST.title: Contemporary Theories of American Studies and Ethnicity
AMST.description: Seminar in representative theoretical works in the fields of American Studies and Ethnic Studies published in the past fifteen years.

AMST.title: Research
AMST.description: Research leading to the doctorate.  Maximum units which may be  applied to the degree to be determined by the department.  Graded  CR/NC.

AMST.title: Doctoral Dissertation
AMST.description: Credit on acceptance of dissertation.  Graded IP/CR/NC.

AMST.title: Doctoral Dissertation
AMST.description: Credit on acceptance of dissertation.  Graded IP/CR/NC.

AMST.title: Doctoral Dissertation
AMST.description: Credit on acceptance of dissertation.  Graded IP/CR/NC.

AMST.title: Doctoral Dissertation
AMST.description: Credit on acceptance of dissertation.  Graded IP/CR/NC.

AMST.title: Doctoral Dissertation
AMST.description: Credit on acceptance of dissertation.  Graded IP/CR/NC.

ARCG.title: Archaeology: Our Human Past
ARCG.description: Archaeology as the means of investigating our shared human past, from the origins of humanity to the foundations of current civilization.

ARCG.title: Ethics and Global Heritage
ARCG.description: Archaeology and global heritage debates, laws, ethical conundrums, and stakeholder perspectives reveal goals and guiding values of societys exploration of the past.

ARCG.title: Archaeology of the Americas
ARCG.description: Pre-Columbian culture from early hunters to the Spanish conquest in major geographical areas of Mexico, Central America, Peru or the United States.

ARCG.title: Roman Art and Archaeology
ARCG.description: Survey of the art and architecture of ancient Rome and its empire, from the beginnings of the city through Constantine (8th century BCE to 4th century CE).

ARCG.title: Directed Research
ARCG.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

ARCG.title: Lab Methods and Theories in Archaeology
ARCG.description: Archaeological research design, data recovery, artifact analysis, interpretation and analogy, publication, and ethics.

ASTR.title: The Universe
ASTR.description: Survey of the universe: planets, satellites, comets, stars, nebulae, galaxies. Practical component includes planetary observations and dark-sky field trip. Not available for major credit.

ASTR.title: Special Laboratory
ASTR.description: Laboratory component for ASTR 100Lxg for transfer students with  equivalent lecture credit from another institution.  For transfer  students only.  Departmental approval.  Graded CR/NC.

ASTR.title: Life in the Universe
ASTR.description: Survey of the prospects for life in our solar system and beyond, based on the evolution of life on Earth.

ASTR.title: Cosmology
ASTR.description: Concepts of space-time, general relativity applied to an homogeneous and expanding universe. Universe's content and thermal history. Introduction to current observational tests of cosmology. Prerequisite: PHYS 153L or PHYS 163L.

ASTR.title: Directed Research
ASTR.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

COLT.title: Masterpieces and Masterminds: Literature and Thought
COLT.description: A broad introduction to the great works of Western culture from antiquity to 1800.

COLT.title: Asian Aesthetic and Literary Traditions
COLT.description: A comparative study of the Asian aesthetic heritage of poetry, painting, music, and drama; of literary themes, trends, and myths.

COLT.title: Globalization: Culture, Change, Resistance
COLT.description: Cultural dimensions of issues in globalization: migration,  diaspora, terrorism, communications, climate change, collectives,  production and technology, money and exchange.

COLT.title: Heroes, Myths and Legends in Literature and the Arts
COLT.description: Study of transformations of characters and themes from myth, legend or fairytale (Oedipus, Antigone, Faust, Don Juan, Cinderella, Comic and Tragic Twins, Hero and Monster).

COLT.title: Modern Arab Culture and Literature
COLT.description: Examines contemporary Arab state-society relations using literature to illustrate how people construct meanings and portray issues of national, social, and cultural significance.

COLT.title: Modernist Fiction
COLT.description: Study of the Modernist aesthetic in narrative texts by Gide, Joyce, Kafka, Woolf and others; possible focus on related trends in other literary traditions.

COLT.title: Literature and Popular Culture
COLT.description: Study of mass-reproduced verbal and visual art forms, such as  graphic novels, comics, animation, popular music, video, graffiti,  advertising.

COLT.title: Psychoanalysis and the Arts
COLT.description: Introduction to psychoanalytic literature on the arts, including  classic texts by Freud, Jones, Lacan, Derrida, and others.   Readings of theoretical and fictional works.

COLT.title: Zen and Daoism in Asian Literature
COLT.description: Studies of the presence and influence of Zen Buddhism and Daoism in Asian literature, with a focus on China and Japan.

COLT.title: Flamenco In Spanish Culture
COLT.description: A historical and theoretical study of flamenco's aesthetic, social, political and philosophical implications in Spanish culture. Relate flamenco to other artistic and cultural practices and questions of national, ethnic, racial, class, gender or sexual identity.

COLT.title: Literature, Theory, History
COLT.description: Examines the relation between historical and theoretical  approaches to literary works.

COLT.title: Politics and the Novel
COLT.description: Examination of the modern realist novel with special focus on the representation of social change (revolution, class conflict, sexual politics).

COLT.title: Family in Theory and Literature
COLT.description: Representations of the family in literary works and films across  different cultures and historical periods.  Readings in  anthropology, philosophy, psychoanalysis, and feminist and gender  theory.

COLT.title: Directed Research
COLT.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

COLT.title: Senior Honors Thesis
COLT.description: Writing of an honors thesis under individual faculty supervision.

COLT.title: Translation in Theory and Practice
COLT.description: Workshop in translation; capstone to graduate certificate in Translation Studies.

COLT.title: Studies in Literary and Cultural History
COLT.description: Literary and cultural currents from classical antiquity through modernity. Varying focus on specific genres, periods, movements or problematics.

ALI.title: Academic and Professional Writing Skills I
ALI.description: Required for international students whose writing skills are assessed to be at the low intermediate level by the International Student English Examination (ISE) or previous ALI course.

ALI.title: Academic and Professional Speaking Skills II
ALI.description: Required for international students whose oral skills are assessed to be at the intermediate level by the International Student English Examination (ISE) or previous ALI course.

ALI.title: Academic and Professional Writing III
ALI.description: Required for international students whose writing skills are assessed to be at the high intermediate level by the International Student English Examination (ISE) or previous ALI course.

ALI.title: Intermediate Oral Communication for ITAs
ALI.description: Required for international teaching assistants (ITAs) whose oral skills are assessed to be at the intermediate level by the ITA Exam or previous ALI course. Graded CR/NC.

ALI.title: Advanced Pronunciation
ALI.description: Required for international students whose pronunciation skills are assessed at the advanced level by the International Student English Examination (ISE) or previous ALI course.

ALI.title: Academic and Professional Speaking Skills IV
ALI.description: Required for international students whose oral skills are assessed to be at the advanced level by the International Student English Examination (ISE) or previous ALI course.

ALI.title: Academic and Professional Writing Skills IV
ALI.description: Required for international students whose writing skills are assessed to be at the advanced level by the International Student English Examination (ISE) or previous ALI course.

ALI.title: High Intermediate Oral Communication for ITAs
ALI.description: Required for international teaching assistants (ITAs) whose oral skills are assessed to be at the high intermediate level by the ITA Exam or previous ALI course. Graded CR/NC.

ALI.title: Advanced Oral Communication for ITAs
ALI.description: Classroom interaction skills for International Teaching Assistants, with a focus on the language needed to lead discussions and make presentations. Open to International Teaching Assistants only. Graded CR/NC.

ALI.title: Language Tutorial for International Teaching Assistants
ALI.description: Individualized tutorial on the language and oral skills used by  International Teaching Assistants in the performance of his or her  duties.  Based on observation and feedback.  Open to International  Teaching Assistants only.  Graded CR/NC.

ALI.title: Advanced Academic and Professional Spoken English
ALI.description: Required for International Teaching Assistants (ITAs) who, after taking the ITA Oral Interview Exam, are determined to need the particular skills taught in this course.

ARAB.title: Arabic I
ARAB.description: Introduction to Modern Standard Arabic: Development of speaking, listening, reading, and writing skills in contemporary cultural contexts. (Duplicates credit in former MDES 122)

ARAB.title: Arabic II
ARAB.description: Continuation of Arabic I. Prerequisite: ARAB-122. (Duplicates credit in former MDES 152)

ARAB.title: Arabic III
ARAB.description: Intermediate Modern Standard Arabic. Continued development of speaking, listening, reading, and writing skills. Prerequisite: ARAB 152. (Duplicates credit in former MDES 222)

ARAB.title: Advanced Arabic II
ARAB.description: Continuation of Advanced Arabic I. Prerequisite: ARAB 322. (Duplicates credit in former MDES 352)

CSLC.title: Introduction to Comparative Studies in Culture
CSLC.description: Examination of culture as an instrument of discursive practice that shapes social formations in Asia, Europe, North and Latin America.

CSLC.title: Translation in Theory and Practice
CSLC.description: Workshop in translation; capstone to graduate certificate in Translation Studies.

CSLC.title: Studies in Literary and Cultural History
CSLC.description: Literary and cultural currents from classical antiquity through modernity. Varying focus on specific genres, periods, movements or problematics.

CSLC.title: Directed Research
CSLC.description: Research leading to the master's degree.  Graded CR/NC.            Duplicates credit in former COLT 590.

CSLC.title: Internship for Curricular Practical Training
CSLC.description: Part-time or full-time practical work experience in the student's field of study. The internship must be located at an off-campus facility. Students are individually supervised by faculty. May not be taken until the student has completed at least on semester of enrollment in the graduate program.

CSLC.title: Seminar in Film and Visual Studies
CSLC.description: Intensive study of various types of discourse (film, photography, literature) and their intersection with wider social, political, and theoretical issues.

CSLC.title: Professional Development II: Writing the Prospectus
CSLC.description: Methodology of writing a dissertation prospectus; a structured workshop environment for completing a prospectus.

CSLC.title: Professional Development III: Writing the Doctoral Dissertat
CSLC.description: A formal occasion to critically interrogate the organization of doctoral dissertation and experiment with academic writing as a creative process.

CSLC.title: Professional Development IV: Applying for Academic Positions
CSLC.description: Designed to familiarize students in the Comparative Studies in Literature and Culture doctoral program with the process of seeking an academic position.

CSLC.description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units that may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

CSLC.description: Credit on acceptance of dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC.

SCDC.title: How Washington Really Works
SCDC.description: Provides students with a DC insider's understanding of American politics, campaigning and elections.

SCDC.title: National Security Decision Making
SCDC.description: Examines U.S. decision making and current and future complexities of a rapidly evolving national and international security environment.

SCDC.title: Making of Middle East Foreign Policy
SCDC.description: Selected topics offered within the USC Dornsife Washington, D.C. Program.

EALC.title: Conversational Chinese and Intercultural Communication
EALC.description: Basic Mandarin conversational skills for effective communication in familiar, everyday Chinese contexts and better understanding of intercultural communication through content-based language acquisition. Graded CR/NC. Not available for credit to East Asian Area Studies, East Asian Languages and Cultures, and East Asian Studies majors and minors.

EALC.title: Language, Art and Culture: Calligraphy
EALC.description: This course introduces students to the origin of the basic  components of Chinese scripts and the basic principles and styles  of calligraphy.

EALC.title: Chinese I
EALC.description: The sound system of modern Chinese; aural comprehension, oral expression, basic patterns, and writing system.

EALC.title: Chinese II
EALC.description: Dialogue practice and conversation; reading of simple stories and essays; comparison of Chinese and English grammar; writing of paragraphs.

EALC.title: Extensive Reading in Chinese
EALC.description: Develops reading fluency in Chinese through the Extensive Reading method, emphasizing large-volume reading with minimal unfamiliar vocabulary to build comprehension and enjoyment.

EALC.title: East Asian Humanities: The Great Tradition
EALC.description: Introduction to the major humanities traditions of China, Japan, and Korea through an examination of representative works drawnfrom literature, aesthetics, philosophy, religion, and historicalwriting.

EALC.title: Korean I
EALC.description: Basic Korean conversation practice, aural comprehension, basic grammar and building proficiency of reading and writing with Hangul (Korean alphabet).

EALC.title: Korean II
EALC.description: Continuation of EALC 115, basic conversation practice, aural comprehension, basic grammar and building proficiency of reading and writing.

EALC.title: Japanese I
EALC.description: Basic Japanese conversation practice, basic grammar and building proficiency of reading and writing Hiragana and Katakana (Japanese alphabetical systems) and some basic kanji (Chinese characters).

EALC.title: Extensive Reading in Japanese I
EALC.description: Development of reading skill in Japanese for elementary level students through short stories written for learners of Japanese and authentic materials written for native Japanese speakers.

EALC.title: Japanese II
EALC.description: Continuation of EALC 120.  Basic Japanese conversation practice,  basic grammar and building proficiency of reading and writing  Hiragana and Katakana and basic kanji.

EALC.title: Introduction to Contemporary East Asian Cinema and Culture
EALC.description: An introduction to and overview of the contemporary cinemas of East Asia: China (Hong Kong, the People's Republic, and Taiwan), Japan, and Korea.

EALC.title: Introduction to East Asian Ethical Thought
EALC.description: Foundations of East Asian ethical and philosophical thought and how they apply to modern ethical issues, such as the death penalty, abortion or climate change.

EALC.title: Language, Art, and Culture: Calligraphy II
EALC.description: Furthers students' knowledge in the Chinese writing system and develops students' skills in a more advanced calligraphy style.

EALC.title: Chinese III
EALC.description: Conversational practice: reading of stories and essays; writing of short essays.

EALC.title: Chinese IV
EALC.description: Continuation of 204, with emphasis on reading and writing, frequent interaction with native speakers.

EALC.title: Korean III
EALC.description: Drill to increase proficiency in dialogue, reading, and writing;  intermediate level readings.

EALC.title: Japanese III
EALC.description: Continuation of EALC 122.  Conversation practice, basic to  intermediate grammar, and building proficiency of reading and  writing Hiragana and Katakana with additional kanji.

EALC.title: Extensive Reading in Japanese II
EALC.description: Development of reading skills in Japanese for intermediate level students through short stories written for learners of Japanese and authentic materials written for native speakers.

EALC.title: Japanese IV
EALC.description: Continuation of EALC 220. More sophisticated grammar and  vocabulary for natural conversation. Enhancing fundamental reading  and writing skills, expanding the knowledge of kanji.

EALC.title: Asian Aesthetic and Literary Traditions
EALC.description: A comparative study of the Asian aesthetic heritage of poetry, painting, music, and drama; of literary themes, trends, and myths.

EALC.title: Science Fiction in East Asia
EALC.description: Cross-cultural examination of science fiction literature and film in East Asia. Analysis of the genres historical developments and its synergy and conflict with technoindustrial modernity in the region.

EALC.title: Advanced Modern Chinese II
EALC.description: Continuation of 304; composition exercises in different styles of writing.

EALC.title: Advanced Korean II
EALC.description: Continuation of EALC 315, with emphasis on the use of Chinese  characters, translation, and composition exercises.

EALC.title: Advanced Japanese I
EALC.description: Strengthen intermediate Japanese language proficiency.  Oral/aural  communication skills as well as reading and writing skills.   Promote an understanding of the present-day Japanese culture.

EALC.title: Advanced Japanese II
EALC.description: Continuation of EALC 320.  Improve and strengthen abilities to  speak, listen, read and write, coping with more involved materials  and situation.

EALC.title: Introduction to Korean Film
EALC.description: Survey of Korean film, the film industry and critical issues from the colonial period to the present.

EALC.title: Korean Culture from Ancient to Modern Times
EALC.description: The history of Korean literature and culture from the ancient to the modern era. Recommended Preparation: HIST 105g.

EALC.title: Global East Asia
EALC.description: Maymester Study Abroad Program to China or Japan with a focus on globalization.

EALC.title: Chinese Professional Internship: Communication and Culture
EALC.description: Combined classroom discussion and supervised internship at companies. Practical experience in applying communication and cultural knowledge in a professional, "real world" employment context.

EALC.title: Visual Cultures of Asia
EALC.description: Exploration of one or more major traditions of visual culture in Asia through cross-cultural, interdisciplinary perspectives.

EALC.title: News and Web Chinese
EALC.description: Reading selections from newspaper articles and online reports to further develop proficiency in advanced Chinese and understanding of the society and culture.

EALC.title: Business Chinese
EALC.description: Continuation of EALC 412a.

EALC.title: Advanced Japanese IV
EALC.description: Continuation of EALC 422.  Students continue to improve their  Japanese language competence in the course of acquiring Japanese  pragmatic skills and cultural knowledge.

EALC.title: Gender and Sexuality in Korean Literature and Culture
EALC.description: Examination of the changing representations of gender and sexuality in Korean cultural texts over the course of the twentieth century.

EALC.title: Japanese Fiction
EALC.description: Japanese fiction from early to modern times; literary, philosophical, and social aspects of tales and novels. Conducted in English.

EALC.title: Topics in East Asian Media and Film
EALC.description: Examines gangster films in East Asian contexts, focusing on history, socio-political meanings of violence in films by Andrew Lau, Johnnie To and others.

EALC.title: Topics in Korean Visual and Cultural Studies
EALC.description: Examination of dominant and emergent critical issues in the study of modern and contemporary Korean visual culture.

EALC.title: Topics in Chinese Photography
EALC.description: An exploration of key topics in the history, theory and criticism of photography in China, from the mid 19th century to the present.

EALC.title: Directed Research
EALC.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

EALC.title: Honors Thesis
EALC.description: Research and writing of original thesis under guidance of faculty  member.

EALC.title: Honors Thesis
EALC.description: Research and writing of original thesis under guidance of faculty  member.

EALC.title: Selections from Classical Chinese Literature
EALC.description: Writings of the important periods and genres of Chinese literary history. Prerequisite: 406 or departmental approval

EALC.title: East Asia in Cross-Cultural Theories
EALC.description: Introduction to major theoretical paradigms particularly relevant to the study of East Asian cultures. Seminal Western theoretical texts with studies on East Asia.

EALC.title: Directed Readings
EALC.description: Assigned readings according to individual needs.

EALC.description: Assigned readings according to individual needs.

EALC.description: Familiarizes advanced graduate students with topics relevant to academic work in East Asian humanities, including research planning, dissertation writing, publishing, and conference presentation.

EASC.description: Advanced-level introduction to China and its relations with the wider world in historic and contemporary perspective.

EASC.title: Global East Asia
EASC.description: Maymester Study Abroad Program to China or Japan with a focus on globalization.

EASC.description: Research skills to launch a specific research project, usually a master's thesis.

EASC.title: Internship for Curricular Practical Training
EASC.description: Part-time or full-time, practical work experience in the student's field of study. The internship must be located at an off-campus facility. Students are individually supervised by faculty. May not be taken until the student has completed at least one semester of enrollment in the graduate program with a cumulative 3.0 GPA.

CLAS.title: The Legacy of Rome
CLAS.description: Ancient Roman values, ideas, and institutions of relevance to later periods of civilization.

CLAS.title: Nature and Environment in Ancient Mediterranean Culture
CLAS.description: Perspectives on nature and the natural world in cultures of the  ancient Mediterranean from survey of sources in literature, art,  philosophy and the history of science.

CLAS.title: Archaeology: Our Human Past
CLAS.description: Archaeology as the means of investigating our shared human past, from the origins of humanity to the foundations of current civilization.

CLAS.title: The Byzantine Empire, 324 - 1453
CLAS.description: Overview of Byzantine political, social, economic, legal, cultural and religious history and its legacy today; primary sources and approaches which historians use to reconstruct the richness and complexity of the Byzantine past. Contacts with Arabic, Latin, Slavic, Georgian, Armenian, Persian, Turkic and Aramaic cultures; Byzantiums own Greek, Roman and Christian heritage.

CLAS.title: Roman Art and Archaeology
CLAS.description: Survey of the art and architecture of ancient Rome and its empire, from the beginnings of the city through Constantine (8th century BCE to 4th century CE).

CLAS.title: Ancient Drama
CLAS.description: Tragedies and comedies of the ancient world; later influences.

CLAS.title: Ancient Empires
CLAS.description: History and cultures of the ancient empires of southwest Asia, from Cyrus the Great to the establishment of Islam.

CLAS.title: Directed Research
CLAS.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.
Intensive study of individual authors, genres, periods, or areas of classical scholarship. Recommended Preparation: knowledge of Greek or Latin.

CLAS.title: Seminar in the Reception of Classical Antiquity
CLAS.description: Introduces students to the study of the post-classical reception (medieval through modern) of Greek and/or Roman culture and literature.

CLAS.title: Theoretical and practical approaches to the Roman empire
CLAS.description: Latin literature from the Augustan period to that of Antonines.

CLAS.title: Directed Research
CLAS.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

CLAS.title: Doctoral Dissertation
CLAS.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

CLAS.title: Doctoral Dissertation
CLAS.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

CLAS.title: Doctoral Dissertation
CLAS.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

CLAS.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

CLAS.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

ENST.title: Introduction to Environmental Studies
ENST.description: Gateway to the majors and minors in environmental studies. Provides students with an overview of how government agencies and societal institutions address (or fail to address) the interrelated social and scientific aspects of environmental problems and policies.

ENST.title: Environmental Issues in Society
ENST.description: Exploration of the major social, political, economic, religious, and philosophical disagreements that exist between scholars, leaders, and citizens concerning today's most serious environmental issues and problems. Not available for credit to environmental studies majors and minors.

ENST.title: Sustainable Fisheries Management
ENST.description: Examination of scientific, social, political, and economic factors of fisheries management, engaging students in key issues of coastal and marine sustainability.

ENST.title: Water and Soil Sustainability: Energy and Air Sustainability
ENST.description: Overview of issues related to water and soil sustainability including science, policy and business aspects. Recommended Preparation ENST-100.

ENST.title: Water and Soil Sustainability: Energy and Air Sustainability
ENST.description: Overview of issues related to water and soil sustainability including science, policy and business aspects. Recommended Preparation ENST-100.

ENST.title: Politics of Global Environment
ENST.description: Examines the politics of managing the global environment. The nature of ecosystems, commons problems, population and resource utilization problems along with biodiversity and global governance are emphasized.

ENST.title: Science, Health and the Environment
ENST.description: Exploration of environmentally transmitted human diseases; understanding the human/pathogen/environment nexus that leads to disease in human populations; disease transmission reduction.

ENST.title: Environmental Ethics
ENST.description: Explores issues concerning behavior of humans towards the nonhuman world. Examines a wide spectrum of ethical issues.

ENST.title: Environmental Law
ENST.description: Introduces students to central concepts and theories in environmental law and regulation; analyzes present environmental laws and regulations.

ENST.title: Systems Thinking for Sustainability
ENST.description: Analysis of the complex interplay of technical, social, psychological, and environmental factors to address real-world sustainability challenges.

ENST.title: Economics for Natural Resources and the Environment
ENST.description: An introduction to the economic tools and issues that affect natural resource use and environmental management.

ENST.title: Directed Governmental and Political Leadership Internship
ENST.description: Intensive experience in governmental and political offices. Minimum time requirement; evaluation by office and intern report required.

ENST.title: The Global Environment
ENST.description: Earth's development as a habitable planet, from origin to human impacts on global biogeochemical cycles in the ocean, land, atmosphere. Discussion of environmental alternatives.

ENST.title: Global Climate Change: Policy and Society
ENST.description: Examines climate change policy at the international, national, state, and local levels, and explores the role civil society plays in climate change politics.

ENST.title: Business and Environmental Sustainability
ENST.description: Focuses on how businesses both contribute to and can help address environmental sustainability challenges and the role of the broader political-economy in shaping that interaction.

ENST.title: Resource and Environmental Economics
ENST.description: Management and extraction of renewable and non-renewable natural   resources; environmental externalities and regulation of air,      water, and land pollution; market incentives versus direct         regulation.

ENST.title: Directed Research
ENST.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

ENST.title: Directed Environmental Policy and Science Internship
ENST.description: Provides opportunities for professional development in environmental policy and science and prepares students for career or graduate school in environmental-related fields. Students are placed in internships and guided before and during the internship period and gain practical experience and learn how government and nongovernmental organizations pursue and implement environmental policy and science work.

ENST.title: Senior Seminar in Environmental Studies
ENST.description: Students form multidisciplinary teams and are asked to study and resolve a major environmental problem facing a particular region or target population.

ENST.title: Infrastructure and Environmental Justice in U.S. History
ENST.description: Selected topics dealing with environmental issues and problems.

ENST.title: Environmental Law and Policy
ENST.description: Introduces students to the central issues, concepts, and theories in environmental law and policy and analyzes present environmental laws and regulations.

ENST.title: Environmental Risk Analysis
ENST.description: Analyzes various potential environmental risks and examines how  science, government, and business measure and prepare for  environmental risks.

ENST.title: Directed Research
ENST.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

GSEC.title: Security and Global Governance
GSEC.description: Major theoretical approaches to the study of war; focus is on recent issues in security studies.

GSEC.title: Transnational Crime and Global Illicit Networks
GSEC.description: Introduction to and overview of transnational organized crime; its effects on international security, political, social and economic development of countries around the world.

GSEC.title: Human Impact of Genocide and Mass Violence
GSEC.description: Analysis of the consequences of genocide and mass violence on human security and individual well-being and an exploration of processes to address mass atrocities.

FREN.title: French I
FREN.description: Introduction to current French. Oral practice, listening and reading comprehension; grammar necessary for simple spoken and written expression.

FREN.title: French Language and Diction
FREN.description: Developing competence in listening, vocal pronunciation, speaking, singing, International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA), reading and writing French. Emphasizes musical texts including French song and operatic arias.

FREN.title: French II
FREN.description: Continuation of 120.

FREN.title: Accelerated French for Speakers of Spanish and   Other Romance Languages
FREN.description: Accelerated introduction to written and spoken French for students with a high level of proficiency in Spanish or another Romance Language. Students completing this course may enroll in the third semester of the basic language sequence FREN 220.

FREN.title: French III
FREN.description: Continuation of FREN 150.  Review of structural patterns of  French; selected cultural and literary readings; conversation and  composition.

FREN.title: Intermediate Conversational French
FREN.description: Designed for non-majors/minors interested in maintaining and developing French language competency. Builds vocabulary, ease of communication, and cultural knowledge through discussion of contemporary topics. Graded Credit/No Credit. Not available for credit to French majors. Not open to French majors.

FREN.title: Professional Communication in French
FREN.description: Professional communication skills and cultural competency as preparation for working in an international environment. Not available for major credit to French majors or minors.

FREN.title: French IV
FREN.description: Introduction to French literature through the study of texts and audiovisuals organized around a central theme; develops close-reading techniques and discursive skills; reviews French grammar.

FREN.title: Plants, Animals and other Non-Humans
FREN.description: Exploration of phenomena such as climate change, predators and viruses, using ecological and interspecies perspectives provided by French philosophers, ecofeminists and thinkers in science and technology studies.

FREN.title: French Grammar and Composition
FREN.description: Grammatical structure and vocabulary building with practical application to written composition. Prerequisites: FREN 250.

FREN.title: Public Memory and the Ghosts of History
FREN.description: An exploration of cultural haunting in post-Revolutionary France, grounded in critical approaches to literature, with a focus on collective memory, loss and historical violence.

FREN.title: The French New Wave and its Legacy
FREN.description: Film-making in France from the earliest experiments to current trends. Emphasis on the political, social, historical context of French films. Taught in English. Reading knowledge of French recommended.

FREN.title: Critical Writing in French
FREN.description: Advanced composition through critical reading of literary texts; comprehensive analysis of difficult grammatical structures and stylistics. Prerequisite: FREN 300.

FREN.title: Popular Music in France - Culture, Politics, Protest
FREN.description: History and contemporary dynamics of popular musical culture in France, from chanson to EDM. Emphasis on the intersections between musical culture, political and social history.

FREN.title: Global Narratives of Illness and Disability
FREN.description: Study of difference as represented through French, Francophone and related narratives of disability and illness, with attention to race and gender. Conducted in English.

FREN.title: Studies in Early Modernity
FREN.description: Study and analysis of representative works and major intellectual, cultural, and artistic trends from the early modern period (pre-1789). Prerequisite: FREN 330.

FREN.title: Feminism, Gender and Sexuality
FREN.description: Major feminist thinkers and writers viewed from the perspective of the evolution of gender and sexuality in contemporary France. Conducted in French.

FREN.title: Directed Research
FREN.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

FREN.title: Choix Goncourt: Reading French Contemporary Literature
FREN.description: Selected topics in French. Prerequisite: FREN 330.

FREN.title: Directed Research
FREN.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

FREN.title: Topics and/or Themes in Francophone Literature
FREN.description: Advanced seminar with varying focus on the Francophone literature and culture of West Africa, North Africa, the Caribbean, Quebec, and Southeast Asia.

ECON.title: Principles of Microeconomics
ECON.description: Behavior of firms and consumers, functions of the price system, competition and monopoly, labor markets, poverty, government regulation, international trade, and the environment.

ECON.title: Principles of Macroeconomics
ECON.description: Unemployment, inflation and output determination and links.Effects of government taxation and spending on growth, investment,saving, consumption, and trade.

ECON.title: Intermediate Microeconomic Theory
ECON.description: Decision-making by business firms, consumer preferences and behavior, uncertainty, competition, monopoly, labor and resource markets, efficient resource allocation, externalities, and government policy.

ECON.title: Intermediate Macroeconomic Theory
ECON.description: The determinants of aggregate income, employment, and inflation; economic fluctuations; fiscal and monetary policy; financial markets; the national debt.

ECON.title: Introduction to Statistics for Economists
ECON.description: Introduction to statistical methods appropriate for analyzing economic data: probability theory, random variables and probability distributions, sampling, estimation, statistical inference.

ECON.title: Introduction to Econometrics
ECON.description: Application of statistical methods to economic data: estimating economic relationships using regression analysis, testing hypotheses involving economic behavior, forecasting economic variables.

ECON.title: Innovation Economics and Business: Beer, AI and Video Games
ECON.description: Analyze varied industries using legal, business, and economic  principles. Emphasis is on how these forces shape marketing  strategies.

ECON.title: Philosophy of Economics
ECON.description: Central topics in the philosophy of economics, including models of economic rationality, the aggregation of preferences and the conditions in which markets yield undesirable outcomes.

ECON.title: Economics of Less Developed Countries
ECON.description: Causes of economic underdevelopment: historical, institutional,    structural, ideological, technological, cultural. Patterns and     theories of development. Role of government, international trade,  and education in economic growth.

ECON.title: Economics of Transition and Development: China
ECON.description: A focus on the Chinese economy, its reform and transition to a  market economy, its relation with East Asian countries and  integration into the world economy.

ECON.title: Microeconomics for Business
ECON.description: Development and business applications of: theory of the firm;      theory of the consumer; inter-temporaldecisions; decisions under   risk; market failures; industrial and enterprise structure.        Prerequisites: MATH 118 or MATH 125 or MATH 126 or MATH 226. Not   for major credit for: Economics, Economics/Mathematics, Social     Sciences (Economics). Duplicates credit in BUAD 351.

ECON.title: Macroeconomics for Business
ECON.description: Theoretical development and significance to business and markets   of economic growth; inflation;unemployment; monetary and fiscal    policy; business cycles; savings and investment; exchange rates.   Corequisite: ECON 351. Recommended preparation: introductory       economics course, high school math, and algebra. Not for major     credit for: Economics, Economics/Mathematics, Social Sciences      (Economics). Duplicates credit in BUAD 352.

ECON.title: Money, Credit, and Banking
ECON.description: The money, bond, stock, and other financial markets; portfolio     choice; determinants of asset prices and interest rates;           inflation; interactions between financial markets and government   policies.

ECON.title: Understanding Financial Crises
ECON.description: Key facts and basic mechanisms concerning financial crises and related topics (bank runs, sovereign default decision, currency collapse).

ECON.title: Economic Policy Analysis
ECON.description: Main frameworks, theories, practices of applied economics policy in real-world settings; creating competencies for elected officials, central bank personnel, public administrators, regulators, nonprofit executives, implementers and evaluators.

ECON.title: Economic Policy Issues
ECON.description: Selected policy dilemmas in economics. Topics vary.

ECON.title: Games and Economics
ECON.description: Analysis of strategic economic interactions. Topics include bargaining, insurance, patents, voting, environment depletion, strategic trade, learning, reputation, strikes, corporate takeovers, and the provision of public goods.

ECON.title: Neuroeconomics
ECON.description: Introduction to the methodology used in experimental neuroeconomics and discussion of neural correlates of decision-making. Prerequisite: ECON 303.

ECON.title: Economics of Health and Healthcare
ECON.description: Detailed discussion of economic models, including models of health, addiction, demand for healthcare and demand for insurance.

ECON.title: Behavioral Economics
ECON.description: Examination of the traditional and behavioral theories of decision-making and the state of the art in the field. Prerequisite: ECON 303.

ECON.title: Values and Social Analysis
ECON.description: Factors that make values an essential feature of human society; how values develop, change and are abandoned; role of values in economic development.

ECON.title: The Politics of International Trade
ECON.description: Economic approaches and political processes are used to explain observed international trade policy choices. Topics covered include globalization, regionalism, labor standards, the environment and sanctions. Recommended preparation: Micro- and Macroeconomics.

ECON.title: Financial Markets
ECON.description: General equilibrium analysis of economics with financial markets; decision making under uncertainty; methods of risk reduction; portfolio theory and valuation of securities; efficiency of security markets.

ECON.title: Economic Applications of Machine Learning
ECON.description: A capstone course that introduces state-of-the-art estimation methods for high-dimensional data.

ECON.title: The Principles of Market Design
ECON.description: Fundamental principles in designing successful market mechanisms to allocate resources.

ECON.title: Professional Research in Economics and Data Science
ECON.description: Delve into data science through industry led projects with real data. Develop effective communication skills and production-grade coding.

ECON.title: Economic Consulting and Applied Managerial Economics
ECON.description: Economic consulting and managerial economic methods applied in real world problems. Economic methods to analyze issues of intellectual property, environmental damage, trademark infringement, brand value, and consumer demand.

ECON.title: Resource and Environmental Economics
ECON.description: Management and extraction of renewable and non-renewable natural   resources; environmental externalities and regulation of air,      water, and land pollution; market incentives versus direct         regulation.

ECON.title: Directed Research
ECON.description: Supervised individual research. Not available for graduate credit. Requires departmental approval.

ECON.title: Honors Thesis
ECON.description: Individual research supervised by a faculty advisor. Successful completion required for departmental honors degree.

ECON.title: Microeconomic Analysis and Policy
ECON.description: Theories of the household and the firm; product and factor markets; perfect and imperfect competition; welfare criteria.

ECON.title: Macroeconomic Analysis and Policy
ECON.description: Theories of aggregate economic activity; design and use of macroeconometric models; stabilization and control of inflation, unemployment, and growth.

ECON.title: Game Theory with Economic and Financial Applications
ECON.description: Applying game theory to economic and financial markets and interactions in a diverse set of examples like reputation, herding, bubbles and crashes, auctions, strategic information revelation and information accumulation in markets. Witnessing the wide range of applications that is amenable to game theoretical analysis.

ECON.title: Practice of Econometrics
ECON.description: Application of econometric tools using standard econometric software packages for microcomputers; empirical applications to selected economic problems of estimation and inference.

ECON.title: Time Series Analysis
ECON.description: Understanding and implementing models commonly used in time series econometrics. Emphasis is placed on intuition and application. Assists students understanding how to use time series data to test hypotheses and serve as an introduction to the ideas and techniques of forecasting.

ECON.title: International Macroeconomics and Financial Policy
ECON.description: The balance of payments, macroeconomic policy in an open economy, exchange rate determination, exchange rate systems, currency crises, international financial arrangements and monetary history.

ECON.title: Economic Development
ECON.description: Development, underdevelopment and the problems thereof; agriculture, industry, trade, population, human capital, capital formation; structural, technological, environmental and institutional changes; political economy of the state.

ECON.title: Topics in Asset Pricing Theory
ECON.description: How do investors evaluate risks? With what information? How do they form their beliefs? Via empirical evidence and theoretical works, this course addresses these questions.

ECON.title: Cryptoeconomics and Blockchain Mechanisms
ECON.description: Introduction to the economics of decentralized blockchain systems; explores how mechanism design and cryptography are used in combination to build secure, trustless, consensus-driven blockchains

ECON.title: Big Data Econometrics
ECON.description: Introduction to the theory and practice of causal econometrics in modern settings of large-scale data. Major algorithms from machine learning focused on methodology and applications.

ECON.title: Economics of Digital Platforms
ECON.description: Introduces the novel business model and important features associated with digital platforms and analyzes firms various competitive behavior and anticompetitive conducts in the digital space.

ECON.title: Foundations of Financial Economics
ECON.description: Broad training in theoretical and empirical finance. Choice under uncertainty; equilibrium asset pricing; static portfolio choice; factor pricing models, asset allocation; the Black-Scholes-Merton Formula.

ECON.title: Antitrust Economics and Competition Policy
ECON.description: Efficiency, market failure, government regulation, some basics for antitrust economics, competition policy analysis and collusion and agreements among competitors.

ECON.title: Economic Consulting and Applied Econometrics
ECON.description: Economic methods to analyze issues of intellectual property, environmental damage, trademark infringement, brand value and consumer demand, using an applied econometric approach.

ECON.title: Urban Economics
ECON.description: The role of designing incentives to reduce negative urban externalities and the interplay between spatial Big Data and testing urban economics hypotheses.

ECON.title: Directed Research
ECON.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

ECON.title: Internship for Curricular Practical Training
ECON.description: Part-time or full-time, practical work experience in the student's  field of study. Students must have a specific job/internship  offer. Job must be related to students major. The internship must  be located at an off-campus facility. Students are individually  supervised by faculty. Students must have been in F-1 student  status for at least one academic year in a degree-seeking program  before they can apply for CPT, with a cumulative 3.0 GPA. Course  does not apply to degree credit. Open only to graduate students.

ECON.title: Topics in Political Economy
ECON.description: Selected topics in economics as developed by the instructor.

ECON.title: Microeconomic Theory II
ECON.description: General equilibrium theory; existence, uniqueness, and stability; welfare economics; social choice; dynamic models and uncertainty; special topics. Prerequisite: ECON-601.

ECON.title: Macroeconomic Theory II
ECON.description: Macroeconomic theory based on the concepts of optimal growth and intertemporal equilibrium; overlapping generations models; recent developments in macroeconomic theory. Prerequisites: ECON-601 and ECON-602.

ECON.title: Behavioral Theories of Decision-Making
ECON.description: Examination of behavioral theories used to describe and predict choices made in both an individual decision-making setting and strategic environments.

ECON.title: Econometric Methods
ECON.description: Review of statistical methods of estimation and inference, linear regression with multicollinearity and serial correlation; multivariate regression and simultaneous equations. Prerequisite: ECON 611. Duplicates credit in former ECON 511.

ECON.title: Applied Econometrics
ECON.description: Use of quantitative models to describe and forecast economic activity; estimation and application of such models to selected policy problems. Prerequisites: ECON 609.

ECON.title: The Economics and Psychology of Decision-Making
ECON.description: Analyze how psychology and behavioral economics together contribute to our understanding of decision-making: inter-temporal choice, self-control problems, cooperative and risky behavior, social preferences.

ECON.title: Experimental Methods II
ECON.description: Experimental methods relying on non-choice data. Design methods of experiments that record information in decision-making and physiological data of emotions.

ECON.title: Empirical Analysis of Economic Development
ECON.description: Theory and empirics of the sources of and barriers to economic development and the micro underpinnings of macroeconomic dynamics of growth, inequality, and productivity. Prerequisites: ECON 601 and ECON 609.

ECON.title: Empirical International Economics
ECON.description: Empirical treatment of advanced topics in international finance including the determination of real and nominal exchange rates; stabilization policies in developing currencies and currency crisis models. Econometric methods in analyzing foreign exchange data and in forecasting.

ECON.title: Topics in Macroeconomics
ECON.description: Current areas of research in macroeconomics: Structural Change; Inequality and Macroeconomics.

ECON.title: Empirical Methods in Economics
ECON.description: Think about and design empirical studies in economics using cutting-edge approaches to causal inference -- structural and discrete choice models, micro-macro models and historical data models.

ECON.title: Seminar in Economic Theory
ECON.description: Current research in economic theory presented by faculty, students, and outside scholars. Graded CR/NC.

ECON.title: Seminar in Econometrics
ECON.description: Current research in econometrics presented by faculty, students, and outside scholars. Graded CR/NC.

ECON.title: Seminar in Economic Development
ECON.description: Current research in international, regional, and urban development economics presented by faculty, students, and outside scholars. Graded CR/NC.

ECON.title: Seminar in Applied Economics and Public Policy
ECON.description: Current research in applied microeconomics, macroeconomics, and public policy presented by faculty, students, and outside scholars. Graded CR/NC.

ECON.title: Seminar in Dynamic Economics
ECON.description: Topics in dynamic economics involving business fluctuations, economic growth and development, microeconomic adjustments and market mechanisms; related quantitative and qualitative methods; empirical research involving economic change. Graded CR/NC.

ECON.title: Empirical Microeconomics Seminar
ECON.description: Presentations on current research in empirical microeconomics by  outstanding scholars from leading Economics departments and  faculty at USC.  Open only to Economics Ph.D. students.  Graded  CR/NC.

ECON.title: Applied Micro Reading Group
ECON.description: Examination of various frontier research topics of economics through critical discussions of research papers that study the most recent economic research agendas.

ECON.title: Econometrics Reading Group
ECON.description: Examination of various frontier research topics of economics through critical discussions of research papers that study the most recent economic research agendas.

ECON.title: Macro Reading Group
ECON.description: Examination of various frontier research topics of economics through critical discussions of research papers that study the most recent economic research agendas.

ECON.title: Micro Reading Group
ECON.description: Examination of various frontier research topics of economics through critical discussions of research papers that study the most recent economic research agendas.

ECON.title: Doctoral Dissertation
ECON.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

ECON.title: Doctoral Dissertation
ECON.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

ECON.title: Doctoral Dissertation
ECON.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

ECON.title: Doctoral Dissertation
ECON.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

ECON.title: Doctoral Dissertation
ECON.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

GEOL.title: Planet Earth
GEOL.description: Geologic structure and evolution of planet earth. Principles ofplate tectonics, rocks and minerals, processes of mountainbuilding, continent and ocean formation, earthquakes, volcanism,development of landforms by running water and glaciers. Lecture, 3hours; laboratory, 2 hours. One all-day or two-day field triprequired.

GEOL.title: Oceanography
GEOL.description: Physical, chemical, and geological character of the oceans andocean basins. Origin of the oceans. Ocean processes and agents.Economic value of the oceans. Lecture, 3 hours; laboratory, 2 hours. One all-day field trip required.

GEOL.title: Natural Disasters and Their Global Impact
GEOL.description: The science behind natural disasters and their impacts on society, focusing on earthquakes, tsunamis, volcanic eruptions, landslides, floods, hurricanes, tornadoes and wildfires, often through Southern California-based examples.

GEOL.title: The History of Life on Earth: A View from the Museum
GEOL.description: Topically-driven exploration of evolution, environmental change, and the history of life on Earth via the fossil record with the Natural History Museum of Los Angeles as a laboratory. How the changing Earth and life co-evolved through time.

GEOL.title: Introduction to Geosystems
GEOL.description: Survey of natural geological/ environmental processes (systems) and variability active near the earth's surface in the region that houses most life (the biosphere).

GEOL.title: Energy Systems
GEOL.description: Energy resources from a global perspective, including fossil fuels, nuclear, and renewable energy.

GEOL.title: Tba
GEOL.description: Laboratory component for GEOL 105Lg, 107Lxg, 108Lg, 125Lxg,  130Lxg, 150Lxg, or 240Lxg for students with equivalent lecture  credit from another institution.

GEOL.title: Climate Systems
GEOL.description: Introduces systems behavior in the context of climate dynamics. Modules of instruction geared to climate system application to real world problems. Prerequisite: MATH 125.

GEOL.title: The Global Environment
GEOL.description: Earth's development as a habitable planet, from origin to human impacts on global biogeochemical cycles in the ocean, land, atmosphere. Discussion of environmental alternatives.

GEOL.title: Geochemistry
GEOL.description: Composition, origin, and evolution of the Earth; principles of physical chemistry applied to aqueous systems; reaction-diffusion modeling and problems in sedimentary geochemistry; global (bio)geochemical cycles and environmental problems. Lecture, 3 hours; laboratory/discussion, 2 hours.

GEOL.title: Field Geology
GEOL.description: GEOL 465 Field Geology (4, SmSp)Ten days to four weeks of field study in an area of geological complexity, with preparatory instruction.

GEOL.title: Tectonic Geomorphology
GEOL.description: Focuses on the analysis of landforms that develop and evolve in tectonically active settings through the interplay of tectonics, climate, and surface processes.

GEOL.title: Directed Research
GEOL.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

GEOL.title: Earth Sciences Internship
GEOL.description: Local, national, and international internships providing earth sciences experience in a professional setting. Not available for graduate credit. Department permission required.

GEOL.title: Senior Thesis
GEOL.description: Writing of a thesis under individual faculty supervision.  Not  available for graduate credit.

GEOL.title: Paleoceanography
GEOL.description: Mesozoic and Cenozoic paleoceanography; analytical approaches      applied to water mass history, paleocirculation,                   paleoproductivity, nutrient cycling, and paleotemperature          reconstruction. Lecture, readings, and research project.  Recommended preparation: GEOL 412 or GEOL 512 and GEOL 460L.

GEOL.title: Geochemistry Seminar
GEOL.description: Current topics in geochemistry.

GEOL.title: Organic Geochemistry
GEOL.description: Advanced course on the fundamentals and frontiers of organic geochemistry. Topics include biomarker and isotope geochemical approaches to reconstructing past marine, terrestrial environmental change. Recommended preparation: CHEM 105abL, CHEM 322abL, GEOL 150L, GEOL 412, or equivalent background.

GEOL.title: Directed Research
GEOL.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

GEOL.title: Master's Thesis
GEOL.description: Credit on acceptance of Thesis.

GEOL.title: Master's Thesis
GEOL.description: Credit on acceptance of Thesis.

GEOL.title: Master's Thesis
GEOL.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation.

GEOL.title: Earth Sciences Colloquium
GEOL.description: Exploration of prominent topics at the frontiers of research in  the geosciences, through weekly talks presented by leading  researchers in the field. Specific topics vary by semester.

GEOL.title: Seminar in Sedimentary Geology
GEOL.description: Analysis and discussion of current topics in sedimentary geology;  topics will be chosen by students and faculty to focus on areas of  recent advances.

GEOL.title: Seminar in Earthquake Physics
GEOL.description: Current research on the physics governing earthquakes and faults, including results from continuum and fracture mechanics, statistical physics, lab experiments and seismological observations.

GEOL.title: Data Science for  Climate Change and Health
GEOL.description: Introduces fundamental concepts on climate, epidemiology and biostatistics; follows with data science methods to study impacts of climate-related events on human health.

GEOL.title: Research
GEOL.description: Research leading to the doctorate.  Maximum units which may be  applied to the degree to be determined by the department.  Graded  CR/NC.

GEOL.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation.

GERM.title: German I
GERM.description: Introduction to modern German. Oral practice, listening and reading comprehension. Basic structures necessary for simple spoken and written expression.

GERM.title: German II
GERM.description: Continuation of German I. Introduction to German culture. Prerequisite: 101.

GERM.title: German III, Conversation and Composition
GERM.description: Intermediate German. Increasing emphasis on listening and speaking skills and a review of basic structures of German. Discussion of cultural aspects. Prerequisite: 101 and 102.

GERM.title: Conversational German IV
GERM.description: Conversational German in a variety of topical settings and vocabulary domains. Prerequisite: 3rd semester German or equivalent.

GERM.title: Composition and Conversation on Contemporary Affairs
GERM.description: Practice in oral and written German, emphasizing contemporary cultural and social developments in the German-speaking countries of Europe. In German.

AHIS.title: Foundations of Western Art: Renaissance to Contemporary
AHIS.description: European art and its legacy in the Americas. Painting, sculpture, architecture and other visual media considered in relation to social and cultural history.

AHIS.title: The Arts and Society in Latin America, Colonial  to Contemporary
AHIS.description: Survey of the art, architecture, and visual culture of Latin America from the colonial period to the present, focusing on connections to culture and society.

AHIS.title: Studies in Architecture and Urbanism
AHIS.description: Analyzing a wide range of case studies, this course provides a roadmap to analyze and interpret the built environment in many different eras and contexts.

AHIS.title: Art, Modernity and Difference
AHIS.description: Consideration of various categories of "The Modern" as they have been constructed in Western art of the late 19th and 20th centuries.

AHIS.title: Guardians of the Past?:Art Preservation, Ethics, and the Law
AHIS.description: Introduction to key ethical, historical, and legal debates about art preservation and collecting across the globe.

AHIS.title: Roman Art and Archaeology
AHIS.description: Survey of the art and architecture of ancient Rome and its empire, from the beginnings of the city through Constantine (8th century BCE to 4th century CE).

AHIS.title: African American Art
AHIS.description: A survey of the fine arts produced by people of African descent in  the United States from the nation's inception in the late 18th  century until the contemporary moment.

AHIS.title: Modern Art I: 1700-1850
AHIS.description: A cultural and historical examination of European art and  architecture from 1700 (Rococo) to 1850 (Realism), focusing on the  beginnings of modernism in the age of revolution.

AHIS.title: Modern Art III: 1940 to the Present
AHIS.description: Questions of social engagement and political structure address this examination of major international movements in art since 1940.

AHIS.title: Visual Cultures of Asia
AHIS.description: Exploration of one or more major traditions of visual culture in Asia through cross-cultural, interdisciplinary perspectives.

AHIS.title: Undergraduate Apprenticeship
AHIS.description: Independent work in art museums, galleries or art history related  institutes supervised by on-site professionals and USC faculty.    Not available for credit for AHIS majors. CR/NC

AHIS.title: Archaeological Theories, Methods, and Practice
AHIS.description: Various theoretical approaches, methods, and practice of archaeology in a seminar style format, with lectures, oral presentations, and museum visits.

AHIS.title: Studies in the Decorative Arts and Design
AHIS.description: Exploration of a specified topic in the history of the decorative  arts and design in Europe and America.

AHIS.title: The Art of Walt Disney
AHIS.description: The trajectory of Walt Disney's career, artistic influences and his artistic reception within a broad range of institutional contexts, including museums.

AHIS.title: Directed Research
AHIS.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

AHIS.title: Museum Educator Training
AHIS.description: Experiential research conducted at the Getty Center museum; supervised development of docent skills.

AHIS.title: Undergraduate Proseminar in Art History
AHIS.description: Historiography and methodology: introduction to techniques of research and writing. Required of all art history majors, preferably in junior year.

AHIS.title: Undergraduate Honors Thesis
AHIS.description: Research and writing of original thesis under guidance of faculty member. Prereq: Consent of instructor.

AHIS.title: Undergraduate Honors Thesis
AHIS.description: Research and writing of original thesis under guidance of faculty member. Prereq: Consent of instructor.

AHIS.title: Seminar in Modern Art
AHIS.description: In-depth exploration of a specified topic within the area of European art of the late 19th and early 20th centuries.

AHIS.title: Directed Research
AHIS.description: Research leading to graduate degree. Maximum units which may be applied to degree determined by department.  Graded CR/NC.

AHIS.title: Research
AHIS.description: Research leading to the Doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

AHIS.title: Doctoral Dissertation
AHIS.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

AHIS.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.
