AHIS.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

ANTH.title: Culture, Medicine and Politics
ANTH.description: Survey of the impact of public institutions, private interests and cultural practices on health and the delivery of health care.

ANTH.title: The Human Animal
ANTH.description: Foundations of the human species. Examination of scientific evidence from Darwinian theory, primate behavior, fossils, and the behavior of modern people. Laboratory. Duplicates credit in former ANTH 200Lg.

ANTH.title: Archaeology: Our Human Past
ANTH.description: Archaeology as the means of investigating our shared human past, from the origins of humanity to the foundations of current civilization.

ANTH.title: Global Media
ANTH.description: An anthropological approach to examine social and cultural practices of media production, circulation and consumption, engaging with a variety of multimedia.

ANTH.title: Introduction to Global Studies and Cross-cultural Research
ANTH.description: The effects of globalization on social life in diverse communities, approaching related issues from an ethnographic perspective. Gateway course for the Global Studies Major.

ANTH.title: Race and Sexual Politics in Southeast Asia
ANTH.description: Southeast Asia is studied as a meeting place of different races and cultural traditions, with emphasis on the precolonial heritage of sexual equality and postcolonial reinterpretations of men's and women's worlds.

ANTH.title: Culture, Performance and Personal Narrative
ANTH.description: Explore personal narratives: Stories people tell about their own lives and experiences as objects of artistic expression and sites for formation of individual and social identity.

ANTH.title: Exploring Culture through Film
ANTH.description: Concepts of social anthropology, using filmic representations of societies throughout the world. Gateway course for the Anthropology major.

ANTH.title: Anthropology of the Arts
ANTH.description: Addresses what it means to study the arts anthropologically. Highlights anthropological methods for examining the making, doing, meaning-making and context-making processes integral to arts.

ANTH.title: Biology of the Non-Human Primates
ANTH.description: Behavior and ecology of living nonhuman primates, with an emphasis on field studies of apes and monkeys. Topics include aggression, communication, reproduction and cognition.

ANTH.title: Archaeology of the Americas
ANTH.description: Pre-Columbian culture from early hunters to the Spanish conquest in major geographical areas of Mexico, Central America, Peru or the United States.

ANTH.title: Documenting Latinx Los Angeles Food Cultures
ANTH.description: Explores Latinx food in Los Angeles through an anthropological lens. Students experience, document and analyze local food knowledge and traditions through active field study.

ANTH.title: The Nature of Maya Civilization
ANTH.description: A seminar forum on Maya culture from the earliest form to thepresent; problems of origins, classic florescence, systemscollapse, conquests, persistance, and transformation today.

ANTH.title: Native North Americans
ANTH.description: Indigenous peoples of North America: major cultural themes, contemporary issues, language revitalization, native sovereignty, environmental issues, decolonization.

ANTH.title: Ethics and Global Heritage
ANTH.description: Archaeology and global heritage debates, laws, ethical conundrums, and stakeholder perspectives reveal goals and guiding values of societys exploration of the past.

ANTH.title: Global Studies Research Methods
ANTH.description: Methods for research in international settings including ethnography, archival work, surveying and documentation; preparation for independent projects and senior capstone.

ANTH.title: European Folklore and Ethnology
ANTH.description: Investigates the folklore of Europe, viewing European cultures and societies through an anthropological lens with a focus on shared, expressive cultural traditions.

ANTH.title: Forms of Folklore
ANTH.description: Introduction to folklore as a discipline, including folklore research methods and theory. Core course for the minor in Folklore and Popular Culture.

ANTH.title: Cultures of Genocide, Cultures of Care
ANTH.description: The comparative analysis of genocide in different cultures and historical moments as well as different cultural responses to it, including human rights and humanitarianism.

ANTH.title: Cross-Cultural Research on Urban Gangs
ANTH.description: Youth gang dynamics and their effects on institutions. Comparative analysis of Asian, African, and Mexican American gangs.

ANTH.title: Magic, Witchcraft and Healing
ANTH.description: Analysis of the practices of witches and witch doctors, priests,  diviners and traditional healers in Western and non-Western  societies, relating their practices to religion and medicine.

ANTH.title: Directed Internship
ANTH.description: Real-world work experience in an internship position, while also learning to apply anthropological theory and research methods to complete a related research project. Enrollment requires permission from department.

ANTH.title: African American Humor and Culture
ANTH.description: Examination of one of several traditions of African American humor  for insights into shifting notions of race, culture, language, and  identity in and beyond Black America.

ANTH.title: Environment and Politics in the Middle East
ANTH.description: Introduction to key environmental and political challenges facing the contemporary Middle East and North Africa (MENA).

ANTH.title: Evolutionary Medicine
ANTH.description: Evolutionary, cultural, and environmental factors in the emergence and existence of diseases; a Darwinian examination of illness in the human species.

ANTH.title: Thesis Seminar in Ethnographic Analysis
ANTH.description: Social analysis of qualitative and ethnographic research data, advanced ethnographic writing and representation. Capstone course for Anthropology Major.

ANTH.title: Multimodal Methods in Visual Anthropology
ANTH.description: Projects in practicing anthropology across multiple media, making ethnographic research and anthropological knowledge collaborative, public and scalable in new ways.

ANTH.title: Global Studies Capstone Seminar
ANTH.description: Provides senior Global Studies majors with the practical and theoretical skills needed to complete the required Senior Capstone project in Global Studies.

ANTH.title: Directed Research for Honors
ANTH.description: Individually guided research and readings culminating in the production of an honors thesis. prerequisite: 3.0 gpa; 201g plus 8 units of upper division ANTH courses.

ANTH.title: Contemporary Theory in Anthropology
ANTH.description: Explores the emergence and transformation of modern anthropology as an empirically based, but theoretically informed, practice of knowledge production about human sociality and culture.

ANTH.title: Graduate Seminar in Medical Anthropology
ANTH.description: Examines issues in the anthropology of health, illness, medicine and the contemporary biosciences.

ANTH.title: Directed Research
ANTH.description: Research conducted at the master's or pre-PhD candidacy level. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded C/NC.

ANTH.title: Experiments in Ethnography
ANTH.description: A practice based course that explores different modalities of rendering ethnographic experience.

ANTH.title: Seminar on Nationalism and Ethnicity
ANTH.description: Cross-cultural analysis of nationalism and ethnicity from an  ethnographic perspective.  Graduate standing.

ANTH.title: Research
ANTH.description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum number of units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

GR.title: Greek I
GR.description: Essentials of classical Greek grammar and vocabulary.

GR.title: Greek III
GR.description: Reading Greek literature.  Introduction to reading and translation  of classical Greek prose and poetry.  Extensive grammar review.

GR.title: Aristophanes
GR.description: A study of at least three comedies.

GR.title: Readings in Greek Literature
GR.description: Readings in various authors and genres of Greek literature.

HEBR.title: Hebrew II
HEBR.description: A continuation of Hebrew I. Offers a higher level of skill development in reading, writing and conversation. Prerequisite: HEBR 120.

HEBR.title: Modern Hebrew Language (Hebrew IV)
HEBR.description: Examines Hebrew in depth and introduces students to Modern Hebrew literature through major poems, novels and films from the 20th and 21st centuries. Prerequisite: HEBR 220.

HIST.title: The Worlds of Medieval Europe
HIST.description: The social, political, religious, intellectual and cultural landscapes of Europe and the Mediterranean, c. 300 to c. 1400.

HIST.title: The Emergence of Modern Europe
HIST.description: Political, intellectual, and cultural developments in Europe,1300-1815. Renaissance and Reformation; absolute monarchy,scientific changes, and Enlightenment; French Revolution andNapoleon.

HIST.title: Modern Europe
HIST.description: The Enlightenment, French Revolution, industrialization, Darwinism, socialism, nationalism, technological revolutions, mass culture, imperialism, race, fascism, communism, world wars, genocide, migration, the Cold War, terrorism.

HIST.title: Introduction to the History of Japan
HIST.description: Japan from the earliest times to the present; social, cultural,and political dimensions.

HIST.title: Histories of South Asia
HIST.description: History of South Asia from the tenth century to the present day; examines imperialism, capitalism, nationalism, and immigration.

HIST.title: African History Since 1880
HIST.description: Surveys the social, economic and political lives of Africans since the imposition of European colonial rule in the late nineteenth century.

HIST.title: The Arts and Society in Latin America, Colonial  to Contemporary
HIST.description: Survey of the art, architecture, and visual culture of Latin America from the colonial period to the present, focusing on connections to culture and society.

HIST.title: Approaches to History
HIST.description: Methods and theories of historical interpretation of evidence; uses of archives; modes of presenting the past to the public. Required of all History majors. Duplicates credit in former HIST-300.

HIST.title: Race in America
HIST.description: Examines the origins of the idea of race and how this idea influenced the development of the United States from the colonial period to the present day.

HIST.title: Film, Power, and American History
HIST.description: U.S. motion pictures as both a response to and comment upon major events, problems, and themes in 20th century America.

HIST.title: The Byzantine Empire, 324 - 1453
HIST.description: Overview of Byzantine political, social, economic, legal, cultural and religious history and its legacy today; primary sources and approaches which historians use to reconstruct the richness and complexity of the Byzantine past. Contacts with Arabic, Latin, Slavic, Georgian, Armenian, Persian, Turkic and Aramaic cultures; Byzantiums own Greek, Roman and Christian heritage.

HIST.title: Ottomans and Empire: Anatolia, the Middle East,  and the Mediterranean World
HIST.description: Overview of the history of the Ottomans and their imperial subjects.

HIST.title: The Renaissance
HIST.description: The flowering of arts, literature, and learning at the end of the Middle Ages.

HIST.title: History of China Since 1800
HIST.description: Western impact and dynastic decline; problems of the Chinese Republic; nationalism and communism.

HIST.title: The American Civil War
HIST.description: The causes, course, campaigns, and consequences of the American Civil War, 1861-1865.

HIST.title: The African-American Experience
HIST.description: An historical and social analysis of the African- American experience from Colonial times to the present.

HIST.title: Religion and Difference in the Modern Middle East
HIST.description: Introduction to the diversity of religions in the Middle East and how they have responded to imperialism, colonialism and nationalism in the modern period.

HIST.title: History of the Mexican American
HIST.description: Racial and cultural background of Mexico; immigration and  conquest; the Mexican in California and the southwest; the rise of  contemporary Mexican-American consciousness.

HIST.title: Introduction to Asian American History
HIST.description: Comparative examination of the social, economic, and political     experiences of Asian immigrants and their descendants in the U.S., 1840s-present.

HIST.title: Modern Iran
HIST.description: History and culture of modern Iran from the nineteenth century to present through historical and ethnographic approaches to Iran today, richly contextualizing events and people.

HIST.title: Quantitative Historical Analysis
HIST.description: Reading and doing quantitative research with historical data. Covers research designs, appropriate statistical analysis, and software packages for the use of historians.

HIST.title: Gender, Madness and Modernism in Freud's Vienna
HIST.description: An exploration of modernism, madness, Jews and politics in Vienna around 1900 which foregrounds women, gender and sexuality. Includes international travel to Vienna.

HIST.title: Carolingian Europe
HIST.description: Political, religious, and intellectual culture of England and the  Continent in the 8th and 9th centuries.

HIST.title: Histories of the Apocalypse
HIST.description: A historical overview of apocalyptic hopes and fears, from Revelations to the present. New World explorations, utopian communes, nuclear war, zombies, climate change.

HIST.title: The History of Drink
HIST.description: Explores the history of different beverages to show how commodities alter societies and how attitudes towards them reflect social norms and tensions.

HIST.title: War and Peace in Medieval Japan
HIST.description: Medieval Japan, focus on war, cultural flourishing, historical memory.

HIST.title: Defeat and Occupation in Modern Japan
HIST.description: History of the Allied Occupation of Japan after the Second World War, with particular focus on democratic reforms, war crime trials, gender and popular culture

HIST.title: The Spanish Inquisition in the Early Modern Hispanic World
HIST.description: The Spanish Inquisition in Spain and Colonial Latin America, major  theories and interpretations.  Junior or senior standing  recommended.

HIST.title: Directed Research
HIST.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

HIST.title: Honors Thesis
HIST.description: Writing of the honors thesis; for students in the History Honors Program.

HIST.title: Law, History and Culture Honors Thesis Seminar
HIST.description: Writing of the honors thesis; capstone for students in the Law, History and Culture major.

HIST.title: America 250: Telling the Story of the United States,         1776-2026
HIST.description: Advanced study in historical analysis and writing on selected topics and themes. Seminar enrollment limited to 15 students. Recommended preparation: HIST 201

HIST.title: Studies in Later Medieval History
HIST.description: Intensive study of subjects selected from the later Middle Ages, emphasizing source material, bibliography, and historiographic problems.

HIST.title: Global Borderlands
HIST.description: Introduction to the scholarship and methodologies of borderlands history across various geographic regions.

HIST.title: Studies in the American West
HIST.description: Zones of contact -- physical, economic, political, ecological, symbolic, cultural, metaphorical -- between peoples "west" of the Eurasian land mass since the rise of capitalist global expansion.

HIST.title: Studies in the Politics of American Popular Culture
HIST.description: Selected themes, theories, and key works in the politics of  American popular culture.

HIST.title: Directed Research
HIST.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

HIST.title: Master's Thesis
HIST.description: Credit on acceptance of thesis. Graded IP/CR/NC

HIST.title: Master's Thesis
HIST.description: Credit on acceptance of thesis. Graded IP/CR/NC

HIST.title: Master's Thesis
HIST.description: Credit on acceptance of Thesis. Graded CR/NC.

HIST.title: Practicum in Teaching the Liberal Arts
HIST.description: Basic principles of history pedagogy, with emphasis on practical applications and the importance of career-long skill development. Required for first semester teaching assistants in history. Graded CR/NC.

HIST.title: History Research Seminar
HIST.description: Provides a framework for students in history and neighboring fields to conduct research based on primary source materials and the relevant historical literature.

HIST.title: Historical Explanation and Research Design
HIST.description: Designed for all doctoral candidates in their last year of course  work, this practicum helps students define a dissertation topic  and produce a prospectus.

HIST.title: Research
HIST.description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

INDS.title: Topical and Multidisciplinary Seminars
INDS.description: Small group investigation from an interdisciplinary perspective.

INDS.title: Directed Research and Tutorials
INDS.description: Research and Study with LAS Faculty Associates and other faculty.

INDS.title: Field Study
INDS.description: In-service experience in a variety of off-campus institutions     under the supervision of an LAS Faculty Associate.

INDS.description: Small group investigation from an interdisciplinary perspective.

INDS.description: Research and study with LAS Faculty Associates and other faculty.

INDS.title: Field Study
INDS.description: In-service experience in a variety of off-campus institutions under the supervision of an LAS Faculty Associate.

INDS.title: Topical and Multidisciplinary Seminars
INDS.description: Small group investigation from an interdisciplinary perspective.

INDS.title: Directed Research and Tutorials
INDS.description: Research and study with LAS Faculty Associates and other faculty.

INDS.title: Field Study
INDS.description: In-service experience in a variety of off-campus institutions under the supervision of an LAS Faculty Associate.

INDS.title: Senior Thesis
INDS.description: Writing the IDM senior thesis under the supervision of a faculty guidance committee.

IR.title: International Relations
IR.description: Basic concepts of world affairs for non-majors. Development ofcompetency to understand and critically evaluate global relationsand international events, stressing empirical approaches. Not available for major credit.

IR.title: Environmental Issues in Society
IR.description: Exploration of the major social, political, economic, religious, and philosophical disagreements that exist between scholars, leaders, and citizens concerning today's most serious environmental issues and problems. Not available for credit to environmental studies majors and minors.

IR.title: International Relations: Introductory Analysis
IR.description: Comprehensive introduction to contending theoretical and analytical approaches; development of critical, evaluative, cognitive, and analytical competencies regarding historical and contemporary issues.

IR.title: International Relations: Approaches to Research
IR.description: Introduction to theoretically oriented research approaches and designs; emphasis on the logic of argumentation.

IR.title: Historical Approaches to International Relations
IR.description: Introduction to historical research methods with an emphasis on historical texts and modes of discourse.

IR.title: National Intelligence and the Shaping of Policy
IR.description: The focus is intelligence to improve the making of policy, with attention to collection; overt and covert, operations; domestic intelligence; and oversight in democracies.

IR.title: International Organizations
IR.description: The emergence of international organizations as a permanent feature in world politics; role of the United Nations Organization as well as regional international organizations.

IR.title: Coercion in the Globalized Economy
IR.description: Analysis of recent events, forces, and conditions in the international political system.

IR.title: Economic Globalization
IR.description: Globalization makes national borders and regulations increasingly obsolete. Analyzes the economic foundation of globalization, its consequences and efforts to manage it.

IR.title: Peace and Conflict Studies
IR.description: Interdisciplinary study of the pursuit of peace, including causes of wars, arms races, conflict resolution, peace movements, nonviolent resistance, and peace with justice.

IR.title: Introduction to Data Analysis
IR.description: Introduction to statistical analysis with R, with applications to the study of International Relations: data manipulation, hypothesis testing, regression, causality, text analysis, visualization, and network analysis.

IR.title: Human Security and Humanitarian Intervention
IR.description: Explore causes of human security, international  responses to issues like violence, displacement and climate change; and the costs, benefits and effects of humanitarian intervention.

IR.title: Technology and International Relations
IR.description: Impact of technological advances to global security and development. Focus on surveillance and cyber conflict; nuclear weaponry, aviation and UAVs missiles and BMD; submarines and ASW.

IR.title: Civil War, Peace Building and International Intervention
IR.description: Examination of the causes of civil war, the dynamics and consequences of civil war and how peace is or is not built.

IR.title: Politics of Global Environment
IR.description: Examines the politics of managing the global environment. The nature of ecosystems, commons problems, population and resource utilization problems along with biodiversity and global governance are emphasized.

IR.title: Politics of the World Economy
IR.description: Exploration of questions and concepts in international economics and politics, especially as they relate to flows of trade, capital, people, and problems across borders.

IR.title: The Global Economy 2040
IR.description: Examination of key ideas from economics, demography and technology. Guest lecturers illuminate possible conditions of the Global Economy in 2040.

IR.title: Money, Guns and Oil
IR.description: Introduction to the relationship between economics, security, and U.S. foreign policy. Topics covered: U.S. grand strategy, Chinas rise, energy security, resource competition, and the resource curse.

IR.title: China in International Affairs
IR.description: Economic reform, the open door, and China's changing role in the  international system.  Relations with the United States, Japan,  and other key powers in Asia.  Tensions between the interests of  American business and the human rights community over China policy.

IR.title: The Political Economy of China
IR.description: Sources, consequences, challenges to China's economic growth, including rural and urban economies, entrepreneurship, central and local governments, inequality, trade, investment, finance, demographics, and the environment.

IR.title: U.S. Foreign Policy Since World War II
IR.description: Analysis of U.S. foreign policy since 1945 as a basis for understanding significant new trends. Explanation of contemporary issues in U.S. relations with other nations.

IR.title: Russian and Post-Soviet Foreign Policy
IR.description: Overview of Tsarist and Soviet experience as background to detailed examination of the political, economic and ideological forces behind contemporary Russian foreign policy.

IR.title: Power and Authority in the Middle East
IR.description: A comparative examination of social relations of power and institutions with a special focus on intellectual traditions, the law, and social movements.

IR.title: The United States and the Middle East
IR.description: Critical perspectives on U.S. relations with the Middle East, including the discourses surrounding democracy and globalization.

IR.title: The International Relations of the Contemporary Middle East
IR.description: Introduction to problems and issues in the Middle East today: religio-ethnic rivalries, conflicting nationalisms and ideologies, the Arab-Israeli conflict, Middle East oil.

IR.title: Middle East Political Economy
IR.description: Examination of general economic development issues: population, agriculture, industrialization, trade, oil, etc. Several Mideast case study countries are then explored in depth.

IR.title: Politics and Democracy in Latin America
IR.description: Examines Latin America's experience with democracy emphasizing  events since the 1980s.  Analyzes the roles of interest groups,  ideology, domestic politics, bureaucratic processes, perceptions  and analogical reasoning.

IR.title: Mexico and its Relations with the United States
IR.description: Analysis of Mexico and U.S.-Mexico relations, both historically and in the present day, to understand better the challenges in this key bilateral relationship.

IR.title: Conflict Mediation and Negotiation
IR.description: Focuses on the international politics of resolving crises.  Application of theories of conflict and negotiation in a UN  Security Council Simulation.

IR.title: Terrorism and Counterterrorism
IR.description: Examination of terrorism and responses to terrorism, including how societies understand and deal with terrorism; focus on ethical and normative issues.

IR.title: Directed International Relations Field Study
IR.description: Intensive internship experience in international relations professional areas with academic research component (may be repeated for credit different semesters)

IR.title: Chinese Foreign Policy
IR.description: The domestic and international sources of Chinese foreign policy; political, military, and economic issues in China's relations with its neighbors.

IR.title: Environment and Politics in the Middle East
IR.description: Introduction to key environmental and political challenges facing the contemporary Middle East and North Africa (MENA).

IR.title: Applied Data Science for International Relations 2
IR.description: Intermediate statistical computing and data visualization in R. Focus the on graphical presentation of complex statistical relationships. Students create publication-ready figures for actual faculty research projects.

IR.title: Political Economy of Corruption
IR.description: Examines causes, consequences and how to combat corruption as an economic, political and social problem.

IR.title: The New Triangle: China, the U.S. and Latin America
IR.description: China's rise in the international political economy raises policy research questions, including an analysis of how this trend relates to U.S and Latin American relations. Recommended preparation: Micro and macro economics

IR.title: Seminar on Economics and Security
IR.description: Introduction to important economic issue areas that are understood as security-related in the contemporary world: population, food, trade, debt, etc.

IR.title: The Politics of International Trade
IR.description: Economic approaches and political processes are used to explain observed international trade policy choices. Topics covered include globalization, regionalism, labor standards, the environment and sanctions. Recommended preparation: Micro- and Macroeconomics.

IR.title: Comparative Genocide
IR.description: An interdisciplinary treatment of the tragic phenomenon of genocide. Subject matter includes historical cases and analysis of contemporary global efforts toward prevention.

IR.title: Directed Research
IR.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

JS.title: Jewish History
JS.description: Major ideas, personalities, and movements in Jewish history from antiquity to the present in light of the interaction of the Jews with the general culture.

JS.title: Judaism
JS.description: Jewish beliefs, practices, and history from the biblical period to the present; Judaic contributions to Western civilization.

JS.title: The Holocaust
JS.description: Historical background and responses to the Holocaust, withspecial emphasis on ethical implications.

JS.title: The Eastern European Jewish Experience: Literature and Film
JS.description: Analyzes works by different artists -- writers, filmmakers, painters -- in order to understand the significant contribution that the Jewish experience in Eastern Europe has made to Jewish communities worldwide.

JS.title: The Sephardic World
JS.description: Sephardic Jews trace their ancestry to medieval Iberia and now  comprise a global diaspora. Explore the creation and expansion of  the Sephardic diaspora.

JS.title: Jewish Names: People, Families, Pets and Organizations
JS.description: Introduces history and customs related to Jewish names, from individuals to organizations to places by discussing name popularity, histories of name changing and naming rituals.

JS.title: Mixing and Matching: Intermarriage in 21st Century
JS.description: An investigation into inter-ethnic, interracial, and inter-religious marriage in the 21st century.

JS.title: Judaism as an American Religion
JS.description: The development of American expressions of Judaism as part of the American religious context, from the perspective of the social scientific study of religion.

JS.title: Directed Research
JS.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

JS.title: Directed Research
JS.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

LAT.title: Latin I
LAT.description: Essentials of Latin grammar and vocabulary.

LAT.title: Latin II
LAT.description: Essentials of Latin grammar and vocabulary, continued.  Basic  reading skills.

LAT.title: Latin III
LAT.description: Reading Latin literature.  Introduction to reading and translation  of classical Latin prose and poetry.  Extensive grammar review.

LAT.title: Ovid and Classical Mythology
LAT.description: Selections from the Metamorphoses and Fasti; collateral reading on classical mythology.

SWMS.title: Identity Development of the Contemporary Female
SWMS.description: Exploration of identity development in terms of social, political, and cultural constructs; examination of collegiate athletics and the contributions of women of color.

SWMS.title: Introduction to Gender and Sexuality: American Perspectives
SWMS.description: Examination of how gender and sexuality have been constructed, experienced and legislated.

SWMS.title: Introduction to Feminist Theory
SWMS.description: Emergence of feminist thought from the Enlightenment to the present; historical development of female subjectivity; advancement of womens rights; feminisms from alternative ideological perspectives.

SWMS.title: Introduction to Queer Theory
SWMS.description: Genealogies of queer theory, from psychoanalytic theories to feminism and post-structuralism; evolving concepts of gender; relation to social justice, resistance and power.

SWMS.title: Death and Gender in Urban Contexts
SWMS.description: Experiential course examining how beliefs about mortality are produced by history, gender, culture, and context; how the handling of death shapes urban society.

SWMS.title: Gender and Social Justice
SWMS.description: Exploration of the ways in which developments and policies, including neoliberalism, the carceral state, and economic precarity, are connected and gendered.

SWMS.title: Gender and Sexuality Studies: Internship
SWMS.description: Intensive experience with gender-focused community organizations; analysis of relationships between organizations and feminist and queer theory.

SWMS.title: The Undisciplined Mother
SWMS.description: Constructions of motherhood; mothering beyond the binary; the 'single mother; medical configurations of motherhood; queer and trans mothering; motherhood and disability; motherhood and activism.

SWMS.title: Women, Gender and Sexuality in Hip Hop
SWMS.description: Complicates representations of women, gender and sexuality in hip hop music utilizing Black feminist theory, performance studies and queer of color critique.

SWMS.title: Gender and Sexuality in Renaissance Italy
SWMS.description: Interdisciplinary exploration of gender and sexuality in Italian renaissance literature and visual arts by male and female authors and artists from the fourteenth through the sixteenth century.

SWMS.title: Human Sexuality
SWMS.description: Psychological and physiological base of sexuality; gender identity, childbearing, birth control, venereal diseases; dysfunctions and treatments.

SWMS.title: Junior Seminar in Gender and Sexuality Studies
SWMS.description: Research methods in gender and sexuality studies scholarship; study of feminist, queer and post-colonial epistemologies.

SWMS.title: Gender, Media and Communication
SWMS.description: Issues of gender in communication, including: mediarepresentations of femininity and masculinity; and gender's rolein communication at the interpersonal, public, and cultural levels.

SWMS.title: Men and Masculinities
SWMS.description: Examines how gender and sexuality are figured in cinema and television with an emphasis on the development of feminist media theory.

SWMS.title: Gender and Sexuality in Korean Literature and Culture
SWMS.description: Examination of the changing representations of gender and sexuality in Korean cultural texts over the course of the twentieth century.

SWMS.title: Women and Aging: Psychological, Social, and      Political Implications
SWMS.description: Problems and resources of the middle-aged and older woman in a changing society; including discrimination, stereotypes, employment, social interaction, etc.

SWMS.title: Feminism, Gender and Sexuality
SWMS.description: Major feminist thinkers and writers viewed from the perspective of the evolution of gender and sexuality in contemporary France. Conducted in French.

SWMS.title: Gender and the News Media
SWMS.description: Gender and news media evolving images of women and men in print and electronic media.  Impact of gender in content and style of news, television and cinema.  Open to non-majors.

SWMS.title: Directed Research
SWMS.description: Independent research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

SWMS.title: Gender and Sexuality Studies: Honors Thesis
SWMS.description: Writing of the honors thesis; for students in the Gender and Sexuality Studies Honors Program.

SWMS.title: Feminist Theory
SWMS.description: History of feminist theory and major perspectives of current feminist theory: liberal feminism, socialist/Marxist feminism, radical feminism, psychological feminism, spiritual feminism, and ecological feminism.

SWMS.title: Directed Research
SWMS.description: Research leading to the master's degree in cognate fields. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

SWMS.title: Sex and Gender in Society
SWMS.description: The social organization of gender in the contexts of work, families, intimacy, sexuality, reproduction, violence. Variations by race, ethnicity, social class. Processes of social change. Duplicates credit in former SOCI 552.

ENGL.title: Creative Writing for Non-Majors
ENGL.description: Introductory workshop in writing poetry, short fiction and nonfiction for love of the written and spoken word. Not for English major credit. Not for English major or English (Creative Writing) major credit.

ENGL.title: The Art of Poetry
ENGL.description: Introduction to the pleasures and power of poetry, exploring elements drawn from high-points of English poetry, and the lives and works of major poets. (Duplicates credit in ARLT 101g)

ENGL.title: Reading the Heart: Emotional Intelligence and the Humanities
ENGL.description: A study of emotional intelligence through literature, history and the arts with a focus on anger, happiness, love and empathy.

ENGL.title: Shakespeare and His Times
ENGL.description: Close study of Shakespeare's plays and poems to introduce his language, stagecraft, literary "genius," social and literary contexts, precursors and rivals, and legacy.

ENGL.title: Literary Arts
ENGL.description: Introduction to theory and practice of literary study.

ENGL.title: The African Diaspora
ENGL.description: History, political-economy and aesthetics of the African Diaspora with emphasis on Latin America, the Caribbean, Europe and Africa.

ENGL.title: English Literature to 1800
ENGL.description: Intensive reading of major writers to 1800.

ENGL.title: English Literature since 1800
ENGL.description: Intensive reading of major writers, 1800-1950.

ENGL.title: American Literature
ENGL.description: Intensive reading of representative writers.

ENGL.title: Studying Narrative
ENGL.description: Introduction to major forms, styles and theories of narrative, with attention to characterization, plot, genres, ethics, empathy, perspective, audience and social conditions.

ENGL.title: Introduction to Dramatic Literature
ENGL.description: Study of forms of dramatic writing, focusing on craft, formal structure, literary and cultural history, relationship to performance.

ENGL.title: Introduction to the Genre of Nonfiction
ENGL.description: Study of forms of nonfiction writing, focusing on craft and process: how it works and how to read, write and write about it.

ENGL.title: The Art and Craft of the Essay
ENGL.description: Intensive practice in crafting literary essays.

ENGL.title: Writing Narrative
ENGL.description: Introduction to the techniques and practice of writing narrative in fiction and literary non-fiction

ENGL.title: Introduction to Fiction Writing
ENGL.description: Introduction to the techniques and practice of writing prose fiction.

ENGL.title: Introduction to Poetry Writing
ENGL.description: Introduction to the techniques and practice of writing poetry.

ENGL.title: Images of Women in Contemporary Culture
ENGL.description: Representations of women and gender relations in contemporary literature and mass culture, using the tools of feminist, literary, and political theory.

ENGL.title: Literature of California
ENGL.description: Novels, stories, essays, poems, and plays written in and about California from the Gold Rush to the present.

ENGL.title: Bookpacking America
ENGL.description: Literary travel using novels to explore regional culture and unify the study of literature, history, geography, politics and social studies.

ENGL.title: Bookpacking Los Angeles
ENGL.description: Literary travel using novels to explore regional culture and unify the study of literature, history, geography, politics and social studies.

ENGL.title: Bookpacking in New Orleans: A Cultural and Literary Journey
ENGL.description: Literary travel using novels to explore regional culture and unify the study of literature, history, geography, politics and social studies.

ENGL.title: Contemporary Poetry
ENGL.description: Study of poetry written in English since 1945, with special emphasis on the last two decades.

ENGL.title: Contemporary Drama
ENGL.description: Selected British, Irish, and American drama from the post World War II period (1945 to the present).

ENGL.title: The Modern Novel
ENGL.description: Studies of the narrative experiments and innovations in fiction following the realist novel; emphasis on gender, empire and class and the pluralities of "modernisms."

ENGL.title: Literary Genres and Film
ENGL.description: Literary studies in the relationship between fiction and drama and their adaptation as films.

ENGL.title: Literature and Society
ENGL.description: Theoretical and applied studies of literature in English as social activity and cultural production; its expression of, and influence upon, social values, concepts, and behavior.

ENGL.title: Science Fiction
ENGL.description: Investigation of the scope and possibilities of British and American science fiction as a genre, with some attention to its historical development.

ENGL.title: Comics and Graphic Novels
ENGL.description: Introduction to issues in visual and popular culture, focused on critical and historical interpretation of words and images in comic books and graphic novels.

ENGL.title: Visual and Popular Culture
ENGL.description: Course in the theory and practices of "popular culture," highlighting modern and comtemporary culture, film, video and popular music, as well as narrative forms.

ENGL.title: Creative Nonfiction Writing
ENGL.description: Intermediate practice in writing creative nonfiction.

ENGL.title: Fiction Writing
ENGL.description: A practical course in composition of prose fiction.

ENGL.title: Poetry Writing
ENGL.description: A practical course in poetry writing.

ENGL.title: Advanced Poetry Writing
ENGL.description: Prerequisite: Acceptance of manuscript by instructor.

ENGL.title: English Literature of the Middle Ages (1100-1500)
ENGL.description: Selected studies in the major figures, genres, and themes of Middle English literature to Malory, with special emphasis on Chaucer.

ENGL.title: English Literature of the Romantic Age (1800-1832)
ENGL.description: Selected studies of major writers, including Blake, Austen, Wordsworth, Coleridge, Byron, Mary Shelley, P.B. Shelley, and Keats.

ENGL.title: Shakespeare
ENGL.description: Major history plays, comedies, and tragedies.

ENGL.title: American Literature, 1865 to 1920
ENGL.description: American poetry and prose with special attention to Twain, James, Dickinson, Henry Adams, Crane, and Dreiser.

ENGL.title: Native American Literature
ENGL.description: Survey of Native American literature, including oral traditions  and print genres, such as short story, poetry, novel, and  autobiography, from 1700 to the present.  Recommended preparation:  ENGL 263.

ENGL.title: The Literatures of America: Cross-Cultural Perspectives
ENGL.description: Introduction to African-American, Chicano, Asian American, and     Native-American literatures--and to the literary diversity of      American cultures.

ENGL.title: Contemporary African American Literature
ENGL.description: Survey of African American literary and cultural production after the Civil Rights Movement, with special emphasis on the New Black and Post-Soul Aesthetics.

ENGL.title: Black British Literature
ENGL.description: Survey of Black British literature from the earliest time to the present; development of prose, poetry, novels and plays.

ENGL.title: Politics and the Novel
ENGL.description: Examination of the modern realist novel with special focus on the representation of social change (revolution, class conflict, sexual politics).

ENGL.title: Directed Research
ENGL.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

ENGL.title: Senior Seminar in Literary Studies
ENGL.description: Selected problems in literary history and criticism.

ENGL.title: Narrative Studies Capstone Seminar
ENGL.description: Individual research, reading, writing and project development as a senior capstone experience in the study of narrative.

ENGL.title: Senior Honors Thesis
ENGL.description: Seminar in workshop form to accompany completion of Senior HonorsThesis. Bi-weekly meetings to complete thesis according to contract.

ENGL.title: Creative Writing and the (Ir)resistible Rise of AI
ENGL.description: Studies in the works of one or more authors, or in the development of a theme or genre.

ENGL.title: History, Theories and Practice of Cultural Studies
ENGL.description: Looking at specific case histories, this course introduces students to the basic methods, theories and activities in Cultural Studies.

ENGL.title: Renaissance English Literatures and Cultures
ENGL.description: Studies in poetry and patronage, the popular tradition in literature and drama, the social and sexual dynamics of comedy, historical and cultural uses of genres, among other topics.

ENGL.title: Poetry and Prose into Drama
ENGL.description: Plays for the stage shall be written using public-domain poetry and prose as inspiration and source material, complemented with exploring poetry, prose, and varied dramas as context for the student writer. Students should be well-versed in literature, and have written in one or more genres.

ENGL.title: Foundations in the Environmental Arts and Humanities
ENGL.description: A survey of traditional as well as recent foundational methods and topics within the environmental arts and humanities.

ENGL.title: 20th Century American Literatures and Cultures
ENGL.description: Studies in rural and urban fictions, modernism, the shift from imagism and symbolism to confessional poetry, recovered writers, hemispheric traditions, literature and kindred arts, and other topics.

ENGL.title: Practicum in Teaching English and Narrative Studies
ENGL.description: Practical principles for development of effective teaching within the disciplines of English, Creative Writing, and Narrative Studies. Intended for teaching assistants in English.

ENGL.title: Manuscript Prep
ENGL.description: Thematic, theoretical, or experimental studies in British and      American literatures and cultures.

ENGL.title: Writers in the World: Text and Context
ENGL.description: Editing and publishing within the tradition of literary and cultural influences upon a wide range of authors, readers and genres.

ENGL.title: The Literary Landscape: Digital Toolkit
ENGL.description: Research and identification of internships; preparation of application materials for submission to in-person and remote internship opportunities.

ENGL.title: Digital Publishing and Literary Writing for New Media
ENGL.description: Discussion of literary texts combined with hands-on digital practice in composition, design and fabrication for electronic publication, including formal, technical and philosophical issues.

ENGL.title: Publishing on Both Sides of the Transom
ENGL.description: Editorial and publishing workshop with an intensive hands-on student project following the progress of a single piece of writing from manuscript to print.

ENGL.title: Internship in Editing and Publishing: Eloquence and Ethics
ENGL.description: Practical experience in the publishing world for acquiring skills and knowledge beyond the classroom.

ENGL.title: Theory and Criticism
ENGL.description: Studies in meaning and meaning-making, form, comparative theory, theories of history and culture, theory in the classroom, and other topics.

ENGL.title: Second-Year Pro-Seminar
ENGL.description: Introduces second-year PhD students to genres of professional academic writing and development of student specialization in specific fields within the discipline.

ENGL.title: Graduate Nonfiction Writing Workshop
ENGL.description: Intensive practicum in advanced level nonfiction writing, intended to develop high level creative compositional ability.

ENGL.title: Graduate Poetry Writing Workshop
ENGL.description: Intensive practicum in advanced level poetry writing, intended to develop high level creative compositional ability. Open only to Creative Writing PhD degree candidates.

ENGL.title: Graduate Fiction Writing Workshop
ENGL.description: Intensive practicum in advanced level fiction writing, intended to develop high level creative compositional ability. Open only to Creative Writing PhD degree candidates.

ENGL.title: Theories and Practices of Professional Development I
ENGL.description: A structured environment in which to craft a research project,  write a dissertation prospectus, and define areas of professional  expertise.  Graded CR/NC.  Recommended preparation: passage of  screening exam.  Not available for degree credit.

ENGL.title: Theories and Practices of Professional Development II
ENGL.description: This two-credit course helps ABD students craft their professional  identities and placement materials as they make the transition  from graduate school to their academic position.  Graded CR/NC.   Not available for degree credit.

ENGL.title: Academic Writing: Journal Articles and Dissertation Chapters
ENGL.description: Academic writing workshop focused on producing dissertation chapters and revising seminar papers for publication.

ENGL.title: Research
ENGL.description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

ENGL.title: Doctoral Dissertation
ENGL.description: Credit on acceptance of dissertation.

ENGL.title: Doctoral Dissertation
ENGL.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. GRADED CR/NC.

ENGL.title: Doctoral Dissertation
ENGL.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

ENGL.title: Doctoral Dissertation
ENGL.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

ENGL.title: Doctoral Dissertation
ENGL.description: Credit upon acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

ITAL.title: Italian I
ITAL.description: Introduction to current Italian. Oral practice, hearing and reading comprehension; grammar necessary for simple spoken and written expression. Lecture, classroom drill, laboratory drill.

ITAL.title: Italian Language and Diction
ITAL.description: Developing competence in listening, vocal pronunciation, speaking, singing, International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA), reading and writing Italian. Emphasizes musical texts including Italian song and operatic arias.

ITAL.title: Accelerated Italian for Speakers of Spanish and  Other Romance Languages
ITAL.description: Accelerated introduction to written and spoken Italian for students with a high level of proficiency in Spanish or another Romance Language.  Students completing this course may enroll in the third semester of the basic language sequence ITAL 220.

ITAL.title: Italian III
ITAL.description: Continuation of Italian II. Review of structure of the language, drill in aural and reading comprehension, practice in oral expression.

ITAL.title: Italian Professional Internship: Communication and Culture
ITAL.description: Combined classroom discussion and supervised internship at companies. Practical experience in applying communication and cultural knowledge in a professional employment context.

ITAL.title: Italian IV
ITAL.description: Continuation of Italian III.  Review and expand upon abilities to create with the language in concrete exchanges, descriptions, comparisons, questions and discussions relevant to current issues and topics.

ITAL.title: Inventing Modern Italy
ITAL.description: An interdisciplinary introduction to the literary, artistic, and  political movements which contributed to the shaping of modern  Italy. Taught in English.

ITAL.title: Gender and Sexuality in Renaissance Italy
ITAL.description: Interdisciplinary exploration of gender and sexuality in Italian renaissance literature and visual arts by male and female authors and artists from the fourteenth through the sixteenth century.

ITAL.title: Storytelling in the Italian Tradition
ITAL.description: Reading and close textual scrutiny of major short stories from Boccaccio's Decameron to the present. Conducted in English. (Duplicates credit in former ITAL 462)

ITAL.title: Italian Theatre
ITAL.description: Italian dramatic literature from the earliest written documents to the present. Reading and close textual scrutiny of plays by major dramatists from the Renaissance to the present. Taught in Italian.

ITAL.title: Directed Research
ITAL.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

HBIO.title: Introduction to Human and Evolutionary Biology
HBIO.description: Introduction to the major and field of human and evolutionary biology; sub-disciplines, career options and areas for research; guest speakers.

HBIO.title: The Human Animal
HBIO.description: Foundations of the human species. Examination of scientific evidence from Darwinian theory, primate behavior, fossils, and the behavior of modern people. Laboratory. Duplicates credit in former ANTH 200Lg.

HBIO.title: Nutrition for Life
HBIO.description: To develop an understanding of Nutrition, especially as it         pertains to optimal health and prevention of diseases. A study of  macro and micro nutrients.

HBIO.title: The Science of Sport
HBIO.description: The physiological and nutritional basis of human performance. Factors that facilitate and limit athletic achievement. Lecture, 3 hours; laboratory, 2 hours. Not available for major credit. Duplicates credit in former EXSC 205Lxg.

HBIO.title: Human Anatomy
HBIO.description: Major organ systems; functional implications of their relationships; gross and microscopic examination with an emphasis on practical skills in recognizing, dissecting, and differentiating anatomical structures. Duplicates credit in former EXSC 301L.

HBIO.title: Biology of the Non-Human Primates
HBIO.description: Behavior and ecology of living nonhuman primates, with an emphasis on field studies of apes and monkeys. Topics include aggression, communication, reproduction and cognition.

HBIO.title: Sociopsychological Aspects of Sport and Physical Activity
HBIO.description: Examination of the individual in a social environment related to sport and physical activity; personality, motivation, attitude, and group behavior viewed in physical activity contexts. Duplicates credit in former EXSC 310.

HBIO.title: Muscle Physiology
HBIO.description: Analysis of the skeletal muscular system (anatomy, physiology, biochemistry, and development) and its functional properties under both normal and pathological conditions.

HBIO.title: Genetics and Disease
HBIO.description: An overview of the genetic underpinning of human health and disease. Inheritance of mendelian diseases, common diseases, developmental diseases and cancer; prenatal testing, genetic counseling and genetic therapies.

HBIO.title: Motor Control and Learning
HBIO.description: Theories of control and learning applied to motor performance; variables affecting performance in exercise, games, sports and dance.

HBIO.title: Physiology of Movement
HBIO.description: The physiological effects of exercise and training on musculoskeletal and circulatory systems, and the biomechanics of athletic performance

HBIO.title: Evolutionary Medicine
HBIO.description: Evolutionary, cultural, and environmental factors in the emergence and existence of diseases; a Darwinian examination of illness in the human species.

HBIO.title: Endocrinology and Metabolism
HBIO.description: Regulation of metabolic pathways and endocrinology in health and metabolic diseases.

HBIO.title: Metabolic Diseases
HBIO.description: Examination of the etiology, prevention, and treatment of metabolic disorders such as diabetes mellitus and obesity that are major threats to public health.

HBIO.title: Applied Human Physiology
HBIO.description: The physiology of the respiratory, cardiovascular, renal, musculoskeletal, digestive, endocrine and nervous systems in humans, with application to human health and pathology.

HBIO.title: Neurobiology of Feeding Behavior and Obesity
HBIO.description: Neurobiological systems that control feeding behavior and energy balance with an emphasis on the determinants of obesity.

HBIO.title: Evaluation and Rehabilitation of Athletic Injuries
HBIO.description: Application of scientific principles to evaluating and rehabilitating athletic injuries.

HBIO.title: Laboratory Experience in Kinesiology
HBIO.description: Practical laboratory experience in basic and applied exercise physiology, biochemistry, and/or biomechanics. Emphasizing development of laboratory techniques. Prerequisites: HBIO 203, HBIO 301, HBIO 302, HBIO 320. Duplicates credit in former EXSC 491.

BISC.title: Humans and Their Environment
BISC.description: An examination of the physical and biological laws that influence agriculture, pollution, population dynamics (including humans), climate, biodiversity and ecosystem structure and function. Not available for major credit.

BISC.title: General Biology for the Environment and Life
BISC.description: Study of common skills in biology, including basics of evolution, systematics, ecology, genetics, biochemistry and molecular biology, physiology, and anatomy.

BISC.title: Special Laboratory I
BISC.description: Laboratory component for BISC 120 for entering freshmen or  transfer students with advanced placement or equivalent lecture  credit from another institution.

BISC.title: Special Laboratory II
BISC.description: Laboratory component for BISC 220 for entering freshmen or  transfer students with advanced placement or equivalent lecture  credit from another institution.

BISC.title: Good Genes, Bad Genes
BISC.description: Introduction to the scientific method; basic instruction in molecular biology with emphasis on how biological research advancement has impacted medicine, commerce and society in general.

BISC.title: The Biology of Food
BISC.description: Exploration of molecular biology, biochemistry, microbiology, nutrition and the history of biology through the study of food, focusing on food's relationship to the biological world.

BISC.title: General Biology: Organismal Biology and Evolution
BISC.description: In-depth survey of key topics related to advances in our knowledge of the diversity of life and evolution; origin of life; eukaryotes/prokaryotes; ecology.

BISC.title: Evolution
BISC.description: Changes in the physical and biological universe over time; origins of life, dinosaurs, human evolution. Implications of evolutionary mechanisms and mass extinctions for human survival.

BISC.title: Introduction to Research II
BISC.description: A series of lectures and discussions at which faculty of the department introduce their research activities to students entering biology and related majors.

BISC.title: Neuroscience Colloquium
BISC.description: Introduction to research activities conducted by Neuroscience faculty at USC.

BISC.title: General Biology: Cell Biology and Physiology
BISC.description: In-depth survey of key topics related to advances in our knowledge of cellular biology and physiology; cell composition/metabolism; gene action; organism structure and function. Recommended preparation: high school chemistry; BISC 120L or BISC 121L.

BISC.title: Advanced General Biology: Cell Biology and Physiology
BISC.description: Equivalent to 220L, but taught at a higher level for exceptionally well-prepared students. Admission to the course by departmental approval only.

BISC.title: The Biology of the Brain
BISC.description: Exploration of the unique properties of brain cells that allow complex perceptions and behaviors; examination of structure and activity of brain cells that underlie function.

BISC.title: Introduction to Biological Research
BISC.description: Experience in basic techniques through supervised research in the research laboratory of a departmental faculty member.

BISC.title: Introduction to Microbiology
BISC.description: Comparative approach to bacteria, Archaea and viruses; their structure, life cycles, geochemical activity, ecology and nutrition. Fundamentals of metabolism and microbial genetics.

BISC.title: The Kingdom Plantae: An Introduction to Botany
BISC.description: Introduction to the major lineages of vascular plants by the comparative examination of anatomy, physiology, diversity, evolution and integration of form, function and ecology.

BISC.title: General Physiology
BISC.description: Physiological functions of the circulatory, digestive, endocrine, integuementary, musculoskeletal, nervous, respiratory, and         urogenital systems in animals. Lecture, 3 hours; Laboratory, 3     hours.

BISC.title: Statistical Thinking for Quantitative Biology
BISC.description: Introduction to general statistical theory with higher-level mathematics for biological data analysis. Basic programming in R. Discussion of techniques to describe, visualize and model different types of data.

BISC.title: Molecular Biochemistry
BISC.description: Structure and function of biological macromolecules; major metabolic pathways including glycolysis and photosynthesis. DNA replication, repair, and recombination; gene expression, regulation and epigenetics.

BISC.title: Evolution and Population Genetics
BISC.description: History of evolutionary thought; molecular basis for evolution; dynamics of genes in populations; specialization and macroevolution; patterns of evolution. Recommended preparation: BISC-320, BISC-325, and familiarity with algebra, basic chemistry, and basic physics.

BISC.title: Multidisciplinary Seminar: Science, Technology and Society
BISC.description: Builds upon a basic science background to provide students with an awareness of cutting edge scientific research, its technological applications and its societal ramifications.

BISC.title: Biochemistry
BISC.description: Basic biochemical principles; classes of molecules - structure and function; cellular energetics.

BISC.title: Science, Health and the Environment
BISC.description: Exploration of environmentally transmitted human diseases; understanding the human/pathogen/environment nexus that leads to disease in human populations; disease transmission reduction.

BISC.title: Mammalogy
BISC.description: Introduction to the morphology, classification, distribution and physiology of mammals; study of major mammalian groups worldwide and identification and field study of local species.

BISC.title: Introduction to Computational Analysis of Biological Data
BISC.description: A project-based course integrating biology, computer science, and statistics through the analysis of genomic datasets available publicly or collected and sequenced during the semester.

BISC.title: Ecology and Biodiversity
BISC.description: Introduction to community ecology, macroecology, biodiversity and ecosystem functions, and current debates on trends in biodiversity; concepts include ecological theory, modeling, data management and analysis.

BISC.title: Cellular and Molecular Neuroscience
BISC.description: An examination of individual nerve cell development, target location, and establishment of functional synapses; how dysfunction in these processes contributes to neurological and neuropsychiatric diseases.

BISC.title: Systems Neuroscience: From Synapses to Perception
BISC.description: Sensory and motor systems to illustrate concepts regarding the functional organization of the brain, from microcircuitry of neural circuits to global processes such as perception. Prerequisite: BISC 421.

BISC.title: Applications of Molecular Biology to Medicine
BISC.description: Advances and trends in the understanding, diagnosis and treatment of human diseases.

BISC.title: Advanced Cell Biology
BISC.description: The synthesis, transport and assembly of the complex structures that mediate eukaryotic cellular function. Electrical and biochemical mechanisms underlying intercellular communication.

BISC.title: Epilepsy to Ecstasy: Biological Basis of Neurological Disord
BISC.description: Examination of various neurological disorders originating from developmental signaling and/or anatomical abnormalities.

BISC.title: The Global Environment
BISC.description: Earth's development as a habitable planet, from origin to human impacts on global biogeochemical cycles in the ocean, land, atmosphere. Discussion of environmental alternatives.

BISC.title: Cancer Immunology
BISC.description: In-depth study of the role of the immune system in oncogenesis.  Discussion of cellular transformation, immune surveillance, immune-based therapies, and new approaches in cancer treatment.

BISC.title: Advanced Biochemistry
BISC.description: Macromolecular structure and function; enzymology; metabolic regulation. Lecture, 3 hours; discussion, 2 hours.

BISC.title: Biodemography of Aging
BISC.description: Consideration of the biological and social-cultural factors that govern the evolution of life spans and the life of humans and selected animal models

BISC.title: Fundamentals of Vertebrate Biology
BISC.description: Evolution and comparative anatomy of vertebrates.

BISC.title: Protein Engineering
BISC.description: Fundamentals of protein engineering and its biotechnological applications in medicine, chemical processes and energy; methods for engineering biological molecules and designing protein engineering strategies.

BISC.title: CEED Seminar Series
BISC.description: Topical seminar in marine and environmental biology.  Junior,  senior or graduate standing.

BISC.title: Biotechnology and Chemical Biology in Modern Biomedical      Research
BISC.description: Topical seminar in molecular and computational biology. Junior, senior or graduate standing.

BISC.title: The Neurobiology of Dopamine: From Reward Learning to Motor  Control
BISC.description: Topical seminar in neurobiology.

BISC.title: Neuroimmunology
BISC.description: Exploration of the complex interactions between the nervous and immune systems, and disorders encompassing both neuroscience and immunology. Topics include autoimmunity, cancer, neurodevelopment, neuroimmunological treatments.

BISC.title: Marine Biology
BISC.description: Oceanography and marine biology, sampling techniques, evolutionary adaptations, morphology, systematics.

BISC.title: Systems Biology: Modeling the Dynamics of Life
BISC.description: Foundational skill-building for modeling and analysis of biological data. Hands-on instruction for developing and simulating models of dynamic biological systems.

BISC.title: Directed Research
BISC.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

BISC.title: Honors Seminar
BISC.description: Opportunity to gain experience in experimental biological research and analysis and develop the ability to communicate scientific ideas effectively. Not available for graduate credit.

BISC.title: Honors Thesis
BISC.description: Research and writing of an honors thesis under faculty supervision. Opportunity to provide leadership and mentoring for BISC 493 students. Not available for graduate credit.

BISC.title: Introduction to Computational Neuroscience
BISC.description: Lecture and discussion in specialized areas of the biological sciences. Students cannot register more than twice for this course. Not open to freshmen and sophomores. Recommended preparation: BISC 220L or BISC 221L, BISC 320L, BISC 325 and BISC 330L.

BISC.title: Virology: Germ Theory to Molecular Methods
BISC.description: Lecture and discussion in specialized areas of the biological sciences. Students cannot register more than twice for this course. Not open to freshmen and sophomores. Recommended preparation: BISC 220L or BISC 221L, BISC 320L, BISC 325 and BISC 330L.

BISC.title: Molecular Genetics and Biochemistry
BISC.description: Current genetic and biochemical analysis of replication, recombination, mutagenesis, and repair. Fundamentals of transcription and regulation of gene expression. Recent applications of genetic engineering and genome analysis.

BISC.title: Laboratory Techniques in Cellular and Molecular Biology
BISC.description: Rotation of graduate students through molecular biology research laboratories to learn the major technological skills required in the field. Graded CR/NC.

BISC.title: Hearing and Communication Neuroscience
BISC.description: A basic grounding in broad aspects of the neuroscience of hearing and vocal communication.

BISC.title: Advanced Seminar in Molecular and Microbial Ecology
BISC.description: Microorganisms dominate biological processes in the ocean.  These  species pose significant problems for estimating species  diversity, abundance and activity.  Examination of modern  molecular biological approaches for analyzing aquatic microbial  communities and their ecological roles.

BISC.title: Advanced Seminar in Marine Biogeochemistry
BISC.description: Examination of the interplay between ocean biology and the cycling of carbon, nitrogen and other elements on a local, regional and global scale.

BISC.title: Advanced Seminar in Symbiosis
BISC.description: Introduction to the concept of symbiosis, exploration of mechanisms underpinning the ecology and evolution of these relationships, synthesis of key concepts in contemporary symbiosis research.

BISC.title: Advanced Reading in Molecular Biology
BISC.description: Advanced training for molecular biology graduate students in reading primary journal articles. Emphasis on critical analyses of primary scientific literature.

BISC.title: Seminar in Integrative and Evolutionary Biology
BISC.description: Current topics in integrative and evolutionary biology.

BISC.title: Faculty Lecture Series
BISC.description: Multi-instructor course designed to introduce students to the  breadth and depth of faculty interests within the MEB Section of  Biological Sciences and the Natural History Museum.

BISC.title: Proposal Writing Process and Strategies
BISC.description: Hands-on experience writing and reviewing scientific proposals from faculty and peers. For MEBP, GEOL and OCS students only.

BISC.title: Statistical Methods for Environmental Scientists
BISC.description: Survey of statistical techniques for research and analysis; foundations, underlying assumptions and the power and limitations of such statistical approaches.

BISC.title: Directed Research
BISC.description: Research leading to the Master's Degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

BISC.title: Practicum in Teaching the Biological Sciences
BISC.description: Practical principles for the long-term development of effective teaching within College disciplines. Intended for teaching assistants in Dornsife College.

BISC.title: Internship for Curricular Practical Training
BISC.description: Part-time or full-time, practical work experience in the student's field of study. The internship must be located at an off-campus facility. Students are individually supervised by faculty. May not be taken until the student has completed at least one semester of enrollment in the graduate program with a cumulative 3.0 GPA.

BISC.title: Research
BISC.description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

BISC.title: Doctoral Dissertation
BISC.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC.

CHEM.title: The Molecular World
CHEM.description: Basic chemistry and its impact on the contemporary world. Topics include: structures and reactions of molecules, stoichiometry, nomenclature, gases, solutions.

CHEM.title: General Chemistry
CHEM.description: Fundamental principles and laws of chemistry; laboratory work emphasizes quantitative procedures. Prerequisite to all more advanced courses in chemistry. Lecture, 3 hours; laboratory and discussion, 4 hours. Quiz, 1 hour.

CHEM.title: General Chemistry
CHEM.description: Fundamental principles and laws of chemistry; laboratory work emphasizes quantitative procedures.

CHEM.title: General Chemistry for Chemistry Majors: Kinetics and Equilib
CHEM.description: Fundamental principles and laws of chemistry emphasizing contemporary chemistry; laboratory work focuses on quantitative procedures. Second-semester general chemistry course for majors.

CHEM.title: Advanced General Chemistry
CHEM.description: Equivalent to CHEM 105a  - CHEM 105b, but taught at a higher level for exceptionally well-prepared students.

CHEM.title: Chemical Forensics: The Science, and Its Impact
CHEM.description: Scientific principles underlying forensic approaches to the investigation of crimes and its societal impact on law, culture and media. Not available for major credit.

CHEM.title: Organic Chemistry Tutorial B
CHEM.description: Structured tutorial course, which enables students to understand fundamental principles, better approach problems with success. Explores the major principles of organic chemistry and its relevance. Topics covered will parallel 322B.Prerequisite: CHEM 322aL. Corequisite: CHEM-322bL. Graded CR/NC. Not available for degree credit.

CHEM.title: Special Laboratory
CHEM.description: Laboratory component for CHEM 105a, 105b, 322a, or 322b for students with equivalent lecture credit from another institution. Prereq: Consent of department head.

CHEM.title: Special Laboratory
CHEM.description: Laboratory component for CHEM 105a, 105b, 322a, or 322b for        students with equivalent lecture credit from another institution.

CHEM.title: Special Laboratory
CHEM.description: Laboratory component for CHEM 105a, 105b, 322a, or 322b for        students with equivalent lecture credit from another institution.

CHEM.title: Special Laboratory
CHEM.description: Laboratory component for CHEM 105a, 105b, 322a, or 322b for        students with equivalent lecture credit from another institution.

CHEM.title: Organic Chemistry
CHEM.description: Chemistry of the carbon compounds of the aliphatic and aromatic series; laboratory preparation of typical compounds of both series.

CHEM.title: Organic Chemistry
CHEM.description: Chemistry of the carbon compounds of the aliphatic and aromatic series; laboratory preparation of typical compounds of both series.

CHEM.title: Organic Chemistry
CHEM.description: Required of majors in chemistry.

CHEM.title: Biochemistry
CHEM.description: Basic biochemical principles; classes of molecules - structure and function; cellular energetics.

CHEM.title: Physical Chemical Measurements
CHEM.description: Experimental study of topics discussed in CHEM 430 and CHEM 431; adsorption, magnetic susceptibility; electron spin resonance, kinetics, equilibria, molecular spectra and structure, viscosity, dielectric properties.

CHEM.title: Advanced Laboratory Techniques in Organic and    Inorganic Chemistry
CHEM.description: Advanced synthetic, analytical, and physical measurement          techniques in organic and inorganic chemistry. Emphasis on         laboratory work with discussion of theoretical background.         Lecture, 2 hours; discussion, 1 hour; laboratory, 8 hours.

CHEM.title: Physical Chemistry:  Quantum Mechanics
CHEM.description: Classical and quantum mechanics: atomic structure; molecular structure; chemical bonds; solid state; symmetry; electric and magnetic properties of molecules; atomic spectroscopy; rotational and vibrational spectroscopy; electronic spectroscopy.

CHEM.title: Physical Chemistry for the Life Sciences
CHEM.description: Principles of physical chemistry relevant for the life sciences: thermodynamics, chemical equilibria, molecular dynamics, kinetics, molecular structures and interactions, spectroscopy, statistical thermodynamics and macromolecular structures. Duplicates credit in CHEM 430a.

CHEM.title: Advanced Inorganic Chemistry
CHEM.description: Atomic structure, theory of bonding, molecular structure, metallic state, coordination compounds, transition and nontransition metals, magnetic and optical properties, crystal field theory, mechanism of reactions.

CHEM.title: Chemical Nanotechnology
CHEM.description: Studies in the fundamental principles governing nanoscale materials. Structure and chemical bonding, preparative methods, and electrical, optical and magnetic properties of nanoscale materials and applications.

CHEM.title: Directed Research
CHEM.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

CHEM.title: Advanced Research Experience
CHEM.description: Directed undergraduate research supervised by faculty, with advanced capstone research experience. Not available for graduate credit.

CHEM.title: Advanced Chemical Biology
CHEM.description: Chemical approaches to investigate protein function and posttranslational modifications. Recommended preparation: CHEM 322ab, and BISC 330 (or equivalent).

CHEM.title: Synthetic Organic Chemistry
CHEM.description: A survey of representative groups of widely used synthetic organic reactions; emphasis on scope, limitations, and stereochemical consequences.

CHEM.title: Introduction to Molecular Spectroscopy
CHEM.description: Theoretical and experimental methods of molecular spectroscopy and  applications to chemistry.  Rotational, vibrational, electronic,  electron and nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopies.

CHEM.title: Introduction to Statistical Mechanics
CHEM.description: Study of macroscopic systems from molecular viewpoint using statistical mechanics: ensembles, fluctuations, gases, gas-solid interfaces, crystals, polymers, critical phenomena, non-equilibrium systems.

CHEM.title: Theory of Open Quantum Systems
CHEM.description: The theory of open quantum systems (i.e., systems coupled to an environment) with applications to chemistry, physics and quantum information processing.

CHEM.title: Polymer Synthesis
CHEM.description: Concepts of polymer Structure and sterochemistry. Organic chemistry of polymerization reactions with emphasis on condensation, radical, cationic, anionic, and coordination-metathesis polymerization.

CHEM.title: Advanced Practical Nuclear Magnetic Resonance Spectroscopy
CHEM.description: Application of multidimensional and time resolved NMR spectroscopy to problems in structure determination and thermochemistry. Recommended preparation: CHEM-625.

CHEM.title: Modern Trends in Physical Chemistry
CHEM.description: Emerging research areas in physical and theoretical chemistry  through a thorough discussion of seminal research articles and   presentations of current research topics.  Recommended  preparation: some research experience and familiarity with  literature search.

CHEM.title: Medicinal Chemistry and Drug Design
CHEM.description: a) Introduction to fundamentals of medicinal chemistry with  special attention to the drug discovery process. Recommended  Preparation  PSCI 664 and CHEM 519.

CHEM.title: Medicinal Chemistry and Drug Design
CHEM.description: b) Concepts, methods and examples of current approaches to drug  design including computer-based molecular modeling techniques.  Recommended Preparation: PSCI 664.

CHEM.title: Structural Biology for Biochemists
CHEM.description: Advanced techniques and methods for determining the structure of biological macromolecules with an emphasis on practical work.

CHEM.title: Directed Research
CHEM.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

CHEM.title: Master's Thesis
CHEM.description: Credit on acceptance of Thesis. Graded CR/NC.

CHEM.description: Credit on acceptance of Thesis. Graded CR/NC.
