CHEM.description: Part-time or full-time, practical work experience in the student's field of study. The internship must be located at an off-campus facility. Students are individually supervised by faculty. May not be taken until the student has completed at least one semester of enrollment in the graduate program.

CHEM.title: Chemical Applications of Magnetic Resonance      Spectroscopy
CHEM.description: Elementary theory of magnetic resonance spectroscopy, methods of  spectral analysis, treatment of Fourier transform methods and time dependent phenomena; recent applications in organic chemistry.

CHEM.title: Natural Products Chemistry
CHEM.description: Survey of the chemistry and biogenesis of the major classes of secondary metabolites along biogenetic lines: terpenes, acteogenins and alkaloids.

CHEM.title: Fundamentals of Electrochemical Energy Systems
CHEM.description: Fundamentals of electrochemical energy systems including various batteries, fuel cells and electrolyzers with a focus on materials, operating principles and applications

CHEM.title: Introduction to Surface Chemistry and            Electrocatalysis
CHEM.description: Introduction to principles governing physical and chemical behavior of surfaces: structures, thermodynamics, adsorption, desorption, diffusion, electron transfer and electrocatalytic reactions, and experimental surface analytical techniques.

CHEM.title: Molecular Electronics
CHEM.description: The fundamental physical concepts, chemical principles and potential applications of electronic components formed from single or small groups of molecules.

CHEM.title: Research
CHEM.description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

CHEM.title: Doctoral Dissertation
CHEM.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC.

LING.title: Communication Disorders in Our Communities                                                      \.
LING.description: Introduction to hearing disorders, motor speech disorders, and pragmatic disorders. The impact of these on effective communication. Common methods of diagnosing and intervening.

LING.title: In a Word
LING.description: Words as tools for discovering properties of the human mind. How words are formed of and form various units. Experiments exploring judgments about word interpretation.

LING.title: Language and Society
LING.description: Discourse patterns among diverse social groups in institutional and interpersonal settings; interrelationships among language practices and gender, socioeconomic status, ethnicity; social structures and cultural values as reflected in language policies and practices.

LING.title: American Sign Language I
LING.description: Familiarization with ASL and fingerspelling. Covers visual and gestural communication, comprehension through receptive language skills, basic conversational proficiency, general insights into American Deaf culture.

LING.title: American Sign Language II
LING.description: Increased development of inflectional and non-manual behavior patterns presented with incorporation of selected aspects of Deaf culture and community within receptive and expressive conversations.

LING.title: Introduction to Linguistics
LING.description: Empirical study of the sounds and structures of human language;syntax and semantics; language change; linguistic universals.

LING.title: Human Language and Technology
LING.description: Study of human linguistic competence and technologies that simulate it. Phonetics, vibration and signal processing, speech recognition, neural networks.

LING.title: Introduction to Phonology and Morphology
LING.description: A survey of topics in phonology and morphology.

LING.title: Human Language as Computation
LING.description: Study of language as a complex natural system that requires elaborate mental computation.

LING.title: Second Language Acquisition
LING.description: Theories of second language acquisition in children and adults; comparison of first and second language acquisition including psychological, social, and individual factors.

LING.title: Children's Learning and Cognitive Development
LING.description: Principles of cognitive development, learning, and motivation applied to the development of literacy; includes tutoring a child 2 hours per week. Prerequisite: PSYC 336L.

LING.title: Language, Linguistics and Mind
LING.description: Topics of current interest at the crossroads of philosophy of language, philosophy of mind and linguistics.

LING.title: Speech Synthesis and Recognition
LING.description: Introduction to speech synthesis and speech recognition technologies from both a phonetics point of view and a computational point of view.

LING.title: Directed Research
LING.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

LING.title: Honors Thesis
LING.description: Writing of the honors thesis. Registration is restricted to honors students.

LING.title: Seminar in Linguistics
LING.description: Colloquium for presentation and discussion of student research     paper.  Graded CR/NC.

LING.title: Practicum in Phonetics and Phonology
LING.description: Professional development in phonetics and phonology. Skills workshops, discussion of emerging research in the literature, and internal and external presentations of work in progress.

LING.title: Practicum in Syntax and Semantics
LING.description: Professional development in syntax and semantics. Skills workshops, discussion of emerging research in the literature, and internal and external presentations of work in progress.

LING.title: Practicum in Psycholinguistics
LING.description: Professional development in psycholinguistics. Skills workshops, discussion of emerging research in the literature, and internal and external presentations of work in progress.

LING.title: Phonology
LING.description: Traditional views of phonology; generative phonology; current developments in phonological research and theory.

LING.title: Syntax and Grammatical Theory
LING.description: Principles and comparison of modern theories of grammar with special reference to syntax.

LING.title: Advanced Semantics
LING.description: Intensive work in semantic theory, in preparation for a research specialization in the area.

LING.title: Advanced Psycholinguistics
LING.description: Current issues in psycholinguistic theory.

LING.title: Directed Research
LING.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

LING.title: Directed Readings
LING.description: Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

LING.title: Seminar in Experimental Methods in Linguistics
LING.description: Topics in quantitataive methods in linguistics research, e.g., covariance structure analysis, multi-dimensional scaling, log linear model, meta-analysis.

LING.title: Research
LING.description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

LING.description: Credit on acceptance of dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

MATH.title: Basic Mathematical Skills
MATH.description: Review of Algebra. Real numbers, linear equations and inequalities, functions, graphs, systems of equations, exponents, polynomials, factoring, rational expressions, radicals, quadratic equations and solutions. Graded CR/NC.

MATH.title: Contemporary Precalculus
MATH.description: Equations and inequalities; functions; graphs; polynomial and rational functions; exponential, logarithmic, and trigonometric function; analytic geometry.

MATH.title: Foundations of Statistics
MATH.description: An introduction to the basic tools of statistics. Descriptive statistics; probability; expected value; normal approximation sampling; chance models; tests of significance.

MATH.title: Introduction to Mathematics for Business and Economics
MATH.description: Functions, graphs, polynomial and rational functions, exponential and logarithmic functions, matrices, systems of linear equations.

MATH.title: Calculus for Business and Economics
MATH.description: Derivatives and extrema. The definite integral and u-substitutions. Functions of several variables and their extrema; constrained optimization.

MATH.title: Calculus I
MATH.description: Limits; continuity, derivatives and applications; antiderivatives; the fundamental theorem of calculus; exponential and logarithmic functions.

MATH.title: Calculus II
MATH.description: A continuation of MATH 125: trigonometric functions; applications of integration; techniques of integration; indeterminate forms; infinite series; Taylor series; polar coordinates.

MATH.title: Calculus II for Engineers and Scientists
MATH.description: Trigonometric functions; applications of integration; techniques of integration; indeterminate forms; infinite series; Taylor series; polar coordinates. Engineering and physics applications. Prerequisite: MATH 125. (Duplicates credit in MATH 126 and MATH 127)

MATH.title: Elementary Probability and Statistics
MATH.description: Descriptive statistics, probability, discrete and continuous random variables, expectation and variance, sampling, Central Limit Theorem, estimation, hypothesis testing, correlation and regression. Emphasis on health science. Prerequisite: MATH 118xg or MATH 125.

MATH.title: Linear Algebra and Linear Differential Equations
MATH.description: Matrices, systems of linear equations, vector spaces, linear transformations, eigenvalues, systems of linear differential equations.

MATH.title: Calculus III
MATH.description: Vectors, vector valued functions; differential and integral calculus of functions of several variables; Green's theorem, Divergence theorem, Stoke's theorem.

MATH.title: Calculus III for Engineers and Scientists
MATH.description: A continuation of 129; vectors, vector valued functions;           differential and integral calculus of functions of several         variables; Greens theorem. Engineering and physics applications.   Prerequisite: MATH 126, or MATH 127, or MATH 129.(Duplicates       credit in MATH 226 and MATH 227)

MATH.title: Linear Algebra and Applications
MATH.description: Matrices, systems of linear equations, vector spaces, inner products and norms, linear transformations, eigenvalues, singular value decomposition. Applications such as image compression, graphs, networks or linear programming.

MATH.title: Mathematics of Physics and Engineering I
MATH.description: First-order differential equations; second-order linear differential equations; determinants and matrices; systems of linear differential equations; Laplace transforms.

MATH.title: Mathematical Reasoning and Problem Solving
MATH.description: Preparation for reading and writing proofs with applications from major branches of mathematics, focusing on axiomatic structures and transformations that preserve structure.

MATH.title: Statistical Inference and Data Analysis II
MATH.description: Confidence intervals, hypothesis testing, p-values, likelihood ratio, nonparametrics, descriptive statistics, regression, multiple linear regression, experimental design, analysis of variance, categorical data, chi-squared tests, Bayesian statistics.

MATH.title: Seminar in Problem Solving
MATH.description: Systematic approach to solving non-standard and competition level math problems on inequalities, infinite sums and products, combinatorics, number theory and games.

MATH.title: Probability Theory
MATH.description: Probability spaces.  Main families of discrete and continuous distributions and relations among them.  Moments, characteristic functions, sequences of random variables, laws of large numbers, Central Limit Theorem.

MATH.title: Mathematical Statistics
MATH.description: Principles for testing hypotheses and estimation, confidence intervals, methods of moments, maximum likelihood, information inequality, likelihood ratio tests, goodness of fit and nonparametric methods.

MATH.title: Fundamental Concepts of Modern Algebra
MATH.description: Sets; relations; groups; homomorphisms; symmetric groups; Abelian groups; Sylow's theorems; introduction to rings and fields.

MATH.title: Fundamental Concepts of Analysis
MATH.description: The real number system, metric spaces, limits, continuity, derivatives and integrals, infinite series.

MATH.title: Fundamental Concepts of Analysis
MATH.description: Implicit function theorems, Jacobians, transformations, multiple integrals, line integrals.

MATH.title: Theory of Numbers
MATH.description: Introduction to the theory of numbers, including prime factorization, congruences, primitive roots, N-th power residues, number theoretic functions and certain diophantine equations.

MATH.title: Applied Combinatorics
MATH.description: Mathematical induction, counting principles, arrangements, selections, binomial coefficients, generating functions, recurrence relations, inclusion-exclusion, symmetric groups, graphs, Euler and Hamiltonian circuits, trees, graph algorithms; applications.

MATH.title: Introduction to Differential Geometry
MATH.description: Vectors, elements of vector analysis, applications to curves and surfaces, standard material of differential geometry.

MATH.title: Mathematics of Physics and Engineering II
MATH.description: Vector field theory; theorems of Gauss, Green, and Stokes; Fourier series and integrals; complex variables; linear partial differential equations; series solutions of ordinary differential equations.

MATH.title: Mathematics of Machine Learning
MATH.description: Mathematical aspects of Machine Learning. PAC Learning, VC-dimension and complexity. Linear predictors (regression, perceptron, SVM). Convex learning and gradient descent. Neural networks and backpropagation.

MATH.title: History of Mathematics
MATH.description: Evolution of mathematical ideas and techniques as seen through a  study of the contributions of eminent mathematicians to the        formulation and solution of celebrated problems.  Recommended  preparation: upper division MATH course.

MATH.title: Game Theory
MATH.description: Partial games, partisan games, zero sum games, von Neumanns Minimax Theorem, general sum games, Nash equilibrium, fixed point theorems, evolutionary game theory, signaling, coalitions, auctions, social choice theory.

MATH.title: Numerical Methods
MATH.description: Rounding errors in digital computation; solution of linear algebraic systems; Newton's method for nonlinear systems; matrix eigenvalues; polynomial approximation; numerical integration; numerical solution of ordinary differential equations.

MATH.title: Dynamic Modeling
MATH.description: Formulation and study of models arising in population dynamics, growth of plankton, pollution of rivers, highway traffic, morphogenesis and tidal dynamics: stability, oscillations, bifurcations, chaos. The lab will consist of computer simulation of models using commercially available software.

MATH.title: Topics in Linear Algebra
MATH.description: Polynomial rings, vector spaces, linear transformations, canonical forms, inner product spaces.

MATH.title: Introduction to Theory of Complex Variables
MATH.description: Complex numbers and functions.  Power series, analytic functions, harmonic functions.  Complex integration, Cauchy's theorem, Cauchy's formula.  Conformal mapping.  Applications in physics and engineering.

MATH.title: Directed Research
MATH.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

MATH.title: Graduate Colloquium
MATH.description: Lectures directed to mathematics graduate students by faculty of  the department and by outside speakers.  Problem solving  workshops.  Graded CR/NC.

MATH.title: Numerical Analysis and Computation
MATH.description: Linear equations and matrices, Gauss elimination, error estimates, iteration techniques; contractive mappings, Newton's method; matrix eigenvalue problems; least-squares approximation, Newton-Cotes and Gaussian quadratures; finite difference methods. Prerequisite: linear algebra and calculus.

MATH.title: Numerical Analysis
MATH.description: Computational linear algebra; solution of general nonlinear       systems of equations; approximation theory using functional        analysis; numerical solution of ordinary and partial differential  equations.

MATH.title: Applied Probability
MATH.description: Markov processes in discrete or continuous time; renewal processes; martingales; brownian motion and diffusion theory; random walks, inventory models, population growth, queuing models, shot noise.

MATH.title: Theory of Probability
MATH.description: a: Probability spaces; distributions and characteristic functions; laws of large numbers, central limit problems; stable and infinitely divisible laws; conditional distributions. Prerequisite: 525a or 570. b: Dependence, martingales, ergodic theorems, second-order random functions, harmonic analysis, Markov processes.

MATH.title: Algebra
MATH.description: B: Commutative Algebra: Integrality, Hilbert Basis theorem, Hilbert Nullstellensatz; Modules: modules over PID's, chain conditions, tensor products; Noncommutative Rings: Jacobson radical, Artin-Wedderburn theorem, Maschke's theorem.

MATH.title: Data Analysis
MATH.description: Major parametric and non-parametric statistical tools used in biomedical research, computer packages including SAS. Includes laboratory. Lecture, 2 hours; laboratory, 2 hours.

MATH.title: Data Analysis
MATH.description: Statistical methods for analysis of categorical data including dichotomous, ordinal, multinomial and count data, using Stata package.  Includes laboratory.

MATH.title: Algebraic Geometry
MATH.description: Geometry of varieties and schemes including sheaf theory, morphisms of schemes, projective schemes, coherent and quasi-coherent sheaves, line bundles, and projective space.

MATH.title: Complex Analysis
MATH.description: Theory of analytic functions--power series and integral           representations, calculus of residues, harmonic functions, normal  families, approximation theorems, conformal mapping, analytical    continuation.

MATH.title: Real Analysis
MATH.description: a: Measure and integration over abstract measure spaces, Radon-Nikodym theorem, Fubini's theorem, convergence theorems, differentiation. Prerequisite: 425ab. b: Metric spaces, contraction principle, category, Banach spaces, Riesz representation theorem, properties of Lp, Hilbert spaces, orthogonal expansions, Fourier series and transforms, convolutions. Prerequisite: 525a.

MATH.title: Stochastic Calculus and Mathematical Finance
MATH.description: Advanced topics in stochastic analysis, asset pricing in continuous time, stochastic control, Hamilton-Jacobi-Bellman equations, incomplete markets, American options, exotic options, term structure of interest rates. Duplicates credit in the former MATH-506.

MATH.title: Algebraic Combinatorics
MATH.description: Combinatorics motivated by Representation Theory and Algebraic Geometry. Topics may include: representations of the symmetric group, symmetric functions, Young tableaux and plane partitions, permutation enumeration.

MATH.title: Differential Geometry
MATH.description: Elementary theory of manifolds, Lie groups, homogeneous spaces, fiber bundles and connections. Riemannian manifolds, curvature and conjugate points, second fundamental form, other topics. Prerequisite: 440.

MATH.title: Algebraic Topology
MATH.description: Vector bundles, classifying spaces and characteristic classes. Steenrod operations.  Spectral sequences. Homotopy groups and homotopy theory.

MATH.title: Introduction to Mathematical Statistics
MATH.description: Parametric families of distributions, sufficiency.  Estimation:  methods of moments, maximum likelihood, unbiased estimation.   Comparison of estimators, optimality, information inequality,  asymptotic efficiency.  EM algorithm, jacknife and bootstrap.

MATH.title: Introduction to Time Series
MATH.description: Transfer function models; stationary, nonstationary processes; moving average, autoregressive models; spectral analysis; estimation of mean, autocorrelation, spectrum; seasonal time series.

MATH.title: Machine Learning in Quantitive Finance
MATH.description: Mathematical foundations of machine learning, machine learning algorithms, applications in financial forecasting, derivatives valuation and hedging, portfolio optimization.

MATH.title: Partial Differential Equations
MATH.description: Second-order partial differential equations of elliptic,          parabolic, and hyperbolic type; in particular, potential and wave  equations.

MATH.title: Ordinary Differential Equations
MATH.description: Existence, uniqueness and continuation of solutions, differential inequalities, linear systems, Sturm-Liouville theory, boundary     value problems, Poincare-Bendixson theory, periodic solutions,     perturbations, stability, fixed point techniques.

MATH.title: Directed Research
MATH.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

MATH.description: Credit on acceptance of thesis.

MATH.description: Part-time or full-time, practical work experience in the students field of study. The internship must be located at an off-campus facility. Students are individually supervised by faculty. May not be taken until the student has completed at least one semester of enrollment in the graduate program with a cumulative 3.0 GPA.

MATH.title: Topics in Algebraic Geometry
MATH.description: Introduction to both classical and modern aspects of algebraic geometry.  Topics include aspects of commutative algebra, algebraic curves, algebraic varieties and schemes, and sheaf cohomology.

MATH.title: Topics in Differential Geometry
MATH.description: Topics to be chosen from the following: geometry of complex       manifolds, relations between topology and curvature, homogeneous   spaces, symmetric spaces, geometry of submanifolds.

MATH.title: Topics in Statistics
MATH.description: Current methods, techniques, and results in statistics, data science and machine learning.

MATH.title: Seminar in Combinatorics
MATH.description: Topics in combinatorics

MDES.title: The Middle East
MDES.description: Introduction to the natural and cultural diversity of the Middle East.

MDES.title: The Global Middle East
MDES.description: Explores the modern Middle East by focusing on the process         of globalization.

MDES.title: Modern Iran
MDES.description: History and culture of modern Iran from the nineteenth century to present through historical and ethnographic approaches to Iran today, richly contextualizing events and people.

MDES.title: The United States and the Middle East
MDES.description: Critical perspectives on U.S. relations with the Middle East, including the discourses surrounding democracy and globalization.

MDES.title: Modern Arab Culture and Literature
MDES.description: Examines contemporary Arab state-society relations using literature to illustrate how people construct meanings and portray issues of national, social, and cultural significance.

MDES.title: Power and Authority in the Middle East
MDES.description: A comparative examination of social relations of power and institutions with a special focus on intellectual traditions, the law, and social movements.

MDES.title: Ancient Empires
MDES.description: History and cultures of the ancient empires of southwest Asia, from Cyrus the Great to the establishment of Islam.

MDES.title: The International Relations of the Contemporary Middle East
MDES.description: Introduction to problems and issues in the Middle East today: religio-ethnic rivalries, conflicting nationalisms and ideologies, the Arab-Israeli conflict, Middle East oil.

MDES.title: Middle East Political Economy
MDES.description: Examination of general economic development issues: population, agriculture, industrialization, trade, oil, etc. Several Mideast case study countries are then explored in depth.

MDES.title: Environment and Politics in the Middle East
MDES.description: Introduction to key environmental and political challenges facing the contemporary Middle East and North Africa (MENA).

MDES.title: Directed Research
MDES.description: Individual research and readings. Not for graduate credit.

NSCI.title: Hearing and Communication Neuroscience
NSCI.description: A basic grounding in broad aspects of the neuroscience of hearing and vocal communication.

NSCI.title: Advanced Overview of Neurosciences II
NSCI.description: Sensory and motor systems, cognitive neuroscience, behavioral systems, computational neuroscience. Prerequisite: BISC 421. Open only to master and doctoral students. (Duplicates credit in former NEUR 525.)

NSCI.title: Computational Neural Engineering
NSCI.description: Introduction to computational modeling methods fundamental to neural engineering, with applications in brain-machine interfaces, neural prostheses, neuromodulation and neural system modeling.

NSCI.title: Seminar in Neurobiology
NSCI.description: Seminar in Neurobiology. Open only to master and doctoral students. (Duplicates credit in former NEUR 539.)

NSCI.title: Internship for Curricular Practical Training
NSCI.description: Part-time or full-time, practical work experience in the student's field of study. The internship must be located at an off-campus facility. Students are individually supervised by faculty. May not be taken until the student has completed at least one semester of enrollment in the graduate program with a cumulative 3.0 GPA.

NSCI.title: Research
NSCI.description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC. Open only to master and doctoral students in Neuroscience Graduate and Neuroscience majors. (Duplicates credit in former NEUR 790.)

NSCI.description: Credit on acceptance of dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC. Open only to doctoral students in Neuroscience Graduate and Neuroscience majors. (Duplicates credit in former NEUR 794a.)

MDA.title: South Asian Studies: Arts, Cultures, History and Religion
MDA.description: Introduction to the cultural origins, history, art, literature, and films of South Asia, comprising Afghanistan, Bangladesh, India, the Maldives, Nepal, Pakistan and Sri Lanka.

IRAN.title: Persian II
IRAN.description: Continuation of Persian I. Prerequisite: IRAN 120. (Duplicates credit in former MDES 150)

IRAN.title: Persian IV
IRAN.description: Continuing Intermediate Persian (Farsi). Building conversational skills, listening and reading comprehension, grammar and vocabulary necessary for intermediate level spoken and written expression. Prerequisite: IRAN 220. (Duplicates credit in former MDES 250)

IRAN.title: Advanced Persian II
IRAN.description: Continuation of Advanced Persian I. Prerequisite: IRAN 320. (Duplicates credit in former MDES 350)

NEUR.title: Neuroscience Colloquium
NEUR.description: Introduction to research activities conducted by Neuroscience faculty at USC.

NEUR.title: Cellular and Molecular Neuroscience
NEUR.description: An examination of individual nerve cell development, target location, and establishment of functional synapses; how dysfunction in these processes contributes to neurological and neuropsychiatric diseases.

NEUR.title: Systems Neuroscience: From Synapses to Perception
NEUR.description: Sensory and motor systems to illustrate concepts regarding the functional organization of the brain, from microcircuitry of neural circuits to global processes such as perception. Prerequisite: BISC 421.

NEUR.title: Epilepsy to Ecstasy: Biological Basis of Neurological Disord
NEUR.description: Examination of various neurological disorders originating from developmental signaling and/or anatomical abnormalities.

NEUR.title: Neuropsychopharmacology
NEUR.description: Pharmo-chemical nature of the brain; diseases of the brain and     drug treatments. Recommended Preparation: background in biological  psychology, biology and/or neuroscience.

NEUR.title: Foundations of  Cognitive Neuroscience
NEUR.description: Introduction to the major components of cognition (perception, memory, intelligence) in terms of the neural coding characteristic of the relevant brain areas.

NEUR.title: The Neurobiology of Dopamine: From Reward Learning to Motor  Control
Directed Research
NEUR.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit. Departmental approval.

NEUR.title: Neuroscience Honors Seminar
NEUR.description: Students attend lectures of distinguished neuroscientists visiting USC and give short, chalk-talk presentations summarizing the lecture. The presentations are critiqued by the students. Not available for graduate credit. Prerequisite: BISC-220L or BISC-221L. Recommended preparation: BISC 421.

NEUR.title: Honors Thesis
NEUR.description: Not available for graduate credit.  Programmatic approval.

PHYS.title: The Physical World
PHYS.description: The fundamentals of physics are presented, exploring the structure and beauty of physical laws and their manifestations, ranging from events observed in everyday life to subatomic and cosmic phenomena.

PHYS.title: Physics for Architects
PHYS.description: Fundamental laws and principles of physics with emphasis on theapplication of physical principles to the problems ofarchitecture. Lecture, 4 hours; laboratory, 3 hours.

PHYS.title: Physics for the Life Sciences
PHYS.description: Fundamental laws and principles of physics emphasizing areasrelated to life sciences. Prerequisite for Biological Sciences,Medicine, Dentistry, Pharmacy. Lecture, 4 hrs.; Lab, 3 hrs.

PHYS.title: Physics for the Life Sciences
PHYS.description: Fundamental laws and principles of physics emphasizing areas       related to life sciences. Prerequisite for Biological Sciences,    Medicine, Dentistry, and Pharmacy. Lecture, 4 hrs.; Lab, 3 hrs.    (Duplicates credit in 105abLg and 125L).

PHYS.title: Special Laboratory I
PHYS.description: Laboratory component for PHYS 151Lg for transfer students with equivalent lecture credit from another institution. For transfer students immediately after matriculation. Graded CR/NC.

PHYS.title: Special Laboratory II
PHYS.description: Laboratory component for PHYS 152L for transfer students with equivalent lecture credit from another institution. For transfer students immediately after matriculation. Graded CR/NC.

PHYS.title: Special Laboratory III
PHYS.description: Laboratory component for PHYS 153L for transfer students with equivalent lecture credit from another institution. For transfer students immediately after matriculation. Graded CR/NC.

PHYS.title: Fundamentals of Physics I: Mechanics and Thermodynamics
PHYS.description: Gateway to the majors and minors in Physics and Astronomy. Statics and dynamics of particles and rigid bodies, conservation principles, gravitation, simple harmonic oscillators, thermodynamics, heat engines, entropy.

PHYS.title: Fundamentals of Physics II: Electricity and Magnetism
PHYS.description: Electrostatics, magnetostatics, electrical circuits, wave motion, sound waves, electromagnetic waves.

PHYS.title: Fundamentals of Physics III: Optics and Modern Physics
PHYS.description: Geometrical optics, interference, diffraction, special relativity, quantum mechanics, atomic physics, solid state physics.

PHYS.title: Advanced Principles of Physics I
PHYS.description: Gateway to the majors and minors in Physics and Astronomy. Introductory treatment intended for well-qualified students. Dynamics of particles and rigid bodies, conservation laws, wave motion, thermodynamics, heat engines, entropy.

PHYS.title: Advanced Principles of Physics III
PHYS.description: Interference and diffraction of waves, special relativity, quantum mechanics, atomic physics, nuclear physics, condensed matter physics, elementary particles.

PHYS.title: Thermodynamics and Statistical Mechanics
PHYS.description: First, second, and third laws; thermodynamic potentials, applications; distribution laws, kinetic theory, transport phenomena, specific heats.

PHYS.title: Electricity and Magnetism
PHYS.description: b: Electromagnetic induction; AC circuits; Maxwell's equations.

PHYS.title: General Relativity and Gravitation
PHYS.description: Geometry of the Universe, special relativity, curved metrics, black holes, equivalence principle, cosmology, Friedman-Robertson-Walker geometry, Einstein's equations. Prerequisite: PHYS 304.

PHYS.title: Introduction to Quantum Mechanics and its Applications
PHYS.description: Concepts and techniques of quantum mechanics; free and bound states, the hydrogen atom.

PHYS.title: Directed Research
PHYS.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit. Prerequisite: consent of instructor.

PHYS.title: Advanced Experimental Techniques
PHYS.description: Development of modern experimental techniques, including computer interface with data acquisition hardware and data analysis by software, applied specifically to experiments in modern physics. Emphasis on laboratory work with discussion of theoretical background.

PHYS.title: Senior Project
PHYS.description: An original project will be constructed applying computer technology (in either hardware or software) to produce a result useful in the physics classroom or laboratory.

PHYS.title: Graduate Colloquium
PHYS.description: Topics of current research interest in physics and astronomy.   Lectures directed to physics graduate students by faculty of the  department and by outside speakers.  Graded CR/NC.

PHYS.title: Advanced Electricity and Magnetism
PHYS.description: a: Electrostatics, boundary value problems, multiple expansions, microscopic models of matter, magnetostatics. b: Maxwell's equations, potentials and gauge transformations; electromagnetic waves; wave guides; electromagnetic radiation; special relativity.

PHYS.title: Applications of Quantum Computing
PHYS.description: Training on available quantum computing hardware and the respective functional principles, available software, and algorithms; the opportunity to program quantum computers and run sample problems; hands-on tutorials.

PHYS.title: Python for Data Science and Scientific Computing
PHYS.description: Introduction to programming, data science, statistics and selected numerical methods; exploration of applications in the natural sciences.

PHYS.title: Methods of Computational Physics
PHYS.description: Introduction to algorithm development.  Integration of ordinary  differential equations; chaotic systems; molecular dynamics; Monte  Carlo integration and simulations; cellular automata and other  complex systems. Recommended preparation: ability to program in C  or C++

PHYS.title: Solid State Physics
PHYS.description: Fundamental concepts and techniques in solid state physics;       electron gas at metallic densities; semiclassical transport;       crystallography; band structure; phonons; screening;               superconductivity; magnetic ordering. Recommended preparation  PHYS-518a and 558a

PHYS.title: Theory of Open Quantum Systems
PHYS.description: The theory of open quantum systems (i.e., systems coupled to an environment) with applications to chemistry, physics and quantum information processing.

PHYS.title: Quantum Mechanics
PHYS.description: a: General formulation of quantum mechanics with applications; theory of measurement; exactly solvable problems; angular momentum formalism.

PHYS.title: Directed Research
PHYS.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

PHYS.title: Practicum in Teaching Physics and Astronomy
PHYS.description: Practical principles for the long-term development of effective teaching within the physical sciences. Intended for teaching assistants in Dornsife College. Graded CR/NC.

PHYS.description: Credit on acceptance of thesis.

PHYS.title: Topics in Current Research
PHYS.description: Course content will vary each year.  It will include topics of  current interest in research conducted in academica and industry.

PHYS.description: Coursework taken on campus at Caltech as part of the Caltech-USC  cross-registration program.  Graded CR/NC.

POIR.title: Conflict Processes
POIR.description: Seminar in international conflict, crisis and war. General perspectives on factors that bring about war or peace. Focus on ethnopolitics and conflict processes. MA and other students outside of POIR must obtain faculty permission to register for the course.

POIR.title: Democracy and Democratization in Comparative Perspective
POIR.description: Seminar generates and tests theories of democratization. Readings will focus on Europe, Latin America, Soviet Eurasia emphasizing core theoretical and methodological aspects. MA and other students outside of POIR must obtain faculty permission to register for the course.

POIR.title: Feminist Theory
POIR.description: History of feminist theory and major perspectives of current feminist theory: liberal feminism, socialist/Marxist feminism, radical feminism, psychological feminism, spiritual feminism, and ecological feminism.

POIR.title: Directed Research
POIR.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

POIR.title: Internship for Curricular Practical Training
POIR.description: Part-time or full-time practical work experience in the student's field of study. The internship must be located at an off-campus facility. Students are individually supervised by faculty. May not be taken until the student has completed at least one semester of enrollment in the graduate program.

POIR.title: Experimental Political Science
POIR.description: Introduction to experimental techniques and applications of experiments in political science. Addresses both the advantages and disadvantages of experiments in political science research. Open only to doctoral students.

POIR.title: Maximum Likelihood Estimation
POIR.description: Maximum likelihood estimation of binary choice models, duration models, count models, and other models in political science, international relations, and social sciences. MA and other students outside of POIR must obtain faculty permission to register for the course.

POIR.title: Comparative Politics II
POIR.description: Seminar covering literature and methods in the study of political economy, authoritarianism, redistribution, and political conflict.

POIR.title: International Political Economy
POIR.description: Survey of approaches to international political economy. Intellectual roots; the management of collective goods; North-South relations are examined. Open only to doctoral students.

POIR.title: Political Psychology
POIR.description: Integrates findings of psychology into the study of international relations and political science. Covers foreign policy decision-making, public opinion, ideology, emotion and common heuristics and biases among other topics.

POIR.title: Research
POIR.description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

PDF.title: Postdoctoral Fellows
PDF.description: Course created for visiting postdoctoral fellows scholars.  The  course is created for enrollment purposes, zero units, full time  status, scheduled in session 018, and never appears in the student  academic records system.

QBIO.title: Introduction to Quantitative Biology Seminar
QBIO.description: Introduction to quantitative biology and its role in biology and relationship to chemistry, computer science, engineering, mathematics, medicine and physics, including the field's impact on industry.

QBIO.title: Drug Discovery: From Genes to Medicines
QBIO.description: The course will explore the science of modern drug discovery and development, its key challenges and pitfalls in the personal health and socioeconomic context.

QBIO.title: Statistics for Biological Sciences
QBIO.description: Statistical methods in biological science and medicine, including populations and samples, random sampling, confidence intervals, paired samples and regression.

QBIO.title: Statistical Thinking for Quantitative Biology
QBIO.description: Introduction to general statistical theory with higher-level mathematics for biological data analysis. Basic programming in R. Discussion of techniques to describe, visualize and model different types of data.

QBIO.title: Introduction to Computational Analysis of Biological Data
QBIO.description: A project-based course integrating biology, computer science, and statistics through the analysis of genomic datasets available publicly or collected and sequenced during the semester.

QBIO.title: Artificial Intelligence in Biology and Medicine
QBIO.description: Al techniques including traditional machine learning and advanced deep learning methods for genomics, system biology, data integration, drug discovery and medical imaging; project-based.

QBIO.title: Computational Genome Analysis
QBIO.description: Introduction to algorithms and statistics for genome analysis and their applications. Analysis of DNA sequencing, sequence comparison, genetic variation, gene expression, disease association and evolution.

QBIO.title: Systems Biology: Modeling the Dynamics of Life
QBIO.description: Foundational skill-building for modeling and analysis of biological data. Hands-on instruction for developing and simulating models of dynamic biological systems.

QBIO.title: Directed Research
QBIO.description: Individual research and readings. Project approval by  faculty adviser and QCB department required.

QBIO.title: Quantitative Biology Honors Thesis
QBIO.description: Experience in conducting research and writing an honors thesis or publishable manuscript under the supervision of a faculty adviser.

QBIO.title: Molecular Biology for Quantitative Scientists
QBIO.description: In-depth study of molecular biology techniques and experiments with an emphasis on those that are able to generate "big data." Intended for quantitative science students.

QBIO.title: Introduction to Systems Biology
QBIO.description: Computational methods for simulation and analysis of metabolic networks, cellular signaling pathways, and gene regulatory networks. Biochemical kinetics, differential equations, stability analysis, sensitivity analysis.

QBIO.title: Seminar in Computational Biology
QBIO.description: Experience and training in giving science research presentations. Students will discuss recent research in computational biology and bioinformatics.

QBIO.title: Scientific Writing in Quantitative and Computational Biology
QBIO.description: Practical guidance on the writing of scientific articles and research proposals in the field of Quantitative and Computational Biology.

QBIO.title: Computational Molecular Biology
QBIO.description: Applications of the mathematical, statistical and computational sciences to data from molecular biology. Algorithms for genomic sequence data: sequence and map assembly and alignment, RNA secondary structure, protein structure, gene-finding, and tree construction.

QBIO.title: Computational Molecular Biology
QBIO.description: Applications of the mathematical, statistical and computational sciences to data from molecular biology. Statistics for genomic sequence data: DNA sequence assembly, significance of alignment scores, hidden Markov models, genetic mapping, models of sequence evolution and microarray analysis.

QBIO.title: Directed Research
QBIO.description: Research leading to a graduate degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

QBIO.title: Internship for Curricular Practical Training
QBIO.description: Part-time or full-time, practical work experience in the student's field of study. The internship must be located at an off-campus facility. Students are supervised by faculty. May not be taken until the student has completed one semester of enrollment in a graduate program with a cumulative 3.0 GPA. The course is graded CR/NC.

QBIO.title: Research
QBIO.description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

QBIO.description: For doctoral students who have passed the qualifying exam. Credit on acceptance of dissertation.

PORT.title: Portuguese II
PORT.description: For students with some language proficiency in Portuguese; increased emphasis on listening, comprehension, oral communication, reading, and writing. Students will be required to take a Portuguese placement exam in the Spanish and Portuguese Department. Prerequisite: PORT 120.

PORT.title: Accelerated Portuguese I
PORT.description: Encourages rapid acquisition through intensive exposure to Portuguese while following a proficiency-oriented approach.  Recommended for students with a background in Spanish or another Romance language.

PORT.title: Portuguese IV
PORT.description: Four-skills course with review of grammar. Writing and reading  intensive. Authentic materials related to Lusobrazilian culture  and civilization.

PSYC.title: Introduction to Psychology
PSYC.description: Introduction to psychological science, including historical and contemporary approaches. Behavior examined from biological, cognitive, social, developmental, and personality perspectives. Disorders and treatments.

PSYC.title: Drugs, Behavior, and Society
PSYC.description: An integrative systems perspective of drugs; including their historical, economic, and cultural importance, psychopharmacology, addiction, relationship to crime, and therapeutic use in treating psychological disorders.

PSYC.title: Music, Mind and the Brain
PSYC.description: An interdisciplinary approach to music, mind and brain. Explores music as an object with its own properties and as a form of human behavior.

PSYC.title: Scientific Inquiry and Reasoning in Health Care
PSYC.description: Critical analysis and reasoning skills required to solve scientific problems in human behavior, including presentation of data, logic of research design, statistics, and research ethics. Not for major credit for Psychology majors.

PSYC.title: Statistics
PSYC.description: Introduction to the use of statistics in psychology: basic ideas in measurement; frequency distributions; descriptive statistics; concepts and procedures in statistical inference.

PSYC.title: Supervised Research in Psychology
PSYC.description: Supervised Research with department faculty.

PSYC.title: Cognitive Processes
PSYC.description: Experimental and theoretical aspects of human memory, perception, thinking, and language. Lectures, demonstrations, and individual experiments. Prerequisite: 100g or departmental approval.

PSYC.title: Sensation and Perception
PSYC.description: Receptor processes and stimulus organization; traditional topics  in the perception of objects, space, time. Laboratory              demonstrations and exercises.

PSYC.title: Learning and Memory
PSYC.description: Principles involved in classical and operant conditioning.        Concentration on basic causes of behavior; consideration of the    relevance of simple behavioral laws to complicated human behavior.

PSYC.title: Experimental Research Methods
PSYC.description: Experimental research methods in psychology; nature and concepts of scientific method.

PSYC.title: Non-Experimental Research Methods
PSYC.description: Non-experimental research methods in psychology. Observational, survey and data analysis exercises

PSYC.title: Behavioral Neuroscience
PSYC.description: Neural bases of behavior. Concentration on sensory and motor processes and the interaction of neural, chemical, and hormonal systems.

PSYC.title: Developmental Psychology
PSYC.description: Child and adolescent behavior and associated theories;            exploration of the continuity between child and adult behavior.    Laboratory projects.

PSYC.title: Origins of the Mind
PSYC.description: Exploration of ancient philosophical questions concerning the origins of human knowledge through empirical studies of infants, animals, and adults from diverse cultures.

PSYC.title: Systems Thinking for Sustainability
PSYC.description: Analysis of the complex interplay of technical, social, psychological, and environmental factors to address real-world sustainability challenges.

PSYC.title: Close Relationships
PSYC.description: Scientific perspective of close relationships: intimate relationships, friendships and others, evolutionary and biological bases of attraction and love, historical, social , cultural influences. Prerequisite: PSYC 100. (Duplicates credit in PSYC 359)

PSYC.title: Social Psychology
PSYC.description: Theoretical and experimental analysis of human behavior. Social   processes involved in attitudes, conformity, compliance,           interpersonal perception, liking, affiliation, aggression,         altruism, and group dynamics.

PSYC.title: Psychological Disorders
PSYC.description: The commonly diagnosed behavior pathologies; biological, social, cultural and developmental antecedents of abnormal behavior; principles of learning, perception and motivation, as they relate to psychopathology.

PSYC.title: Introduction to Clinical Psychology
PSYC.description: Introduction to the scientist-practitioner model of clinical psychology, including research methods, psychological assessment and diagnosis, psychotherapeutic interventions, and treatment of special populations.

PSYC.title: Introduction to Forensic Psychology
PSYC.description: Survey of current topics, technologies and techniques. Students acquire a basic understanding of how forensic psychologists contribute their unique expertise to the American legal system. Prerequisites: PSYC 100. Duplicates credit in former PSYC 465.

PSYC.title: Stress, Health, and the Mind-Body Connection
PSYC.description: Introduction to psychological, biological and behavioral processes affecting physical health, including stress, coping with disease, health behaviors and socioeconomic and cultural influences on health.

PSYC.title: Human Sexuality
PSYC.description: Psychological and physiological base of sexuality; gender identity, childbearing, birth control, venereal diseases; dysfunctions and treatments.

PSYC.title: Junior Honors Seminar
PSYC.description: Advanced study of scientific inquiry in psychology with in-depth  analysis of current research by faculty in the Psychology          Department. Preparation for senior honors thesis research.         Prerequisite: acceptance in Psychology Undergraduate Honors        Program and consent of instructor.

PSYC.title: Not Easy Being Green: Decision-Making for Sustainability
PSYC.description: Factors to consider when making decisions that frontline sustainability and psychological barriers that stand in the way of sustainable action.

PSYC.title: Current Topics In Social Psychology
PSYC.description: Extensive examination of select current research in social psychology, based on original research papers. Specific topics change by semester.

PSYC.title: Functional Imaging of the Human Brain
PSYC.description: Introduction to the physical and physiological bases of Magnetic           Resonance Imaging (MRI), and principles of functional MRI, safety,         design and analysis of experiments, and operation.

PSYC.title: Motivated Behaviors and Addiction
PSYC.description: Social, environmental, and physiological influences on behaviors associated with aggression, eating, reproduction, and sleep. Will focus on behavioral disorders such as addiction.

PSYC.title: Neuropsychopharmacology
PSYC.description: Pharmo-chemical nature of the brain; diseases of the brain and     drug treatments. Recommended Preparation: background in biological  psychology, biology and/or neuroscience.

PSYC.title: From Eugenics to Neurodiversity: History of DisAbility
PSYC.description: An introductory overview of the primary historical issues, questions, concerns and developments that directly impact our current thought and action around disability and inclusion of disabled people in society.

PSYC.title: Children's Learning and Cognitive Development
PSYC.description: Principles of cognitive development, learning, and motivation applied to the development of literacy; includes tutoring a child 2 hours per week. Prerequisite: PSYC 336L.

PSYC.title: Adolescent Development
PSYC.description: The adolescent years from both an applied and a research-oriented perspective. Topics include physical, cognitive, and moral development; socialization; and sexual and sex-role development.

PSYC.title: Science of Yoga and Meditation
PSYC.description: Reviews intersection between modern science and ancient contemplative practices of yoga and meditation. Explores mind-body-spirit connection through personal practice, review of contemplative texts and empirical research.

PSYC.title: Foundations of  Cognitive Neuroscience
PSYC.description: Introduction to the major components of cognition (perception, memory, intelligence) in terms of the neural coding characteristic of the relevant brain areas.

PSYC.title: Neural Network Models of Social and Cognitive Processes
PSYC.description: Introduction to using neural network or connectionist models to simulate cognitive, social, emotional and motivational processes; basic concepts and tools in computational neuroscience.

PSYC.title: Social Neuroscience
PSYC.description: Overview of principles and research in social neuroscience, which uses neuroscience approaches to inform social processes including empathy, inter-group relations, emotion, morality and social decision-making.

PSYC.title: Cognitive Behavior Therapy
PSYC.description: The philosophical, ethical, historical, theoretical and procedural aspects of cognitive behavior therapy (CBT), including how theory guides practice and how practice informs theory.

PSYC.title: Psychology of Marriage and the Family
PSYC.description: Theories and research on family relationships across the life  span, including research methods, cultural and developmental  perspectives, communication, conflict, attachment, individual  psychopathology, and family violence.

PSYC.title: Introduction to Autism Spectrum Disorder
PSYC.description: A comprehensive overview of the assessment, diagnosis and treatment of individuals diagnosed with autism spectrum disorder.

PSYC.title: Happiness:  Research in Neuroscience and Positive Psychology
PSYC.description: Neuroscientific and psychological perspectives that investigate the basis of happiness and well-being.

PSYC.title: Senior Honors Seminar
PSYC.description: Advanced study of empirical approaches in psychology. Progress    presentations and evaluations of Senior Honors Thesis research.    In-depth exploration of issues in science. Not available for       graduate credit.

PSYC.title: Directed Research
PSYC.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

PSYC.title: The Infant Brain
PSYC.description: Selected topics in the various specialty areas within psychology.  Topic will vary from semester to semester.

PSYC.title: Regression and the General Linear Model
PSYC.description: Multiple regression as a tool in experimental and non-experimental data; analysis of variance and covariance as regression on coded variables. Computer applications.  Laboratory  exercises.

PSYC.title: Research Methods in Applied Social Psychology
PSYC.description: Various research techniques that are useful in a variety of different real world settings, such as business, governmental agencies and charities. Open only to M.S., Applied Psychology students.

PSYC.title: Qualitative Research Methods in Applied Psychology
PSYC.description: Examines qualitative research in applied settings. Learn to design, execute and report qualitative research in response to stakeholder needs.

PSYC.title: Group Dynamics and Leadership
PSYC.description: Theory and research on effective teams and characteristics of strong leaders. Negotiation, morale-building, managing expectancies, utilization of cultural diversity as a strength. Open only to M.S., Applied Psychology students.

PSYC.title: User Experience (UX) Research
PSYC.description: Provides a broad introduction to the social science methods UX researchers most commonly use, including qualitative approaches, and quantitative approaches.

PSYC.title: Affective Computing
PSYC.description: Overview of the theory of human emotion, techniques for recognizing and synthesizing emotional behavior, and design application.

PSYC.title: Research Methods in Behavior Analysis
PSYC.description: Survey of methods for measuring behavior. Examines theoretical background for single subject research methods, practical application of research methods to treatment evaluation, and analyzes strengths and limitations of single subject research methods.

PSYC.title: Behavioral Interventions
PSYC.description: Examines empirically supported behavioral interventions across a range of socially relevant behavioral excesses, skill deficits, disorders, and age ranges. Focuses on least-intrusive, person-centered approaches.

PSYC.title: Organizational Behavior Management
PSYC.description: Surveys evidence-based practices in the application of behavioral principles of learning and motivation to assessing and supporting organizational behavior change.

PSYC.title: Origins of Human Nature
PSYC.description: Examines cognitive development through the lens of comparative psychology: identifying cognitive and social traits that are uniquely human or shared with other animals.

PSYC.title: Behavioral Approaches to Skill Acquisition
PSYC.description: Examines contemporary research on behavioral procedures for teaching complex skills to individuals of a variety ages and populations, including language, social, cognitive, vocational, and independent living skills.

PSYC.title: Experimental Analysis of Behavior
PSYC.description: Examines a collection of experimental procedures and findings within the experimental analysis of behavior (EAB); basic principles of operant and respondent learning and motivation; translate findings of basic research to the development of applied sciences of behavior change.

PSYC.title: Proseminar in Human Behavior
PSYC.description: The nature of the human mind, social interactions, conflicts, cooperative behavior, mutual influence and effectiveness. Application of psychological principles to the dynamics of commercial entities. Open only to M.S., Applied Psychology students.

PSYC.title: Proseminar in Human Behavior
PSYC.description: Application of psychological principles to the dynamics of commercial entities. Develop practical skills with a focus on professional development.

PSYC.title: Decision Neuroscience
PSYC.description: Neuroscientific studies attempting to understand the neural basis  of judgment and decision-making, social behavior, and market  economies.

PSYC.title: Principles of Consumer Psychology
PSYC.description: Examination of the attitudes and decisions of consumers, and how to effectively reach consumers by using persuasion and proper positioning in the marketplace. Open only to M.S., Applied Psychology students.

PSYC.title: Psychology of Interactive Media
PSYC.description: Examination of the diverse methods of communicating with a target audience with a special emphasis on the newest computer-based tools for providing information and influence.

PSYC.title: Organizational Psychology
PSYC.description: Examination of the psychological factors that impact employee motivation, job satisfaction, teamwork, leadership, and organizational development. Open only to Master of Applied Psychology students. Not available for major credit for GSBA majors

PSYC.title: The Psychology of Employee Selection and Assessment
PSYC.description: Develop an understanding of recruitment and selection practices, processes, and approaches into the strategic role that recruitment and selection plays in organizational success.

PSYC.title: Multilevel Modeling
PSYC.description: Topics in multilevel modeling including two- and three-level hierarchical linear models (HLM), random intercepts and slopes, longitudinal models and growth curve models, non-nested models as well as some recent development.

PSYC.title: Workshop in Quantitative Methods
PSYC.description: Practical, hands-on experience in the application of selected quantitative methods to empirical data. Includes training in the use of relevant computer software.

PSYC.title: Advanced Psycholinguistics
PSYC.description: Current issues in psycholinguistic theory.

PSYC.title: Practicum in Applied Behavior Analysis
PSYC.description: Provides supervised practical experience in implementing behavior analytic assessment and treatment services. Meets supervision requirements for the Board Certified Behavior Analyst exam. Students meet with course instructor to present and discuss cases for two hours per week every semester, including one summer session. Practicum hours in the field vary from 18-20 hours per week during the academic year to 30 hours per week during the summer.

PSYC.title: Directed Research
PSYC.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

PSYC.title: Applied Psychology Internship
PSYC.description: Internship in a non-university setting, such as business, governmental agency, or NGO. Graded CR/NC. Open only to M.S., Applied Psychology students.

PSYC.title: Applied Psychology Treatise
PSYC.description: Requires a research paper of substantial length and high quality that integrates the Internship experience with concepts and principles of human behavior. Credit/No Credit. Open only to M.S., Applied Psychology students.

PSYC.title: Master's Thesis
PSYC.description: Credit on acceptance of Thesis. Graded CR/NC.

PSYC.title: Master's Thesis
PSYC.description: Credit on acceptance of Thesis. Graded CR/NC.

PSYC.title: Master's Thesis
PSYC.description: Credit on acceptance of Thesis. Graded CR/NC.

PSYC.title: Practicum in Clinical Psychology
PSYC.description: Supervised experience in interviewing skills and in assessment, including psychological test administration, and the preparation of reports. Graded CR/NC.

PSYC.title: Internship for Curricular Practical Training
PSYC.description: Part-time or full-time, practical work experience in the students field of study. The internship must be located at an off-campus facility. Students are individually supervised by faculty. May not be taken until the student has completed at least two semesters of enrollment in the graduate program.

PSYC.title: Capstone Project in Behavior Analysis
PSYC.description: Supervision for completing independent project, consisting of practical treatment evaluation, program development, or literature review.

PSYC.title: Computational Language Neuroscience
PSYC.description: Selected topics in the various specialty areas within psychology at the graduate level. Topic will vary from semester to semester.

PSYC.title: Luddite Cognition
PSYC.description: Selected topics in the various specialty areas within psychology at the graduate level. Topic will vary from semester to semester.

PSYC.title: Applied Research Design
PSYC.description: Selected topics in the various specialty areas within psychology at the graduate level. Topic will vary from semester to semester.

PSYC.title: Applied Rsearch Design
PSYC.description: Selected topics in the various specialty areas within psychology at the graduate level. Topic will vary from semester to semester.

PSYC.title: Seminar in Advanced Social Psychology
PSYC.description: An intensive consideration of selected concepts, theories, and research problems in social psychology.

PSYC.title: The Economics and Psychology of Decision-Making
PSYC.description: Analyze how psychology and behavioral economics together contribute to our understanding of decision-making: inter-temporal choice, self-control problems, cooperative and risky behavior, social preferences.

PSYC.title: Psychological Intervention
PSYC.description: Study of clinical psychological treatment: Research and theory     about major psychological approaches to intervention. (One of 4    clinical psychology core courses: PSYC 514, PSYC 515, PSYC 619,  PSYC 620.)

PSYC.title: Applied Machine Learning
PSYC.description: Machine learning techniques, including Bayesian and Neural Networks, for analyzing different types of human-generated data.

PSYC.title: Seminar in Clinical Psychology
PSYC.description: Selected topics in clinical psychology.

PSYC.title: Internship in Clinical Psychology
PSYC.description: Supervised clinical work in an approved mental health setting. Graded CR/NC. Prerequisite: Good standing in clinical program and departmental approval.

PSYC.title: Advanced Practicum in Clinical Psychology
PSYC.description: Didactic practicum combining theory and research on psychological intervention with clinical practice in assessment and treatment, focused on particular client groups or disorders. Graded CR/NC.

PSYC.title: Externship for Practical Training
PSYC.description: Externship for Practical Training is for clinical-related training experience in the students fieldof study. Students are individually supervised at their site.

PSYC.title: Research
PSYC.description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

PSYC.title: Doctoral Dissertation
PSYC.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC.

PHIL.title: Central Problems of Philosophy
PHIL.description: Explores questions about human beings and their place in nature, including questions about knowledge, mind and body, freedom and determinism, and the existence of God.

PHIL.title: Reasoning and Argument
PHIL.description: Techniques for constructing good arguments and for assessing and criticizing the arguments of others. (Duplicates credit in former PHIL 250a)

PHIL.title: Reasoning and Argument
PHIL.description: Techniques for constructing good arguments and for assessing and criticizing the arguments of others. (Duplicates credit in former PHIL 250b)

PHIL.title: Current Moral and Social Issues
PHIL.description: Critical study of controversial social issues such as abortion, euthanasia, the death penalty, war and terrorism, sexual morality, affirmative action and economic justice.

PHIL.title: The Meaning of Life
PHIL.description: Explores philosophical treatments of the problem of the meaning or purpose of human life. (Duplicates credit in former PHIL 155)

PHIL.title: Foundations of Cognitive Science
PHIL.description: Introduction to research in interdisciplinary cognitive science, highlighting ideas and methods from philosophy, psychology, linguistics, neuroscience, and computer science.

PHIL.title: The Ways of Paradox
PHIL.description: Focusing on selected paradoxes in science and philosophy calling into question common views of infinity, space and time, causation and rational belief and action.

PHIL.title: Probability and Rational Choice
PHIL.description: Explores formal tools for thinking about uncertainty. In an uncertain world, how is it rational to form our beliefs, make decisions, and interact with others?

PHIL.title: Ethical Theory and Practice
PHIL.description: Explores various conceptions of morality and what makes actions right or wrong, together with the implications of these views for concrete ethical issues.

PHIL.title: Ideas on Trial
PHIL.description: The trials of Socrates, Joan of Arc, the Salem witches, Galileo, Scopes and the Nuremberg and Eichmann trials; their social and cultural consequences.

PHIL.title: History of Western Philosophy: Ancient Period
PHIL.description: Major figures in the history of Western philosophical thought from the presocratics to the Hellenistic period; emphasis on Plato and Aristotle.

PHIL.title: History of Western Philosophy: Medieval Period
PHIL.description: Central themes in Jewish, Christian and Islamic philosophy from  late antiquity through the scholastic period.

PHIL.title: Philosophy of Economics
PHIL.description: Central topics in the philosophy of economics, including models of economic rationality, the aggregation of preferences and the conditions in which markets yield undesirable outcomes.

PHIL.title: Intermediate Logic
PHIL.description: Basic techniques of propositional and quantificational logic, and elements of probability. Especially useful to philosophy, mathematics, science and engineering majors.

PHIL.title: Possible Worlds
PHIL.description: Introduction to possible worlds as a tool for asking and answering questions about what might be, what must be, and what can never be.

PHIL.title: British Empiricism
PHIL.description: Development of philosophy in Great Britain from the seventeenth to the nineteenth centuries; emphasis on Locke, Berkeley, and Hume.

PHIL.title: History of Ethics to 1900
PHIL.description: An historical and critical study of the great moral philosophers, including Plato, Aristotle, Aquinas, Kant, and the British moralists.

PHIL.title: Higher-order Logic
PHIL.description: Typed and higher-order languages, emphasizing the use of logical methods for system building and applications in contemporary philosophy.

PHIL.title: Metaphysics
PHIL.description: Systematic introduction to basic concepts, including identity, difference, existence, individuals, substance, quality, and relation; emphasis on idealism, materialism, and the ontology of intentionality.

PHIL.title: Language, Linguistics and Mind
PHIL.description: Topics of current interest at the crossroads of philosophy of language, philosophy of mind and linguistics.

PHIL.title: Theory of Knowledge
PHIL.description: Examination of contemporary accounts of the nature, scope, sources--and value--of human knowledge and justified belief.

PHIL.title: Directed Research
PHIL.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

PHIL.title: Senior Thesis
PHIL.description: Independent studies for philosophy majors, and guidance in the preparation of the senior thesis for students who wish to graduate with honors in philosophy.

PHIL.title: Honors Capstone
PHIL.description: In-depth study synthesizing important recent developments in one or more central areas of philosophy pursued at a beginning graduate level.

PHIL.title: Seminar in Recent Philosophy
PHIL.description: Contemporary philosophical issues and literature.

PHIL.title: Introduction to Contemporary Philosophical Literature on Value
PHIL.description: Analysis of selected philosophical problems and theses of current  interest; explication of major contemporary papers and/ or books  is emphasized.

PHIL.title: Seminar in Social and Political Philosophy
PHIL.description: Advanced literature on selected topics in social and political philosophy, including the nature of law, man, and society; ideals such as justice and freedom.

PHIL.title: Seminar in Metaphysics
PHIL.description: Advanced topics in metaphysics.

PHIL.title: Philosophy of Mind
PHIL.description: Contemporary approaches to a variety of questions about the nature of mental states and our knowledge of them.

PHIL.title: Seminar in Philosophy of Science
PHIL.description: Advanced topics in the philosophy of science.

PHIL.title: Directed Research
PHIL.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may  be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.       Graded CR/NC.

PHIL.description: Credit on acceptance of Thesis. Graded IP/CR/NC.

PHIL.description: Designed for advanced teaching assistants in philosophy at USC.

PHIL.title: Internship for Curricular Practical Training
PHIL.description: Part-time or full-time, practical work experience in the student's field of study. The internship must be located at an off-campus facility. Students are individually supervised by faculty. May not be taken until the student has completed at least two semesters of enrollment in the graduate program.

PHIL.title: Dissertation Seminar
PHIL.description: A focused environment in which to present and evaluate dissertation work-in-progress. Focus on peer and faculty feedback, developing professional presentation skills, improving critical communication skills. Graded CR/NC. Open only to Philosophy doctoral students.

PHIL.title: Research
PHIL.description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

RUSS.title: Beginning Russian I
RUSS.description: Introduction to the Russian language with emphasis on basic conversational skills, major points of grammar and reading.

RUSS.title: Intermediate Russian I
RUSS.description: Development of thematic conversational skills with emphasis on extended dialogue. Review of basic morphology with special attention to verbs of motion. Reading of authentic material is emphasized.

RUSS.title: Intermediate Russian II
RUSS.description: Continuation of RUSS 220. Development of proficiency in conversation skills, reading and writing.

RUSS.title: Intercultural Communication in Russian
RUSS.description: Advanced language training focusing on specific issues of communication with Russians. Analysis and translation of literary texts. Advanced syntax. Conducted in Russian.

RUSS.title: Seminar in Russian Studies
RUSS.description: Readings and discussion in Russian of current topics in Russian culture, politics and society. Content varies each time offered.

REL.title: The World of the Hebrew Bible
REL.description: The Hebrew Bible in the cultural setting of the ancient Near East; the formation of theological and ethical concepts which have shaped Western culture.

REL.title: The New Testament
REL.description: Historical investigation of New Testament characters, events, ethics and theology in relation to its social, intellectual, and religious contexts in the Jewish and Greco-Roman world.

REL.title: Introduction to Buddhism
REL.description: Focus primarily on works of Buddhist literature written in a       variety of genres.  Introduction of basic teachings that link      Buddhist traditions across time and space.

REL.title: Chinese Religions and Culture
REL.description: Historical and thematic survey of Chinese religious history from earliest times to the present.

REL.title: Global Religions in Los Angeles
REL.description: Congregational and individual expressions of religion in Los Angeles.

REL.title: Ethics and Global Heritage
REL.description: Archaeology and global heritage debates, laws, ethical conundrums, and stakeholder perspectives reveal goals and guiding values of societys exploration of the past.

REL.title: Thought and Life of Islam
REL.description: History, thought, institutions, and religious practices of Islam.

REL.title: Religious Experience in the Greco-Roman World
REL.description: Varieties of religious experience as reflected in the literature, art, and cultic practices of the Hellenistic world.

REL.title: Religion and Colonial Encounter
REL.description: Survey of religious responses to colonial encounter in the Americas. Emphasis given to study of religious innovations of Amerindians, Africans and Europeans.

REL.title: Buddhist Modernism
REL.description: Examines various topics in the process of rapid modernization and globalization in Buddhism including environmentalism, gender, nationalism, social activism, and war and peace.

REL.title: Zen and Daoism in Asian Literature
REL.description: Studies of the presence and influence of Zen Buddhism and Daoism in Asian literature, with a focus on China and Japan.

REL.title: Religion, Media and Hollywood: Faith in TV
REL.description: How religion, ethics and spirituality are embedded, embodied and emplotted in television drama; how secular texts represent "lived religion" to increasingly diverse audiences.

REL.title: Religion and Violence
REL.description: Religious and moral perspectives on war, pacifism, violent and non-violent protest, and religion-based terrorism and militia.

REL.title: Sociology of Religion
REL.description: The role of religion in modern society from the standpoint of sociological theory and research.

REL.title: Directed Research
REL.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

REL.title: Undergraduate Honors Research
REL.description: Individual research for honors in the major leading to a  substantial project.

REL.title: Lab Methods and Theories in Archaeology
REL.description: Archaeological research design, data recovery, artifact analysis, interpretation and analogy, publication, and ethics.

REL.title: Dare to Care for the Past
REL.description: Selected topics in religious studies.

REL.title: Colloquium in Jewish Studies
REL.description: Foundation for and exposure to a number of sub-fields in Jewish Studies.

REL.title: Directed Research
REL.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

REL.title: Practicum in Teaching the Liberal Arts
REL.description: Practical principles for the long-term development of effective teaching within liberal arts disciplines. Graded CR/NC.

REL.title: Advanced Graduate Seminar in Christian Studies
REL.description: Comparative and transhistorical methods for understanding the most prominent developments in premodern or modern globalized Christianity.

REL.title: Readings in Classical Christian Texts
REL.description: Survey of the different genres of texts in the history of Christian spirituality from ancient Christianity to the present.

REL.title: Education and Preaching
REL.description: Study of varied Asian Buddhist texts in translation and in original languages. Exploration of the major secondary literature on Buddhist texts.

REL.title: Research Seminar in Religious Studies
REL.description: Skills for academic professionalization, presentation of research in progress and formal responses to academic writing.

REL.description: Credit on acceptance of dissertation. Graded CR/NC.
