PHED.title: Weight Training
PHED.description: Improvement of body shape, muscle endurance, and muscle  strength; understanding of weight training and nutrition  principles that can be utilized for future weight training  development.

PHED.title: Self-Defense
PHED.description: Basic instruction of self-defense for beginners; strategies for  standing and ground fighting situations with and without weapons.

PHED.title: Self-Defense
PHED.description: Intermediate instruction involving more advanced fighting  strategies and techniques.

PHED.title: Principles of Self Defense and Personal Safety
PHED.description: Application of learned skills and strategies for identifying physical threats; increased situational awareness; understanding of when physical force may be required.

PHED.title: Physical Conditioning
PHED.description: a: Improvement in cardiorespiratory endurance, body composition,  muscle endurance and flexibility; running, circuit training,  resistance exercises; fitness principles and nutrition to develop  individualized program.

PHED.title: Swimming
PHED.description: a: Instruction and practice of basic strokes for beginners and  intermediate swimmers; elementary springboard diving; water safety  techniques; endurance training as a fitness program.

PHED.title: Surfing
PHED.description: Fundamental instruction of surfing skills; water safety and wave etiquette; wave recognition and forecast interpretation; surf culture; board selection; surf related strengthening and conditioning.

PHED.title: Sustainability and Self-Care
PHED.description: Alternative ways to integrate sustainability practices into a daily routine; develop individual self-care modalities and connect to our planet; navigate climate anxiety.

PHED.title: Sleep for Peak Performance
PHED.description: Introduction to sleep as it relates to physical and mental performance; breathing and meditation modalities to support healthy sleep; study of sleep systems, disorders, strategies.

PHED.title: Introduction to Mindfulness
PHED.description: Introduction to the principles of mindfulness; application of learned techniques to enhance mind body awareness; cultivate strategies to improve physical and mental health.

PHED.title: Course Emphasis: Athletic Performance
PHED.description: Introduction to the principles of mindfulness; application of learned techniques to enhance mind body awareness; cultivate strategies to improve physical and mental health.

PHED.title: Yoga
PHED.description: Introduction to meditation, breathing techniques and postures as a means towards relaxation; increase muscle flexibility, understanding of basic anatomy and nutritional guidelines.

PHED.title: Yoga
PHED.description: A continuing study of intermediate and advanced yoga postures,  breathing techniques and meditation as a means toward relaxation  and stress-reduction.

PHED.title: Kundalini Yoga
PHED.description: Ancient yoga practice combining postures, meditation, breathing, mantras and focus techniques; designed to improve mind body awareness, balance, strength, flexibility, techniques and nervous system function.

PHED.title: Yoga Therapy
PHED.description: Holistic discipline combining traditional yoga techniques with a modern medicine approach to treating a variety of health conditions; includes physical, mental and breathing practice.

PHED.title: Walking for Fitness
PHED.description: Develop a strong fitness foundation through walking; fitness assessment and individualized programs; gait biomechanics and power walking; injury prevention; strategies for special populations.

PHED.title: AcroYoga
PHED.description: Groups work together to build strength, balance, coordination and communication skills, emphasizing dynamic movement of acrobatics, mindfulness of yoga, spotting and handstand training.

PHED.title: Principles of Yoga Through Community Outreach
PHED.description: Introduction and reinforcement of yoga postures, breathing techniques and meditation; sharing yoga principles and benefits with grade schools; teaching and community service opportunity.

PHED.title: Cardio Group Fitness
PHED.description: Group fitness instruction incorporating a variety of training methods such as cycling, HITT (high intensity interval training), step, circuits; nutritional guidelines.

PHED.title: Distance Running
PHED.description: Introduction to distance running while training for a 5k, 10k or half marathon; gait biomechanics and running efficiency; injury prevention; nutrition guidelines.

PHED.title: Hiking
PHED.description: Introduction to hiking; specific conditioning to develop muscle strength and endurance; equipment; various terrain, weather conditions, safety; environmental impact and trail etiquette.

PHED.title: Backpacking
PHED.description: Acquisition of backpacking knowledge and skills; conditioning plan; nutrition and equipment selection; ethics and environmental considerations; navigation, safety and wilderness first aid; trip planning.

PHED.title: Beach Volleyball
PHED.description: Fundamental instruction of skills and tactics specific to sand volleyball and related physical conditioning; rules and strategies; history and culture.

PHED.title: Volleyball
PHED.description: a: Introduction to beginning and intermediate volleyball skills, rules, game tactics, and strategies. Emphasis on the development of: passing, setting, hitting, serving, blocking, and digging.

PHED.title: Volleyball
PHED.description: b: Advanced techniques; focus on offenses and defenses used in  game situations.

PHED.title: Tennis
PHED.description: Fundamental instruction of basic strokes for beginners and  intermediate players; rules, scoring, court etiquette, strategies;  singles and doubles; practice and match play.

PHED.title: Pickleball
PHED.description: Introduction to pickleball; develop basic skills, techniques and fundamentals; rules, scoring, etiquette and strategies of play (singles/doubles play).

PHED.title: Archery
PHED.description: Fundamental instruction of archery technique for beginners and intermediates; historical origins; form; the shot cycle; mindfulness; scoring; equipment; sport specific training.

PHED.title: Table Tennis
PHED.description: Fundamental instruction of basic strokes for beginning and intermediate players; rules, scoring strategies; singles and doubles; practices and match play.

PHED.title: Table Tennis
PHED.description: Reinforcement of basic strokes for experienced players; development of advanced strokes including serves, use of spin, counter hits, footwork; drills and match play.

PHED.title: Badminton
PHED.description: Fundamental instruction of basic strokes for beginners and intermediate players; rules, scoring, strategies; footwork and court positioning; practical drills and games.

PHED.title: Futsal
PHED.description: Fundamental instruction of skills and tactics specific to Futsal; rules; strategies; elements of play that differ from soccer; conditioning, drills and games.

PHED.title: Soccer
PHED.description: Development of basic skills for beginners, intermediate and  advanced players; rules, positioning elements of play, small group  and team tactics; full field scrimmages.

PHED.title: Golf
PHED.description: Basic skills development and knowledge in stance, grip and swing mechanics; course strategy; use of woods, irons and putting; history rules and etiquette.

PHED.title: Stress Management for Healthy Living
PHED.description: Instruction on the effects of stress as it relates to work, sport  and academics; coping strategies are discussed and applied through  physical conditioning interventions.

PHED.title: Principles of Athletic Coaching
PHED.description: Introduction to coaching strategies; team management; philosophy; ethics; leadership. Methodologies in sport specific training; skill progression; conditioning; athlete motivation; budgeting; fundraising.

PHED.title: Health Coaching
PHED.description: Skills and strategies of coaching principles promoting healthy lifestyle change. Motivational communication techniques; goal setting; designing safe, effective exercise program; health coach certification exam preparation.

PHED.title: Varsity Athletics
PHED.description: Participation in the University's intercollegiate programs as      sanctioned and governed by the PAC-10 conference and/or the NCAA.   Graded CR/NC.

SOCI.title: Changing Family Forms
SOCI.description: The peculiarity of the "modern" Western family system in historical and cross-cultural perspective; focus on the "postmodern" family crisis in the United States.

SOCI.title: Introduction to Sociology
SOCI.description: Basic concepts of sociology with special reference to group life,social institutions, and social processes.

SOCI.title: Science, Technology, and Social Conflict
SOCI.description: Science and technology change society and how we understand ourselves. In turn, social struggles influence science. We will explore the interplay between these forces.

SOCI.title: Migration, Law and Society
SOCI.description: Migration policies worldwide are negotiated by different stakeholders and create different contexts of reception that differently impact the everyday lives and livelihoods of migrants.

SOCI.title: Sociology, Demography and Health
SOCI.description: Sociological and demographic concepts focusing on the causes of disease, health and wellness. Empirical analysis of population composition and its connection to health.

SOCI.title: Sociological Theory
SOCI.description: Historical and contemporary approaches to sociological theory; analysis of conceptual frameworks applied to the study of society and social interaction.

SOCI.title: Gender and Social Justice
SOCI.description: Exploration of the ways in which developments and policies, including neoliberalism, the carceral state, and economic precarity, are connected and gendered.

SOCI.title: Sociological Research Methods
SOCI.description: Logic of theory construction, research design, elementary data collection and analysis.

SOCI.title: Analyzing Social Statistics
SOCI.description: Sociological measurement, univariate description, elementary correlation, introduction to statistical inference.

SOCI.title: Applied Social Research Methods
SOCI.description: Use quantitative or qualitative analysis skills to study major social issues using large existing survey data sets or qualitative methods. Become conversant in describing data to a variety of audiences.

SOCI.title: Social Exclusion, Social Power and Deviance
SOCI.description: Examines meanings of deviance and connection with status, power, and social control. Topics include homelessness, mental health, sexuality, the body, drugs, gambling and corporate crime.

SOCI.title: Crime, Punishment and Society
SOCI.description: Explores cultural definitions, media constructions and measurement of crime. Places crime and punishment in larger social context and examines socio-cultural, economic and political factors.

SOCI.title: Social Inequality: Class, Status and Power
SOCI.description: Inequalities in wealth, prestige and power in the United States; the American class structure and the extent of upward mobility in that structure.

SOCI.title: The Family in a Changing Society
SOCI.description: Changing family patterns; personality development; family unity, predicting success in marriage; the family in transition; crises such as economic changes, death, divorce; family reorganization.

SOCI.title: Mixing and Matching: Intermarriage in 21st Century
SOCI.description: An investigation into inter-ethnic, interracial, and inter-religious marriage in the 21st century.

SOCI.title: Judaism as an American Religion
SOCI.description: The development of American expressions of Judaism as part of the American religious context, from the perspective of the social scientific study of religion.

SOCI.title: Volunteers, Non-Governmental Organizations, and Everyday Pol
SOCI.description: Theory, practice, and history of civic life. Examines communication, personal obligation, collective imagination, and political representation, in grassroots, state-sponsored, and non-governmental organization-sponsored civic associations around the world.

SOCI.title: Non-Governmental Organizations/Non-profits Field Practicum
SOCI.description: Internship in a Non-Governmental Organization (NGO). Students will conduct sociological research on issues surrounding NGOs and the work they do.

SOCI.title: Sociology of Religion
SOCI.description: The role of religion in modern society from the standpoint of sociological theory and research.

SOCI.title: Medical Sociology
SOCI.description: Social and cultural factors in causation of disease, health care utilization and health care delivery.

SOCI.title: Directed Research
SOCI.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

SOCI.title: Sociological Theory II
SOCI.description: Developments in sociological theory from World War II to the present. Duplicates credit in former SOCI 610.

SOCI.title: Qualitative Research Methods
SOCI.description: Seminar in epistemologies, ethics, and techniques of qualitative  research.  Critical reading and practice in social observation,  interviewing, fieldwork, and research design.  Preparation of IRB  proposal.

SOCI.title: Feminist Theory
SOCI.description: History of feminist theory and major perspectives of current feminist theory: liberal feminism, socialist/Marxist feminism, radical feminism, psychological feminism, spiritual feminism, and ecological feminism.

SOCI.title: Directed Research
SOCI.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

SOCI.title: Master's Thesis
SOCI.description: Credit on acceptance of thesis.

SOCI.title: Master's Thesis
SOCI.description: Credit on acceptance of thesis.

SOCI.title: Quantitative Methods and Statistics II
SOCI.description: Casual modeling and the inter-relationships among social phenomena: covers the basic elements of casual inference and generalizability, linear regressions analysis, and categorical data analysis.

SOCI.title: Sex and Gender in Society
SOCI.description: The social organization of gender in the contexts of work, families, intimacy, sexuality, reproduction, violence. Variations by race, ethnicity, social class. Processes of social change. Duplicates credit in former SOCI 552.

SOCI.title: Social Demography
SOCI.description: Theoretical perspectives of population, historical and contemporary accounts of population trends and statistics, and the latest research on the causes and consequences of demographic processes.

SOCI.title: Critical Theories of Race and Culture
SOCI.description: Examines the historical emergence of ideas about race, modernity and colonialism and the role of culture in shaping how we understand race today.

SOCI.title: Seminar in Immigration
SOCI.description: Survey of key theoretical approaches and relevant issues in immigration studies. Themes include: transationalism, globalization, gendered migration, segmented assimilation, immigrant labor markets, social incorporation and citizenship. Open to Ph.D. in Sociology students only. Duplicates credit in former SOCI 575.

SOCI.title: Writing for Publication in Sociology
SOCI.description: Prepares graduate students to publish in peer reviewed journals. Prerequisite: SOCI 620 or SOCI 622. Graded CR/NC.

SOCI.title: Research
SOCI.description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be     applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded   CR/NC.

SOCI.title: Doctoral Dissertation
SOCI.description: Credit on acceptance of dissertation.

SOCI.title: Doctoral Dissertation
SOCI.description: Credit on acceptance of dissertation.

SOCI.title: Doctoral Dissertation
SOCI.description: Credit on acceptance of dissertation.

SOCI.title: Doctoral Dissertation
SOCI.description: Credit on acceptance of dissertation.

RNR.title: International Academy Holding Course
RNR.description: Course created per request from the International Academy to  create a zero unit, zero charge course for the purpose of enabling  services for the student  population.  Tuition is paid directly to  the Academy.

RNR.title: International Academy Holding Course (Part II)
RNR.description: Course created per request from the International Academy to  create a zero unit, zero charge course for the purpose of enabling  services for the student population. This course serves the  popuation that has successfully completed RNR-050.  Tuition is  paid directly to the Academy.

SPAN.title: Spanish I
SPAN.description: For students with limited proficiency in Spanish. Practice in     listening comprehension, oral communication, elementary reading    and writing.

SPAN.title: Spanish II
SPAN.description: Continuation of Spanish 110 or 120; increased emphasis on listening comprehension, oral expression, reading and writing.

SPAN.title: Spanish III
SPAN.description: Continuation of SPAN 150; intensive work in listening comprehension, oral communication, reading, and writing with emphasis on free expression; readings related to Hispanic culture and civilization. Prereq: SPAN 150 or equivalent.

SPAN.title: Spanish IV
SPAN.description: Intensive review of Spanish grammar with emphasis on four skills. Audio-visual materials and readings related to Hispanic culture and civilization.

SPAN.title: Advanced Spanish: Arts and Sciences
SPAN.description: Development of students' oral and writing skills using literary and scientific materials; grammar review. Duplicates credit in the former SPAN 266.

SPAN.title: Spanish for Heritage Speakers
SPAN.description: Culture-based course designed for Spanish speakers not formally trained in the language. Review language and grammar and hone presentational skills.

SPAN.title: Conversational Spanish
SPAN.description: Discussions of short films, cultural and literary texts and other activities designed to improve conversational skills. Prerequisite: SPAN 220. Not for credit for Spanish majors.

SPAN.title: Introduction to Latin American and Iberian       Studies
SPAN.description: Introduction to the cultural history of Spain, Portugal and Latin America with a focus on literature and visual works from the early-modern period to the twenty-first century.

SPAN.title: Introduction to Literature and Film
SPAN.description: Introduction to critical reading and interpretation of poetry, narrative fiction, drama and film from Spain and Latin America.

SPAN.title: Screen Cultures: From Film to the Internet
SPAN.description: A survey of Spanish and Latin American cinema from the silent film era to the present, acquainting students with various critical and theoretical approaches to cinema studies. Conducted in Spanish.

SPAN.title: The Art of Fiction
SPAN.description: A survey of Spanish and Latin American fiction from the Middle Ages to the present, acquainting students with various critical and theoretical approaches to narrative. Conducted in Spanish.

SPAN.title: Business and the Law.
SPAN.description: The language and culture of a particular area of study or profession, such as medicine and healthcare, political and social sciences, business and the law. Limited to 4 units for major or minor credit.

SPAN.title: The Transatlantic Golden Age: New Worlds Real and Imagined
SPAN.description: Selected readings from 1500 to 1700 exploring Renaissance and baroque visions of the classical and new worlds.

SPAN.title: Literature of Mexico
SPAN.description: Principal writers and their works from Colonial times to the present. Non-majors may write assignments in English. Recommended preparation: advanced comprehension of oral and written Spanish.

SPAN.title: Narco-World
SPAN.description: Study of the contemporary situation in Mexico through the lens of global terror, neoliberal economy, and postmodern aesthetics (film, literature, television, music).

SPAN.title: Flamenco In Spanish Culture
SPAN.description: A historical and theoretical study of flamenco's aesthetic, social, political and philosophical implications in Spanish culture. Relate flamenco to other artistic and cultural practices and questions of national, ethnic, racial, class, gender or sexual identity.

SPAN.title: Oaxaca and Oaxacalifornia: Food, Culture, Art and Migration
SPAN.description: Explore Oaxaca's mountains, beaches, villages and capital city; first hand experience in culture, traditional food, street artists and agricultural systems.

SPAN.title: Latinx Food and Social Justice
SPAN.description: Examines food justice in Latinx communities, Mexico and Latin America; examines some of the inequalities people experience in their relationship to food.

SPAN.title: Literature and Popular Culture
SPAN.description: An examination of popular culture and literary genres with an  emphasis on the evolving canons and identities of Latin America  and Spain. Recommended preparation: SPAN 304 or SPAN 306 or SPAN  308

SPAN.title: Topics in Spanish and Latin American Literature and Culture
SPAN.description: Study of topics in Spanish and Latin American literature and culture across periods, genres and nations.

SSCI.title: Maps in the Digital World
SSCI.description: The role of formal reasoning, abstract representation and empirical analysis in building maps for sharing knowledge across the physical, life and social sciences and humanities.

SSCI.title: Sustainability Science in the City
SSCI.description: The influence of sustainability science on public policy and vice versa in the context of social/ethical theories, analytical methods and solutions.

SSCI.title: Principles of Geodesign
SSCI.description: Foundations of geodesign combining place-making, design, collective action, and the science of location-based information to improve human interaction with the functioning of the Earth.

SSCI.title: Human Populations and Natural Hazards
SSCI.description: Introduction to the complex relationship between human development and natural hazards, which are increasingly causing damage and displacement to human populations throughout the world.

SSCI.title: The Water Planet
SSCI.description: An exploration of earth's water, ranging from water properties, chemistry, and pollution, to groundwater dynamics, watershed processes, and oceanic-atmospheric circulation. Implications for past and future societies. Lecture and laboratory.

SSCI.title: Maps and Spatial Reasoning
SSCI.description: Role of maps and spatial reasoning in the production and use of geographic information for representing and analyzing human and environmental activities and events.

SSCI.title: Comparative Sustainability Theory and Practice for Geodesign
SSCI.description: Use of sustainability theory and practice to compare various geodesign practices; application to specific locations around the world to promote a sustainable global environment.

SSCI.title: International Geodesign
SSCI.description: Intensive living-learning research and field experience in Los Angeles and abroad; application of geodesign strategies to local societal challenges.

SSCI.title: Geographic Information Science: Spatial Analytics
SSCI.description: The various ways in which geography can be used to acquire, represent, organize, analyze, model and visualize information. Laboratories are organized around ArcGIS software suite.

SSCI.title: Geographic Information Science: Geospatial Modeling and Cust
SSCI.description: Fundamentals of spatial modeling and remote sensing and how to use GIS customization and programming to streamline complex spatial analysis and modeling workflows.

SSCI.title: Spatial Sciences Internship
SSCI.description: Intensive experience in local public agency, private firm, or nonprofit agency engaged in applied geospatial analysis, modeling and mapping work.

SSCI.title: Geodesign Practicum
SSCI.description: Application of design concepts, planning protocols and spatial analysis skills to a complex planning or design problem sponsored by a local public, private or not-for-profit client in a studio setting.

SSCI.title: Human Security and Geospatial Intelligence Practicum
SSCI.description: Create conceptual solutions for a real-world human security and geospatial intelligence issue by developing a problem set and recommended solution to the same.

SSCI.title: Directed Research
SSCI.description: Individual research and readings. Open only to juniors and seniors. Not available for graduate credit.

SSCI.title: Spatial Econometrics
SSCI.description: Introduction to the theoretical foundations, methods, and software systems for spatial econometrics using a variety of use cases.

SSCI.title: Spatial Data Science
SSCI.description: Introduce the spatial data scientific approach to issues and present a holistic generalizable analysis pipeline.

SSCI.title: Human Security and Disaster Management
SSCI.description: The relationship between human security (population growth, urbanization, conflict) and disasters, both man-made and natural, where complex emergencies are impactful to human populations.

SSCI.title: Concepts for Spatial Thinking
SSCI.description: The unique characteristics and importance of spatial information as they relate to the evolving science, technology, and applications of Geographic Information Systems.

SSCI.title: Spatial Databases
SSCI.description: Design, implementation, and interrogation of relational, object-oriented and other types of geospatial databases. Recommended preparation: SSCI 581.

SSCI.title: Spatial Analysis and Modeling
SSCI.description: Provides the knowledge and skills necessary to investigate the spatial patterns which result from social and physical processes operating at or near the Earth's surface.

SSCI.title: Geospatial Technology Project Management
SSCI.description: Concepts, principles, and use of project management tools and the people issues encountered running GIS projects. Recommended preparation: SSCI 581.

SSCI.title: GIS Programming and Customization
SSCI.description: Design, coding, and implementation of GIS-based software and models using the Python programming language. Recommended preparation: SSCI 582. Duplicates credit in former GEOG 586.

SSCI.title: Spatial Data Acquisition
SSCI.description: Role of global positioning systems, maps, geocoding, and other kinds of sensors as geospatial data sources. Includes field data acquisition excursion on Catalina Island. Recommended preparation: SSCI-581. Duplicates credit in former GEOG 587.

SSCI.title: Remote Sensing for GIS
SSCI.description: Principles of remote sensing, satellite systems, and role of remote sensing data in GIS applications. Recommended preparation: SSCI 581.

SSCI.title: Cartography and Visualization
SSCI.description: Principles of visual perception, spatial cognition and cartographic design and their contributions to the maps, animations, virtual reality and multimedia displays produced with modern GIS. Recommended preparation: SSCI 581.

SSCI.title: Directed Research
SSCI.description: Research leading to the master's degree in cognate fields. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

SSCI.title: Master's Thesis
SSCI.description: Credit on acceptance of thesis. Graded CR/NC.

SSCI.title: Master's Thesis
SSCI.description: Credit on acceptance of thesis. Graded CR/NC.

SSCI.title: Master's Thesis
SSCI.description: Credit on acceptance of thesis. Graded CR/NC.

SSCI.title: Applied Geospatial Intelligence Problem Solving
SSCI.description: Provides hands-on problem solving opportunity that requires knowledge and GEOINT skills to provide an informed recommendation involving a variety of human security settings.

SSCI.title: Internship in Spatial Sciences
SSCI.description: Part-time or full-time practical work experience in the student's field of study at an off-campus facility under faculty direction.

SSCI.title: Social Demography
SSCI.description: Theoretical perspectives of population, historical and contemporary accounts of population trends and statistics, and the latest research on the causes and consequences of demographic processes.

SSCI.title: Advanced Spatial Computing
SSCI.description: The role of spatial computing in understanding the world, in knowing and communicating our relationships to specific places, and for navigating through those places.

SSCI.title: Principles of Spatial Data Analysis
SSCI.description: The theoretical foundations and techniques of spatial analysis and the ways in which they have been used to identify spatial processes and patterns. Recommended preparation: Enrollment in a USC PhD Program.

SSCI.title: Spatial Modeling with GIS
SSCI.description: An introduction to spatial models identifying the key issues influencing the success of these models in simulating key social and environmental processes and health exposures.

SSCI.title: Research
SSCI.description: Research leading to the doctoral degree. Maximum units which may  be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Open  only to doctoral students.

SSCI.title: Doctoral Dissertation
SSCI.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Open only to doctoral students in Population, Health, and Place major. Graded: IP/CR/NC.

SSCI.title: Doctoral Dissertation
SSCI.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Open only to doctoral students in Population, Health, and Place major. Graded: IP/CR/NC.

SSCI.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Open only to doctoral students in Population, Health, and Place major. Graded: IP/CR/NC.

SSCI.title: Doctoral Dissertation
SSCI.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Open only to doctoral students in Population, Health, and Place major. Graded: IP/CR/NC.

SSCI.title: Doctoral Dissertation
SSCI.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Open only to doctoral students in Population, Health, and Place major. Graded: IP/CR/NC.

SLL.title: Russia in the Modern Era
SLL.description: Key moments in the development of Russian culture since its westernization in the early eighteenth century to the present day. Focus on works of literature, art and other products of the culture that have significantly influenced Russian self-understanding as well as the ways in which Russians perceive the rest of the world.

SLL.title: Chess and Critical Thinking
SLL.description: Analysis of significant chess games, reflecting societal attitudes  towards science, competition, art, gender, psychology, politics,  and technology.  Graded CR/NC.

SLL.title: Chess - Advanced Thinking Techniques
SLL.description: Development of advanced understanding of the game of chess. Critical analysis of games and of the problem-solving techniques applicable in various game situations. Graded CR/NC.

SLL.title: The Eastern European Jewish Experience: Literature and Film
SLL.description: Analyzes works by different artists -- writers, filmmakers, painters -- in order to understand the significant contribution that the Jewish experience in Eastern Europe has made to Jewish communities worldwide.

SLL.title: Tolstoy: Writer and Moralist
SLL.description: Tolstoy's major works in the context of his ethical views.Readings and lectures in English.

SLL.title: The Novels of Vladimir Nabokov
SLL.description: Survey of Vladimir Nabokov's novels written in Europe and Americafrom the 1920s - 1960s. Primary focus on the structure of thenovels and their themes of art and emigration. Readings inEnglish.

SLL.title: Directed Research
SLL.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

SLL.title: Symbolism
SLL.description: Russian symbolist literature; cultural and philosophical background of this late 19th and early 20th century movement. Prerequisite: three years of college Russian.

SLL.title: Directed Research
SLL.description: Research leading to the Master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

SLL.title: Seminar in Russian Literature
SLL.description: Detailed study of single literary period, movement, or genre; two  or more selected authors; specific school of literary criticism.   May be repeated, with departmental permission, if content of the   seminar is different. Recommended preparation: one year of  graduate study.

SLL.title: Seminar in Russian Culture and the Arts
SLL.description: Subject varies from year to year. A trend or major figure will be  studied in its cultural and artistic contexts. May be repeated,    with departmental permission, if content of the seminar is         different. Recommended preparation: one year of graduate study.

SLL.title: Research
SLL.description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

SLL.description: Credit on acceptance of dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC

SMGT.title: Introduction to Sustainability
SMGT.description: History and evolution of sustainability, including definitions, models and policies relevant to current global sustainability and advocacy.

SMGT.title: Sustainability Fundamentals
SMGT.description: Evolution of business sustainability; environmental, social and governance (ESG) performance; and the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs).

SMGT.title: Business Strategy for a Sustainable World
SMGT.description: Business strategies, practices, and performance metrics that champion sustainability as part of organizational purpose.

SMGT.title: Leading Organizational Transformation for Sustainability
SMGT.description: Organizational transformation through integration of sustainability into values, culture, leadership, talent, workflow and strategy.

SMGT.title: Sustainable Supply and Global Value Chains
SMGT.description: Sustainable management of supply chains and global value chains to increase benefits to business, the environment and society.

SMGT.title: The Circular Economy and Sustainable Design
SMGT.description: Interrelationship of circular economy and sustainable design strategies to reduce waste and negative social and environmental impacts.

SMGT.title: Sustainability Strategies for Human Rights
SMGT.description: Strategies for businesses to address a range of human rights concerns and monitor their effects on individuals, society and the environment.

SMGT.title: Systems Thinking and Tools for Sustainability
SMGT.description: Application of systems theory, thinking and tools to address complex sustainability-related problems.

SMGT.title: Sustainability Metrics and Reporting
SMGT.description: Strategies for organizations to identify, measure and report on prioritized sustainability issues.

SMGT.title: Sustainability Management Strategy Capstone
SMGT.description: Knowledge and skills gained throughout the Sustainability Management program are synthesized in a culminating capstone project.

CORE.title: Symbols and Conceptual Systems: Thematic Option Honors Progr
CORE.description: Study of the structures through which we shape our experience in religion, philosophy, literature, music, and the visual arts, and of competing theories of interpretation. Students may not take this course on a P/NP basis.

CORE.title: The Process of Change in Science: Thematic Option Honors Pro
CORE.description: Critical problems in the development of scientific thought, studied as vehicles for understanding the content and structure of the sciences. Specific subject matter in selected scientific disciplines will be presented. Students may not take this course on a P/NP basis.

CORE.title: Change and the Future: Thematic Option Honors Program
CORE.description: Analysis of historical change; social and political theory and revolutionary thought; introduction to competing images of future states of affairs; the continuing process of change. Students may not take this course on a P/NP basis.

CORE.title: Writing Seminar II: Thematic Option Honors Program
CORE.description: Instruction on analytic writing that integrates methods of research, identifying and addressing specific audiences and  presenting ideas publicly. Readings examine  modernity and postmodernity.

CORE.title: Liberal Arts Reading Salon
CORE.description: Critical readings of a series of texts in the liberal arts  designed to promote discussion of important themes, theoretical  approaches, research directions, and interdisciplinary  connections.  Graded CR/NC.

CORE.title: Modes of Inquiry
CORE.description: Modern tools of cultural and discursive analysis which seek to  demystify "the natural," as it appears in the formation of  cultures, their institutions, and individuals.

CORE.title: Teaching Analytical Writing through Readings in the Humanities
CORE.description: Theories and practices in university-level teaching of  close-reading and analytical writing, using texts central to  Western tradition.  Graduate student professionalization throught  topical workshops and discussions.  Open to assistant lecturers  and teaching assistants only.  Graded CR/NC.

VISS.title: Introduction to Visual Studies:  Methods and Debates
VISS.description: A critical introduction to the field of visual studies focusing on interdisciplinary approaches to images, objects, and visual technologies as well as key texts and interpretive debates.

POSC.title: Ideology and Political Conflict
POSC.description: Modern political ideologies; their assumptions, perceptions, and prescriptions regarding political stability and social injustice:anarchism, communism, socialism, liberalism, conservatism, and fascism.

POSC.title: Comparative Politics
POSC.description: Gateway to the major in political science. Comparative analysis of political institutions and processes in selected industrial, developing and socialist countries, in terms of contrasting ideologies, parties, elites, and economies.

POSC.title: Law, Politics and Public Policy
POSC.description: Interaction between law and politics; overview of the American legal system; value conflicts and public policy questions which arise within it.

POSC.title: Law and Politics
POSC.description: Examination of the rules and realities of American politics, and the role politics plays in American life and culture.

POSC.title: Human Rights
POSC.description: Overview of human rights controversies across the globe. Introduction to techniques of analysis for social issues, interdisciplinary research methods, and interpretation of complex political problems.

POSC.title: Political Analysis
POSC.description: Methodological and theoretical problems of micro-analytic studies in political science. Techniques of data collection and assimilation.

POSC.title: Great Races from the Senate to the White House
POSC.description: Provides students with the knowledge and skills necessary to become active in politics based on understanding the history, theory, and practices of public participation.

POSC.title: State Politics
POSC.description: American state politics from a comparative perspective. Examines political processes, differing policy outcomes and the impact of social change on system performance.

POSC.title: Political Parties, Campaigns, and Elections
POSC.description: Organization and function of political parties, nominations and elections, strategy and tactics of campaigning, professional candidate management finance, political machines, voting behavior.

POSC.title: Constitutional Law
POSC.description: Development of constitutional law by the courts; leading cases bearing on major constitutional issues; the federal system; powers of government; civil liberties.

POSC.title: Environmental Law
POSC.description: Introduces students to central concepts and theories in environmental law and regulation; analyzes present environmental laws and regulations.

POSC.title: Politics in the People's Republic of China
POSC.description: The Chinese revolution; social, political, and economic developments in post-1949 China; China after Mao Zedong (Mao Tse-tung).

POSC.title: Comparative Political Institutions
POSC.description: Institutions and processes of advanced industrial societies; political culture, interest articulation and aggregation, the governmental process.

POSC.title: Cities and Regions in World Politics
POSC.description: Cities and the rise of states; globalization and localization;  federalism and decentralization; comparative politics of urban  regions in developed and developing countries. Recommended  preparation: comparative or urban politics.

POSC.title: European Political Thought II
POSC.description: Western political thought since the French Revolution. Rise of Marxist socialism, communism, anarchism, fascism, National Socialism, other doctrines; the democratic tradition; new theories of the state.

POSC.title: Directed Governmental and Political Leadership Internship
POSC.description: Intensive experience in governmental and political offices. Minimum time requirement; evaluation by office and intern report required.

POSC.title: Trial Advocacy: Theory and Practice
POSC.description: Course covering substantive law, evidence, public speaking and use  of societal mores in courtroom advocacy. Open only to Mock Trial  team members.

POSC.title: Ethnic Politics
POSC.description: Analysis of the political behavior and roles of ethnic and racial groups in the American political system; policy issues and patterns of political action are examined.

POSC.title: Latino Politics
POSC.description: Analysis of the historic and contemporary roles of Latinos in the  American political system; patterns of political participation and  representation are examined.

POSC.title: Political Economy of Mexico
POSC.description: Examination of contemporary Mexico: the role of the state in the Mexican economy; development of the government party and opposition groups.

POSC.title: Politics of Local Criminal Justice
POSC.description: Roles and behavior of major legal and political participants in the criminal justice system including the police, the legal profession, judges, and the public.

POSC.title: Conflict, Cooperation, and Policy in Government Agencies
POSC.description: Intensive examination of critical issues of particular interest in the field of American politics.

POSC.title: Sexuality and Politics
POSC.description: Intensive examination of critical issues of particular interest in the field of American politics.

POSC.title: The Politics of U.S. Immigration and Border Enforcement
POSC.description: Intensive examination of critical issues of particular interest in the field of American politics.

POSC.title: Civil and Political Rights and Liberties
POSC.description: An examination of debates and controversies surrounding the nature and scope of civil rights and civil liberties.

POSC.title: Global Justice: Interdisciplinary Perspectives
POSC.description: Classical and contemporary theories of justice, from an interdisciplinary perspective.

POSC.title: Political Psychology
POSC.description: Psychological forces shaping politics and persons, processes and interactions; emphasis on political socialization and cognitive and effective orientations to politics.

POSC.title: Political Economy of Redistribution
POSC.description: Intensive examination of critical issues of particular interest in the field of comparative politics.

POSC.title: Politics of Food.
POSC.description: Intensive examination of critical issues of particular interest in the field of comparative politics.

POSC.title: Critical Issues in Political Thought: World Poverty
POSC.description: An introduction to world poverty, approached through the three main tasks of understanding the causes, exploring solutions, and defining our obligations to the global poor.

POSC.title: Directed Research
POSC.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

WRIT.title: Writing and Critical Reasoning--Thematic Approaches
WRIT.description: Academic writing, emphasizing analysis and argumentation, rhetorical judgment, critical reasoning, creative insight, the careful use of evidence, ethical perspectives, logical organization, stylistic and grammatical fluency. Duplicates credit in WRIT 130 and WRIT 140.

WRIT.title: Advanced Writing for Pre-Law Students
WRIT.description: Academic writing, emphasizing analysis and argumentation, rhetorical judgment, critical reasoning, creative insight, the careful use of evidence, ethical perspectives, logical organization, stylistic and grammatical fluency. Duplicates credit in WRIT 130 and WRIT 140.

WRIT.title: Community Engagement
WRIT.description: Academic writing, emphasizing analysis and argumentation, rhetorical judgment, critical reasoning, creative insight, the careful use of evidence, ethical perspectives, logical organization, stylistic and grammatical fluency. Duplicates credit in WRIT 130 and WRIT 140.

WRIT.title: Education and Intellectual Development
WRIT.description: Academic writing, emphasizing analysis and argumentation, rhetorical judgment, critical reasoning, creative insight, the careful use of evidence, ethical perspectives, logical organization, stylistic and grammatical fluency. Duplicates credit in WRIT 130 and WRIT 140.

WRIT.title: Globalization Current Issues & Cross-Cultural Perspectives
WRIT.description: Academic writing, emphasizing analysis and argumentation, rhetorical judgment, critical reasoning, creative insight, the careful use of evidence, ethical perspectives, logical organization, stylistic and grammatical fluency. Duplicates credit in WRIT 130 and WRIT 140.

DES.title: Design Fundamentals
DES.description: Introduction to the basic elements and processes of visual communication and design. Instruction includes studio projects, lectures and readings. Various media used.

DES.title: Art and Design Studio I
DES.description: Introduction to the fundamental elements in art making, design creation and thinking, including key principles of  process and critical analysis.

DES.title: Art and Design Studio II
DES.description: Introduction to the fundamental elements in art making, design creation and thinking, including the key principles of process and critical analysis.

DES.title: Drawing for Art and Design
DES.description: An introduction to drawing, both skill and perception oriented, as the basic tool for all the visual arts and design.

DES.title: The Design Challenge: Exploring the Design Process
DES.description: An overview of the creative design process and introduction to techniques to solve visual problems.

DES.title: Design II
DES.description: Exploration of essential elements of traditional and digital design, including color and image-text integration, editing information, typography and sequencing.

DES.title: Digital Design Fundamentals
DES.description: Exploration of digital processes for the creation of art and design. Centered around the use of the computer and its peripherals for production of 2D media.

DES.title: Foundation Studio Intensive
DES.description: Cohort building studio intensive that ensures incoming transfers have foundational concepts and skill sets for intermediate and advanced studio courses.

DES.title: Digital 3D Design
DES.description: Exploration of digital methods and computational tools for art and design. With an emphasis on three-dimensional physical and virtual output.

DES.title: 3D Design: Materials and Tools
DES.description: Introduction to the study of 3-D Design. Includes a wide investigation of materials, tools, and techniques specific to dimensional design as they apply to package, product, and environmental design.

DES.title: Design III
DES.description: Advanced exploration of typography and image-text integration, including collaborative projects, pre-press and proofing techniques, narrative concepts and information architecture.

DES.title: Advanced Digital Design
DES.description: Exploration of digital processes for art and design with a focus on interactivity, motion, and sound in the virtual realm.

DES.title: Graphic Design in Fashion
DES.description: An intensive studio and lecture course focusing on the applications of graphic design in fashion and related fields.

DES.title: Illustration for Art and Design
DES.description: Illustration techniques and professional practices across the range of fine art, comics, editorial illustration, narrative arts, visual development and others. Digital and hybrid approaches.

DES.title: Publication Design
DES.description: Application of layout, typography, design principles and image making in the design and production of books, magazines, zines and digital books.

DES.title: Design Theory
DES.description: A comprehensive study of visual communication focusing on graphic design from 1900 to the present. An introduction to design thinking, language and principles including political and cultural implications.

DES.title: Typography
DES.description: The study of visual communication through the use of letterforms from historical tradition to contemporary experimental rebellion.

DES.title: Typography
DES.description: Continuation of DES 332a.

DES.title: Advanced Design Projects
DES.description: Advanced information design within a flexible curriculum. Emphasis on team-oriented projects.

DES.title: Professional Practice in Design
DES.description: A summation of one's practice, with a focus on transitioning to a career as a professional designer.

DES.title: Independent Studies in Design
DES.description: Independent research of specific topics under the direction of a faculty member. Administrative and faculty approval required.

DES.title: Professional Internship in the Arts
DES.description: An experiential/academic opportunity in a museum, gallery, community cultural center or related facility. Lectures, seminars, written analysis and working internship.

DES.title: Special Projects in Design
DES.description: Students work on projects for outside clients, and receive instruction in professional practices, advanced design techniques, and sophisticated technology. By invitation or portfolio review only. Only open to upper division students.

DES.title: Senior Thesis
DES.description: Research and writing of a senior-level thesis or thesis project under the supervision of a faculty committee.

DES.title: Senior Thesis
DES.description: Research and writing of a senior-level thesis or thesis project under the supervision of a faculty committee.

DES.title: Designers in Residence Forum
DES.description: Seminar in the professional practice of design featuring formal presentations and mentoring opportunities by designers in residence.

DES.title: Individual Studies
DES.description: Investigation of creative problems through various design media.

DES.title: Design Theory
DES.description: A critical examination of issues, theories, movements and practices that are relevant to the contemporary professional designer.

DES.title: Design Studio Co-Lab
DES.description: A critical examination of contextual issues, theories, movements and ideas that are relevant to the contemporary design practice in collaboration with a professional client.

DES.title: Group Critique
DES.description: Investigation of issues relative to the student's work in individual studies and thesis; analysis, conceptual development and subjective observations by faculty and student peers.

DES.title: Directed Research
DES.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

DES.title: Field Internship Experience
DES.description: Supervised internship in a design firm, or with an independent designer, on projects and research specific to design practice.

DES.title: Master's Thesis
DES.description: Credit on acceptance of thesis.

DES.title: Master's Thesis
DES.description: Credit on acceptance of thesis.

DES.title: Master's thesis
DES.description: Credit upon acceptance of master's thesis.

ART.title: Art and Design Studio I
ART.description: Introduction to the fundamental elements in art making, design creation and thinking, including key principles of  process and critical analysis.

ART.title: Art and Design Studio II
ART.description: Introduction to the fundamental elements in art making, design creation and thinking, including the key principles of process and critical analysis.

ART.title: Drawing for Art and Design
ART.description: An introduction to drawing, both skill and perception oriented, as the basic tool for all the visual arts and design.

ART.title: Painting I
ART.description: Practical introduction to oil and acrylic pigments, painting tools, mediums, processes and contemporary concepts. Primary experience in: color, composition and perception through representational and abstract painting.

ART.title: Ceramics I
ART.description: Practical and theoretical exploration of the nature of surface, form, volume and mass as fundamental elements of clay sculpture and the ceramic object.

ART.title: Wheel Throwing
ART.description: An introductory course using wheel throwing techniques for ceramics to explore a variety of forms through three-dimensional exercises.

ART.title: Sculpture I
ART.description: Practical and theoretical introduction to sculpture as dimensional manipulation. Primary exploration of form, mass, gravity, surface, structure and associative recognition in three-dimensional art.

ART.title: Creating and Understanding Visuals
ART.description: Lecture-studio course on the theory and history behind contemporary art, design, and visual communication; students also create work, informed by ideas from the lecture.

ART.title: Black and White Film and Darkroom Photography
ART.description: Introduces film cameras, development, and darkroom techniques, photographic history, theory and practice within an art context.

ART.title: Introduction to Photography: Process and Concept
ART.description: Digital photography as a medium of contemporary art. Includes  concept development, DSLR cameras, lighting, digital workflow,  software, large format printing and installation.

ART.title: Foundation Studio Intensive
ART.description: Cohort building studio intensive that ensures incoming transfers have foundational concepts and skill sets for intermediate and advanced studio courses.

ART.title: Two-Dimensional Art Workshop
ART.description: Studio practice to develop drawing fundamentals for game designers, animators and narrative artists.

ART.title: Two-Dimensional Art Workshop
ART.description: Continuation of ART 207a.

ART.title: Studio Critique I
ART.description: Interdisciplinary forum where students develop research skills, learn how to best articulate their artistic production, discuss materials related to their research interests, and critique the work of their peers.

ART.title: Drawing II
ART.description: Directed examination of personal approaches to drawing with emphasis on making visual and artistic decisions and developing additional skills and sources of inspiration. Individual expression will be encouraged.

ART.title: Comics Project
ART.description: All aspects of comics will be covered, from writing and composition to inking and marketing through the production of an individual multi-page comic creation.

ART.title: Illustration for Art and Design
ART.description: Illustration techniques and professional practices across the range of fine art, comics, editorial illustration, narrative arts, visual development and others. Digital and hybrid approaches.

ART.title: Ceramics II
ART.description: Directed examination of aesthetic concepts and investigation into personal ideas as they relate to the development of a creative visual language in ceramics.

ART.title: Sculpture II
ART.description: Directed examination of three-dimensional aesthetic concepts; development of an individual creative vision.

ART.title: Intermediate Photography: Studio, Field, Independent Project
ART.description: Continued examination of the conceptual, technical, aesthetic and historical tools necessary for a well-informed deliberate art practice. Emphasis on generating self-directed ideas.

ART.title: Post-Internet Art and Aesthetics
ART.description: A technically and conceptually intensive studio exploring contemporary processes and practices of Internet art and online expression.

ART.title: Printmaking
ART.description: Introductory course in various printmaking techniques; necessary skills and inherent expressive qualities of different printmaking methods are explored.

ART.title: Studio Critique II
ART.description: A continuation of ART 280 for third-year students, providing an interdisciplinary forum for artistic practice and a deepening critique of one's work and the work of peers.

ART.title: Topics in Advanced Drawing
ART.description: Examination of personal approaches and professional careers in drawing and 2D art making, emphasis on making a body of work with creative freedom in committed studio space.

ART.title: Advanced Comics Project
ART.description: Creation of an advanced comic/chapter of a graphic novel of meaningful content, development of the student voice and to learn professional practices for careers in Comics.

ART.title: Rendering from the Live Model
ART.description: A studio examination of rotating topics in drawing/painting, either media-based or content-driven, with individual and collaborative projects; topics change each semester.

ART.title: Digital Painting Studio
ART.description: Create a portfolio of images reflecting student interests, voice and sensibilities, through digital painting/drawing and using the software and hardware of their choice.

ART.title: 2D Projects
ART.description: Independent research of specific topics under the direction of a faculty member. Administrative and faculty approval required.

ART.title: 3D Projects
ART.description: Independent research of specific topics under the direction of a faculty member. Administrative and faculty approval required.

ART.title: 4D Projects
ART.description: Independent research of specific topics under the direction of a faculty member. Administrative and faculty approval required.

ART.title: Professional Internship in the Arts
ART.description: An experiential/academic opportunity in a museum, gallery, community cultural center or related facility. Lectures, seminars, written analysis and working internship.

ART.title: Topics in Advanced Painting
ART.description: Examination of personal approaches and professional careers in painting and 2D art making, emphasis on making a body of  work with creative freedom in committed studio space.

ART.title: Topics in Advanced Ceramics
ART.description: Continued directed examination of aesthetic concepts and investigation into personal ideas as they relate to the development of a creative visual language in ceramics.

ART.title: Clay and Glazes
ART.description: A foundation in the formulation of clay bodies and glaze materials through lectures and studio exercises to suit specific needs with the artist in mind.

ART.title: Woodworking
ART.description: Exploration of the essential skills in woodworking through lecture, demonstration and hands-on training. Includes instruction in joinery and relevant machinery and hand tools.

ART.title: Modeling and Mold Making
ART.description: Introduction to plaster mold making using clay and wax for both ceramics and sculpture. Exploration of various casting materials.

ART.title: Metal
ART.description: Introduction to metal in fine art. Emphasis on technical proficiencies and effective solutions working in a variety of metals.

ART.title: Topics in Advanced Photography
ART.description: In-depth exploration of photographic and artistic concepts as they apply to the articulation of personal work.

ART.title: Cut and Paste: Photo Collage Analog and Digital
ART.description: Exploration of methods with working photographically through collage.

ART.title: Motion Graphics for Art and Video
ART.description: An intensive investigation of the mechanics and methodology of contemporary software for video art. Recommended to be taken concurrently with ART 260.

ART.title: Topics in Advanced Printmaking
ART.description: Directed examination of specific printmaking media in relation to personal aesthetic goals and expressive concepts.

ART.title: Super-8 and the Hand-Made Film
ART.description: An advanced studio and discussion course aims to expand a students relationship to, and understanding of, contemporary artistic dissemination, discourse, and display via a series of rotating topics.

ART.title: Studio Capstone
ART.description: A faculty-mentored course supporting advanced conceptual exploration and the development of an ambitious, self-defined series or body of work; may culminate in a group exhibition or individual project.

ART.title: Senior Thesis
ART.description: Individual research under guidance of faculty member for senior-level BFA students, leading to a substantial paper or other project.

ART.title: Visiting Artist and Scholar Seminar
ART.description: Lecture and discussion course in the professional practice of art featuring formal presentations by visiting artists and scholars. (Duplicates credit in FA 515)

ART.title: Individual Studies
ART.description: Investigation of creative problems through various media. Course may be repeated. (Duplicates credit in former FA 520)

ART.title: Making and Curating Art: Pedagogy and Praxis
ART.description: Provides students with a foundation in the history and theory of studio art and curatorial education and develops their teaching skills in these areas.

ART.title: Group Critique
ART.description: Presentation and critique which builds students' skills in presenting and contextualizing their artwork for peer review; analytic discussion regarding directions in contemporary art.

ART.title: Directed Research
ART.description: Research leading to graduate degree. Maximum units which may be applied to degree determined by department. Graded CR/NC. (Duplicates credit in former FA 590)

ART.title: Master's Thesis
ART.description: Credit on acceptance of Thesis. Open only to master students. Graded CR/NC. (Duplicates credit in former FA 594a)

ART.description: Credit on acceptance of Thesis. Open only to master students. Graded CR/NC. (Duplicates credit in former FA 594z)

FDN.description: Exploration of textiles and materials in the creation of garments and other forms of wearable designs.

CRIT.title: Histories of Art, Design and Visual Culture
CRIT.description: A loosely chronological, thematic survey of art, visual culture, design, and critical theory from the early modern period through modernism (1500  1950).

CRIT.title: Critical Theory in Art, Design and Visual Culture
CRIT.description: An issues-based introduction to critical theory in the twentieth and twenty-first centuries, especially as it relates to philosophy, art, design, and visual culture.

CRIT.title: Global Art, Design and Visual Culture since 1960
CRIT.description: A critical history of art, design, visual culture, and visual theory since 1960, addressing through a postcolonial/decolonial lens the concepts and practices of "global" art.

CRIT.title: Performing and Visualizing the City
CRIT.description: Explores the relationships among art, design, visual culture, urban spaces and institutions, through urban, social and visual theory.

CRIT.title: Visiting Artist and Scholar Seminar
CRIT.description: Lecture and discussion course in the professional practice of art featuring formal presentations by visiting artists and scholars. (Duplicates credit in FA 515)

CRIT.title: Making and Curating Art: Pedagogy and Praxis
CRIT.description: Provides students with a foundation in the history and theory of studio art and curatorial education and develops their teaching skills in these areas.

CRIT.title: Methods of Curating: Introduction to Curatorial Practicum
CRIT.description: First in a sequence of three courses on history/theory of curatorial methods, with practical experience necessary to mounting exhibitions and devising interfaces with the public. (Duplicates credit in former PAS 555a)

CRIT.title: Curatorial Practicum: Group Project Summation
CRIT.description: Third in a sequence of three courses on history/theory of curatorial methods, with practical experience necessary to mounting exhibitions and devising interfaces with the public. Prerequisite: CRIT 556. (Duplicates credit in former PAS 555c)

CRIT.title: Performance Theory and Praxis
CRIT.description: Social Practice as a transitional platform for intersectional themes between visual art, media culture, political advocacy, policy making and public space.

CRIT.title: Directed Research
CRIT.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC. (Duplicates credit in former PAS 590)

CRIT.title: Field Internship Experience
CRIT.description: Supervised internship in an art institution or an art agency, or with an independent curator or artist, on projects and research specific to public space. Recommended preparation: Completion of first year of courses. Graded CR/NC. (Duplicates credit in former PAS 591)

CRIT.title: Master's Thesis
CRIT.description: Credit on acceptance of thesis. Graded IP/CR/NC. (Duplicates credit in former PAS 594a)

CRIT.title: Master's Thesis
CRIT.description: Credit on acceptance of thesis. Recommended preparation: 28 units of coursework. Graded IP/CR/NC. (Duplicates credit in former PAS 594b)

CRIT.title: Master's Thesis
CRIT.description: Credit on acceptance of thesis. Recommended preparation: 28 units of coursework. Graded IP/CR/NC. (Duplicates credit in former PAS 594z)

IDSN.title: Inclusive Design and Design Allyship
IDSN.description: Design processes for products, services, systems and policies that lead to effective solutions for diverse audiences.

IDSN.title: Physical Product Design
IDSN.description: Initial design and development of consumer products; from ideation through visualization, market research, and prototyping to ready-to-market solutions; 3D modeling and 3D printing.

IDSN.title: Designing Networked Objects: From IoT to Smart Environments
IDSN.description: Introduces concepts of interaction design through the medium of physical computing. Students learn the technological basics to create innovative, interactive experiences in physical objects.

IDSN.title: Extended Reality for Fashion
IDSN.description: The intersection of fashion and extended reality in digital fashion design, retail and showcasing experiences and production of sharable and co-creative art.

IDSN.title: Extended Reality Development
IDSN.description: Overview of modern XR programming practices; 3D UX, physics forces, animations, behaviors, visual effects and spatial audio; advancements in XR hardware and software APIs.

IDSN.title: Augmented Intelligence
IDSN.description: Human intelligence; machine learning; augmentation of human intelligence through machine learning; and the development of augmented intelligence systems.

IDSN.title: Embedded Computing for Human Performance
IDSN.description: A project-based exploration of biometric sensing technologies which are embedded in wearable devices and intended for measuring various real-time factors of human performance.

IDSN.title: Capstone
IDSN.description: Faculty-mentored, applied project with individual and team components. Implement a prototype solution to a problem. Deploy relevant tools, methods and processes learned throughout the program.

IDSN.title: Industry Practicum in Fashion Innovation
IDSN.description: Develop the capacity to found, run and scale a fashion business. Work with industry partners to engage problems and needs in their market segment.

IDSN.title: Analytics and Marketing for Challenge-Based Innovation
IDSN.description: Selected topics in design, business and technology.

IDSN.title: Modern Brand and Community Playbook
