ACAD.title: Innovators Forum
ACAD.description: Leaders in diverse disciplines, industries and the arts present and discuss problems facing society and critique real-world projects that challenge the concept of innovation.

ACAD.title: Rapid Visualization
ACAD.description: Techniques, methods, concepts, tools, and materials that are used to quickly visualize and communicate ideas and develop problem-solving skills.

ACAD.title: Digital Toolbox: Design
ACAD.description: Basics of industry-standard creative, analytical and presentation software. Applications include design, illustration, presentation and publishing.

ACAD.title: Digital Toolbox: Motion Graphics
ACAD.description: Basics of industry standard software for motion graphics, visual effects, animation design, generative art and interactive visual experiences.

ACAD.title: Disruptive Innovation
ACAD.description: Critical approaches to social and cultural changes stemming from disruptive innovations in the arts, science, technology, communications, new media, politics and business. Open only to Arts, Technology and the Business of Innovation students.

ACAD.title: Digital Toolbox: Computational Visual Design
ACAD.description: The use of algorithms in custom-designed computer software for visual output; applications in the areas of graphic design, interaction design, motion graphics and simulation.

ACAD.title: Modeling Products with Solidworks
ACAD.description: Tools and techniques for Solidworks CAD design and design improvements, specially focused on the ideation and development of new products.

ACAD.title: Statics
ACAD.description: Analysis of forces acting on particles and rigid bodies in static equilibrium; equivalent systems of forces; friction; centroids and moments of inertia; introduction to energy methods.

ACAD.title: Mechanics of Materials and Structures
ACAD.description: Stress, strain and deflection of mechanical elements due to tension, shear, bending, or torsion; combined loads; plates, shells, statically indeterminate structures; strength-based design, trusses.

ACAD.title: Communication and Culture
ACAD.description: Examines cultural institutions, ideologies, artifacts, and productions; role of culture in everyday life; cultural studies as methodology; culture and power.

ACAD.title: Narrative Technology and the Human Experience
ACAD.description: Exploring craft and innovation in communicating concepts, products  and experiences. Students employ video narration, interaction and  augmented reality in service of engaging an audience.

ACAD.title: Introduction to Data Innovation and Analytics
ACAD.description: Introduction to data innovation and analytics, converting data to knowledge and insights, statistical techniques, analytics models, implementing data analytics through real-world examples and situations.

ACAD.title: Introduction to Machine Intelligence
ACAD.description: Introduction to artificial intelligence and machine learning through programming models, training models with several methodologies, support vector machines, decision trees, ensemble learning and random forests.

ACAD.title: Fundamentals of Product Design
ACAD.description: Introductory course in learning how to design physical products, including the processes for determining consumer need, market opportunity and competitive product analysis.

ACAD.title: Introduction to Healthcare Innovation
ACAD.description: Introductions to various health innovations, including pathways, technology, techniques and outcomes. A framework for innovation in healthcare and overview of tools for health innovators.

ACAD.title: Designing Interactive Data Systems
ACAD.description: The design of interactive interfaces for data systems and simulations; introduction to business intelligence, data engineering, web development and user experience design.

ACAD.title: Dev I
ACAD.description: Web page design and creation, web objects, scripting and interactivity. Includes developing skills to design and build interactive websites.

ACAD.title: Constructing Experiences
ACAD.description: Experience-based solutions for the design of digital and physical environments, and the development of entertaining, informational and inspirational interactions based on human behavior.

ACAD.title: Constructing Digital Worlds
ACAD.description: The design and construction of digital twins for objects and environments with real-time rendering and collaboration; workflow optimization; 3D data aggregation.

ACAD.title: Computer-Aided Design for Bio-Mechanical Systems
ACAD.description: Concepts of computer-aided design in 2-dimensions and 3-dimensions. Creating advanced parts using extrusions, surfaces, and equation driven sketches. Forming assemblies and sub-assemblies, for motion analysis

ACAD.title: Dreams and Madness: The Art of Japan's Golden Age of Animation
ACAD.description: An in-depth look at the art, politics, and cultural impact of  several Japanese filmmakers including Isao Takahata, Hayao  Miyazaki, Satoshi Kon, Mamoru Hosoda and Makoto Shinkai.

ACAD.title: Design for User Experience
ACAD.description: Fundamental concepts, techniques, practices, workflows and tools associated with the practice of user experience and interaction design in web and mobile applications.

ACAD.title: Materials Behavior and Processing
ACAD.description: Mechanical behavior of metals, polymers, ceramics, and composites. Structure-process-property relationships. Mechanical testing, stress-strain relationships, microstructural characteristics and analysis. Material failure (fracture, fatigue, creep) and degradation.

ACAD.title: Basics of Project and Operations Management for Non-Majors
ACAD.description: Introduction to tools and methods for the design, production, and delivery of goods and services. Techniques for planning, monitoring, and controlling complex projects. Not available for degree or major credit for business and accounting majors. Duplicates credit in BUAD 311 and BUAD 313.

ACAD.title: The Practice of Design: Ideation to Innovation
ACAD.description: History and application of proven collaborative design processes and methodologies as they relate to ideation and innovation.

ACAD.title: Design Strategy: Problem Solving for Organizations
ACAD.description: A professional, collaborative and multidisciplinary consulting approach to diagnosing problems and applying design-based solutions on behalf of organizations.

ACAD.title: Managing Data in C++
ACAD.description: Data structures in C++ including vectors, linked lists, stacks, queues, trees, hash tables, graphs and parallelism.

ACAD.title: Business and Professional Communication
ACAD.description: Oral and written communication skills demanded in the workplace including informative and persuasive speeches; interviewing; team communication; and training material preparation. Recommended preparation: COMM 204

ACAD.title: Advanced Back-End Web Development
ACAD.description: Topics include Model-View-Controller (MVC) pattern, RESTful APIs, Object Relational Mapping (ORM), testing and Node.js, an asynchronous server-side alternative using JavaScript.

ACAD.title: Web Application Security
ACAD.description: Examine web applications from an offensive security standpoint. Topics include information gathering, vulnerability discovery and validation, exploitation and privilege escalation techniques.

ACAD.title: Collaborative Prototyping in Health Innovation
ACAD.description: Health innovation collaborative capstone project; ideating, prototyping and evaluating a health innovation prototype driven by an industry-based or community-based prompt/project.

ACAD.title: Designing Products For Licensing
ACAD.description: Understanding of bringing a product to market via licensing through the process of determining consumer pain points, competitive analysis, marketability, feasibility and supporting business model.

ACAD.title: Applications of Machine Learning
ACAD.description: Hands-on approach to the fundamental modeling techniques and machine learning algorithms that enable students to build robust predictive models of real-world data and test their validity.

ACAD.title: Web Application Project
ACAD.description: Skills to plan, analyze, build and launch professional Web sites with actual clients. Includes project management, documentation, technology assessment, security, UI, Q/A and various methodologies.

ACAD.title: Managing Innovation in Business: How Companies Win
ACAD.description: How firms in different industries manage strategic innovation for competitive advantage. Analysis of industry dynamics. Crafting and implementing innovation strategy.

ACAD.title: The Garage Experience
ACAD.description: Continuation of ACAD 475a. Students refine and perfect outcomes, leading to a pitch/presentation to faculty and industry experts for funding or validation, and critical networking.

ACAD.title: Technologies for Interactive Marketing
ACAD.description: Technologies, concepts and strategies in the emerging online advertising ecosystem; learn to drive traffic to a website and measure efficacy; work with a real client and budget to craft and execute an online marketing plan.

ACAD.title: Extended Reality for Fashion
ACAD.description: The intersection of fashion and extended reality in digital fashion design, retail and showcasing experiences and production of sharable and co-creative art.

ACAD.title: Extended Reality Development
ACAD.description: Overview of modern XR programming practices; 3D UX, physics forces, animations, behaviors, visual effects and spatial audio; advancements in XR hardware and software APIs.

ACAD.title: Augmented Intelligence
ACAD.description: Human intelligence; machine learning; augmentation of human intelligence through machine learning; and the development of augmented intelligence systems.

ACAD.title: Embedded Computing for Human Performance
ACAD.description: A project-based exploration of biometric sensing technologies which are embedded in wearable devices and intended for measuring various real-time factors of human performance.

ACAD.title: Industry Practicum in Fashion Innovation
ACAD.description: Develop the capacity to found, run and scale a fashion business. Work with industry partners to engage problems and needs in their market segment.

ACCT.title: External Financial Reporting Issues
ACCT.description: Understanding of decision-making, problem solving, and research skills as a supplement to financial accounting knowledge for accounting professionals.

ACCT.title: Introduction to Accounting Systems
ACCT.description: Understanding of technology and controls needed to capture data used by professionals in financial and managerial accounting, auditing and taxation.

ACCT.title: Foundations of Accounting
ACCT.description: Non-technical presentation of accounting for users of accounting information; introduction to financial and managerial accounting. Not open to students with course credits in accounting. Not available for unit or course credit toward a degree in Accounting or Business.

ACCT.title: Financial Statement Analysis
ACCT.description: Analysis of corporate financial reports from a decision-maker's perspective.

ACCT.title: Accounting Ethics
ACCT.description: Theoretical knowledge and practical application accountants need to identify ethical issues and reconcile conflicts among competing stakeholders' interests in all major areas of accounting practice.

ACCT.title: Tax Analysis with Data Analytics
ACCT.description: Capabilities to identify and analyze relevant tax issues; apply research tools to find solutions and provide alternate approaches using data analytics.   Duplicates credit in the former ACCT 374 and the former ACCT 474.

ACCT.title: Auditing with Data Analytics
ACCT.description: Auditing with data analytics from the perspective of management    and other users of financial statements including external         auditors and assurance professionals.  Duplicates credit in the    former ACCT 373 and the former ACCT 473.

ACCT.title: Advanced External Financial Reporting Issues
ACCT.description: Develop capabilities to identify and resolve advanced external financial reporting challenges, focusing primarily on operating, financing, and investing activities of business enterprises.

ACCT.title: Directed Research
ACCT.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

ACCT.title: Global Accounting Experience
ACCT.description: Cross-border transactions in the global economy examining accounting, legal, and tax environments, economic and political systems, and cultural differences. Includes international travel to selected region.

ACCT.title: Fair Value Accounting: GAAP, IFRS and Emerging Issues
ACCT.description: Case study approach to explore fair value issues in accounting; research and analysis of causes of valuation differences.

ACCT.title: Financial Accounting for Mergers and Acquisitions
ACCT.description: Practical problems in accounting for business combinations. Consolidated financial statements: fair value, acquisition and equity basis accounting. Duplicates credit in former ACCT 582.

ACCT.title: Mergers and Acquisitions: Tax Planning and Strategy
ACCT.description: Tax planning and strategy in corporate restructuring including mergers, acquisitions, and divestitures.  Tax background not required to be successful in this course.  Duplicates credit in former ACCT 582.

ACCT.title: AI and Emerging Technologies in Accounting and Auditing
ACCT.description: Investigate the future of data and analytics and emerging technologies in accounting and business to facilitate innovation and prediction.

ACCT.title: Fraud Analytics in the Audit
ACCT.description: Understanding/identifying fraud risk from an auditor's perspective; development of an analytics skillset to detect financial fraud risk.

ACCT.title: IT Audit and Data Applications
ACCT.description: Exploration of the role systems play in organizations, the technology that supports these systems and issues relating to technology risk, system/application security and system review/audit.

ACCT.title: Taxation of Partnerships
ACCT.description: Federal taxation of flow-through entities including partnerships, limited liability partnerships (LLPs), and limited liability companies (LLCs).

ACCT.title: Advanced Financial Statement Auditing Topics
ACCT.description: Advanced coverage of topics in financial statement auditing  including market effects of auditing, auditor litigation and  client acceptance, errors and fraud, analytical procedures, and  going-concern assessment.

ACCT.title: Strategy and Operations Through CFO Lens
ACCT.description: Examination of strategic objectives and operations within specific industries and companies. Chief Financial Officers present how they view the business as a whole and measure performance effectively.

ACCT.title: State and Local Tax Concepts
ACCT.description: State income taxes; property tax; other state and local taxes; the effect of state and local taxes on multistate operations.

ACCT.title: Taxation of Business Owners and High Net-Worth Individuals
ACCT.description: Application of tax law in areas of compensation planning, investment planning, tax shelters, and current developments relating to the individual taxpayer.

ACCT.title: Corporate Accounting and Reporting
ACCT.description: A study of financial reporting and disclosure issues with an emphasis on the use of corporate financial statements and their accompanying footnotes. Not open to students with credit in equivalent subjects.

ACCT.title: Accounting and Corporate Governance in Global Business
ACCT.description: How corporate governance and financial reporting systems are influenced by business environments internationally. Global perspective of governance and reporting challenges and mechanisms for their remedy. Recommended preparation: GSBA 510 or other Financial Accounting course.

ACCT.title: Tax Accounting Methods
ACCT.description: Concepts governing timing of recognition of income and deductions for income tax purposes. Covers differences between GAAP and income tax accounting for all taxpayers.

ACCT.title: Financial Statement Analysis
ACCT.description: Analysis of corporate financial reports from a decision-maker's perspective. This course is case-and-applications-oriented. Applications include credit analysis, equity valuation, and financial distress. Duplicates credit in ACCT 527.

ACCT.title: Income Tax Accounting and Auditing
ACCT.description: Examination of FAS 109 and roles of auditors, tax professionals and corporate financial personnel in preparing, analyzing and reviewing accrual of income taxes.

ACCT.title: Family Wealth Preservation
ACCT.description: Analysis of transfer of property during lifetime or at death from a tax saving perspective.

ACCT.title: Management Accounting and Control Systems Research
ACCT.description: Theories underlying management accounting research. Types of research methods used including laboratory and field experiments, survey studies and archival methods.

ACCT.title: Tax Research in Accounting
ACCT.description: Introduction to tax research in accounting and how it fits within the larger bodies of research in accounting, finance and economics.

ACCT.title: Selected Topics in Accounting Research
ACCT.description: Advanced Seminar to address issues/topics covered in accounting research. Open only to doctoral students.

CJ.title: Criminology
CJ.description: Key theories and frameworks used to explain crime and inform responses to crime.

CJ.title: Analysis of Criminal Justice Systems
CJ.description: The criminal justice systems response to crime through a theoretical and interdisciplinary lens.

CJ.title: Criminal Justice Leadership
CJ.description: Theory and practice of traditional and contemporary approaches to leadership in the context of criminal justice.

CJ.title: Applied Research Methods for Criminal Justice
CJ.description: Fundamental research methods and design commonly used to answer questions related to criminal justice.

CJ.title: Applied Statistics and Data Analysis in Criminal Justice
CJ.description: Fundamentals of statistics and statistical analyses commonly used to interpret crime data for evaluation and performance.

CJ.title: Ethical Decision-Making in Criminal Justice
CJ.description: Examination and analysis of how societal expectations for ethical behavior and regulatory oversight affect leaders and managers in criminal justice.

CJ.title: Organizational Change in Criminal Justice
CJ.description: Knowledge, skills, and tools necessary to lead organizational change within the context of criminal justice systems.

CJ.title: Youthful Offenders
CJ.description: Key concepts and evidence-based interventions and responses to promote positive growth and reduced recidivism in the youthful offender population.

CJ.title: Corrections and Community Supervision
CJ.description: Examines evidence-based corrections and community supervision practices including offender rehabilitation, bail, restorative justice and victims issues.

CJ.title: Making a Difference in Criminal Justice
CJ.description: Preparing for the critical role of leadership through policy evaluation and policy change initiatives.

HT.title: Global Hospitality and Tourism
HT.description: History, theories, trends and impacts relevant to global hospitality and tourism.

HT.title: Managing Service Quality in Hospitality and Tourism
HT.description: Strategic management of service quality in hospitality and tourism.

HT.title: Strategic Human Resources in Hospitality and Tourism
HT.description: Broad range of human resource concepts and strategies relevant to hospitality and tourism organizations.

HT.title: Applied Research Methods for Hospitality and Tourism
HT.description: Applied research methods relevant to evidence-based decision-making in hospitality and tourism.

HT.title: Hospitality and Tourism Data Analytics
HT.description: Analysis, interpretation and presentation of data to support evidence-based decision-making in hospitality and tourism.

HT.title: Tourism Development
HT.description: Strategies for planning and evaluating sustainable and responsible tourism development projects.

HT.title: Hospitality and Tourism Events
HT.description: Analysis, planning and evaluation of meetings and events in hospitality and tourism settings.

HT.title: Hospitality and Tourism Capstone
HT.description: Students synthesize knowledge and skills gained throughout the program in a culminating capstone project.

EM.title: Principles of Emergency Management
EM.description: Explores the historical development of emergency management as a distinct discipline in the United States and abroad, including theories, terminology and international coordination.

EM.title: Emergency Management Policies and Regulations
EM.description: Examines policies, regulations, politics and budgets that impact emergency management domestically and internationally in the government, non-profit and private sectors.

EM.title: Critical Decision-Making in Emergency Management
EM.description: Explores how to manage and assess information to limit risk and make ethical, critical decisions under both steady-state and crisis situations.

EM.title: Emergency Management and Disaster Planning
EM.description: Examines the necessary components of deliberate and crisis action plans that are used to prepare for, respond to, and recover from disasters.

EM.title: Operational Coordination in Emergency Management
EM.description: Focuses on the complexity of post-disaster immediate and long-term response and recovery challenges in local, state, federal and international jurisdictions.

EM.title: Critical Infrastructure in Emergency Management
EM.description: Examines the wide spectrum of security threats to critical infrastructure and how to strengthen infrastructure protection and resilience through collaborative partnerships across sectors.

EM.title: Emergency Management Communication
EM.description: Creating inclusive and credible messages of risk across the disaster life cycle through a variety of methods.

EM.title: Driving Successful Outcomes in Emergency Management
EM.description: Explores how effective emergency management leaders develop trust, avoid ethical pitfalls, strengthen partnerships and integrate equity throughout the disaster life cycle.

EM.title: Equity and Resilience in Emergency Management
EM.description: Examines equity and resilience in emergency management as they pertain to areas such as planning, mitigation, disaster logistics and supply chains.

EM.title: Emergency Management Capstone
EM.description: Demonstrate knowledge and skills developed throughout the emergency management program in an integrated way.

HRM.title: Human Resource Strategy
HRM.description: Explores the strategic role that human resources management plays in providing organizations with sustained competitive advantages by unlocking the productive potential of employees human and social capital.

HRM.title: Organizational Culture and Employee Outcomes
HRM.description: Prepares students to create, foster, and manage organizations in which people thrive and perform at their best in order to retain talent and reduce costs in a sustainable way.

HRM.title: Leadership in Human Resources
HRM.description: Focuses on developing the critical social intelligence skills needed to lead people and change through increased self-awareness, understanding of interpersonal differences, and greater influence.

HRM.title: Organization Design
HRM.description: Equips students with a deeper understanding of how to design and develop organizations to increase performance and effectiveness and includes sections on strategy, work, and management processes.

HRM.title: Talent Management
HRM.description: Examines talent management processes that impact employee experience and engagement and explores ways to improve data driven decision making processes including workforce and succession planning.

HRM.title: Total Rewards
HRM.description: Provides a comprehensive look at the employee rewards strategies that human resource practitioners promote and manage including compensation, performance management, benefits, and non-monetary rewards.

HRM.title: Learning and Development
HRM.description: Prepares students to identify, design, and implement effective learning and development interventions and strategies that drive results and enhance organizational competitiveness.

HRM.title: Employee Relations
HRM.description: Applies practical approaches to building positive employee and labor relations and solving related problems through increased employee motivation, effectiveness, and retention.

HRM.title: Human Resources Analytics
HRM.description: Examines and emphasizes strategies and techniques to enable improved organizational and human capital decisions by directing the organizational analytics for more actionable insights.

HRM.title: Management of Diverse and Global Human Resources
HRM.description: Analyzes global diversity in todays environment, fostering a broad understanding of diversity and inclusion and the impact of diversity, inclusion, and inclusive behaviors on organizations.

HRM.title: Change Management and Organization Development
HRM.description: Identifies the common challenges in organizational change management and explores the limitations and opportunities of different models of organizational change.

HRM.title: Anticipating the Future of Human Resources
HRM.description: Explores the forces and emerging trends that are reshaping work, the workforce and workplace  and how to address these transformational changes and be effective as a Human Resources leader.

LIM.title: Foundations of Library and Information Science
LIM.description: History and evolution of libraries and information organizations, including their structure, funding, role in society, and impact on the communities they serve.

LIM.title: User-Centered Collection Development
LIM.description: Collection development focused on the needs of patrons, in service of the institutional mission to serve and partner with the broader community.

LIM.title: Information Organization and Description for User Engagement
LIM.description: Theories, standards, and tools for the organization and description of information with the goal of equitable and inclusive access for users.

LIM.title: Information Sources and Services
LIM.description: Developments in reference and user services, including tools and processes for ethical information evaluation, retrieval and delivery for users in diverse library settings.

LIM.title: Leading Values-Driven Information Organizations
LIM.description: Effective application of interdisciplinary, community-centered leadership concepts in libraries and information organizations, with a focus on mission-driven, inclusive strategic planning and change management.

LIM.title: Project Management in Information Organizations
LIM.description: Practical applications for leadership and management in library and information organizations, with particular emphasis on project management concepts and methods.

LIM.title: Archives and Digital Curation
LIM.description: History and evolution of archival practice, and the strategies and tools needed for contemporary and future-facing archival management, preservation and digital curation.

LIM.title: Justice, Equity and Ethics in Information Organizations
LIM.description: History, theory and potential of social justice in library and information organizations, with the goal of implementing services and programs for diverse stakeholders.

LIM.title: Transformative Technologies in Library and Information Scien
LIM.description: Role of technology in libraries and information organizations, and potential use and ethical considerations of contemporary and emerging technologies to enhance library services.

LIM.title: Capstone in Library and Information Management
LIM.description: Knowledge and skills gained throughout the MMLIS program are synthesized in a culminating capstone project, and deployed in service of career advancement.

PJMT.title: Principles of Project Management
PJMT.description: Concepts including delivering project scope within cost, schedule, and resource constraints and the exploration of the traditional or waterfall project management methodology will be explored.

PJMT.title: Requirements Elicitation and Business Analysis
PJMT.description: Tasks, techniques, and perspectives on how to approach business analysis along with methods for developing requirement process tools and techniques and best practices.

PJMT.title: Schedule Management
PJMT.description: Structured approach to project schedule management, demonstrating how to be proactive and in control of projects by implementing effective schedule management.

PJMT.title: Cost Estimation and Forecasting
PJMT.description: Approaches to project cost estimation and the tools and methodologies best suited for estimates and forecasts that need to be prepared.

PJMT.title: Risk Management
PJMT.description: Coursework will enable students to prepare a comprehensive risk management plan and discover different approaches to identify, assess, and quantify risks and their impacts.

PJMT.title: Agile Project Management Methodologies
PJMT.description: Agile project management concepts and a set of frameworks that covers the people, products, and techniques required to successfully implement projects.

PJMT.title: Quality and Process Improvement
PJMT.description: Quality and performance improvement projects and methodologies used to implement them with a focus on Six Sigma, Lean, and Total Quality Management.

PJMT.title: Specialized Project Management
PJMT.description: Explores several industries and entities and their developed project management methodologies to meet industry-specific needs through traditional approaches and partnerships in various sectors.

PJMT.title: Organizational Change Management and Business Relationships
PJMT.description: Students learn to cultivate the necessary components for stakeholder management on nearly any change within an organization through change management and business relationship management.

PJMT.title: Program Management
PJMT.description: Managing and coordinating multiple organizational projects with a focus on project alignment, organizational goals, performance maximization, risk minimization, and program success.

PJMT.title: Portfolio Management
PJMT.description: Structured approach to design, build, and manage a project portfolio, focusing on strategic implementation and operational initiatives to create sustainable value.

PJMT.title: Project Management Capstone
PJMT.description: Utilize skills gained throughout the program to demonstrate the ability to plan and implement a project from conception to conclusion.

BUCO.title: Managing Communication in Organizations
BUCO.description: Explore, adapt, and develop sophisticated communication solutions and strategies to effectively engage in interpersonal, group, and organizational environments including communication partnerships with AI.

BUCO.title: Defining and Communicating Your Professional Value
BUCO.description: Understand how to define and communicate your individual professional identity and value to employers across diverse professional fields using specialized applied tools.

BUCO.title: Independent Research in Management Communication
BUCO.description: Independent research beyond normal course offerings. Proposal, research and written report/paper required. Graded CR/NC.

BAEP.title: Fundamentals of Entrepreneurship
BAEP.description: Starting and managing one's own business: developing a viable concept, organizing the enterprise, market and financial planning, and controlling the organization. (Duplicates credit in BAEP 451)

BAEP.title: Feasibility Analysis
BAEP.description: Students develop, analyze, and validate entrepreneurial concepts (including marketing, operational, and financial considerations) using customer feedback and risk assessment to conclude worthiness to pursue.

BAEP.title: Venture Management
BAEP.description: Design and application of organization structures and systems in management of new ventures.

BAEP.title: Venture Initiation: Launching and Scaling Your Startup
BAEP.description: Learn to build a startup from concept to reality. Focus on real-world entrepreneurial action and execution. Prerequisite: BAEP 452.

BAEP.title: Founder's Dilemmas
BAEP.description: Prepares potential founders, hires, and investors for the decisions they will face both before and during their involvement with new ventures.

BAEP.title: The Entrepreneurial Mindset- Taking the Leap
BAEP.description: A deeper insight into the entrepreneurial mind, how it approaches opportunities and challenges and gives leadership to an organization.

BAEP.title: Sales Mindset for Entrepreneurs
BAEP.description: The sales planning decisions that entrepreneurs make, including how to accelerate startup revenue, what metrics drive success and how to build great sales teams.

BAEP.title: The Entrepreneur's Guide to Intellectual Property
BAEP.description: The fundamentals of intellectual property -- its value, its basic workings, and its role in entrepreneurship, business in general, science, the arts, and the professions.

BAEP.title: Entertainment Entrepreneurship
BAEP.description: Explore the current entrepreneurial trends and opportunities in the entertainment industry and uncover the key success factors for entrepreneurs in this industry.

BAEP.title: Entrepreneurial Family Business
BAEP.description: Explores the dynamics of family and privately held businesses. Exploring generational and extended family issues, opportunities and obstacles faced in today's environment.

BAEP.title: Practicum in Business Issues (Internship)
BAEP.description: Combined classroom discussion and field application of business  theories and practices; part-time internship employment.  Project  to be jointly defined by student, employer and professor.  Graded  CR/NC.

BAEP.title: The Digital Startup Launchpad
BAEP.description: Real-life challenge of imagining, prototyping, testing and iterating, building, pricing, marketing, distributing and selling a digital product or service.

BAEP.title: Field Project in Entrepreneurship
BAEP.description: Individual or team projects solving real problems for an enterprise. Situation analyses; research proposal composition; field research techniques; statistical analysis; oral and written presentations. Open only to Juniors and Seniors. Graded Credit/No Credit.

BAEP.title: Global Entrepreneurship in India
BAEP.description: Current developments in the field of entrepreneurship: topics to  be selected each semester.

BAEP.title: Venture Initiation
BAEP.description: Learn to launch and scale a new business through entrepreneurial action and execution. Prerequisite: BAEP 552 or BAEP 556 or BAEP 566.

BAEP.title: Founder's Dilemmas: Anticipate and Avoid Startup Pitfalls
BAEP.description: Delves into founders' early decisions about when and whether to found, co-founders, hires, and investors that tend to get them into trouble down the road.

BAEP.title: Technology Commercialization
BAEP.description: Identification, evaluation and commercialization of new technologies. Emphasis will be placed on the legal, financial and marketing aspects of technology transfer and development.

BAEP.title: Investing in New Ventures
BAEP.description: Focus on the entrepreneurial skill set applied to new venture opportunities. Taught from the business plan reader's point of view; focus on selecting opportunities, structuring the relationship, adding value and realizing the value of that investment.

BAEP.title: Entrepreneurship Through Acquisition
BAEP.description: Issues faced by the entrepreneur who wishes to acquire an enterprise; appropriateness of an enterprise, understanding funding sources and valuation methods, developing a plan for due diligence, negotiating and consummating the transaction. The acquisition process, approaches to valuation, and the roles of the various parties in negotiating and consummating an acquisition of an existing business.

BAEP.title: Corporate Entrepreneurship
BAEP.description: How established organizations build successful new businesses through corporate venturing and intrapreneurship. Learn to apply an entrepreneurial mindset and entrepreneurial frameworks within an established organization.

BAEP.title: Venture Lab
BAEP.description: Interact with startups and venture capitalists to develop skills and processes to source deals, perform diligence, evaluate investments, draft investment memoranda and manage portfolio companies.

BAEP.title: Social Entrepreneurship:  Design, Develop, and Deliver
BAEP.description: Develop the analytical, conceptual, and practical skills required to design, develop, and deliver a new social business concept and opportunity.

BAEP.title: The Entrepreneurial CEO: The Real World of Leading Startups
BAEP.description: Practical tools for entrepreneurial leaders to manage themselves,  hire and manage people in their growing start-ups (and beyond),  and make decisions in fast-changing environments.

BAEP.title: Seminar: The Entrepreneurial Mindset
BAEP.description: Explore the art and science of entrepreneurship under the guidance of a master entrepreneur.

BAEP.title: Directed Research
BAEP.description: Research leading to the master's degree.  Maximum units which may   be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.   Graded CR/NC.

BAEP.title: Independent Research in Business Entrepreneurship
BAEP.description: Independent research beyond normal course offerings. Proposal, research and written report/paper required.

BAEP.title: Internship in Business Entrepreneurship
BAEP.description: Supervised on-the-job business experience in the student's area of interest. (Curricular Practical Training.) Recommended             preparation: completion of required MBA, MAcc, MBT, MKT, MSEI, or  MSSE coursework.

BAEP.title: Consulting Project in Business Entrepreneurship
BAEP.description: Individual or team project solving real business problems for an existing business entity, domestic and/or international. Proposal, field research, analyses and oral and written presentations. Open only to Master and Doctoral Students

BAEP.title: Family Business, Honoring the Past and Looking to the Future
BAEP.description: Current developments in the field of entrepreneurship: topics to be selected each semester. May be repeated only if topic is different.

MKT.title: Innovation Economics and Business: Beer, AI and Video Games
MKT.description: Analyze varied industries using legal, business, and economic  principles. Emphasis is on how these forces shape marketing  strategies.

MKT.title: Marketing Research for Consumer Insights
MKT.description: Develop hands-on marketing research skills to actively collect data that informs marketing decisions. Emphasis on the effective application of different methods and data to improve decisions.  Duplicates credit in the former MKT 470.

MKT.title: Introduction to Marketing Analytics
MKT.description: Analyze marketing data and develop actionable insights to guide marketing decisions. Apply statistical tools, machine learning, and economic analysis to digital marketing problems.

MKT.title: Marketing Communication and Promotion Strategy
MKT.description: Develop skills for effective marketing communication and promotion. Consider objectives and components of a strategic plan (including marketplace analysis, research, campaign development, and media planning).

MKT.title: Professional Selling
MKT.description: Principles of business-to-business selling and its function in marketing strategy and the marketing mix. Explore professional selling as a career option.

MKT.title: Digital Marketing Fundamentals
MKT.description: Examine the changing world of the connected consumer. Gain introductory knowledge about consumers online and digital marketing tactics across industries.

MKT.title: Social Media Strategy for Business
MKT.description: Examine the use of social media for business across industries. Understand theories and frameworks for strategic content creation and posting as technology and platforms evolve.

MKT.title: New Product Development and Branding
MKT.description: Learn how marketers create new brands, products and services. Discuss and examine creative ideation, research and development, brand image management and legal issues in branding.

MKT.title: Consumer Behavior and Marketing
MKT.description: Examine diverse consumers behavior including acquisition, usage and disposition of products. Understand the psychological, social and cultural influences that drive consumers decisions.

MKT.title: User Experience (UX) and Design for Marketing
MKT.description: Theories and frameworks to enhance customer engagement and  satisfaction by integrating UX principles into design and  marketing strategies.

MKT.title: Marketing in the Entertainment Industry
MKT.description: Examine the marketing of products and brands in the entertainment industry (including movies, TV shows, music and video games).

MKT.title: Multicultural Marketing
MKT.description: Examine how marketers adapt the marketing mix to serve consumers from diverse cultures, considering differing social norms and regulations across the global marketplace.

MKT.title: Marketing in the Gaming Industry
MKT.description: Examine issues traditionally crucial to the marketing of games including launch marketing, consumer insights, brand management, data analytics, performance marketing and community engagement.

MKT.title: Fashion, Luxury and Lifestyle Marketing: A  Global Perspective
MKT.description: Fundamentals of fashion, luxury and lifestyle marketing in a  global market including visiting relevant companies in Italy  during spring recess.

MKT.title: Customer Insights and Analysis
MKT.description: Use of marketing research techniques and technologies such as databases and statistical tools to collect, analyze and act upon customer information.

MKT.title: Consumer Behavior
MKT.description: Analyze theories of consumer behavior and their relevance to the modern marketplace; examine psychological, social, and cultural factors influencing consumers across contexts.

MKT.title: New Product Development
MKT.description: Systematic approach to product development and management; processes, techniques, and concepts firms use to develop, test, and introduce products and to manage products over their lifecycle.

MKT.title: Brand Strategy and Management
MKT.description: Analyze the behavioral foundations of brands and brand development; explore various marketing tools and tactics for brand development and management.

MKT.title: Digital Marketing Strategy
MKT.description: Develop strategy for digital marketing using existing and emerging tools and technologies; analyze various tactics, including search, display, video, social media, e-commerce, and influencers.

MKT.title: Marketing Strategy
MKT.description: Design and implementation of marketing strategies applied to domestic and global business challenges that span multiple industries complimented by a consumer packaged goods marketing strategic plan project.

MKT.title: Decision Making Using Marketing Analytics
MKT.description: Applications and models of marketing-related data analyses to the development of data-driven marketing strategies and making data-driven marketing decisions.

MKT.title: Marketing Metrics for Business Decisions
MKT.description: Application, development, interpretation and implementation (in Excel and Tableau) of marketing metrics using case studies, data, and practitioner talks.

MKT.title: Directed Research
MKT.description: Research leading to the master's degree.  Maximum units which may  be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.   Graded CR/NC.

MKT.title: Field Research in Marketing
MKT.description: Individual or team projects studying the marketing practices of an industry, company, government agency, country, geographic region, etc. Proposal, data collection, analyses, and written report. Graded CR/NC.

MKT.title: Independent Research in Marketing
MKT.description: Independent research beyond normal course offerings. Proposal, research and written report/paper required. Graded CR/NC.

MKT.title: Internship in Marketing
MKT.description: Supervised on-the-job business experience in the field of marketing. (Curricular Practical Training.) Graded CR/NC.

MKT.title: Consulting Project in Marketing
MKT.description: Individual or team project solving real business problems for an existing business entity, domestic and/or international. Proposal, field research, analyses and oral and written presentations. Graded CR/NC

MKT.title: Influencer Marketing
MKT.description: Examination of current literature and emerging and timely topics in marketing, social marketing, consumerism, macromarketing, marketing of individuals, organizations, and ideas.

MKT.title: Sustainability-Focused Marketing for Impact and Profit
MKT.description: Examination of current literature and emerging and timely topics in marketing, social marketing, consumerism, macromarketing, marketing of individuals, organizations, and ideas.

MKT.title: Consumer Behavior and Decision Making
MKT.description: A foundation in judgment, decision-making, and choice aspects of consumer behavior and business. Topics include heuristics and biases, information acquisition, time perception, and intertemporal choice.

MKT.title: Research Forum
MKT.description: Seminar. Review and discuss current research in Marketing. Presentations by faculty, visiting researchers, and advanced students. Open to Marshall Ph.D. students only. Graded CR/NC.

RISK.title: Introduction to Enterprise Risk Management
RISK.description: Understand the concept of risk, risk assessment, and management frameworks. Learn to identify, analyze, manage and mitigate, and communicate this risk to stakeholders. Duplicates credit in the former ACCT 380.

RISK.title: Introduction to Risk Management and Insurance
RISK.description: Understand the underlying economics, structure, and business models of an organization (often an insurance carrier) willing to accept risk for diverse situations: property, life, healthcare. Duplicates credit in the former ACCT 385.

RISK.title: Managing Risks and Crises in Media, Hospitality and Tech
RISK.description: Examination of risks in the media, hospitality and tech industries  and the ways to prepare, manage and recover from crisis  situations.

RISK.title: Risk Management in Entertainment, Sports and the Arts
RISK.description: Knowledge and skills needed to identify, analyze, control, finance and report on the risks particular to entertainment, sports and the arts. Duplicates credit in the former ACCT 387.

RISK.title: Innovating Risk Solutions in Disruptive Environments
RISK.description: Develop the skills needed to think critically about identified and assessed risks and develop innovative solutions to control and transfer those risks. Duplicates credit in the former ACCT 388.

RISK.title: Advanced Enterprise Risk Management
RISK.description: The practical application of enterprise risk management across a broad spectrum of business settings and industry types, from start-up to multinational organizations.

RISK.title: Distressed, Unique, High-Capacity, and Emerging Risk         Transfer
RISK.description: Current developments in the field of Risk Management. Topics vary from semester to semester. May be repeated only if topic is different.

RISK.title: The Top Five Risks and What to Do About Them
RISK.description: Current developments in the field of Risk Management. Topics vary from semester to semester. May be repeated only if topic is different.

GSBA.title: Data Science for Business
GSBA.description: Principles of probability theory and classical statistics applied to business decision problems; survey analysis, estimation and prediction methods, evaluation, and control techniques. Duplicates credit in GSBA 506ab, GSBA 516, GSBA 545.

GSBA.title: Marketing Management
GSBA.description: Marketing is treated as a managerial decision-making process. Emphasis is given to understanding the concepts, tools, and techniques that comprise a comprehensive marketing strategy. Duplicates credit in GSBA 509, the former GSBA 509ab, and GSBA 546.

GSBA.title: Strategic Formulation for Competitive Advantage
GSBA.description: Analyses of environments and competition, the bases of competitive strategy, strategy models, and the achievement of sustainable competitive advantage. Duplicates Credit in GSBA 519a, GSBA 519b and GSBA 540.

GSBA.title: Corporate Finance
GSBA.description: Modern theory of corporate investment and financing decisions. (Duplicates credit in GSBA 521a and GSBA 521b.)

GSBA.title: Management and Organization of the Creative Industries
GSBA.description: How creative industries (motion pictures, television, publishing, radio, music, arts, games) operate and are organized. Critical discussion of pressing issues that these industries face.

GSBA.title: Business Management and Operations
GSBA.description: Thematic focus on the formulation and implementation of business strategies related to issues affecting businesses including managerial accounting, operations, financial, and legal.

GSBA.title: Non-Travel
GSBA.description: Impact of political, economic, social/cultural and institutional factors on business performance and industry structure in a global context. May require international travel.

GSBA.title: Singapore
GSBA.description: Impact of political, economic, social/cultural and institutional factors on business performance and industry structure in a global context. May require international travel.

GSBA.title: London
GSBA.description: Impact of political, economic, social/cultural and institutional factors on business performance and industry structure in a global context. May require international travel.

GSBA.title: Tokyo and Kyoto, Japan
GSBA.description: Impact of political, economic, social/cultural and institutional factors on business performance and industry structure in a global context. May require international travel.

GSBA.title: International Business Consulting Project
GSBA.description: IBEAR team consulting projects addressing international business problems. Projects culminate in written and oral presentations to corporate clients.

GSBA.title: Directed Research
GSBA.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may  be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.  Graded CR/NC.

GSBA.title: Capstone Project
GSBA.description: Apply concepts learned to a complex strategic team project resulting in a presentation to a sponsoring company, written report, and postmortem reflection.

GSBA.title: Field Research in Business
GSBA.description: Individual or team projects studying the business practices of an industry, company, government agency, country, geographic region, etc. Proposal, data collection, analyses, and written report. Graded CR/NC.

GSBA.title: Independent Research in Business
GSBA.description: Independent research beyond normal course offerings. Proposal, research and written report/paper required. Open only to Masters Students. Graded CR/NC.

GSBA.title: Internship in Business
GSBA.description: Supervised on-the-job business experience in the student's area of interest. (Curricular Practical Training) Graduate business students only. Graded CR/NC.

GSBA.title: Research Practicum in Business
GSBA.description: Hands-on practical experience working with a Marshall faculty member on an ongoing research project. Open only to master's and doctoral students. Graded Credit/No Credit.

GSBA.title: Consulting Project in Business
GSBA.description: Individual or team project solving real business problems for an existing business entity, domestic and/or international. Proposal, field research, analyses and oral and written presentations. Open only to master and doctoral students.

GSBA.title: Causal Inference Research Methods
GSBA.description: Contemporary approaches to causal inference in observational data for applied research in the social sciences.

GSBA.title: Selected Issues in Economic Theory II
GSBA.description: Further investigation of selected topics in methodology and research perspectives of economics. Topics vary in response to new developments and current trends in the field.

GSBA.title: Research
GSBA.description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

GSBA.title: Doctoral Dissertation
GSBA.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation.

GSBA.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation.

GSBA.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation.

GSBA.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation.

FBE.title: Financial Literacy in Today's Environment
FBE.description: Introduction to current developments in finance and business economics.

FBE.title: Innovation Economics and Business: Beer, AI and Video Games
FBE.description: Analyze varied industries using legal, business, and economic  principles. Emphasis is on how these forces shape marketing  strategies.

FBE.title: Real Estate Finance and Investment
FBE.description: Introduction to income-producing real estate from the perspective of finance, market analysis, capital markets, development and investment. Includes focus on analytical techniques and computer applications. Duplicates credit in FBE 400.

FBE.title: Introduction to Real Estate Finance and Development
FBE.description: Case analysis examining economic and financial aspects of real  estate decisions for non-business majors. Focuses on dynamics of  financing, markets and the development process. Not available for  degree credit for business majors. Duplicates credit in FBE 391.

FBE.title: Government and Business
FBE.description: Regulation and its effect on business, efficiency, and equity; theories of government in democracies; business responsibilities, strategies and stakeholders.

FBE.title: Introduction to the Legal Environment of Business
FBE.description: Legal principles of business: litigation process, constitutional  law, torts, product liability, crimes, contracts, and leases,  intellectual property, international law, agency, employment law,  and ethics.

FBE.title: Behavioral Finance
FBE.description: Theories and applications of financial decision-making, using insights from psychology and neuroscience. Impact of behavioral biases on market prices. In-class experiments will be conducted.

FBE.title: Financial Analysis and Valuation
FBE.description: Develops and uses tools of financial analysis to evaluate the performance and assess the value of individual companies in an industry context.

FBE.title: Introduction to Venture Capital and Private Equity
FBE.description: Introduction to venture capital and private equity. Topics include fundraising, valuation of new firms and venture capital securities, and exiting investments through public offerings.

FBE.title: Financial Institutions and Capital Markets
FBE.description: Money and capital markets; derivative markets; foreign exchange    markets; investment banks and nonbank finance, financial crises;   commercial banks, Federal Reserve and conduct of monetary policy.  Duplicates credit in former FBE 324.

FBE.title: Real Estate Law
FBE.description: Principles of law regarding real property transactions; buyer-seller, debtor-creditor, landlord-tenant relationships; environmental law and land use control; investments and syndication.

FBE.title: International Business Law
FBE.description: Introductory course on the legal and regulatory environment of  international business transactions.

FBE.title: Corporate Financial Strategy
FBE.description: Linkage between financial theory and policy and corporate strategy, the role of financial managers in developing corporate strategy; applications of concepts and techniques using cases.

FBE.title: Applied Finance in Fixed Income Securities
FBE.description: Emphasis on hedging tools necessary for portfolio managers. Introduction of all securities available in fixed income and provision of tools to analyze investments.

FBE.title: Entrepreneurial Finance: Financial Management    for Developing Firms
FBE.description: Internal financial management of developing firms. Cash flow analysis; capital budgeting; sources of financing; risk analysis; measurement of profits; and mergers and acquisitions.

FBE.title: Investments
FBE.description: Theories and applications of investment decision-making; the behavior of security prices, portfolio theory, asset pricing models, market efficiency, bond valuation and term structure, derivative securities.

FBE.title: Applied Financial Modeling: Principles and Concepts
FBE.description: Analyze complicated financial situations, design specialized Excel tools and models not covered by built-in Excel functions and present analyses in a coherent professional manner.

FBE.title: Practicum in Investment Management - Portfolio Management
FBE.description: Application of advanced investment management techniques in a laboratory setting. Bond portfolio management, quantitative stock screens, derivatives trading, portfolio optimization. Off-site visits and presentations. Duplicates credit in the former FBE 453b.

FBE.title: Law of Forming, Financing and Managing Businesses
FBE.description: Law and ethics of agency, partnerships, corporations, limited liability companies, governmental regulation, mergers, creditor rights, secured transactions, bankruptcy, securities regulation and antitrust.

FBE.title: Financial Derivatives
FBE.description: A rigorous introduction to the pricing and corporate use of financial derivatives -- futures, options, forwards and swaps -- on stocks, exchange rates, bonds and commodities.

FBE.title: Mergers, Acquisitions and Restructuring
FBE.description: Practical understanding of the major strategic, economic, financial, human resources, and governance issues of mergers, acquisitions, and restructuring.

FBE.title: Management of Real Estate Development: Feasibility Studies
FBE.description: By means of a significant real-world case study chosen each term, the development process is examined from the interrelated perspectives of finance, market analysis, and design and construction technology. Team-generated development proposals are presented in a consulting environment that includes industry participants.

FBE.title: Real Estate Investment Trust (REIT) Analysis
FBE.description: Gain skills related to real estate valuation, security analysis and active management.

FBE.title: Mixed Use Development Process
FBE.description: Design, financial, legal and management challenges of mixed use real estate development; field project.

FBE.title: Advanced Real Estate Analysis
FBE.description: Mixed lecture/case approach covering market analysis, asset valuation, ownership structure, negotiation, asset management, corporate real estate, portfolio management, and affordable housing, appraisal and advanced financial modeling.

FBE.title: Quantitative Investment Analysis
FBE.description: Current developments in the field of finance and business economics; topics to be selected each semester.

FBE.title: Investment Banking Fundamentals
FBE.description: The role of an investment banking associate. Students will effectively function as a junior banker through a sell-side merger and acquisition (M & A) process.

FBE.title: The FinTech Revolution: Disrupting Traditional Finance
FBE.description: Emerging business models in finance including crowdfunding, marketplace lending, new payment solutions and wealth management automation.

FBE.title: Behavioral Finance
FBE.description: Applications of behavioral finance and how psychological forces influence investor behavior, asset prices and corporate decision-making.

FBE.title: Entrepreneurial Finance: Financial Management    for Developing Firms
FBE.description: Internal financial management of developing firms. Cash            flow analysis; capital budgeting; sources of financing; risk  analysis; measurement of profits; and mergers and acquisitions.

FBE.title: Financial Analysis and Valuation
FBE.description: An applications-oriented course to develop the financial and accounting tools required to do financial planning valuation and assessment of financial performance.

FBE.title: Applied Finance in Fixed Income Securities
FBE.description: The basic principles underlying fixed income securities and how these principles apply to the practical aspects of fixed income management.

FBE.title: Applied Financial Modeling
FBE.description: Hands-on Excel skills necessary to analyze complicated financial situations and to present the analysis in a coherent and professional manner.

FBE.title: High Yield Bond Investing - Managing Credit Risk
FBE.description: Review the structure of the high yield bond market. Develop a practical approach to assess credit risk and understand how deals are  structured and priced.

FBE.title: Quantitative Investing
FBE.description: Build, test and implement the types of models in use by quantitative asset managers.

FBE.title: Applied Portfolio Management
FBE.description: Application of advanced portfolio management techniques in a  laboratory setting.  Bond portfolio management, quantitative stock  screens, derivatives trading, portfolio optimization.  Off-site  visits and presentations.

FBE.title: Investment Analysis and Portfolio Management
FBE.description: Analysis and management of common stocks and fixed income securities; development of modern portfolio theory and the efficient market hypothesis; organization of securities markets.

FBE.title: Business Law and Ethics
FBE.description: Business law of traditional and e-contracts, UCC, crimes, torts, employment, ethics, social responsibility, intellectual property, digital law, e-commerce, accountants' liability, property, estates, and government regulation.

FBE.title: Law for Structuring, Financing, and Managing Businesses
FBE.description: Legal environment of agency law, general and limited partnerships, limited liability companies, corporate formation and financing, corporate governance, securities law, acquisitions, bankruptcy, and business ethics.

FBE.title: Management of Financial Risk
FBE.description: Analysis of commodity, futures, and options contracts; theoretical and empirical approaches; spot and futures price relationships, speculation and hedging strategies; market efficiency.

FBE.title: Mergers and Acquisitions
FBE.description: Practical application of the critical components of M&A: deal flow strategies, preliminary negotiations, deal structures, due diligence, valuation, post-merger integration, and regulations.

FBE.title: Economics of Urban Land Use: Feasibility Studies
FBE.description: Economic, market and financial analysis related to feasibility of real estate development; theory and case analysis. Prerequisite: GSBA 521b or GSBA 548

FBE.title: Real Estate Finance Analysis and Modeling
FBE.description: Real estate cash flow modeling, analysis and valuation using state-of-the-art software.

FBE.title: Advanced Real Estate Investment Trust (REIT) Analysis
FBE.description: Gain skills related to real estate valuation, security analysis and active management. Open only to managers of the Marshall Real Estate Fund.

FBE.title: Directed Research
FBE.description: Research leading to the master's degree.  Maximum units which may  be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.   Graded CR/NC.

FBE.title: Real Estate Finance and Investment
FBE.description: Analysis of investment in and financing of real estate assets including projections, valuation, deal structure, contracts, portfolio and tax and entity considerations.

FBE.title: Field Research in Finance or Business Economics
FBE.description: Individual or team projects studying the business practices of an industry, company, government agency, country, geographic region, etc. Proposal, data collection, analyses, and written report. Graded CR/NC.

FBE.title: Independent Research in Finance or Business Economics
FBE.description: Independent research beyond normal course offerings. Proposal, research and written report/paper required. Graded CR/NC.

FBE.title: Internship in Finance or Business Economics
FBE.description: Supervised on-the-job business experience in the student's area of interest. (Curricular Practical Training.) Graded CR/NC.

FBE.title: Research Practicum in Finance or Business Economics
FBE.description: Hands-on practical experience working with a Marshall faculty member in the Finance and Business Economics Department on an ongoing research project. Graded CR/NC.

FBE.title: Consulting Project in Finance or Business        Economics
FBE.description: Individual or team project solving real business problems for an existing business entity, domestic and/or international. Proposal, field research, analyses and oral and written presentations.

FBE.title: Research Forum
FBE.description: Seminar. Review and discuss current research in Finance and Business Economics. Presentations by faculty, visiting researchers, and advanced students. Open only to Marshall PhD students.

MOR.title: Business, Government and Society
MOR.description: Explores business-government-society interaction. Examines how diverse interests and identities (social class, race, nationality and gender) affect the conduct and organization of business.

MOR.title: The Business of Digital Hollywood
MOR.description: An overview of how the media and entertainment (M&E) industries operate. History and changing organizational structures in film, television, music and video games.

MOR.title: Mastering Decision Making
MOR.description: Understand the nature, causes, and consequences of deviations from rational choice. Develop frameworks for controlling biases, improving your decision-making, and influencing other peoples decisions.

MOR.title: Management Consulting
MOR.description: Role of professional consultants; data gathering methods;  consulting approaches from strategy, finance, operations,  information systems, marketing, and human resources; action  planning; ethical and career issues.

MOR.title: Business and Environmental Sustainability
MOR.description: Focuses on how businesses both contribute to and can help address environmental sustainability challenges and the role of the broader political-economy in shaping that interaction.

MOR.title: Managing Innovation in Business: How Companies Win
MOR.description: How firms in different industries manage strategic innovation for competitive advantage. Analysis of industry dynamics. Crafting and implementing innovation strategy.

MOR.title: Negotiation and Persuasion
MOR.description: Theories, strategies, and ethics underlying negotiation and  persuasion in contemporary organizations and societies.   Emphasizes the knowledge and skills needed for effective  negotiation and persuasion.

MOR.title: Designing and Leading Teams
MOR.description: Theories and practices for developing and leading teams.  Skills  for creating team structures and facilitating team processes.   Knowledge for diagnosing team problems and devising solutions. Recommended preparation: BUAD 304

MOR.title: The Art of Leadership - Leading on a Global Stage
MOR.description: Study of leaders and applied theory to gain an understanding of what is involved in taking public leadership roles on a global level. Open only to students in the USC Warren Bennis Scholars Program.

MOR.title: The Business of Sports
MOR.description: Addresses the business side of the sports industry; examines  professional sports franchises, amateur athletics, and collegiate  sports and how they relate to corporate America, the media, and  the public sector. Recommended Preparation BUAD 304.

MOR.title: Global Strategy
MOR.description: Examination of corporate strategy practices in an international  context.  Effects of cultures, political systems, markets, and  economic systems on developing effective global strategies.

MOR.title: Sustainable Systems
MOR.description: Selected topics reflecting current trends and recent developments in organizational behavior, business strategy and organizational theory. (Graded CR/NC)

MOR.title: Emotional Intelligence in Modern Organizations
MOR.description: Selected topics reflecting current trends and recent developments in organizational behavior, business strategy and organizational theory.

MOR.title: Leadership through Improvisation and Role Play
MOR.description: Selected topics reflecting current trends and recent developments in organizational behavior, business strategy and organizational theory.

MOR.title: Product Management I-Essentials and Frameworks
MOR.description: Selected topics reflecting current trends and recent developments in organizational behavior, business strategy and organizational theory.

MOR.title: Product Management II-Execution and Alignment
MOR.description: Selected topics reflecting current trends and recent developments in organizational behavior, business strategy and organizational theory.

MOR.title: Strategic Leadership in Product Management
MOR.description: Equip students with strategic and managerial skills in product  management, focusing on leading cross-functional teams, leveraging  technology, and integrating generative AI for innovation.

MOR.title: Applied Product Management
MOR.description: Hands-on experience managing real products from start to finish.  Essential processes and tools to enhance skills and improve  professional prospects.

MOR.title: Leading with Mindfulness and Compassion
MOR.description: Explores mindfulness (non-judgmental awareness), compassion and    their relationship to leadership. Focus is on clarity in           productivity using evidence-based cases and direct practice.  Graded CR/NC.

MOR.title: Fundamentals of Crisis Management
MOR.description: Types of crises, their developmental stages and nature and the faulty rationalizations that adversely affect businesses. How to recognize, diagnose and prevent crises.

MOR.title: Mergers and Acquisitions: Integration and Organization
MOR.description: Organize successful mergers and acquisitions with focus on managing and synthesizing the integration process and impact on people and organizations across functions.

MOR.title: Leading Innovation and Change
MOR.description: Practical knowledge on helping organizations develop innovations and lead change to leverage them. Exploration of innovation and change in different organizations and competitive environments.

MOR.title: Designing High Performance Organizations
MOR.description: Theory and practice of organization design. How to maximize organization performance by aligning structure, rewards, staffing, processes, and culture with strategy and environment.

MOR.title: Strategy and Organization Consulting
MOR.description: How consultants assist clients to formulate strategic plans and realign organizations; approaches used by major consulting firms; information about consulting industry, fee-setting and proposals. Consultant speakers and project.

MOR.title: Strategic Innovation: Creating New Markets
MOR.description: How firms in rapidly changing global environments innovate to develop new markets, products and services, delivery systems and organizational processes and competencies.

MOR.title: Alliances and Cooperative Strategy
MOR.description: Essential issues and problems of cooperative strategy. Recognize and evaluate collaborative opportunities to develop and assess an overall cooperative strategy. Readings, cases and group project.

MOR.title: The Business of Sustainability
MOR.description: How business is changing in order to respond to environmental sustainability challenges  adapting strategy, product design, operations, marketing, and accounting. Cases and speakers.

MOR.title: Interpersonal Influence and Power
MOR.description: Legitimate and effective use of power to resolve conflicts and mobilize action through understanding the talent and self-interest of people involved in decision-making. Readings, cases.

MOR.title: Negotiation and Deal-Making
MOR.description: Strategies and dynamics of deal-making; practical skills necessary to win in a range of business transactions conducted in domestic and international settings. Cases, role-playing, films and simulations.

MOR.title: Leading Effective Teams
MOR.description: Analytical and behavioral tools that will enable students to effectively diagnose complex work group dynamics and take action to improve group performance.

MOR.title: Leadership and Executive Development
MOR.description: Contemporary approaches to leadership, including corporate practices to develop leaders; examples of successful and derailed executives. Students self-assess personal leadership and draft development plans. Readings, speakers, cases.

MOR.title: Leading and Coaching: Foundations and Practicum
MOR.description: Marshall MBA Leadership Fellows Program (MLFP). Learn, practice and teach leadership. Engage in critical thinking and problem solving. (a) Foundations. (b) Practicum. Application required.

MOR.title: Corporate Strategy and Competitive Dynamics
MOR.description: Central challenges facing executives in multi-business firms; toolkit for analyzing and executing strategic and operational aspects of corporate advantage, M&As; and competitive dynamics.

MOR.title: Directed Research
MOR.description: Research leading to the master's degree.  Maximum units which may  be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.   Graded CR/NC.

MOR.title: Field Research in Management and Organization
MOR.description: Individual or team projects studying the management practices of an industry, company, government agency, country geographic region, etc. Proposal, data collection, analyses, and written report. Graded CR/NC.

MOR.title: Independent Research in Management and Organization
MOR.description: Independent research beyond normal course offerings. Proposal, research and written report/paper required. Graded CR/NC.

MOR.title: Internship in Management and Organization
MOR.description: Supervised on-the-job business experience in the student's area of interest. (Curricular Practical Training.)

MOR.title: Research Practicum in Management and Organization
MOR.description: Hands-on practical experience working with a Marshall faculty member in the Management and Organization Department on an ongoing research project. Graded CR/NC.

MOR.title: Consulting Project in Management and Organization
MOR.description: Individual or team project solving real business problems for an   existing business entity, domestic and/or international. Proposal, field research, analyses and oral and written  presentations. Graded CR/NC.

MOR.title: Adaptive Leadership: Navigating Complexity and Change
MOR.description: Selected topics reflecting current trends and recent developments in management and policy sciences. May be repeated only if topic is different.

MOR.title: Leading with Purpose: Business, Impact and Social Change
MOR.description: Selected topics reflecting current trends and recent developments in management and policy sciences. May be repeated only if topic is different.

MOR.title: Timeless Leadership
MOR.description: Selected topics reflecting current trends and recent developments in management and policy sciences. May be repeated only if topic is different.

MOR.title: Women in Leadership: Power, Perception and Possibility
MOR.description: Selected topics reflecting current trends and recent developments in management and policy sciences. May be repeated only if topic is different.

MOR.title: Seminar in Organization Theory
MOR.description: Survey of organization theory with focus on the history and development of research on organizations. Open only to Business Administration and Public Policy and Management doctoral students.

MOR.title: Research Forum
MOR.description: Seminar. Review and discuss current research in Organizational Theory, Organizational Behavior and Strategy. Presentations by faculty, visiting researchers, and advanced students. Open to Marshall Ph.D. students only. Graded CR/NC.

MOR.title: Research
MOR.description: Research leading to the doctorate. Open only to Marshall Ph.D. students specializing in Management and Organization. Graded CR/NC.

DSO.title: Data Analysis with Spreadsheets
DSO.description: Applied understanding of how spreadsheets are used to analyze business information. Create real world software applications for use in accounting, finance, marketing and operations.

DSO.title: Business Forecasting
DSO.description: A variety of forecasting techniques used by a variety of businesses. Emphasis on learning to apply these techniques to real data.

DSO.title: Spreadsheet Modeling for Business Insights
DSO.description: Application of decision analysis, simulation and optimization techniques to managerial problems. Learn how to create and present useful spreadsheet models to analyze practical business problems. Recommended Preparation: BUAD 310g or BUAD 312g.

DSO.title: Essentials and Digital Frontiers of Big Data
DSO.description: Overview of key concepts of big data and related digital technologies and their applications to different business problems. Hands-on experience at introductory level.

DSO.title: Designing Digital Processes and User Experiences
DSO.description: Analyzing and improving business processes with digital technologies; use cases; business case design.

DSO.title: Statistical Computing and Data Viz: R, Python, Tableau
DSO.description: Develop skills in statistical computing, data visualization and  programming using R, Python and Tableau. Hands-on projects, coding  exercises and collaborative teamwork for business insights.

DSO.title: Business Analytics with Python
DSO.description: Implement strategies and approaches for defining, performing and presenting business analytics. Analyze cases through the lens of descriptive, predictive and prescriptive tools. Uses Python programming.

DSO.title: Managing a Small Business on the Internet
DSO.description: Foundational knowledge for managing a small business on the internet including strategies, tools, and resources integrated with hands-on skills for developing a small business website. Duplicates credit in former IOM-462.

DSO.title: Supply Chain Management
DSO.description: Issues in supply chain management. Supply chain performance and dynamics. Tools for planning, control and coordination. Supply chain design and strategy.

DSO.title: Operations Consulting
DSO.description: Effective consulting to drive competitive advantage through operations. Application of AI/digital tools, strategy, and data analytics to improve company operations. Team projects for real-world clients.

DSO.title: Hands-on AI for Business
DSO.description: Application of  the technical aspects of machine learning and artificial intelligence, the business side of data-driven decision making and the strategic considerations in adopting  solutions.

DSO.title: Sustainable Supply Chains
DSO.description: Sustainability concepts and frameworks, design for environment, closed-loop supply chains, sustainability in sourcing, green facilities, renewable energy, facility location and transportation decisions, strategic sustainability implementation.

DSO.title: Business Analytics
