DSO.description: Foundational knowledge for business analytics, including strategies, methods, and tools integrated with hands-on skills for defining business analytics for data-driven decision making and innovation.

DSO.title: Probability and Data Modeling
DSO.description: Principles of probability structures and models with uncertainty. Applications to business data with model-building and simulations in Excel.

DSO.title: Blended Data Business Analytics for Efficient Decisions
DSO.description: Build Analytical Models for Classification, Clustering and Association Problems. Leverage third party "Big Data" for enriching and monetizing data. Develop data mining and business analysis.

DSO.title: Applied Modern Statistical Learning Methods
DSO.description: Overview of highly computational modern statistical learning methods; applications of logistic regression, neural networks, LASSO, trees, boosting and GAM, etc., to finance and marketing data.

DSO.title: Digital Foundations for Business Innovation
DSO.description: Developing a strategic perspective on emerging digital innovations shaping consumer-oriented businesses. Topics include artificial intelligence, autonomous vehicles, augmented/virtual reality, post-screen usability and cybersecurity.

DSO.title: Business Decision Modeling and Risk Analysis
DSO.description: Application of Monte Carlo simulation to determine a range of outcomes for all possible courses of action. Application of Excel simulation.

DSO.title: Statistical Computing and Data Visualization
DSO.description: Data cleaning and reshaping; good vs. bad graphics; univariate, bivariate, trivariate, hypervariate and time series graphics; interactive graphics; web-related computing.

DSO.title: Spreadsheet Modeling for Business Insights
DSO.description: Application of decision analysis, simulation and optimization techniques to managerial problems. Learn how to create and present useful spreadsheet models to analyze practical business models.

DSO.title: Application of Lean Six Sigma
DSO.description: Application of Six Sigma practices and techniques to improve operations in organizations. Duplicates credit in ISE 507.

DSO.title: Applying Analytics to Human Capital in Business
DSO.description: Human capital measurement and metrics, predictive analytics tools and methods, reporting standards and core analytic study methods with advanced visualization and storytelling.

DSO.title: SQL Databases for Business Analysts
DSO.description: SQL; relational database systems; data storage; data manipulation; data aggregation.

DSO.title: NoSQL Databases in Big Data
DSO.description: NoSQL; semi-structured and unstructured databases; data storage; data manipulation; distributed databases.

DSO.title: Digital Strategies for Sustainability in Global Markets
DSO.description: Designing and executing business strategies for sustainability (environmental, economic, social/cultural) enabled by digital technologies. Global market contexts; team consulting project; international travel. (Duplicates credit in former GSBA 554.)

DSO.title: Business Models for Digital Platforms
DSO.description: Managing Business models in digital platform ecosystems; designing new products and services for digital platforms; establishing digital platform leadership; assessing emerging niches in digital spaces.

DSO.title: Introduction to Python for Business Analytics
DSO.description: Python programming for descriptive data analytics and technical tools for business applications. Solving business problems and formulating actionable business recommendations including their limitations.

DSO.title: Text Analytics and Natural Language Processing
DSO.description: Acquire, analyze, visualize and perform natural language processing (NLP) on text data. Apply Python, machine learning packages, statistical methodology and computer code to business decision-making.

DSO.title: Supply Chain Analytics
DSO.description: Analytics for supply chain planning. Data-driven decision making, solving real-world problems, utilizing scalable technology, current industry best practices and inventory/network optimization.

DSO.title: Data Analytics Driven Dynamic Strategy and Execution
DSO.description: Achieving and enhancing competitive advantage through applications of data analytics, continuous insight discovery, strategy formulation and execution for the next generation of corporate leaders.

DSO.title: Fundamentals of Sports Performance Analytics
DSO.description: Statistical models for pro sports industry business application. Effectively communicate findings for practical actionable results. Sports science data protocol.

DSO.title: Advanced Sports Performance Analytics
DSO.description: Implement supervised and unsupervised machine learning models to a specific sports performance analytics scenario. Help assess and predict performance.

DSO.title: Project Management
DSO.description: Applications of systems theory and concepts, matrix organizational structures, PERT/CPM project modeling, and management information systems to the management of complex and critical projects.

DSO.title: Supply Chain Management
DSO.description: Issues in supply chain management. Supply chain performance and dynamics. Tools for planning, control and coordination. Supply chain design and strategy. Recommended preparation: GSBA 504b or GSBA 534.

DSO.title: Operations Consulting
DSO.description: Development of conceptual and analytic skills for improving operations. Analysis of business strategy, formulating and implementing operations strategy, process analysis and design, and project management.

DSO.title: Global Operations Management
DSO.description: Exposure to issues crucial to the globalization of operations and their successful/unsuccessful operations management approaches in several countries and industries.

DSO.title: Global Healthcare Operations Management
DSO.description: Application of operations management tools and techniques to improve the performance of healthcare delivery systems. May include international travel.

DSO.title: Supply Chain Finance
DSO.description: Combines finance and supply chain management. Assess financial opportunities, finance fragmentation, challenges, optimizing working capital and managing risk in supply chain finance.

DSO.title: Directed Research
DSO.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC. Open only to master's students. Duplicates credit in former IOM-590.

DSO.title: Field Research in Data Sciences or Operations
DSO.description: Individual or team projects studying the practices of an industry, company, government agency, country, geographic region, etc. Proposal, data collection, analyses, and written report. Graded CR/NC. Recommended Preparation: completion of required M.B.A, M.Acc., or M.B.T. courses. Open only to graduate students. Duplicates credit in former IOM-592.

DSO.title: Independent Research in Data Sciences or Operations
DSO.description: Independent research beyond normal course offerings. Proposal, research and written report/paper required. Graded CR/NC.

DSO.title: Internship in Data Sciences or Operations
DSO.description: Supervised on-the-job business experience in the student's area of interest (Curricular Practical Training). Recommended preparation: completion of required MBA, MSGSCM, or MSBA courses.

DSO.title: Research Practicum in Data Sciences or Operations
DSO.description: Hands-on practical experience working with a Marshall faculty member in the Data Sciences and Operations Department on an ongoing research project. Graded CR/NC. Recommended Preparation: completion of all required courses in the student's program. Open only to graduate students. Duplicates credit in the former IOM-596.

DSO.title: Consulting Project in Data Sciences or Operations
DSO.description: Individual or team project solving real business problems for an existing business entity, domestic and/or international. Proposal, field research, analyses and oral and written presentations. Open only to graduate business students.

DSO.title: Fast & Flow Strategy: Mastering Real-Time Business in AI Age
DSO.description: Selected topics reflecting current trends and recent developments in data sciences, operations management, supply chain management and/or decision support systems. May be repeated only if topic is different.

DSO.title: Battles For Our Digital Ecosystems (Lessons from the Field)
DSO.description: Selected topics reflecting current trends and recent developments in data sciences, operations management, supply chain management and/or decision support systems. May be repeated only if topic is different.

DSO.title: Research Forum
DSO.description: Seminar. Review and discuss current research in Data Sciences and Operations. Presentations by faculty, visiting researchers, and advanced students. Open only to Marshall PhD students. Graded CR/NC.

DSO.title: Dynamic Optimization and Reinforcement Learning
DSO.description: Introduction to dynamic optimization: Markov decision processes, foundation of reinforcement learning, and approximate dynamic programming, with applications in revenue management, supply chain, and operations management. Open only to doctoral students.

BUAD.title: Learning About International Commerce
BUAD.description: Provides insight into the opportunities and challenges faced by business professionals operating in a global environment by focusing on international cultural norms. Graded CR/NC. Open only to Business and Accounting majors.

BUAD.title: The Marshall Difference: Human-Centric Problem Solving
BUAD.description: Develop problem-solving and thinking skills across disciplines at Marshall by analyzing business problems through the lens of each Marshall emphasis.

BUAD.title: Economic Foundations for Business
BUAD.description: Examines fundamental concepts of both microeconomics and macroeconomics as they pertain to business and financial decisions. Not available for degree credit to business majors.

BUAD.title: Introduction to Business for Non-Majors
BUAD.description: Introduction to the principles and practices of businesses, sequence of exercises developing the basic skills, and influence of the economy on business and individual decisions. Not available for credit for business or accounting majors.

BUAD.title: Transfer International Experience
BUAD.description: Experiential study of international business. Analysis of the  impacts of global and international business on an industry.  International travel required. Open only to transfer business and  accounting majors. Graded: C/NC.

BUAD.title: Choosing and Planning a Future Career in Business
BUAD.description: Explore and plan for future career choices and options in business. Learn theoretical principles, best practices and strategies, and contemporary workplace issues/trends. Graded CR/NC.

BUAD.title: Introduction to Financial Accounting
BUAD.description: Emphasis on understanding financial statements and the impact of business transactions on information presented to management and interested stakeholders.  Duplicates credit in BUAD 305.

BUAD.title: Introduction to Managerial Accounting
BUAD.description: An emphasis on how accounting information, combined with a variety of techniques and best practices, supports enhanced management decision making. Duplicates credit in BUAD 305.

BUAD.title: Technology Entrepreneurship
BUAD.description: Starting and managing a technological business: developing a viable concept, market and financial planning, product development, organizing the venture, protecting intellectual property rights.

BUAD.title: Communication Strategy in Business
BUAD.description: Theory, practices, and techniques of business communication strategy essential to external and organizational communication; group and interpersonal communication; development of skill in oral and written communication.

BUAD.title: Organizational Behavior and Leadership
BUAD.description: The role of leadership in business organizations; concepts and skills for managing oneself and others.

BUAD.title: Abridged Core Concepts of Accounting Information
BUAD.description: Uses of accounting information in decision-making; accounting issues concerning income and cash flows, economic resources and capital. Duplicates credit in BUAD 280 and BUAD 281. Open only to transfer business and accounting majors.

BUAD.title: Business Finance
BUAD.description: Financial problems of business enterprise; function of financial manager; sources of funds; instruments, institutions, and practices of finance; problems of financial management using case studies. Recommended Preparation: foundational courses in  microeconomics, financial accounting, and business statistics. Duplicates credit in the former BUAD 215x and BUAD 308.

BUAD.title: Marketing Fundamentals
BUAD.description: Develop a managerial viewpoint in planning, executing, and evaluating marketing decisions of the firm, including decisions related to products, pricing, distribution channels and promotion.

BUAD.title: Advanced Business Finance
BUAD.description: Rigorous coverage of principles and practices of financial management; valuation of cash flows; capital budgeting; risk and return; cost of capital; corporate financial policy. Recommended Preparation: foundational courses in microeconomics, financial  accounting, and business statistics. Duplicates credit in the former BUAD 215x and BUAD 306.

BUAD.title: Applied Business Statistics
BUAD.description: Statistical methods for business analysis; data exploration and description; sampling distributions; estimation; hypothesis testing, simple and multiple regression; model building. Extensive computer applications. (Duplicates credit in BUAD 312 and the former ITP 251.)

BUAD.title: Operations Management
BUAD.description: Fundamentals of operations management. Skills needed to analyze, manage, and improve business processes. Topics include: process, capacity, service, and inventory management and optimization. (Duplicates credit in BUAD 313 and BUAD 315x.)

BUAD.title: Statistics and Data Science for Business
BUAD.description: Statistical methods for exploration, visualization, and analysis of large business datasets; simulation; hypothesis testing, multiple regression modeling, and confidence intervals. Coding taught through data applications. (Faster-paced version of BUAD-310g. Duplicates credit in BUAD 310g and the former ITP 251.)

BUAD.title: Advanced Operations Management and Analytics
BUAD.description: Advanced operations management techniques to analyze and improve business processes.  Decision making under uncertainty through case studies with real data, using state-of-the-art simulation and optimization. (Faster-paced version of BUAD 311. Duplicates credit in BUAD 311 and BUAD 315.)

BUAD.title: Basics of Project and Operations Management for Non-Majors
BUAD.description: Introduction to tools and methods for the design, production, and delivery of goods and services. Techniques for planning, monitoring, and controlling complex projects. Not available for degree or major credit for business and accounting majors. Duplicates credit in BUAD 311 and BUAD 313.

BUAD.title: Introduction to Business Analytics
BUAD.description: Leveraging large corporate datasets; slice and dice data; dash boards; data mining and statistical tools; neural network; multiple and logistic regression; decision tree; gain inference and decision making; clustering.

BUAD.title: Directed Research
BUAD.description: Individual research and readings under the supervision of a faculty advisor. Application and proposal required. Not available for graduate credit.

BUAD.title: Marshall Honors Research Seminar
BUAD.description: Provides the methodological tools to identify research problems, develop researchable hypotheses, apply appropriate methodologies, conduct research, derive meaningful conclusions from data, write a research proposal.

BUAD.title: Strategic Management
BUAD.description: Examination of managerial decision-making, planning, and policy under changing environments; readings, cases, exercises, simulations.

ARCH.title: Architectural Design I
ARCH.description: Introduction to principles and processes; sequence of exercises emphasizing development of basic skills, ideas, and techniques used in the design of simplified architectural projects.

ARCH.title: Fundamentals of Design Communication
ARCH.description: Visual communication techniques applicable to the design of the built environment; drawing, photography, modeling.

ARCH.title: Workshop in Architecture
ARCH.description: Introduction to the ways architecture is created and understood, for minors and non-majors. Hands-on discussion and laboratory session with some drawing and model building. Not available for credit to architecture majors.

ARCH.title: Idea to Reality
ARCH.description: Examines the entrepreneurial process of taking a product from idea to marketplace, including innovation, concepts of feasibility, design, prototyping, getting investors and marketing.

ARCH.title: Architectural Design II
ARCH.description: Continuing development of principles and processes: sequence of projects selected to broaden awareness of design issues at various scales in the urban context. Prerequisite: 102abL.

ARCH.title: Building Science I
ARCH.description: The process and communication of building design: physical building shell, systems for structure, enclosure, and space ordering.

ARCH.title: Materials and Methods of Building Construction
ARCH.description: Basic considerations and design implications of the problem of determination of the materials and the construction details and processes for buildings.

ARCH.title: Building Structures and Seismic Design
ARCH.description: Investigation and design of structure systems : their resistance toseismic and wind forces and integration with architectural design for synergy of form and structure.

ARCH.title: World History of Architecture
ARCH.description: A world-wide perspective of architectural history as a product of social, cultural, religious and political dimensions, 4500 BCE to 1500 CE.

ARCH.title: Resilient Design
ARCH.description: Seminar focused on sustainability and resilient design strategies. Topics such as urban ecology, climate change, sea-level rise, wildfires and Net Zero design will be examined.

ARCH.title: The Architect's Sketchbook
ARCH.description: The architect's sketchbook as a portable laboratory for perceivingand documenting space introduces the study of the builtenvironment. On-site sessions develop drawing, observation, and visualization skills.

ARCH.title: Shelter Design Workshop
ARCH.description: Introduction to design at an occupiable scale -- from tents and pavilions to single units of housing, including issues of materiality, accessibility, constructability, functionality, etc.

ARCH.title: Architectural Design III
ARCH.description: Special integrative year including design issues relating to  housing.

ARCH.title: Principles of Spatial Design I
ARCH.description: Introduction to design principles and processes; sequence of exercises emphasizing development of basic skills, ideas, and techniques used in the creation of simplified urban space design projects.

ARCH.title: Building Science II
ARCH.description: The design of a building as a complex of interacting systems;     relations of subsystems; influences of production and marketing on design.

ARCH.title: Design for the Luminous and Sonic Environment
ARCH.description: Ideas, problems, and computations related to the design of buildings in response to the luminous and sonic environment.

ARCH.title: Place and Culture
ARCH.description: (Study abroad programs only)  Study of the relationships between places and culture through readings, lectures, discussion and  weekly field trips.

ARCH.title: Entrepreneurial Practices for Architecture
ARCH.description: Development of business acumen around new architectural products, materials, systems, etc. Marketing, pitching, business plan development and networking are important aspects of business that all early entrepreneurs need to learn and understand.

ARCH.title: Professional Practicum Workshop
ARCH.description: Students are required to have an architecture-related internship. Students reflect on the nature of their internships and the practice in general through readings and assignments.

ARCH.title: Architectural Design IV
ARCH.description: Selected areas of specialization; three projects chosen with  advisement from a variety of studio offerings that concentrate on  different areas of vital concern.

ARCH.title: Building Science III
ARCH.description: Design of building systems as an experimental process. Prereq: ARCH 305abL.

ARCH.title: Global Studies: Topics in                        Architecture, Urbanism, History and Art
ARCH.description: Offered for particular geographic areas of study. Required prerequisite for all full semester undergraduate global programs. Also intended for general interest in focused study on particular geographic area.

ARCH.title: Architectural Technology
ARCH.description: Architectural design considered as a technological problem; influence of technology on design; buildings as integrated sets of subsystems.

ARCH.title: Geodesign Practicum
ARCH.description: Application of design concepts, planning protocols and spatial analysis skills to a complex planning or design problem sponsored by a local public, private or not-for-profit client in a studio setting.

ARCH.title: Sacred Spaces
ARCH.description: Perspectives in Architecture and Urbanism is an advanced course that allows students to delve deeply into one aspect of world history, theory and/or contemporary issues to develop more focused and critical understanding of that discourse.

ARCH.title: Digital Architectural Photography
ARCH.description: Perceiving and documenting the built environment through the  perspective and frame of the digital camera. Mastering the basic  principles of the digital image through an understanding of frame,  light, exposure, color correction and printing output.

ARCH.title: Field Studies in Architecture
ARCH.description: Field studies using direct observation, site  recordings/documentation, analysis and evaluation supplemented by  discussions and readings in architecture.  Departmental approval.  Recommended preparation: core curriculum

ARCH.title: Field Studies in Urbanism
ARCH.description: Field studies using direct observation, site  recordings/documentation, analysis and evaluation supplemented by  discussions and readings in urbanism.  Departmental approval.  Recommended preparation: core curriculum

ARCH.title: Field Studies in Tectonics
ARCH.description: Field studies using direct observation, site  recordings/documentation, analysis and evaluation supplemented by  discussions and readings in tectonics.  Departmental approval.  Recommended preparation: core curriculum

ARCH.title: Nonconventional Materials for the Built Environment
ARCH.description: An exploration of materials science topics relevant to the application of nonconventional materials in architecture, design, and engineering, addressing a broad range of materials, from the experimental to the vernacular.

ARCH.title: Walking the City
ARCH.description: Through weekly readings and city walks, we'll consider how walking has been conceptualized and put in action by philosophers, artists, poets, city planners and activists.

ARCH.title: Mixed Use Development Process
ARCH.description: Design, financial, legal and management challenges of mixed use real estate development; field project.

ARCH.title: Architectural Studies Capstone
ARCH.description: Collaborative research project and research paper in an area of concentration.

ARCH.title: Conversations on the Expanded Role of the Architect
ARCH.description: Modeled after Renaissance Salons, this "flipped classroom" course relies on lectures by luminaries and discussions as a means to interrogate the role of the architect.

ARCH.title: Furniture Design
ARCH.description: An investigation into 20th century furniture design and its relationships to architecture, art and design.

ARCH.title: Exterior Architectural Light and its Effect on Community and Nature
ARCH.description: Selected topics in various specialty areas of architecture.

ARCH.title: Architectural Design V
ARCH.description: The final architectural project under the guidance of a faculty adviser to demonstrate architectural knowledge, skills, and professional interests and goals.

ARCH.title: Graduate Architecture Design I
ARCH.description: A general introduction to architectural principles, intended to develop design and critical thinking skills and proficiency to communicate those ideas effectively. Open to graduate architecture majors only.

ARCH.title: Material + Process: Material Systems
ARCH.description: Confronts the conventional concepts behind modern building science and material applications, re-applying the processes of fabrication and methods of construction to investigate materiality. Prerequisites: ARCH 211 or ARCH 511.

ARCH.title: Global History of Architecture
ARCH.description: A historical survey of global architecture, analyzed as a product of social, cultural, religious and political forces.a: 4500 BCE to 1500 CE; b: 1500 CE to present.

ARCH.title: Theories of Computer Technology
ARCH.description: Critical studies in building science ranging from sustainability, lighting, acoustics, materials and methods, structures, energy issues, digital media, and fabrication. Students focus on minimum of two topics.

ARCH.title: Sustainability in the Environment:               Infrastructures, Urban Landscapes, and Buildings
ARCH.description: Methodologies and exercises on contextual design and  environmentally sound technologies (EST's) applications for the  sustainability of urban infrastructures, operative landscapes, and  building integration in the urban system.

ARCH.title: Structural Design and Analysis
ARCH.description: a. Introduction to behavior and analysis of building structures. Structural loading, materials, and element types will be explored to understand the basic building blocks of buildings. b. Investigation and design of building structural systems for gravity, wind and seismic loading. Comprehensive design exploration of framing type, materials, detailing, layout, form and integration. Recommended preparation: One-semester college-level course in physics or calculus.

ARCH.title: Professional Practicum
ARCH.description: Comparative studies of professional practice between U.S. firms and firms in other countries. Open to international upper-division undergraduate and graduate architecture students only. Graded CR/NC.

ARCH.title: Professional Practice: Pre-Design, Project and   Office Administration
ARCH.description: Design methodology, typology programming, site analysis, budget formulation and pro-forma procedures. Office management, emphasizing professional service and professional ethics as well as project management focusing on the architect's responsibilities during construction.

ARCH.title: Professional Practice: Legal and Economic        Context, Project Documentation
ARCH.description: The laws and regulations that affect architecture as well as building economics and financing.   Development of comprehensive project documentation, detailing, specifications, drawing formats and organizations.

ARCH.title: Urban Housing: Programs, Precedents, and Recent Case Studies
ARCH.description: Historical overview of the major domestic and international housing developments and innovations since the early 20th century case study format examining a wide range of issues that determine the form of urban housing in various cultures. Major emphasis on the detail analysis of social, technical, and design factors affecting recent housing developments. Recommended preparation: two years of undergraduate architectural studies.

ARCH.title: Landscape Architecture Practice
ARCH.description: Introduction to the principles and ethics, scope and activities, and types of organization for landscape architecture practice.

ARCH.title: Landscape Construction: Topographic Design
ARCH.description: Techniques, strategies, materials, and standards to topographic design and construction in landscape architecture. In-class labs practice basic grading, drainage design, and stormwater management.

ARCH.title: Plant Ecology + Identification
ARCH.description: Principles and concepts of plant ecology and regional plant identification; introduction to California native plant species and communities with field trips and case studies.

ARCH.title: Landscape Architecture Design
ARCH.description: Projects in urban settings with emphasis on landscape continuities  as well as development of integrative schematic proposals and  detailed open space design.

ARCH.title: Landscape Architecture Design
ARCH.description: Projects for the public realm with emphasis on urbanity and  connectivity, place and meaning.

ARCH.title: Landscape as Urbanism: Case Studies
ARCH.description: Cities predominantly in the Global South are studied in relationship to landscape systems. Focus on historic and future urbanization at the interface of natural systems and climate dynamics.

ARCH.title: Contemporary Theories of Landscape Architecture
ARCH.description: Explores contemporary landscape architecture theories, propositions and projects in the context of cities. The exploration methodology includes the study of epochal projects and theoretical texts.

ARCH.title: Advanced Topics in Urban Ecology
ARCH.description: Builds on knowledge related to the impacts of anthropocentrism on our current environmental/landscape condition - stresses on biodiversity, urban heat island, sea-level rise, etc, and strategies at mitigating these conditions - urban forestry, building soils, etc.

ARCH.title: Media for Landscape Architecture: 3D Design
ARCH.description: Developing and communicating landscape architecture design intent using visualization tools for three-dimensional studies.

ARCH.title: Fundamentals of Heritage Conservation
ARCH.description: Concepts and strategies for conservation of significant elements of the built environment: buildings, sites and communities as revealed by readings, site visits, and case studies.

ARCH.title: Heritage Conservation Policy and Planning
ARCH.description: Conservation practice within an economic, political, and cultural context looking at the regulatory environment, public advocacy and policy, real estate development, heritage tourism, environmental sustainability, cultural diversity, and interpretation. Recommended Preparation: ARCH-549.

ARCH.title: Conservation Methods and Materials
ARCH.description: Concepts and techniques for building conservation including identification of treatments, recordation and research, material properties and behavior, building forensics, and project implementation. Recommended preparation: ARCH-549.

ARCH.title: Heritage Conservation Practicum  Advanced Documentation
ARCH.description: Heritage conservation practicum utilizing in-depth documentation methodology to explore the historic built environment of greater Los Angeles. Topics will vary from year to year; may be repeated for credit when subject matter is different.

ARCH.title: Global Perspectives in Heritage Conservation
ARCH.description: In-depth analysis of international heritage conservation practice with a focus on a single country, continent, or world region outside the United States. Topics will vary from year to year; may be repeated for credit when subject matter is different.

ARCH.title: A History of Architectural Theory: 1400-1914
ARCH.description: A seminar on architectural history from Alberti to Scott, reviewing primary texts and subsequent criticisms.

ARCH.title: Urbanism Themes and Case Studies
ARCH.description: Examines urbanism through case studies in theory and design to understand the impacts of globalization, technology, and sustainability on the contemporary city.

ARCH.title: Contemporary Architectural Theory
ARCH.description: Investigates, compares, and critiques modern and contemporary theories of the designed and built environment by focusing on key figures, movements, and texts.

ARCH.title: Cultural Landscape Practicum
ARCH.description: An introduction to the theories, tools and techniques for documenting and researching cultural landscapes.

ARCH.title: Parametric Design
ARCH.description: An in depth and critical look into the reasons and uses for parametric design and its relationship to contemporary form, fabrication, and construction of the built environment.

ARCH.title: Luminous and Auditory Phenomena in Architecture
ARCH.description: The fundamental scientific principles governing light and sound in the built environment will be examined in the context of human physiological, psychological and biological needs.

ARCH.title: Lighting Design
ARCH.description: The physics, technical knowledge, professional knowledge, design, and documentation processes used in architectural lighting design, including first principles, manual calculations and computer simulations..

ARCH.title: Technology-Enabled Architecture, Engineering and Construction
ARCH.description: Integration of architecture, engineering and construction practices through the development of a construction project.

ARCH.title: Techniques in Digital Fabrication
ARCH.description: A practical introduction to digital fabrication. Covered topics include 3D surface milling, thermoforming, materials, casting and shop technology as applied to repeatable surfaces in architecture.

ARCH.title: Communicating for the Built Environment
ARCH.description: Concepts, strategies and skills for communicating effectively in heritage conservation, architecture, landscape architecture, building science and urban planning; with a focus on writing, public speaking, storytelling and strategy.

ARCH.title: Visual Storytelling and Entrepreneurship in Media
ARCH.description: Investigating visual stories as an active tool to critically explore and express design ideas; positions social media and crowdfunding as a foundation for creative action. Not open to Freshmen and Sophomores.

ARCH.title: Directed Research
ARCH.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

ARCH.title: Graduate Architecture Design- Comprehensive
ARCH.description: b. Comprehensive project emphasizing the interaction between general principles and local sites, building technologies and total building design. Open only to Architecture majors.

ARCH.title: Advanced Computation
ARCH.description: Introduction to a range of new technologies and techniques examining their technical and theoretical implications including advanced computational design techniques and geospatial design tools.

ARCH.title: Advanced Digital Fabrication
ARCH.description: Introduction to a range of new technologies and techniques examining technical and theoretical implications including a range of digital fabrication technologies, robotics and film-making techniques.

ARCH.title: Advanced Building Systems Integration
ARCH.description: Design criteria development, material and construction process  methods, occupancy based load profiles, performance/material  life-cycle-mandates, durability for advanced building systems  including integrity in sustainable urban systems.

ARCH.title: Seminar: Environmental Systems Research
ARCH.description: A detailed examination of current issues in the thermal,          acoustical and radiant environment; recent developments in         criteria, systems, controls, design tools and simulations; an      understanding of the relationships between environmental factors,  economics, and architectural goals.

ARCH.title: Future Building Skins: Advanced Applications in Architecture
ARCH.description: Focuses on the development of novel facade solutions that respond to shortcomings of contemporary facades applications in both new and existing buildings.

ARCH.title: Heritage Conservation Thesis Preparation and Thesis
ARCH.description: Introduction to, and exploration of, topics leading to the development of a thesis prospectus and directed research towards the completion of the master's thesis in heritage conservation.

ARCH.title: Heritage Conservation Thesis Preparation and Thesis
ARCH.description: Introduction to, and exploration of, topics leading to the development of a thesis prospectus and directed research towards the completion of the master's thesis in heritage conservation.

ARCH.title: Heritage Conservation Thesis Preparation and Thesis
ARCH.description: Introduction to, and exploration of, topics leading to the development of a thesis prospectus and directed research towards the completion of the master's thesis in heritage conservation. Credit on acceptance of thesis. Registration restricted to Master of Heritage Conservation and Historic Preservation students who have satisfactorily completed 12 hours of graduate course work and have permission of the Program Director. Graded IP/CR/NC.

ARCH.title: Building Science Thesis
ARCH.description: Research and thesis for the Master of Building Science degree. Credit on acceptance of thesis. Graded IP/CR/NC.

ARCH.title: Building Science Thesis
ARCH.description: Research and thesis for the Master of Building Science degree.

ARCH.title: Building Science Thesis
ARCH.description: Research and thesis for the Master of Building Science degree. Credit on acceptance of thesis. Graded IP/CR/NC.

ARCH.title: Research Publication Methods for Building Science
ARCH.description: Technical documentation, graphic representation, and verbal presentation for writing and presenting journal articles and conference presentations in building science.

ARCH.title: Advanced Design-Research
ARCH.description: Directed research option for the MLArch degree.

ARCH.title: Architecture Directed Design Research Option I
ARCH.description: Directed Design Research option for graduate level architecture degree. Credit on acceptance of research project. Open only to Architecture majors. Graded IP/CR/NC.

CTAN.title: Introduction to the Art of Movement
CTAN.description: Theory and practice of animation with a focus on movement, gesture, timing and performance. Open to freshman in Animation and Digital Arts majors only.

CTAN.title: Design Fundamentals for Animation I
CTAN.description: Developing skills in design, composition, shape language, image-making, and visual thinking to create more sophisticated style frames and imagery for animation practice.

CTAN.title: The Rise of Digital Hollywood
CTAN.description: An overview of the evolution of computer graphics in modern media.

CTAN.title: Intermediate Animation Production
CTAN.description: Tools, skills and procedures used in animation production with a focus on professional execution of independent and collaborative productions. Prerequisite: CTAN 102. Open to sophomore animation majors only.

CTAN.title: Introduction to 3-D Character Animation
CTAN.description: 3-D animation performance utilizing preset rigs and virtual characters. Emphasis on timing, gesture, and performance.

CTAN.title: Ideation and Pre-Production
CTAN.description: Emphasis on lateral thinking working across boundaries to find underlying principles in terms of ideation: the act of becoming an agent of ideas.

CTAN.title: Senior Project
CTAN.description: b: Completion and exhibition of the short animated film to demonstrate understanding and further examination of the possibilities of animation time based graphic media. Open to senior animation majors only.

CTAN.title: Concept Design for Animation
CTAN.description: Creating characters and environments for animation, live action, and video games.

CTAN.title: Studio Careers: Story to Screen
CTAN.description: Seminar featuring guest speakers from major animation studios to provide an overview of a feature animation pipeline from development to pre-production, production and post-production.

CTAN.title: The World of Visual Effects
CTAN.description: Introduction to the expanding field of visual effects; topics include integration for cinematic storytelling and the study of digital productions employing the latest visual effects.

CTAN.title: Writing for Animation
CTAN.description: Workshop exploring concept and structure of long and short form animated films through practical writing exercises.

CTAN.title: Introduction to 3-D Computer Animation
CTAN.description: Lecture and laboratory in computer animation: geometric modeling, motion specification, lighting, texture mapping, rendering, compositing, production techniques, systems for computer-synthesized animation using Maya software.

CTAN.title: Real-Time Animation
CTAN.description: The fundamentals of lighting and rendering in real-time. Creating complex, compelling and dynamic scenes and manipulating them in real-time using Unreal Engine.

CTAN.title: Character Design Workshop
CTAN.description: The basics of character design for animation: anatomy, poses, facial expressions, silhouettes, and anthropomorphism. Development of a portfolio.

CTAN.title: Visual Effects
CTAN.description: Survey of contemporary concepts and approaches to production in  the current state of film and video effects work.  Digital and  traditional methodologies will be covered, with a concentration on digital exercises illustrating modern techniques.

CTAN.title: Digital Effects Animation
CTAN.description: All aspects of digital effects animation, including particles, dynamics, and fluids. Creating water, fire, explosions, and destruction in film.

CTAN.title: Advanced Character Animation for Games
CTAN.description: Advanced techniques for animating 3-D creature characters in games. An emphasis on unique non-human fantasy characters.

CTAN.title: Visual Music
CTAN.description: Creating visual music animation in a variety of forms and styles. Exploring the relationship between music, movement, and visual expression. Freshmen and sophomores not eligible.

CTAN.title: Directed Studies
CTAN.description: Individual research under faculty guidance.

CTAN.title: Procedural Animation
CTAN.description: Introduction to software packages and practices exploring current animation techniques that leverage simulation systems. Artificial intelligence as a tool for animation.

CTAN.title: Storyboarding for Animation
CTAN.description: Focus on film grammar, perspective, and layout, staging and acting  as it relates to storyboarding for animation.

CTAN.title: Creative Production in Virtual Reality
CTAN.description: A creative studio course in producing both a linear cinematic virtual reality short film and associated real-time immersive experience.

CTAN.title: Compositing and the Art of Creating Visual Styles
CTAN.description: A comprehensive overview of compositing techniques to effectively create film looks in 3D/2D animations and visual effects.

CTAN.title: Environment Modeling
CTAN.description: Create 3D models for environments for urban and natural settings and props including vehicles, rocks, trees and furniture.

CTAN.title: Inside Story: Creative Development for Animation
CTAN.description: A creative development workshop for animated pitch storytelling, supported by an introduction to character development and story structure fundamentals.

CTAN.title: Fundamentals of 3-D Character Animation
CTAN.description: Applying traditional principles to 3-D character animation in Maya, with a focus on character performance and acting.

CTAN.title: Fictional World Building in Animation
CTAN.description: Constructing a persuasive fictional animated world via narrative  techniques, a fixed premise and a degree of believability  supported by five fundamental visual design elements.

CTAN.title: Animation Production I
CTAN.description: Production of an animation project from creative concept and design through completion.

CTAN.title: Motion Capture Fundamentals
CTAN.description: Fundamental principles of motion capture technology explored while  working through a structured series of assignments based around  performance, gesture and motion.

CTAN.title: 3-D Motion Graphic Design
CTAN.description: A creative 3-D motion graphics course focusing on animation technique, design and skills in Cinema 4-D.

CTAN.title: Cinematic Storytelling for Animators
CTAN.description: Techniques and cinematic language employed in both live action and animation by cinematographers and layout artists to tell visual stories.

CTAN.title: Animation Pre-Thesis Seminar
CTAN.description: Research, development, and preparation of the concept, script, storyboards and preliminary designs for thesis projects to be executed in CTAN 594abz.

CTAN.title: Directed Studies in Animation
CTAN.description: Individual exploration in the areas of contemporary technology, animation techniques or experimental film through internships, residencies or directed studies. Open only to Animation and Digital Arts master students.

CTAN.title: Master's Thesis
CTAN.description: Credit on acceptance of Thesis. Graded CR/NC.

CTXA.title: Audio Design for Animation and Immersive Media
CTXA.description: Experimental and traditional audio design practices for animation, culminating in an immersive audio project utilizing acoustic design, surround sound and professional recording and editing tools.

CTXA.title: Visualizing Science Production
CTXA.description: Principles of 2-D and 3-D digital animation and AI applied to scientific themes and research topics.

CTXA.title: Writing and Story Art for Vision and Motion
CTXA.description: Story, narrative structure and storyboarding techniques examined through a creative lens.

CTXA.title: Applied Expanded Animation
CTXA.description: Examines post-graduation opportunities in Expanded Animation: arts, research, academia and industry. Includes grant writing, independent filmmaking, art galleries, festivals, starting a business and financing.

CTXA.title: Expanded Animation Production I
CTXA.description: Creating a one-minute animated film, installation, VR performance or new media project with sound, including development, pre-production, production and post-production.

CTXA.title: Stop Motion Puppet and Set Design
CTXA.description: Puppet and set design for stop motion animation while providing guidance on armature rigs that allow the character to be animated effectively.

CTXA.title: Stop Motion Performance
CTXA.description: Incorporating classic stop motion techniques for puppet performance and animation. Emphasis on timing, performance, movement, animation and gesture.

CTXA.title: Theory and Practice in Contemporary Animation
CTXA.description: Seminar and practicum featuring an inclusive investigation of contemporary animation theory and practices, with an emphasis on non-mainstream and marginalized themes, voices and methodology.

CTXA.title: Cinematic and Media-Based Installations
CTXA.description: The history and practice of media-based installation art, from site-specific architectural projection mapping, to activist and public art, video sculptures and immersive, physical transformations.

CTXA.title: Animation for Virtual Characters, Robotics and AI
CTXA.description: Designed to explore the illusion of life, sentience and how to develop compelling animation, diverse stories and gesture for virtual characters, AI and robotics.

CTXA.title: Directed Research
CTXA.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

CTXA.title: Expanded Animation Pre-Thesis
CTXA.description: Research and development of the thesis project in expanded animation. Presentation of the thesis proposal at the end of the semester.

CTXA.title: Advanced Storyboarding: Inside the Animation Story Room
CTXA.description: A special projects course in which students study and create new works with a visiting master artist, animator, or researcher.

CMPP.title: Producing Workshop
CMPP.description: Further hands-on creative and physical filmmaking, making more advanced short films. Open to PFTM students only. Duplicates credit in CTPR-504 and CMPP 541.

CMPP.title: Script Development
CMPP.description: From idea and story to finished shooting script. Open to PFTM students only.

CMPP.title: Digital Media and Entertainment
CMPP.description: Exploring the effect of digital media on the entertainment landscape. Open to PFTM students only.

CMPP.title: Producing for Television
CMPP.description: Discussions of the creative and financial aspects of television producing. Open to PFTM students only.

CMPP.title: Seminar on Non-Mainstream Producing
CMPP.description: Discussions on non-major studio producing options, including non-traditional financing and non-theatrical producing. Open to PFTM students only.

CMPP.title: Advanced Television
CMPP.description: Advanced studies of the business of television, including the economic structure of the television industry. Open to PFTM students only.

CMPP.title: Graduate Film Business Seminar
CMPP.description: Economics of the entertainment industry, including entertainment law, and rights acquisition. Focuses on independent low budget producing and studio management.

CMPP.title: Individual Project Seminar
CMPP.description: Directed Research project and seminars in related topics. Open to PFTM students only.

IML.title: Introduction to Digital Studies
IML.description: An introduction to the expressive range of screen languages in their cultural, historical, and technological contexts.

IML.title: The Languages of Digital Media
IML.description: An in-depth investigation of the close interrelationships among technology, culture and communication to form a solid foundation for digital authoring. Duplicates credit in former IML 101.

IML.title: Media Arts and Practice Studio II
IML.description: Intermediate laboratory exploring computational systems through a series of critical design prompts. Emphasis on digital representation, time-based processes, abstract data and the relationship between humans and computers.

IML.title: Introduction to Visual Design
IML.description: An introduction to the principles of visual and graphic design within the field of media art.

IML.title: Introduction to Creative Coding
IML.description: An introduction to the design of poetic and creative artworks using foundational programming concepts.

IML.title: Identity, Power, and Digital Culture
IML.description: Critical analysis of the categories of race, class and gender within the diverse digital spaces of contemporary culture, from video games to the digital divide.

IML.title: Introduction to Creative Web Programming
IML.description: An introduction to the fundamentals of creative web coding and design, with best practices and new creative directions.

IML.title: Professionalism for Media Arts
IML.description: Development of documentation and archival strategies, with an emphasis on techniques of personal and professional representation.

IML.title: Introduction to Sound
IML.description: An introduction to audio and sound technologies, focusing on creating artwork using sound as a primary modality.

IML.title: Introduction to Video
IML.description: An introduction to digital storytelling with a focus on cameras, sound recording and editing techniques to create short, professional video projects.

IML.title: Methods in Digital Research
IML.description: Emphasizing rigorous multimedia research and authorship strategies, this course prepares students to undertake large-scale digital projects.

IML.title: Introduction to 3-D Modeling
IML.description: An introduction to 3-D modeling, with an emphasis on the fundamentals of texturing and lighting for use in animation, game art and interactive 3-D spaces.

IML.title: Digital Fabrication, Interaction Design with TouchDesigner, and Rapid Prototyping
IML.description: Exploration of extended human computer interaction, including new forms of haptic, sonic and other sense modalities, through physical computing and spatial interfaces.

IML.title: Sensory Design
IML.description: Designing media experiences that move beyond vision and sound by incorporating elements of smell, taste, touch and/or other sensory systems.

IML.title: Thesis Studio II
IML.description: Production of a digital thesis project.

IML.title: Procedural and Generative Design
IML.description: Studio class exploring spatial perception and advanced techniques of 3-D representation, stereoscopy, panorama, projection mapping, modeling for real-time environments, parametric modeling and 3-D fabrication.

IML.title: Nature, Design and Media
IML.description: Working in any medium -- video, sound, performance, etc. -- students explore our changing relationship to the world in a time of planetary crisis.

IML.title: AI and Creativity
IML.description: Hands-on exploration of the history, theory and uses of a broad range of AI-related tools for creative expression.

IML.title: Storytelling with AR glasses and Wearable Media
IML.description: A hands-on mentored research lab experience within the context of media art and in association with a real-world project.

IML.title: Advanced Platform: Mixed Realities
IML.description: Exploration of advanced techniques for the creation of mixed reality artworks combining digital content and physical environments.

IML.title: Directed Research
IML.description: Individual research and readings.

IML.title: Creativity and Wellbeing
IML.description: Exploration of  the intersections among creative practice, mindfulness and wellbeing through individual studio-based project work.

IML.title: DIY Music Videos: From Critique to Creation
IML.description: Selected topics in multimedia literacy.

IML.title: Non-Fiction Cinematic Practice I
IML.description: An introduction to video in academic scholarship. Acquisition and editing of images and sound through a series of short, non-fiction media projects.

IML.title: Media, Machines, and Memoirs
IML.description: A hands-on mentored graduate research lab experience within the context of media art and in association with a real-world project.

IML.title: PLANET JUNK: World Building and Narrative Design Systems for Media
IML.description: A hands-on mentored graduate research lab experience within the context of media art and in association with a real-world project.

IML.title: Creative Critical Writing Workshop
IML.description: A writing workshop to explore innovative forms for critical writing, media-rich writing and video that borrow from creative nonfiction, the lyric essay, poetic/vernacular criticism.

IML.title: Directed Research
IML.description: Research leading to the masters degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

IML.title: Media Arts and Practice Colloquium/Professional Seminar
IML.description: Orientation to the profession, opportunities, presentation and analysis of recent developments and applications in Media Arts and Practice. Graded CR/NC. (Duplicates credit in former CNTV 603)

IML.title: Theories of Media Arts and Practice
IML.description: Develops an anti-essentialist theory of technology adequate to the digital age that serves as a conceptual and critical framework for developing a contemporary technological imagination. (Duplicates credit in former CNTV 604)

IML.title: Critique and Criticality
IML.description: Introduction to methods of critique, critiques of critique and alternatives to critique, with specific attention to interdisciplinary media-rich practices and works created by students.

IML.title: Doctoral Dissertation
IML.description: Credit on acceptance of dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC. (Duplicates credit in CNTV 794a)

IML.title: Doctoral Dissertation
IML.description: Credit on acceptance of dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC. (Duplicates credit in CNTV 794b)

IML.title: Doctoral Dissertation
IML.description: Credit on acceptance of dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC. (Duplicates credit in CNTV 794c)

IML.title: Doctoral Dissertation
IML.description: Credit on acceptance of dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC. (Duplicates credit in CNTV 794d)

IML.title: Doctoral Dissertation
IML.description: Credit on acceptance of dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC. (Duplicates credit in CNTV 794z)

CTIN.title: Themed Concept Development: Creativity, Research, Ideation
CTIN.description: Processes used in the themed entertainment industry to research concepts, develop concepts and deliver creative product.

CTIN.title: Game Development Fundamentals
CTIN.description: Covers core skills for creating in a digital game engine, the role of prototyping in the game development and the use of version control systems.

CTIN.title: Digital Media Workshop
CTIN.description: Exploration of a variety of moving image aesthetics and methodologies in order to highlight how the language of cinema shapes contemporary digital and interactive media practices.

CTIN.title: Crew for Advanced Game Project
CTIN.description: Hands-on creating experiences for students who want to work as crew on an advanced game project.

CTIN.title: Themed Entertainment Project Crew
CTIN.description: An introduction to building for themed entertainment and the experience of live operating a ride or exhibit.

CTIN.title: Fundamentals of User Research and Experience
CTIN.description: An introduction to games user research, interface design and user experience, covering both theory and practice.

CTIN.title: Miniature Golf Production
CTIN.description: Workshop on the production of miniature golf holes, considering theming, experience, and build.

CTIN.title: Advanced Visual Design for Games
CTIN.description: The scope of visual game design, including the role of characters,  architecture, indoor and outdoor space, and environmental effects  and sounds.    Recommended preparation: CTAN 443

CTIN.title: User Research for Games
CTIN.description: Concepts and methods of usability assessment. The emphasis will be on understanding the issues surrounding game interfaces, and utilizing usability assessment methods.

CTIN.title: Sound Design for Games
CTIN.description: Introduction to the techniques, terminology, and implementation of  sounds in games, including establishing a sense of place and  concepts of realistic sound.

CTIN.title: Producing Interactive Projects
CTIN.description: An in-depth exploration of the development and production concepts woven into the USC Games curriculum and utilized in the professional games industry.

CTIN.title: Business and Management of Games
CTIN.description: Overview of current business models in games and interactive media, methods for pitching and getting products funded; copyright and intellectual property.

CTIN.title: Anatomy of a Game
CTIN.description: Examine two game products from concept to delivery; introduce students to each of the professional disciplines involved in making digital games. Recommended preparation: CTIN 488.

CTIN.title: Game Studies Seminar
CTIN.description: Rigorous examination of interactive entertainment: genres,  history, aesthetics, cultural context, and social significance.   Topics vary by semester.

CTIN.title: Advanced Games Business
CTIN.description: An advanced dive into the structure of the games industry with a focus on emerging trends and the future of games as business and entertainment.

CTIN.title: Level Design Workshop
CTIN.description: A workshop on focused design tasks, creating many levels on paper and in game engines.

CTIN.title: Directing for Games and Interactive Media
CTIN.description: An introduction to the skills of directorial perspective, scene breakdown, thematic intent, project planning, team building, communication, situational decision-making and response to change.

CTIN.title: Introduction to World Building for Games
CTIN.description: Creative narrative design approaches to augmented reality for use in games, physical spaces and community events.

CTIN.title: Alternative Control Workshop
CTIN.description: Design of game projects using immersive input devices. Development of play mechanics, feedback systems and game design for immersive environments.

CTIN.title: Game Design Workshop
CTIN.description: An introduction to making games. Students will explore the principles of game design through the entirely analog creation of card, board and tabletop games.

CTIN.title: Intermediate Game Design and Production
CTIN.description: A follow-up to the introductory game design class, this course will introduce more advanced concepts in game design and game theories, including ideation, digital prototyping and level design.

CTIN.title: Directed Research
CTIN.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

CTIN.title: Advanced Game Project II
CTIN.description: Students work in teams to polish and finalize a functional digital game suitable for distribution via the web and/or submission into independent games festivals.

CTIN.title: Advanced Themed Entertainment Production
CTIN.description: Production and building for themed attractions. Large scale multidisciplinary teams work together to produce themed entertainment experiences.

CTIN.title: Interactive Media Startup
CTIN.description: Pitching, production planning, forming a company and seeking funding for your creative media idea. Duplicates credit in former CTIN 497ab.

CTIN.title: Research Methods for Innovation, Engagement and Assessment
CTIN.description: Planning, designing, and analyzing a research study for a digital media project. Production of a written report and presentation. Recommended preparation: CTIN-506, CTIN-541, and CTCS-505.

CTIN.title: Graduate Advanced Game Project
CTIN.description: Capstone course for assigned Game Directors or Area Leads to create an innovative, large-scale game project.

CTIN.title: Interactive Design and Production I
CTIN.description: The development of interactive experiences with an emphasis on prototyping and development.

CTIN.title: Interactive Design and Production II
CTIN.description: Rapid prototyping and forward iteration of thesis project ideas developed in CTIN 548.

CTIN.title: Experiments in Interactivity II
CTIN.description: Experimental studio course in application of technology to interactive experience. Open to Interactive Media MFA students only.

CTIN.title: Preparing the Interactive Project
CTIN.description: An advanced production workshop in which students design and  prepare for the production of their advanced project.  Open to  Interactive Media MFA students only.

CTIN.title: Graduate Game Directing Seminar
CTIN.description: Advanced seminar in creative direction for games including material selection, preproduction, working with teams, project planning, documentation, vision building, communication and decision-making.

CTIN.title: Game Development for Designers
CTIN.description: The fundamentals of 3-D real time game engines, scripting for interactivity, and building games with digital tools.

CTIN.title: Directed Research
CTIN.description: Research project leading to the master's degree.  Maximum units  which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the  department.  Graded CR/NC.

CTIN.title: Crew for Graduate Advanced Game Project
CTIN.description: Students from many disciplines work in large teams to create an innovative, large-scale interactive media or game project.

CTIN.title: Game Development Capstone
CTIN.description: Small student teams produce, playtest and polish high quality games and experiences in an intensive project based studio setting.

CTIN.title: Integrative Project: Media-based Interventions in Healthcare
CTIN.description: A project that showcases integrative mastery of prior and newly acquired knowledge, skills and interests. Permission of instructor required.

CTIN.title: Master's Thesis
CTIN.description: Credit on acceptance of thesis. Graded IP/CR/NC. Open to M.F.A., Interactive Media majors only.

CTIN.title: Research Practicum in Interactive Media
CTIN.description: Hands-on practical experience working with a faculty member in the Interactive Media and Games Division on one or more ongoing research projects.

CTWR.title: Writing the Screenplay
CTWR.description: Writing a feature-length screenplay based on treatment developed in CTWR 206a. Includes a first draft and a polish.

CTWR.title: Breaking the Story
CTWR.description: Examination of the fundamental elements of a good story, and how to use those elements to develop new screenplay ideas. Recommended preparation: CTWR 106b.

CTWR.title: From Page to Screen: Adapting Stories for Film and TV
CTWR.description: Detailed investigation of source material and how it translates to screen. Special attention paid to character, genre and story as relates to intellectual property.

CTWR.title: Breaking the Hour-Long Television Series
CTWR.description: Introduction to hour-long television staff writing. Breaking of a complete season and writing episodes. Special attention to season construction, pitching, character and story engine.

CTWR.title: Breaking the Half-Hour Television Series
CTWR.description: The fundamentals of writing for half-hour television. Writing an episode of an existing half-hour television series, with emphasis on conception, pitching, characterization and structure.

CTWR.title: Writing the Narrative Podcast Series
CTWR.description: Development of an original narrative podcast. Emphasis on dramatic elements of auditory storytelling and character development.

CTWR.title: Fundamentals of Screenwriting: Character, Conflict and Story
CTWR.description: Introduction to writing compelling scenes, creating authentic characters, three-act structure and feature film outlining.

CTWR.title: Character Development and Storytelling for Games
CTWR.description: An exploration of characters and story worlds as they relate to  gaming with an emphasis on emotionally rich environments in  interactive entertainment. Recommended preparation: CTIN 488

CTWR.title: Television Script Analysis
CTWR.description: In-depth analysis of the craft of writing prime-time episodic television. Examination of situation comedies and dramas through weekly screenings and lectures.

CTWR.title: Writing the Short Script I
CTWR.description: Preparation of scripts for short films: form, structure, planning. Open only to Cinematic Arts Film and Television Production majors.

CTWR.title: The Screenplay
CTWR.description: Students study story structure and develop several story outlines, write a short script for possible production, a feature film outline and first act. Recommended preparation: CTWR-416. Open only to Cinematic Arts Film and Television Production majors.

CTWR.title: Script Coverage and Story Analysis
CTWR.description: Evaluation of completed scripts prior to their production.  Coverage and analysis of scripts as potential properties from the  perspective of a production company.

CTWR.title: Senior Thesis
CTWR.description: b: Completion and revision of Senior Thesis project and  introduction to motion picture industry procedures and practices through interaction with industry representatives.  Open to B.F.A. Writing for Screen and Television students only.

CTWR.title: Senior Thesis in Dramatic Television
CTWR.description: Revision of original pilot script, writing of mid-season episode, and completion of bible for original dramatic series developed in first semester.

CTWR.title: Creating the Dramatic Television Series
CTWR.description: Examination and creation of the world, characters, and concept for an original hour-long dramatic series. Writing an outline for an original dramatic pilot.

CTWR.title: Writing the Screenplay
CTWR.description: Introduction to formal elements of the screenplay through lectures and the workshopping of a complete first draft of a feature-length script.

CTWR.title: The G.O.A.T.S of Screen Comedy
CTWR.description: Detailed investigation of specific comedy writers, comedy genres, and the works they've influenced. Lectures include screenings and visiting screenwriters.

CTWR.title: Writing Horror - Monsters, Madness, and the Unknown
CTWR.description: Detailed investigation of a specific screenwriter's style and the works they've influenced. Lectures include screenings and visiting screenwriters.

CTWR.title: Writing the Contained Feature
CTWR.description: Preparation of proposals and scripts for different types of film or television programming: emphasis on conception, structure, characterization and format.

CTWR.title: Writing the Original Situation Comedy Pilot
CTWR.description: Advanced workshop for writing an original half-hour comedy series, including a pilot script, summary of characters and story lines for first season.

CTWR.title: Writing the Original Dramatic Series Pilot
CTWR.description: Advanced workshop in creation of an original dramatic series, including a first draft of the pilot and a summary of characters and storylines.

CTWR.title: Advanced Feature Rewriting
CTWR.description: An advanced workshop in which a feature length screenplay will be rewritten using a specific methodology that focuses on a macro to micro approach to revision.

CTWR.title: Pitching for Film, Television and New Media
CTWR.description: Emphasis of verbal storytelling and presentation skills in motion pictures, television, and new media with concentration on story and character.

CTWR.title: Entertainment Industry Seminar
CTWR.description: Examination and analysis of various topics, issues, and resources  pertaining to creative, legal, and business perspectives for  writers in the entertainment industry.

CTWR.title: Creating the Short Film
CTWR.description: Strengthening and deepening the ability to conceive and develop  ideas that will lead to compelling, authentic, and personally  meaningful films.  Duplicates credit in CTWR 528.

CTWR.title: Fundamentals of Storytelling for Animation
CTWR.description: Introduction to the fundamentals of storytelling with techniques and practices that work best for animated stories.

CTWR.title: Basic Dramatic Screenwriting
CTWR.description: Dramaturgy for the fiction and nonfiction work. Techniques for creating the original or adapted theatrical script. Open to graduate screenwriting majors (CTWR) and dramatic writing (Theatre) majors only. Development of an outline and feature-length original script.

CTWR.title: Practicum in Screenwriting
CTWR.description: Comprehensive re-writing of second and third drafts of a feature screenplay leading to a polished and professional piece.

CTWR.title: Advanced Motion Picture Script Analysis
CTWR.description: Critical analysis of the structure of films from the classics to  current award winners.  Students will learn how to identify key  story concepts and break down three act structure in finished  films and scripts.

CTWR.title: Thesis in Half-Hour Television Comedy
CTWR.description: The re-write, casting, and performance stages of television comedy development. The completion of a final draft of the pilot script and series bible. Open only to Writing for Screen and Television master students.

CTWR.title: Thesis in Television Drama
CTWR.description: Part B -- writing the series bible and mid-season episode -- is  part two of the television thesis course.  Students develop their  original series further by writing the bible for the series and  the mid-season episode which is reflective of storylines,  characters and settings developed in part A of the course.  Open  to M.F.A. Writing for Screen and Television students only.

CTWR.title: Advanced Scene Writing Workshop
CTWR.description: Intensive workshop oriented specifically to writing and rewriting the most effective and telling dramatic scenes to heighten audience participation and greater story impact.

CTWR.title: Introduction to the Screenplay
CTWR.description: Introduction to formal elements of the screenplay through lectures and the workshopping of a complete first draft of a feature-length script. Prerequisite: CTAN 536 or CTWR 505 or CTWR 518. Recommended preparation: CTWR 516.

CTWR.title: Intermediate Screenwriting
CTWR.description: Emphasizes structural elements crucial to the feature film. Techniques for creating an original or adapted theatrical-length script.

CTWR.title: Rewriting the Feature Screenplay
CTWR.description: Rewriting the feature-length screenplay.  Focus on macro to micro approach to revision.

CTWR.title: Advanced Half-Hour Comedy Series Pilot
CTWR.description: Development of an original half-hour comedy series; writing of the pilot episode and series bible.

CTWR.title: Advanced Hour-Long Drama Series Pilot
CTWR.description: Development of an original one hour drama series; writing of the pilot episode and series bible.

CTWR.title: Dreams, the Brain, and Storytelling
CTWR.description: Examination of the links between the brain, creativity, neuroscience and storytelling. Through lectures, screenings, and readings, students will log dreams for use in creative exercises.

CTWR.title: Advanced Rewriting Workshop
CTWR.description: Advanced feature screenwriting, emphasizing the rewrite of a first draft script.

CTWR.title: Pitching for Film and Television
CTWR.description: Development and pitching of ideas for motion pictures, episodic, and television pilots. Reducing ideas to basic components enhancing verbal presentation skills.

CTWR.title: Advanced Genre Writing
CTWR.description: Development and execution of writing in various genres of film, television, or new media scripts. Prerequisite: CTWR 514b.

CTCS.title: The Cinematic Arts in Society
CTCS.description: Explorations of media literacies, public discourse and policy  around cinematic arts, and the role of moving image media in  society.

CTCS.title: Introduction to Cinema
CTCS.description: Introductory course in the study of cinematic arts. Study of technique, aesthetics, criticism, and social implications of cinema consisting of lectures, screenings and discussions.

CTCS.title: Introduction to Television and Video
CTCS.description: Exploration of the economic, technological, aesthetic, and ideological characteristics of the televisual medium; study of historical development of television and video including analysis of key works; introduction to TV/Video theory and criticism.

CTCS.title: Race, Class, and Gender in American Film
CTCS.description: Analyzes issues of race, class and gender in contemporary American culture as represented in the cinema.

CTCS.title: History of the International Cinema II
CTCS.description: The development of international cinema from World War II to the present. Lectures, screenings and discussions.

CTCS.title: Introduction to Theories of Cinema and Media
CTCS.description: Introduction to theoretical works in cinema and media studies, emphasizing concepts to interrogate media objects. Lectures and discussion orient majors to their cohort and field.

CTCS.title: History of American Cinema since 1960
CTCS.description: The development of American cinema since the end of Classical Hollywood and its relationship to American history and culture. Lectures, screenings and discussions.

CTCS.title: Practicum in Film/Television Criticism
CTCS.description: Exercise in writing film and television criticism using new and classic films and television programs.

CTCS.title: Bollywood and India
CTCS.description: Detailed investigation of traditions, achievements, and trends of film and/or electronic media in a particular country or region.

CTCS.title: History of American Television
CTCS.description: History of television as an entertainment, information, and art  medium.  Emphasis on programming and institutional history,  including issues of regulation, censorship, aesthetics and  activism.

CTCS.title: Censorship in Cinema
CTCS.description: An inquiry into the practice and patterns of censorship in cinema.

CTCS.title: Men and Masculinities
CTCS.description: Examines how gender and sexuality are figured in cinema and television with an emphasis on the development of feminist media theory.

CTCS.title: Cons and Comedy
CTCS.description: Rigorous examination of film and/or television genres: history, aesthetics, cultural context, social significance, and critical methodologies.

CTCS.title: The Essay Film
CTCS.description: Rigorous examination of film and/or television genres: history, aesthetics, cultural context, social significance, and critical methodologies.

CTCS.title: Theatrical Film Symposium
CTCS.description: Lectures and readings on creative problems in the motion picture industry; current films; interviews with visiting producers, directors, writers, performers.

CTCS.title: Television Symposium
CTCS.description: Lectures and readings on creative problems in the television  industry; study of current and historical trends, interviews with  producers, directors, writers and performers.

CTCS.title: Hollywood vs. Silicon Valley
CTCS.description: Intensive topical study of the social, political and economic contexts in which media are produced, distributed and monetized.

CTCS.title: Billy Wilder's Hollywood
CTCS.description: Intensive study of the style of an auteur, studio, film or television making mode in terms of thematic and formal properties and their influences upon the art of film.

CTCS.title: Blaxploitation
CTCS.description: Intensive study of the style of an auteur, studio, film or television making mode in terms of thematic and formal properties and their influences upon the art of film.

CTCS.title: Interactivity Across Media
CTCS.description: Cultural study of communications technology and its relationship to society. Evaluation of the social and cultural impact of technologies from the telegraph to the Internet.

CTCS.title: Storyworlds
CTCS.description: An examination of transmedia, or cross-platform, entertainment: commercial and grassroots texts, theoretical framework, historical context, and commercial projects. Developing transmedia strategies for existing media properties.

CTCS.title: World Cinema Before 1945
CTCS.description: Historical survey of global cinema from its beginnings until 1945.

CTCS.title: Hollywood's Global Century
CTCS.description: Survey history of the United States film from 1927 to the present, with emphasis upon film as art form, economic institution, technology, and cultural product.

CTCS.title: Survey of Interactive Media
CTCS.description: A survey course exploring the historical, cultural, business,  creative, and technological aspects of the new interactive media.

CTCS.title: Refugee Cinemas
CTCS.description: Seminar on media's impact in defining nation and/or region in specific cultural contexts. Also addresses issues of exile, diaspora, transnationalism and globalism.

CTCS.title: The Politics of Worlding
CTCS.description: Introduction to central concepts, key theories and leading figures in cultural studies, particularly as they relate to issues of popular culture and visual media.

CTCS.title: Electric Cinema and Media Studies
CTCS.description: Contemporary theoretical frameworks and their relationship to film and television studies. Topics differ from semester to semester.

CTCS.title: Advanced Methods and Approaches
CTCS.description: Research seminar in methods and approaches to moving image history including film, television and digital media. Focus on archival research and issues in writing history.

CTCS.title: Research
CTCS.description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

CTCS.title: Doctoral Dissertation
