CTCS.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

CTCS.title: Doctoral Dissertation
CTCS.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

CTCS.title: Doctoral Dissertation
CTCS.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

CTCS.title: Doctoral Dissertation
CTCS.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

CTCS.title: Doctoral Dissertation
CTCS.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

CNTV.title: Fundamentals of Entertainment Law and Dealmaking
CNTV.description: An introduction to the legal aspects of securing and protecting content in all forms of media, and the business side of project development and implementation.

CNTV.title: Business and Cinematic Arts Entertainment Practicum
CNTV.description: Application of business and cinematic arts concepts to entertainment industry networking and career-building experiences. Peer collaboration/competition, and identifying organizational compatibility.

CNTV.title: How to Make "It": Mapping Your Way to Success in Showbiz
CNTV.description: Explores creating film and television projects, starting from the initial stages of sourcing material to the final stages of marketing and advertising.

CNTV.title: Entertainment Industry Launchpad
CNTV.description: Provides senior Business of Cinematic Arts majors with the practical and theoretical skills needed to launch their entry into the Entertainment Industry.

CNTV.title: Directed Research
CNTV.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit. Prerequisite: consent of instructor.

CNTV.title: Internship in Cinematic Arts
CNTV.description: On-the-job film, television, and interactive industry experience in the areas of interest of the individual student. Requires departmental approval.

CNTV.title: The Television Industry: Networks, Cable and the Internet
CNTV.description: The current state of the television industry and future business  paradigms.

CNTV.title: Digital Technologies and the Entertainment Industry
CNTV.description: The impact of digital technologies on the film, television, and  music industries from content creation to distribution.

CNTV.title: Seminar in Motion Picture Business
CNTV.description: Problems of studio operation, production, distribution, exhibition or legal procedures relating to the motion picture.

CNTV.title: The Business of Representation
CNTV.description: Various roles an agent, manager, attorney and publicist play in representing talent, producers and writers. Taught by professionals who are at the forefront of the entertainment industry.

CNTV.title: Directed Research
CNTV.description: Research leading to the Master's Degree. Maximum units which may  be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.   Graded CR/NC.

CNTV.title: Professional Practicum
CNTV.description: Film, media, archival and interactive industry experience in areas of interest to the individual student, and development of a personal brand. Requires departmental approval.

CTPR.title: Lateral Thinking for Filmmaking Practice
CTPR.description: Introduces contemporary concepts of production, emphasizing the variety of contemporary media and significant related concepts. Projects created using laptops, phones and networks.

CTPR.title: Cinematic Communication
CTPR.description: Introduction to the interrelationship of visuals, sound, and editing in cinematic communication. Workshops in directing and producing. Individual and group projects.

CTPR.title: Directing in Documentary, Fiction and New Media
CTPR.description: Basic concepts of directing in new media, documentary and fictional narrative. Includes work with actors, documentary concepts, and creation of short new media projects.

CTPR.title: Cinematic Arts Laboratory
CTPR.description: The aesthetics and tools of the major disciplines of cinematic arts: producing, cinematography, sound, and editing.

CTPR.title: Intermediate Production
CTPR.description: Principles of visual and aural communication; idea development and realization using image, movement, pace, the spoken word and other sounds; small crew projects.

CTPR.title: Motion Picture Cinematography
CTPR.description: Use of high definition motion picture equipment to explore the fundamentals of shot design, movement and lighting.  In class group projects.

CTPR.title: Motion Picture Editing
CTPR.description: Theory, techniques, and practices in picture editing; use of standard editing equipment; individual projects.

CTPR.title: Creating the Motion Picture Sound Track
CTPR.description: Techniques and aesthetics for recording production sound, editing dialogue, sound effects, music, Foley and preparing for the mix. For film, television, and other media.

CTPR.title: Colloquium: Motion Picture Production Techniques
CTPR.description: Basic procedures and techniques applicable to production of all types of films; demonstration by production of a short film from conception to completion.

CTPR.title: Practicum in Podcast Production
CTPR.description: The practice of video podcast production and the skills to develop, produce, record and post original episodes. Podcast formats vary by semester.

CTPR.title: Visual Story and Communication
CTPR.description: How visuals communicate emotions and ideas in streaming media, videos, theatrical films and television for scripted and documentary storytelling.

CTPR.title: Trojan Vision, Live Television Production
CTPR.description: The practice of planning, producing and crewing for classic Trojan Vision television shows that live stream weekly from TV multicam studios.

CTPR.title: Game Show
CTPR.description: The practice of planning, producing and crewing for classic Trojan Vision television shows that live stream weekly from TV multicam studios.

CTPR.title: Live Sports Talk Show
CTPR.description: The practice of planning, producing and crewing for classic Trojan Vision television shows that live stream weekly from TV multicam studios.

CTPR.title: Making the Sports Documentary
CTPR.description: The practice of planning, producing and crewing for classic Trojan Vision television shows that live stream weekly from TV multicam studios.

CTPR.title: The Morning Brew
CTPR.description: The practice of planning, producing and crewing for classic Trojan Vision television shows that live stream weekly from TV multicam studios.

CTPR.title: Unscripted Romance: Producing the Dating Show
CTPR.description: The practice of planning, producing and crewing for classic Trojan Vision television shows that live stream weekly from TV multicam studios.

CTPR.title: The Entertainment Industry: From Idea to Audience
CTPR.description: An exploration of the worldwide media and content business and the roles and careers of the people who develop and monetize creative ideas and storytelling.

CTPR.title: Practicum in Editing
CTPR.description: Workshop in how editing can shape storytelling, using content from a variety of media and in various styles. Modern non-linear equipment and techniques.

CTPR.title: Makeup for Motion Pictures
CTPR.description: Lecture-laboratory in makeup relating it to mood of the story and emulsion of the camera stock.

CTPR.title: Introduction to Special Effects in Cinema
CTPR.description: Introductory workshop in the aesthetics and practices of special   effects, embracing both the classical and contemporary modes.

CTPR.title: Practicum in Cinematography
CTPR.description: Camera and lighting workshop in color cinematography, beginning with digital still photography and moving into 16mm and advanced digital cameras. In-class exercises.

CTPR.title: Production Planning
CTPR.description: Theory, discussion, and practical application of production planning during preproduction and production of a film.

CTPR.title: The Production Experience
CTPR.description: To provide students with basic working knowledge of both the  skills of the motion picture set and production operations through classroom lectures and hands-on experience.

CTPR.title: Introduction to Color Grading
CTPR.description: Exploration of the various aspects of color grading and how it can enhance storytelling.

CTPR.title: Practicum in Producing
CTPR.description: A comprehensive overview of the role of the producer. How projects are conceived, developed, packaged, financed and marketed.

CTPR.title: Practicum in Sound
CTPR.description: Aesthetic and technical skills of production and post-production sound necessary to create a motion picture soundtrack.

CTPR.title: The Capstone Project Crew Experience
CTPR.description: Assistant crew experience on a capstone project including specified weekends. Overview of roles and fundamental thinking typical of each craft.

CTPR.title: Acting for Film and Television
CTPR.description: Intensive examination of skills and techniques necessary for successful performances in film and television. Practical application through in-class exercises and assigned projects.

CTPR.title: Introduction to Art Direction
CTPR.description: Introduction to drafting, set design, set decoration and creating models for students with diverse abilities. Guest lectures, group discussions and hands-on workshop.

CTPR.title: Organizing Creativity: Entertainment Industry    Decision Making
CTPR.description: Analysis of the unique structures in the entertainment industry for organizing and managing creativity. Students research and chart pathways to leadership. Open only to juniors, seniors, and graduate students.

CTPR.title: Film Business Procedures and Distribution
CTPR.description: Financing, budgeting, management as applied to films; problems of distribution, including merchandising, cataloging, evaluation, and film library management.

CTPR.title: Practicum in Production Design
CTPR.description: Practical instruction in script breakdown, location surveys, traditional and computer-aided working drawings, model making, set decoration, construction and scenic departments.

CTPR.title: The Art of the Pitch
CTPR.description: Presenting ideas for feature and television projects to buyers: shaping ideas for pitching, assessing and targeting the marketplace, in-class pitching of projects.

CTPR.title: Spotting Music for Cinema
CTPR.description: A real world approach to spotting music for film: why film music exists and the many ways it is used in storytelling.  For filmmakers as well as composers.

CTPR.title: Documentary Production
CTPR.description: Pairs produce, direct, shoot, and edit a short documentary on a subject of their choice. Finished projects will be suitable for broadcast/festivals.

CTPR.title: Directing The Comedic Scene
CTPR.description: Directing comedy: casting, rehearsing, directing actors, scene analysis, staging, shooting, and editing, leading to the filming of a two-person comic scene

CTPR.title: Practicum in Directing
CTPR.description: Concepts of directing for motion pictures, emphasizing the working relationship of actors and directors. Scenes will be staged in class and filmed for class presentation.

CTPR.title: Development of Episodic TV Series
CTPR.description: Development of an original episodic television series. Episodes will be shot on stage and on location during the following semester.

CTPR.title: Advanced Production Workshop
CTPR.description: Directors, producers, cinematographers, editors and sound designers collaborate to produce, shoot, edit and deliver fictional, documentary or experimental projects.

CTPR.title: Straight to Series: Production of Episodic TV Drama
CTPR.description: Collaborative production and postproduction of an original episodic drama, shot on original sets on stage and on location.

CTPR.title: Music Video and Commercial Production
CTPR.description: Writing, budgeting, shooting, editing and directing a music video and commercial. Getting the job, dealing with the band, working with the record and advertising companies.

CTPR.title: Fundamentals of Directing
CTPR.description: Introductory directing course, emphasizing collaboration, working  with actors, camera techniques and storytelling through filmed  exercises to develop foundational skills in cinematic  communication and visual narrative.

CTPR.title: Visual Expression
CTPR.description: Exploring the relationship between story structure and visual structure, discussion of aesthetics and technical controls, in-class examples and screenings, photographic assignments.

CTPR.title: Production I
CTPR.description: The effective communication of ideas through the language of cinema. Individual and small group exercises; introductions to producing, directing, editing, cinematography and sound.

CTPR.title: Production II
CTPR.description: Practicum in group production, emphasizing the collaborative process and the expressive use of sound and image.

CTPR.title: Realtime CG Filmmaking
CTPR.description: Introduction to the software necessary to create previs, pitchvis, CG films and quick experiments to practice creativity without being on set.

CTPR.title: Virtual Production
CTPR.description: Collaboration on projects using motion-tracking technology to raise the CG production value and realize the vision of previously produced animatics.

CTPR.title: Planning the Documentary Production
CTPR.description: A preproduction workshop for the research and planning of a documentary project to be executed in CTPR 547 or an advanced production workshop class. Prerequisite: CTPR 508.

CTPR.title: Intermediate Directing
CTPR.description: Practical experience in staging dramatic narrative scenes,  emphasizing directing actors, rehearsal techniques and camera  blocking.

CTPR.title: Directing AI: Future Filmmaking
CTPR.description: Practicum in more complex directing issues concentrating both on performance and exploration of shaping scenes visually through blocking of action and placement of camera.

CTPR.title: Intermediate Editing
CTPR.description: Editorial construction of sequences to analyze the interrelationships of the various film elements, both visual and aural.

CTPR.title: Intermediate Cinematography
CTPR.description: Close study through practical in class exercises of the technical and aesthetic principles of cinematography. Introduction to 16mm film and advanced digital cameras.

CTPR.title: Intermediate Producing
CTPR.description: Definition, examination and practical experience in the role of the line producer as it relates to preproduction, production and post production.

CTPR.title: Virtual Production in LED Volumes
CTPR.description: Introduces filmmaking in LED volumes, blending cutting-edge technology with cinematic arts. Students engage in hands-on exercises and creative collaboration, laying the groundwork for future virtual production exploration.

CTPR.title: Production III, Fiction
CTPR.description: An intensive workshop experience in which students, crewing in their area of specialization, complete the shooting and postproduction of projects up to 12 minutes in length. Qualifying courses: for directors, CTPR 532, and for cinematographers, CTPR 537;

CTPR.title: Production III, Documentary
CTPR.description: Intensive workshop; students shoot and finish documentary projects up to about 25 minutes. Qualifying courses: for directors, CTPR 431 or CTPR 531; for cinematographers, CTPR 424 or CTPR 537.

CTPR.title: Advanced Directing
CTPR.description: An advanced production class in directing. Encounters with         experienced directors; and individual student production of a      short. Recommended Preparation: CTPR 533.

CTPR.title: Advanced Sound
CTPR.description: Study of the technical and aesthetic elements of sound design at the professional level. Intended for those contemplating a career in the field of audio. Prerequisite: CTPR 540 or CTPR 546 or CTPR 547.

CTPR.title: Advanced Professional Editing Tools and Software
CTPR.description: Advanced editing tools for picture editors, picture editing assistants, DIT, post supervisors and VFX editors, including AVID, After Effects, Photoshop, Scriptsync, Davinci Resolve and more.

CTPR.title: Advanced Cinematography
CTPR.description: Advanced camera and lighting techniques for those considering a professional career in cinematography.

CTPR.title: Advanced Producing
CTPR.description: Defines and examines the role of the Executive/Feature Producer through the preproduction, production and post production phases. Prerequisites: CTPR-538 or one of the following in equivalent crew position: CTPR 486, CTPR 546, CTPR 547.

CTPR.title: Making Media for Social Change
CTPR.description: Each student will produce and direct a film incorporating a social issue of his/her choice into the narrative of the film. Prerequisites: CTPR 310 or CTPR 508.

CTPR.title: The Pitch Class: Film and TV
CTPR.description: Developing, pitching and selling your feature motion picture and TV projects.

CTPR.title: Developing and Producing the Advanced Project
CTPR.description: An advanced preproduction workshop in which students complete the development and production planning of an advanced project to be executed in CTPR 581, CTPR 582 or CTPR 587a.

CTPR.title: Individual Production Workshop
CTPR.description: Individual experimental projects involving the creative use of visuals (live action or animated) and sound. Qualifying courses: CTPR 532 (for directors); CTPR 558 (for producers). Graded IP/Letter.

CTPR.title: Individual Production Workshop
CTPR.description: Individual experimental projects involving the creative use of visuals (live action or animated) and sound. Graded IP/Letter.

CTPR.title: Individual Production Workshop
CTPR.description: Individual experimental projects involving the creative use of visuals (live action or animated) and sound. Graded IP/Letter.

CTPR.title: Individual Production Workshop
CTPR.description: Individual experimental projects involving the creative use of visuals (live action or animated) and sound. Graded IP/Letter.

CTPR.title: Advanced Production Seminar
CTPR.description: Advanced individual film or video projects under the guidance of a faculty mentor, without benefit of university equipment or resources. Qualifying courses: CTPR 532 (for directors); CTPR 558 (for producers). Graded IP/Letter.

CTPR.title: Advanced Production Seminar
CTPR.description: Advanced individual film or video projects under the guidance of a faculty mentor, without benefit of university equipment or resources. Graded IP/Letter.

CTPR.title: Advanced Production Seminar
CTPR.description: Advanced individual film or video projects under the guidance of a faculty mentor, without benefit of university equipment or resources.  Open to Production students only.

CTPR.title: Advanced Producing Project
CTPR.description: Supervised, individual study leading to the creation of a producer's package. The package will include script, schedule, budget, finance and marketing plan. Graded IP/Letter.

CTPR.title: Advanced Producing Project
CTPR.description: Supervised, individual study leading to the creation of a producer's package. The package will include script, schedule, budget, finance and marketing plan. Graded IP/Letter.

CTPR.title: Advanced Producing Project
CTPR.description: Supervised, individual study leading to the creation of a producer's package. The package will include script, schedule, budget, finance and marketing plan. Graded IP/Letter.

CTPR.title: Group Production Workshop
CTPR.description: Advanced group project involving the creative use of visuals (live action or animated) and sound specifically designed for students who want to work in pairs. Qualifying courses: CTPR 532 (for directors); CTPR 558 (for producers).

CTPR.title: Group Production Workshop
CTPR.description: Advanced group project involving the creative use of visuals (live action or animated) and sound specifically designed for students who want to work in pairs.

CTPR.title: Group Production Workshop
CTPR.description: Advanced group project involving the creative use of visuals (live action or animated) and sound specifically designed for students who want to work in pairs.

CTPR.title: Group Production Workshop
CTPR.description: Advanced group project involving the creative use of visuals (live action or animated) and sound specifically designed for students who want to work in pairs.

COMM.title: Communication and Social Science
COMM.description: Social scientific inquiry into human communication; core theories  of message production and reception in interpersonal, group and    organizational contexts.

COMM.title: Public Speaking
COMM.description: Principles and practices of effective oral communication; analysis  of the speaking-listening process; selection and organization of  speech materials; use of new presentation technologies.

COMM.title: Communication Practicum
COMM.description: Students address communication issues in a field setting. They will evaluate communication practices using appropriate methodology. Projects are jointly evaluated by internship supervisor and professor. Sophomore standing. Graded: CR/NC. Not for major credit for Communication majors.

COMM.title: Communication and Culture
COMM.description: Examines cultural institutions, ideologies, artifacts, and productions; role of culture in everyday life; cultural studies as methodology; culture and power.

COMM.title: Communication and Media Economics
COMM.description: Economic and political economic principles for the analysis of communication and media industries including broadcasting, newspapers, motion pictures, music, video games, advertising and public relations.

COMM.title: Entertainment, Communication and Society
COMM.description: Theoretical foundation for understanding the construction, consumption, and consequences of entertainment from classical to contemporary times; situates entertainment within the ecology of information and communication.

COMM.title: Empirical Research in Communication
COMM.description: Experimental and survey methods for communication study; basic statistical concepts, procedures, and tests.

COMM.title: Understanding Social Science Research
COMM.description: Students learn to be consumers rather than creators of social science research. Examines the challenges and opportunities of communicating research through mass media.

COMM.title: Communication and Technology
COMM.description: Cultural, social, political, and economic dynamics of communication technologies, including internet architecture, social media, participatory cultures, privacy, surveillance, networked journalism, big data, algorithms, online activism.

COMM.title: Media and Society
COMM.description: Interplay between media and society, including family and children's socialization, inter-group relations and community, pornography and violence, gender and race, media ethics, conduct of politics.

COMM.title: Communication and Publics
COMM.description: Forms of civic life; opportunities and obstacles in forming, participating in, and disrupting community; issues of knowledge, power, identity; theories/methods of rhetorical analysis and production.

COMM.title: Communication and Social Media
COMM.description: Social media within the broader social, political, and historical contexts; key themes include labor, Web 2.0, self-branding, celebrity, participation, privacy, online shaming, and activism.

COMM.title: Argumentation and Advocacy
COMM.description: Basic argumentation theory including analysis.  Research and  evidence, case construction, refutation; discursive and visual argument; diverse fields of advocacy including law, politics,  organizations, interpersonal relations.

COMM.title: Intercultural Communication
COMM.description: Cultural variables and social psychological processes that influence intercultural interaction; relationship between communication and culture in diverse settings including business, medicine, and education.

COMM.title: Communication Technology and Culture
COMM.description: This course examines philosophies and popular representations of  technology from the origins of western culture to the present and  identifies the complex attitudes toward technology.

COMM.title: The Cultures of New Media
COMM.description: Cultural implications of computer-mediated communication and       related media. Ideological responses to media innovation; debates  over artificial intelligence, virtual communities, and virtual     reality. Recommended preparation: COMM 339.

COMM.title: Advertising and Communication
COMM.description: Advertising as a mode of communication; US advertising history and institutions; economic and policy contexts (domestic and global); critical analysis of advertising texts

COMM.title: Los Angeles: Communication and Culture
COMM.description: Representations of Los Angeles communicated in diverse media; the city as a rhetorical text; analysis of cultural identities, art, architecture and representations in popular culture.

COMM.title: Media Consumption
COMM.description: Theoretical approaches to the study of media consumption and  audiences; examines international media and consumption practices;  explores new media's impact on consumption.

COMM.title: Public Diplomacy and Global Citizenship
COMM.description: Introduces public diplomacy as a central feature of contemporary international relations and challenges students to locate themselves as both its target and practitioners.

COMM.title: Business and Professional Communication
COMM.description: Oral and written communication skills demanded in the workplace including informative and persuasive speeches; interviewing; team communication; and training material preparation. Recommended preparation: COMM 204

COMM.title: Forensics Laboratory
COMM.description: Directed individual research studies of contemporary problems. Supervised laboratory experience. Open only to members of the University debate squad.

COMM.title: Sports, Business and Media in Today's Society
COMM.description: An inside look at the important stories, topical issues, trends and historical developments related to the growing influence of business and media on college and professional sports; identifying the key components and meeting the influencers in class that help shape the business side of sports, while recognizing the role the media plays in providing daily coverage across multiple platforms.

COMM.title: Sports, Communication and Culture
COMM.description: Rhetorical and critical approaches to sports and public discourse;  application to sports organizations, the news and popular media;  representations of gender and race in sports.

COMM.title: Interpreting Popular Culture
COMM.description: Popular culture as an indicator of cultural values, a producer and reflection of cultural meaning, and a means of communication; theory and case studies.

COMM.title: Organizational Communication
COMM.description: How communication processes both create organizations and are constrained by them. Theory and research into topics such as culture, technology, power, leadership and decision-making in a variety of organizational contexts.

COMM.title: Sports and Social Change
COMM.description: Application of critical, sociological and rhetorical theories to sports events and sport media; examination of the role of sports in enacting social change.

COMM.title: Gender, Media and Communication
COMM.description: Issues of gender in communication, including: mediarepresentations of femininity and masculinity; and gender's rolein communication at the interpersonal, public, and cultural levels.

COMM.title: Crooked Studies of K-pop: The Case of G-Dragon
COMM.description: Advanced readings in communication theory and research (broadly defined); specialized interest areas of individual faculty on the frontiers of knowledge; seminar topics change each semester.

COMM.title: From the Ground Up: Communicating About Food
COMM.description: Explores food communication as a facilitator of human interaction and cultural diplomacy; controversies regarding food production/consumption; and evolution of food entertainment programming.

COMM.title: Communicating About Sex
COMM.description: Communicating with partners, friends, parents and health care professionals about sexual behavior; interpersonal and mediated contexts; understanding of sexual scripts; current theory and research.

COMM.title: Religion, Media and Hollywood: Faith in TV
COMM.description: How religion, ethics and spirituality are embedded, embodied and emplotted in television drama; how secular texts represent "lived religion" to increasingly diverse audiences.

COMM.title: The Internet, Economy and Society
COMM.description: Examines the effects of the Internet on communication industries, the economy, economic policy, and on social, political and cultural practices.

COMM.title: Music as Communication
COMM.description: Examines music's unique characteristics as a communicative form and the cultural, economic, political and social influences in music interpretation and production.

COMM.title: Podcasting: Origin Stories
COMM.description: A foundational understanding of the historic, cultural and theoretical underpinning of the podcast medium with an emphasis on critical listening.

COMM.title: Critical Theories of Sport
COMM.description: Focuses on critical theories that examine social and political roles of sport in society and how these roles play out in media and broadcast platforms.

COMM.title: Visual Communication and Social Change
COMM.description: Analysis of photography's evolution; new strategies for the photographic image, photo documentary work and global social issues; analysis of images on blogs and Websites.

COMM.title: Entertainment, Marketing and Culture
COMM.description: Explores blurring of entertainment, marketing and culture in advanced information economies; intersections of culture and media and their social ramifications.

COMM.title: Gender and the News Media
COMM.description: Gender and news media evolving images of women and men in print and electronic media.  Impact of gender in content and style of news, television and cinema.  Open to non-majors.

COMM.title: Campaign Communication
COMM.description: Problems in political communication: creating an informed electorate, use of mass media, factors in voter persuasion. Guest experts in political analysis, opinion polling, communication evaluation.

COMM.title: Directed Research
COMM.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduatecredit. Available to juniors and seniors only.

COMM.title: Research Practicum
COMM.description: Students gain research experience in the design, implementation,  analysis, and reporting of communication research.  Students serve  as research assistants to faculty members.  Not available for  graduate credit.

COMM.title: Honors Thesis
COMM.description: Writing of the honors thesis. Not available for graduate credit.

COMM.title: Body, Justice and the Planet
COMM.description: Selected topics in communication.

COMM.title: Help Yourself: Self-Help & the Wellness Industry
COMM.description: Selected topics in communication.

COMM.title: The Illusion of Inclusion: Why Hollywood's Efforts Have Resulted in Little Change
COMM.description: Selected topics in communication.

COMM.title: Social Movements as Rhetorical Form
COMM.description: Study of the rhetoric of social change; methodologies for         analysis and appraisal; investigation of specific collective       protest and reform movements.  Not open to M.A. in Communication  Management majors.

COMM.title: Humanistic and Social Scientific Approaches to Human Communication I
COMM.description: Overview of humanistic and social scientific approaches to the     study of communication; emphasis on rhetorical/critical and macro  social scientific perspectives. Not open to M.A. in Communication  Management majors.

COMM.title: Quantitative Research Methods in Communication
COMM.description: Epistemological assumptions, design, and beginning methods of quantitative analysis in communication research.

COMM.title: Social Value: Research Seminar on Networked Social Influence
COMM.description: Theory and practice of social value, the measurement of peoples impact on each other; collaboration on analysis and creation of articles for conferences and journals.

COMM.title: Human-AI Interaction
COMM.description: The impact of AI-powered technology on human interaction, examining how related theories, research and design practices co-evolve with technological advancement.

COMM.title: Advanced Applied AI for Digital Media Product Development
COMM.description: A culmination of foundational training in communication, data science and machine learning. Building AI solutions for digital media and product development.

COMM.title: Directed Research
COMM.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the school. Graded CR/NC.

COMM.title: Global Media Industries
COMM.description: Conduct research, design and produce a group-based research report and website to assess disruption within Global Media Industries over the past year or two.

COMM.title: Global Communication Thesis
COMM.description: Conduct original or revised global media and communication research thesis projects for submission to academic journals and conferences.

COMM.title: Experiential Course: Promoting i-dle in the U.S.
Meta-Analysis in Health Communication
COMM.description: Learning how to conduct (and write up) a meta-analysis using comprehensive meta-analysis software tools to enter and analyze data for meta-analysis.

COMM.title: Identity, Embodiment, and Data
COMM.description: Current problems in communication theory and research; advanced, specialized interest areas of individual faculty on the frontiers of knowledge.

COMM.title: Virtual Qualitative Research Methods
COMM.description: Current problems in communication theory and research; advanced, specialized interest areas of individual faculty on the frontiers of knowledge.

COMM.title: Communication Networks
COMM.description: Conceptual and analytic issues in network perspectives; emphasis on communication patterns, processes, content, influences and impacts.

COMM.title: Experimental and Quasi-Experimental Designs
COMM.description: Advantages and drawbacks to experimental designs and quasi experimental designs for social research and theory building. Emphasis on how to design and report experiments.

COMM.title: Critical Theories of Race and Culture
COMM.description: Examines the historical emergence of ideas about race, modernity and colonialism and the role of culture in shaping how we understand race today.

COMM.title: Economic Cultures
COMM.description: Explores and analyzes the interaction between culture and economy by observing different types of economic practices.

COMM.title: Independent Study
COMM.description: A supervised course tailored to specific student interests. The professor and student develop a syllabus that permits exploration of advanced or specialized topics. Graded CR/NC.

COMM.title: Preliminary Research Paper
COMM.description: Independent research designed to demonstrate the student's ability to conceptualize, conduct, and present scholarly research.         Parallel to COMM 794. Graded CR/NC.

COMM.title: Research
COMM.description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

COMM.title: Doctoral Dissertation
COMM.description: Credit on acceptance of dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC.

COMM.title: Doctoral Dissertation
COMM.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC.

COMM.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC.

COMM.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC.

COMM.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC.

ASCJ.title: Navigating Media and News in the Digital Age
ASCJ.description: Students will be engaged as discriminating media/news consumers and contributors. Emphasis on critical skills needed to understand, employ, enjoy and help shape our media landscape.

ASCJ.title: Contours of Change in Media and Communication
ASCJ.description: Provides an introduction to cultivating a curious, critical, and proactive approach to the challenges of social change. Students will be encouraged to develop an expansive and critical definition and understanding of change as it relates to the role of media and communication in producing and responding to political and cultural transformations that shape our status as citizens and our ideas of citizenship.

JOUR.title: The Power and Responsibility of the Press
JOUR.description: Explores the role of journalism and social media in society - its influence on government, technology, business, national security, sports, science and entertainment.

JOUR.title: Culture of Journalism: Past, Present and Future
JOUR.description: Understanding key moments, debates and ideas that have shaped journalism in the United States from the Revolutionary War period through today.  Examination of the social, cultural, political and technological aspects of journalism and its impact on the profession and public service.

JOUR.title: Journalism Practicum
JOUR.description: Field experience in journalism, public relations, or related field.

JOUR.title: Reporting and Writing Practicum
JOUR.description: Report, write and distribute in-depth stories for diverse audiences; enhance understanding of news judgment; develop and maintain sources; engage communities through field reporting.

JOUR.title: Reporting and Writing I
JOUR.description: Provides students with foundational skills to report, write and produce journalism content across multiple platforms, including broadcast, digital and text.

JOUR.title: Basics of News Production for Non-Majors
JOUR.description: Introduction to television, radio, and/or digital news production. Examination of issues in journalism. Graded CR/NC.

JOUR.title: Reporting and Writing II
JOUR.description: Report, write, produce and distribute in-depth stories produced off beats on multiple platforms for diverse audiences; enhance understanding of news judgment; develop and maintain sources; engage communities through field reporting and emerging digital tools.

JOUR.title: Introduction to Coding for Storytelling
JOUR.description: Introduction to basic web technologies; conceive, design, code and produce an advanced multimedia story package.

JOUR.title: Visual Journalism
JOUR.description: Video for digital platforms, principles of photography, design for web and mobile platforms. Introduction to principles of digital news design, interactivity and presentation in interactive storytelling.

JOUR.title: Introduction to Investigative and Data Journalism
JOUR.description: Reportorial and analytical skills and techniques required for portraying and evaluating contemporary newsworthy events using basic data journalism techniques and tools for statistical analysis.

JOUR.title: Photojournalism
JOUR.description: Emphasis on fundamental skills necessary for photojournalism  including camera techniques, story ideas and digital darkroom.

JOUR.title: Rewriting History: Reporting Rome
JOUR.description: Develop reporting skills by studying historical unsolved Italian crimes. Visit crime scenes, examine evidence, interview sources, analyze media reports and write articles for each crime.

JOUR.title: Introduction to Sports Media
JOUR.description: Highlight norms, routines of content, including print, broadcast, video. Focus on opportunities, constraints posed by roles of reporters, fans, players, publicists, agents, leagues, teams.

JOUR.title: Engaging Diverse Communities
JOUR.description: Explores how to engage diverse local communities through participatory journalism and communication strategies. Focuses on using digital tools to increase engagement with communities via field reporting and mobile platforms to produce stories across platforms.

JOUR.title: Sports, Business and Media in Today's Society
JOUR.description: An inside look at the important stories, topical issues, trends and historical developments related to the growing influence of business and media on college and professional sports; identifying the key components and meeting the influencers in class that help shape the business side of sports, while recognizing the role the media plays in providing daily coverage across multiple platforms.

JOUR.title: Entertainment, Business and Media in Today's Society
JOUR.description: An examination of the symbiotic relationship of the entertainment  business and the media; press coverage of the entertainment  industry; Hollywood's relationship with news media.

JOUR.title: Television News and Sports Production
JOUR.description: Production of television news and sports programs while developing video, writing and communication skills and managing content in collaboration with others under deadline pressure.

JOUR.title: Produce and Host Sports Content in Studio A
JOUR.description: Interview, present and design sports segments for television/video in Studio A.

JOUR.title: Non-Fiction Television
JOUR.description: Presentation and selection in non-fiction television programs including documentaries, electronic magazines and news series; ethical problems, field research, reporting, interviewing, pre-production.

JOUR.title: Radio Storytelling and Podcasts
JOUR.description: Techniques for audio journalism, including effective use of sound, art of the interview, writing for the ear and crafting stories to engage listeners.

JOUR.title: Podcasting: Origin Stories
JOUR.description: A foundational understanding of the historic, cultural and theoretical underpinning of the podcast medium with an emphasis on critical listening.

JOUR.title: Advanced Digital Media Storytelling
JOUR.description: Production of a well-reported advanced multimedia package, with a blend of text, audio, video, photos, navigation and interactivity; final projects will be published by the Annenberg Media Center.

JOUR.title: Writing the Film Review
JOUR.description: Techniques of writing the film review; preparation and treatment of form and content; problems, responsibilities and ethics of film reviewing.

JOUR.title: Sports Commentary
JOUR.description: Techniques of reporting and writing sports columns and commentary for print, video, radio and Web-based media.

JOUR.title: Writing Magazine Non-Fiction
JOUR.description: A seminar in "how to" interview, research, write -- and place -- professional quality articles for a full range of magazines/newspapers including women's, sports, ethnic, local and national.

JOUR.title: Sports Reporting
JOUR.description: News and feature coverage of sporting events, including social and economic factors influencing sports in America.

JOUR.title: Reporting on Race
JOUR.description: Examines how journalism shapes and reflects racial dynamics, equipping students to ethically cover race and justice issues with historical, theoretical and practical frameworks.

JOUR.title: Entertainment Reporting
JOUR.description: Techniques of reporting and writing about the entertainment business, economics and finances. Analysis of the skills and background needed for reporters specializing in this area of the news.

JOUR.title: Arts Reporting
JOUR.description: Techniques of reporting and writing about the arts, including television, film, theatre, music, graphic arts, architecture and design.

JOUR.title: Food of Our Families
JOUR.description: Tell stories that explore food culture and culinary traditions, become familiar with cultural areas of Los Angeles and become immersed in global food and culture.

JOUR.title: Law of Mass Communication
JOUR.description: Press law; government controls on the news media; legal responsibilities of the journalist.

JOUR.title: Experiential Journalism in Latin America
JOUR.description: Embedded reporting experience in partnership with a media outlet, partner university or other organization focuses on ongoing or current issues in Latin America.

JOUR.title: Gender and the News Media
JOUR.description: Gender and news media evolving images of women and men in print and electronic media.  Impact of gender in content and style of news, television and cinema.  Open to non-majors.

JOUR.title: Print and Digital Design for 21st Century Storytelling
JOUR.description: Art, typography, and other graphic elements in publication design; traditional, contemporary, and advanced production methods, processes, and equipment; representative examples; practice in design.

JOUR.title: Sports and Media Technology
JOUR.description: Examine and analyze the ever-changing technology sector of the sports business and sports media worlds. Identify emerging technologies being developed in the sports industry and how they are being utilized to enhance the fan experience.

JOUR.title: Directed Research
JOUR.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

JOUR.title: Honors Seminar
JOUR.description: Intensive study of a subject of contemporary relevance or of professional importance to journalists and public relations practitioners.

JOUR.title: Creating with AI: Multimedia Tools for Journalism
JOUR.description: Selected topics in journalism.

JOUR.title: Data Tools for Journalists
JOUR.description: Selected topics in journalism.

JOUR.title: Advanced Interpretive Writing
JOUR.description: Analysis and writing of editorials, essays, Op-Ed page articles, profiles, and other shorter forms of journalism, combined with study of historic practitioners of those forms.

JOUR.title: Advanced Investigative Reporting
JOUR.description: Advanced reportorial and analytical skills and techniques required for evaluating newsworthy events. Group research and publication of stories on important current topics.

JOUR.title: Video Documentary Production
JOUR.description: Production of video documentary including research and reporting techniques, writing, interviewing, field work, editing, legal issues, economics, aesthetics, balanced presentation, ethics, diversity and production problems.

JOUR.title: Advanced Video Reporting
JOUR.description: Reporting, production and writing for broadcast and other video platforms; practical experience; role of the video broadcast journalist; similarities and differences between media.

JOUR.title: This California Life: Storytelling for Radio and Podcasting
JOUR.description: Advanced production techniques for public radio-style reports: writing, sound, editing, narrative voice. Techniques applicable for broadcast features or Web audio documentaries.

JOUR.title: Advanced Disruption: Innovation with Emerging Technology
JOUR.description: Apply emerging technologies to tell innovative stories based on a production trip during spring break.

JOUR.title: Foreign Affairs Reporting
JOUR.description: News stories analyzed, researched, and critiqued for validity and background; projects to include editorials, news stories, magazine articles or broadcast reports.

JOUR.title: Digital Investigations II: OSINT Reporting Lab
JOUR.description: Advanced techniques in open-source investigations and investigative reporting. Group research and publication of stories on important current topics grounded in digital investigations.

JOUR.title: The Art of (Macro) Food Journalism: A Global View
JOUR.description: Food is a powerful lens for thinking about cities, community, climate, technology, culture - even our relationship to other species. Focus is on the global.

JOUR.title: Reporting on Entertainment and Popular Culture
JOUR.description: Reporting about entertainment, popular culture and their impact on American society; survey of past media coverage and current practices.

JOUR.title: Journalism Internship
JOUR.description: Field experience in journalism, public relations, or related field.

JOUR.title: Reporting on Race and Justice
JOUR.description: Develop the skills, critical thinking and expertise to report on the ongoing struggles over race, equality and justice in America.

JOUR.title: Specialized Reporting: Religion
JOUR.description: Reporting and writing on religion; survey of world religion, religion and public life-including politics, gender and science.

JOUR.title: Directed Research
JOUR.description: Research leading to the Master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

JOUR.title: Arts Criticism and Commentary
JOUR.description: Writing workshops and independent fieldwork; development of critical skills to write socially valuable criticism and commentary about art, entertainment and culture.

JOUR.title: Master's Thesis
JOUR.description: Credit on acceptance of thesis.

JOUR.title: Follow the Money: Business and Economics
JOUR.description: Reporting and writing on business, economics and public finance; students produce a series of professional projects for publication.

JOUR.title: Journalism Capstone Project
JOUR.description: Production of a journalism capstone project with multimedia elements for a master's degree. Projects can be single stand-alone pieces, or series of pieces.

DSM.title: Introduction to Digital Social Media
DSM.description: Explores the sector of digital social media and online communities, with a focus on user experience, social impact, strategic content creation and models for success.

DSM.title: Managing Technologies for Digital Media
DSM.description: Strategies and decision-making for development and management of online sites, mobile apps and social platforms, including search optimization, monetization, product development and user experience testing.

DSM.title: The Future of Advertising: AdTech Innovations and AI Trends
DSM.description: Programmatic advertising, adtech and AI trends through hands-on digital marketing projects with real clients, media dollars, ad platforms and student team-led client partnership.

DSM.title: Brand Strategy for Digital Media
DSM.description: Exploration of the essential art of branding in the digital age; building relationships between consumers and brands

DSM.title: Analytics and Research Methodology
DSM.description: Teaches the use and interpretation of digital analytics as well as the use of research design, methodology, and basic statistics for digital sites and apps.

DSM.title: Digital Social Media Internship
DSM.description: Integration of practical experiences with academic learning to apply digital media strategies, design and innovation in creating impactful solutions, fostering critical thinking and problem-solving skills.

DSM.title: Final Project Capstone
DSM.description: Students produce a working site, app or embedded social platform project with digital/multimedia elements. Development includes pitching, conceptualization and launching of the final project.

DSM.title: Algorithmic Influence: AI, Search, Content and Social Medial in the Digital Age
DSM.description: Special Topics in Digital Social Media.

DSM.title: Leveraging Social Media for Social Impact
DSM.description: Special Topics in Digital Social Media.

DSM.title: Podcasting for Brand Building
DSM.description: Special Topics in Digital Social Media.

DSM.title: Streaming Entertainment: Innovation and Disruption in        Culture, Technology and Business
DSM.description: Special Topics in Digital Social Media.

PR.title: Effective Writing for Strategic Public Relations and Adverti
PR.description: Focus on the unique writing requirements of social, online, broadcast, print and other media in public relations/advertising; emphasis on judgment, context and audience understanding. Non-majors who are interested in enrolling must have at least a 2.5 GPA.

PR.title: Strategic Public Relations and Advertising: An Introduction
PR.description: Strategies/practices in the growing field of public relations and advertising, including landmark cases, campaign planning; special emphasis on historical roots, current and future practice.

PR.title: Introduction to Advertising
PR.description: History and development of advertising; basic advertising campaigns showing relationships of marketing, creative, print and electronic media.

PR.title: Multichannel Strategy and Content Creation
PR.description: Introduction to media relations, social media and influencer engagement; intensive writing and creating multimedia content for traditional, emerging and social media.

PR.title: Public Relations Media and Content for Non-Majors
PR.description: Learn advanced public relations writing and editing, basic design skills and sophisticated video planning, shooting, editing and production skills.

PR.title: Practicum for PR Media Center
PR.description: A hands-on learning lab, exploring how to create original social media content while adhering to media production cycle.

PR.title: London Calling: Public Relations in the UK Hub
PR.description: Examines how politics affects and influences public relations campaigns in the UK and Europe.

PR.title: Structured Inquiry in Public Relations and Advertising
PR.description: Apply contemporary research methods to create actionable insights for integrated, multi-channel communication campaigns, including social media monitoring, measurement and evaluation.

PR.title: Business and Economic Foundations of Public Relations and Ad
PR.description: Relationship between public relations/advertising and other organizational disciplines; understanding business goals and objectives; economic literacy; financial/investor relations; how PR/communication agencies are built and managed.

PR.title: Integrated Media Planning and Buying
PR.description: Fundamentals of media planning and buying across traditional and new media; how each media channel works independently and as part of an integrated media plan.

PR.title: Advertising Campaign Construction
PR.description: Develop an integrated marketing communication campaign that will compete against other universities in the national Collegiate Effie competition.

PR.title: Advertising Copywriting
PR.description: Master the art of advertising copywriting. Develop breakthrough concepts and craft compelling campaigns across all media channels. Transform creativity into strategic impact.

PR.title: Building Integrated Campaigns
PR.description: In-depth study of methods for planning, managing and evaluating strategic communication campaigns; critical analysis of contemporary cases; development of campaigns for real world clients.

PR.title: Public Relations in Entertainment
PR.description: Public relations in the design, promotion, and presentation of popular entertainment, including films, broadcasting, music, expositions, amusement parks, resorts and arenas.

PR.title: Sports Public Relations
PR.description: Introduction to the field of sports information and promotion, including lectures, media assignments, role-playing, and presentations by sports professionals.

PR.title: The Role of Celebrity in Public Relations
PR.description: Understanding of the history and application of celebrity in public relations, focusing on the entertainment industry and the notoriety attached to politics and the media.

PR.title: Political Public Relations and Advocacy
PR.description: Application of public relations principles to the context of political campaigns; emphasis on message development and delivery; relationship between candidate, news media, and electorate.

PR.title: Advanced Lifestyle Public Relations
PR.description: In-depth look at various aspects of Lifestyle PR with special emphasis on food, fashion and beauty, travel/tourism, hospitality, furniture/housewares, toys and more.

PR.title: Social Media Analytics: Data, Content Creation and Campaign
PR.description: Application of monitoring tools to become social media analysts and real-time content creators; interpretation of large data sets drawn from the social web; understanding of how to present data visually for optimal impact.

PR.title: Multimedia PR Content: Introduction to Digital Design Tools
PR.description: Hands-on lab; producing multimedia content; basic principles of design; tools and techniques to create digital images and layouts.

PR.title: Multimedia PR Content: Introduction to Audio/Video Tools
PR.description: Hands-on lab; audio/video tools for conceiving, shooting, editing, delivering and archiving compelling stories for online audiences; personal brand building; digital storytelling trends and applications.

PR.title: Directed Research
PR.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

PR.title: Fan Relations
PR.description: Examines fan relationships and explores fan activation strategies across sports, television, motion pictures, music, comic books, theme parks, social media and more.

PR.title: Personal Branding
PR.description: Learn to build, promote and manage a personal brand through critical analysis, case study, interactive interpretation and creative problem solving.

PR.title: Public Relations Honors Seminar
PR.description: Leadership workshop inspires students to be braver and more creative; encourages them to discover their leadership potential/explore new challenges inside and outside of classroom.

PR.title: Advertising, PR & Content for A Global Sports Property
PR.description: Selected topics in public relations.

PR.title: AI Tools for PR and Advertising
PR.description: Selected topics in public relations.

PR.title: The Power of the Pitch -- Big Asks and Public Speaking for a Better Futurre
PR.description: Selected topics in public relations.

PR.title: Public Policy Communication
PR.description: Study and evaluation of communications campaigns by civil society actors to influence public policy with a focus on messaging and efforts to shape news coverage.

PR.title: Advanced Audience Insight Mining
PR.description: Provides student training with cutting-edge digital research methods and applied data analytic skills relevant to current and future public relations and advertising practices.

PR.title: Multimedia Content Creation for Brand Storytelling I
PR.description: Covers the conceptualization and creation of strategy-based, engaging, primarily web-based multimedia content for use by organizations of all types.

PR.title: Business and Economic Foundations for Communicators
PR.description: Speaking the language of the board room; understanding business goals and objectives; economic literacy; financial/investor relations;  understanding organizational disciplines and how they relate to corporate communication; PR/communication business processes and management.

PR.title: Social Value: Research Seminar on Networked Social Influence
PR.description: Theory and practice of social value, the measurement of peoples impact on each other; collaboration on analysis and creation of articles for conferences and journals.

PR.title: Corporate Public Relations and Reputation
PR.description: Learn all aspects of corporate communications and reputation management through real-time news analysis, cases and senior guest speakers from the world's largest, most admired companies.

PR.title: Crisis Management in Strategic Public Relations
PR.description: Focuses on theories, concepts and practices in risk assessment, issues monitoring, and crisis anticipation/management in a wide variety of organizational contexts, and from multiple perspectives.

PR.title: Directed Research
PR.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

PR.title: Improvisational Leadership
PR.description: Leadership workshop inspires stepping outside of comfort zones to be braver and more creative.  Encourages discovery of leadership potential by exploring new ideas and challenges.

CMGT.title: Communication Management Pro-Seminar
CMGT.description: Theories, core concepts and practice in management of communication; analysis based on cases, structured and semi-structured data, historical research and participant observation.

CMGT.title: Communication in Work Settings
CMGT.description: How work settings impact communication: social structures of communication, organizational culture, socialization, feedback, dissent and adaptation. Applications for all working professionals.

CMGT.title: Influential Communication in the Marketplace
CMGT.description: Promotional messages as both creative expressions and agents for  behavioral change; application of social science theories of  persuasion and compliance in interpersonal and mass-media venues.

CMGT.title: Communication and Persuasion
CMGT.description: Theory and research on persuasion, value and attitude formation and change;  implication for communication and behavior in various market and professional contexts.

CMGT.title: Communication Ethics for New Media and Technology
CMGT.description: Ethics for new media and technology. Leverages case studies, historical analysis, observational analysis. Equips data-oriented communication practitioners to be ethical stewards of data.

CMGT.title: Analytical Tools for Communication Decisions
CMGT.description: Measurement and advanced data gathering and statistical analyses; data mining; data model formulation for prediction. Statistical inferences for and effective communication about solutions.

CMGT.title: Communication in the Luxury Fashion Industry
CMGT.description: Examines luxury fashion marketing communication, focusing on connecting with the audience. Topics include history of the industry, media channels, digital platforms and communicating values.

CMGT.title: Technoclash: Social Psychology and New Media Industries
CMGT.description: How new media technologies impact us and our relationships. Uses history, social psychology, communication theory and industrial organization to make sense of an always-evolving landscape.

CMGT.title: The Industry, Science and Culture of Video Games
CMGT.description: History, social dynamics, and cultural impact of video games;  developments in technology and design; issues confronting the  video game industry and organizations.

CMGT.title: Integrated Communication Strategies
CMGT.description: Communication strategies for product marketing and advertising; communication's role in developing domestic and international marketplaces; practical applications of persuasion theory.

CMGT.title: Business Strategies of Creator Firms
CMGT.description: An overview of business strategies in creator-based firms. Emphasis on active cases. Students prepare strategic and executional aspects for agencies and platforms.

CMGT.title: Creating Differentiation for Organizations: Meaning and Grow
CMGT.description: Explores how organizations combine values, culture, experience and markets to create meaning, engage audience and customers, and grow.

CMGT.title: Hollywood 3.0-Entertainment Industry in the Convergence Age
CMGT.description: In-depth analysis of the challenges confronting the entertainment industry in the wake of media convergence including a survey of media convergence history and theories.

CMGT.title: Visual Storytelling: Production, Management and Culture
CMGT.description: Focuses on management, production and distribution of scripted film, television and web stories to understand visual storytelling as a communicative strategy for advertising and education.

CMGT.title: Online Marketing Communication Development and Analysis
CMGT.description: Analysis and development of online communication and marketing campaigns; exploration of current Internet best practices in social media, SEM, privacy, location-based marketing, and online measurement.

CMGT.title: Global Marketing Communication
CMGT.description: Communication strategies in a global marketing environment; analysis of global aE* local challenges and opportunities; effective global integrated communication to create and sustain competitive advantage

CMGT.title: International Entertainment Marketplaces
CMGT.description: Global influences on linear and streaming television and theatrical. Case analyses of organizations and content focusing on interconnected partnerships and promotions to attract local audiences.

CMGT.title: Influencer Strategies
CMGT.description: Students master skills and strategies to distinguish the truly influential from the merely popular, manage international influencer campaigns and develop successful influencers.

CMGT.title: Artificial Intelligence and Communication Technologies
CMGT.description: Foundational concepts surrounding communication-related artificial intelligence, focus on generative AI products and services in contemporary communication, content and media industries, organizations and work.

CMGT.title: Streaming Media: Data and Strategies
CMGT.description: Studies streaming media platforms through data and algorithms; also focus on ownership, policy, production, programming and marketing

CMGT.title: Entertainment Media: Content, Theory, and Industry Practices
CMGT.description: Examination of social scientific theory and research on patterns of media content; effects of mass media exposure on individuals and society; and industry practices.

CMGT.title: Audience Analysis
CMGT.description: Conceptualization of client research problems: sampling and segmentation; advanced questionnaire design; audience observation; quantitative-qualitative analyses and synthesis; effective communication of findings and solutions.

CMGT.title: Directed Research
CMGT.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may  be applied to the degree to be determined by the school. Graded    CR/NC.

CMGT.title: Communication Internship
CMGT.description: Field experience in applying communication principles to settings in organizations, campaigns, or other contexts; analysis and assessment of issues and problems.

CMGT.title: Communication Research Practicum
CMGT.description: Communication management research project design and execution - thesis formulation, literature review, methods choice and instrument design. Analysis and reporting with appropriate quantitative or qualitative techniques.

CMGT.title: Communication Research Practicum
CMGT.description: Communication management research project design and execution - thesis formulation, literature review, methods choice and instrument design. Analysis and reporting with appropriate quantitative or qualitative techniques.

PUBD.title: Public Diplomacy and Global Citizenship
PUBD.description: Introduces public diplomacy as a central feature of contemporary international relations and challenges students to locate themselves as both its target and practitioners.

PUBD.title: The Americas
PUBD.description: In-depth examination of historical, political, economic, cultural  factors that influence public diplomacy efforts within specific  geographic regions.

PUBD.title: Public Diplomacy Evaluation
PUBD.description: Critical examination of challenges and benefits of measuring Public Diplomacy's impact; terminology and mechanics of evaluation, the measurement community, and varying approaches for evaluation

PUBD.title: Directed Research
PUBD.description: Research leading to the master's degree.  Maximum units which may  be applied to the degree to be determined by the school.  Graded  CR/NC.

PUBD.title: Practicum in Public Diplomacy Research
PUBD.description: Development and production of original research-based project in  the area of public diplomacy.  Graded CR/NC.

PUBD.title: Digital Diplomacy and International Organizations
PUBD.description: Special topics in the area of public diplomacy.

ADNT.title: Internship: Dental Education
ADNT.description: Practical experience teaching predoctoral students. Units and hours variable.

DENT.title: Introduction to Dentistry
DENT.description: History and current role of dental science in the health services field; review of research; overview of dental procedures with laboratory experience and practice observation.

DENT.title: Fundamentals of Craniofacial and Dental Technology
DENT.description: Biomedical engineering and technology applied to oral health professions. Dental biomaterials, CAD-CAM, digital dental technology and tissue engineering applications to craniofacial diseases, disorders, and enhancements. Recommended preparation: junior standing.

DPBL.title: Dental Problem Based Learning--Human Structure I
DPBL.description: Problem based learning presentation of normal and abnormal structures including anatomy, cell biology, embryology, histology, pathology from cells, tissues and organs of the human body. All material discussed with direct relationship to a well-characterized human clinical case. Acceptance to DDS program required.

DPBL.title: Dental Problem Based Learning -- Human Function I
DPBL.description: Problem based learning presentation of normal and abnormal function including biochemistry, endocrinology, genetics, immunology, microbiology, nutrition, pharmacology, physiology from cells, tissues and organs of the human body. All material discussed with direct relationship to a well-characterized human clinical case. Acceptance to DDS program required.

DPBL.title: Dental Problem Based Learning -- Human Behavior I
DPBL.description: Problem based learning presentation of normal and abnormal behavior including communication, ethics, multiculturalism, patient management, phobias associated with the treatment of patients with and without special needs. All material discussed with direct relationship to a well-characterized human clinical case. Acceptance to DDS program required.

DPBL.title: Dental Problem Based Learning -- Human Clinical Dentistry I
DPBL.description: Problem based learning approach to the delivery of dental health care. Didactic, preclinical and clinical principles of endodontics, geriatrics, oral diagnosis, oral pathology, oral radiology, oral surgery, orthodontics, pediatric dentistry, periodontics, prosthodontics and restorative dentistry will be presented with a direct relationship to a well-characterized human clinical case. Acceptance into DDS program required.

DPBL.description: Problem based learning presentation of normal and abnormal structures including anatomy, cell biology, embryology, histology, pathology from cells, tissues and organs of the human body. All material discussed with direct relationship to a well-characterized human clinical case.
