DSCI.title: Introduction to Data Science
DSCI.description: Fundamentals of data science: representation of data and knowledge, role of a data scientist, data storage/processing/analytics, machine learning, big data and data visualization.

DSCI.title: Foundations of Data Management
DSCI.description: Data modeling, data storage, indexing, relational databases, key-value/document store, NoSQL, distributed file system, parallel computation and big-data analytics.

DSCI.title: Applied Machine Learning and Data Mining
DSCI.description: Foundational course focusing on the understanding, application and evaluation of machine learning and data mining approaches in data-intensive scenarios.

DSCI.title: Data Visualization and User Interface Design
DSCI.description: Design of systems for data visualization; user interface design for exploring and interacting with data.

DSCI.title: Principles of Programming for Data Science
DSCI.description: Programming in Python for retrieving, searching and analyzing data from the Web. Learning to manipulate large data sets.

DSCI.title: Research Methods and Analysis for User Studies
DSCI.description: Introduction to research methods and data analysis techniques for human subject research; experimental research design, correlational research, data analysis, ensuring validity and ethics.

DSCI.title: Trusted System Design, Analysis and Development
DSCI.description: Analysis of computer security and why systems are not secure. Concepts and techniques applicable to the design of hardware and software for Trusted Systems.

DSCI.title: Secure Systems Administration
DSCI.description: The administrators role in information system testing, certification, accreditation, operation and defense from cyber attacks. Security assessment. Examination of system vulnerabilities. Policy development. Recommended preparation: previous degree in computer science, mathematics, computer engineering, data science and/or information security undergraduate program. Also, it is highly recommended that students have successfully completed course work involving policy and network security.

DSCI.title: Security and Privacy
DSCI.description: Covers societal implications of information privacy and how to design systems to best preserve privacy. Recommended Preparation: general familiarity with the use of common Internet and mobile applications.

DSCI.title: Fairness in Artificial Intelligence
DSCI.description: Basic and advanced fairness concepts and methods; applications to societal data for studying fairness and bias; fairness and bias effects in learning algorithms.

DSCI.title: Introduction to Computational Thinking and Data Science
DSCI.description: Introduction to data analysis techniques and associated computing concepts for non-programmers. Topics include foundations for data analysis, visualization, parallel processing, metadata, provenance and data stewardship. Recommended preparation: mathematics and logic undergraduate courses.

DSCI.title: Data Science at Scale
DSCI.description: Big data informatics fundamentals. Data lifecycle; the data scientist; machine learning; data mining; NoSQL databases; tools to store, process, analyze large data sets on clusters.

DSCI.title: Foundations of Data Management
DSCI.description: Function and design of modern storage systems, including cloud; data management techniques; data modeling; network attached storage, clusters and data centers; relational databases; the map-reduce paradigm.

DSCI.title: Machine Learning for Data Science
DSCI.description: Practical applications of machine learning techniques to real-world problems. Uses in data mining and recommendation systems and for building adaptive user interfaces.

DSCI.title: Foundations and Applications of Data Mining
DSCI.description: Data mining and machine learning algorithms for analyzing very large data sets. Emphasis on System Building with Spark. Case studies.

DSCI.title: Data Visualization
DSCI.description: Graphical depictions of data for communication, analysis and decision support. Cognitive processing and perception of visual data and visualizations. Designing effective visualizations. Implementing interactive visualizations.

DSCI.title: User Experience Design and Strategy
DSCI.description: The practice of User Experience Design and Strategy principles for the creation of unique and compelling digital products and services.

DSCI.title: Building Knowledge Graphs
DSCI.description: Foundations, techniques and algorithms for building knowledge graphs and doing so at scale. Topics include information extraction, data alignment, entity linking and the Semantic Web.

DSCI.title: Data Science Professional Practicum
DSCI.description: Student teams working on external customer data analytic challenges; project/presentation based; real client data and implementable solutions for delivery to actual stakeholders; capstone to degree.

DSCI.title: Predictive Analytics
DSCI.description: Supervised learning. Linear regression, cross validation, ridge and lasso regression, logistic regression, k-nearest-neighbors, decision trees, random forest and gradient-boosting models, support vector machines, neural networks.

DSCI.title: Medical Diagnostics, Therapeutics and            Informatics Applications
DSCI.description: Picture archive communication system (PACS) design and implementation; clinical PACS-based imaging informatics; telemedicine/teleradiology; image content indexing, image data mining; grid computing in large-scale imaging informatics; image-assisted diagnosis, surgery and therapy.

DSCI.title: Probability and Statistics for Data Science
DSCI.description: Fundamental concepts in probability and statistics from a data science perspective; rigorous probabilistic reasoning and problem solving; statistical methods used in data science.

DSCI.title: Directed Research
DSCI.description: Research leading to the masters degree; maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

CSCI.title: Introduction to Programming
CSCI.description: Fundamental concepts of algorithmic thinking as a primer to programming. Introduction to C++.

CSCI.title: Object Oriented Programming
CSCI.description: Basic datatypes, assignments, control statements (if, switch, for, while), input/output (printf, scanf, cin, cout), functions, arrays, structures, recursion, dynamic memory, file handling. Programming in C/C++.

CSCI.title: Data Structures
CSCI.description: Data structures including linked lists, balanced search trees, heaps, hash tables; probability and number theory applicable to the analysis of randomized data structures.

CSCI.title: Programming Fundamentals for Computing
CSCI.description: Introduction to Python and C++ with examples from various domains in computational science; intended for students without prior programming experience.

CSCI.title: Programming for Applications of Computing
CSCI.description: Solutions to computational science problems using Python and C++; data structures; searching and sorting algorithms; computational efficiency.

CSCI.title: Discrete Methods in Computer Science
CSCI.description: Boolean algebra, propositional and first-order logic, proof techniques. Sets, functions, series, summations. Big-O notation; algorithm analysis. Recursion; basic sorting algorithms.  Graphs and basic graph algorithms.

CSCI.title: Principles of Software Development
CSCI.description: Object-oriented paradigm for programming in Java; writing concurrent applications using threads; writing web client/server applications using Web Services and SQL databases; team project.

CSCI.title: Introduction to Algorithms and Theory of Computing
CSCI.description: Algorithm analysis. Greedy algorithms, divide and conquer, dynamic programming, graph algorithms. NP-completeness and basic recursion theory and undecidability. Sorting lower bounds. Number-theory based cryptography.

CSCI.title: Programming for Applications for Computational Science
CSCI.description: Selected topics in Computer Science.

CSCI.title: Programming Fundamentals for Computational Science
CSCI.description: Selected topics in Computer Science.

CSCI.title: Software Engineering
CSCI.description: Introduction to the software engineering process and software lifecycle. Covers project management, requirements, architecture, design, implementation, testing, and maintenance phase activities in team based projects. Prerequisites: CSCI 201. Duplicates credit in former CSCI 377.

CSCI.title: Fundamentals of Operating Systems
CSCI.description: Basic issues in concurrency, deadlock control, synchronization scheduling, memory management, protection and access control, inter-process communication, and structured design. Laboratory experiences with Unix-like operating system.

CSCI.title: Internetworking
CSCI.description: Global Internet: design principles, layering, protocol design/analysis. Networked applications, Internet structure/architecture, Protocols for transport/congestion control, network layer/routing, link layer/MAC. Network security.

CSCI.title: Computer Systems
CSCI.description: Computer organization; entity abstraction and representation; program execution; code optimization; memory usage; exception handling; processing control; computer performance; hands-on work done in C and assembly.

CSCI.title: Artificial Intelligence: Principles and Foundations
CSCI.description: Concepts and algorithms underlying the understanding and construction of intelligent systems. Agents, problem solving, search, representation, reasoning, planning, machine learning.

CSCI.title: Cross-Platform App Development
CSCI.description: Programming applications with dynamic graphical user interfaces. Topics include events, controls, resources, data bindings, styles and user experience.

CSCI.title: Video Game Programming
CSCI.description: Underlying concepts and principles required for programming video games (topics include vectors, transformations, 3-D math, geometric primitives, matrices).

CSCI.title: Capstone: Design and Construction of Large       Software Systems
CSCI.description: Group project with an outside stakeholder to develop real-world    software solutions to large-scale problems. Topics include         software engineering, professional preparation, and recent         computer science research. Duplicates credit in CSCI 477a and CSCI  477b.

CSCI.title: Operating Systems
CSCI.description: Concurrency, deadlock control, synchronization, process and thread scheduling, memory management, file systems, security and access   control, communication and networking, distributed file systems,   data management. Duplicates credit in CSCI 350.

CSCI.title: Computer Graphics
CSCI.description: Computer graphics, OpenGL, 2D and 3D transformations, Bzier splines, computer animation, rendering including ray tracing, shading and lighting, artistic rendering, virtual reality, visualization.

CSCI.title: Game Prototyping
CSCI.description: Developing games or technology based on current and relevant special topics.

CSCI.title: Computer and Network Security
CSCI.description: A broad overview of security threats and defenses, security systems and functionalities. Includes homeworks and in-class exercises to provide practical experience working with such systems. Prerequisite: CSCI 104.

CSCI.title: Professional C++
CSCI.description: Applications of advanced concepts in C++ including lambda expressions, templates, secure coding, parallel programming, writing performant code, CMake and continuous integration.

CSCI.title: Natural Language Processing
CSCI.description: Natural language processing; language modeling; deep neural networks for language processing; language technologies and their socioeconomic and societal impacts

CSCI.title: Foundations of Robotics
CSCI.description: Designing and programming mobile robots; sensors, effectors, basic control theory, control architectures, planning, some advanced topics, illustrations of state-of-the-art. Weekly robot programming labs; final project.

CSCI.title: Introduction to Computer Networks
CSCI.description: Network architectures; layered protocols, network service interface; local, wide area, wireless networks; Internet protocols; link protocols; addressing; routing; flow control; software defined network; multimedia networks.

CSCI.title: Parallel and Distributed Computation
CSCI.description: Introduction to parallel programming techniques, models and optimization strategies; Application mapping to multi-core, accelerator, GPU and cloud platforms; High Performance Computing and Data Science applications.

CSCI.title: Introduction to Programming Systems Design
CSCI.description: Intensive introduction to programming principles, discrete mathematics for computing, software design and software engineering concepts. Not available for credit to computer sciencemajors, graduate or undergraduate.

CSCI.title: Computer Systems Organization
CSCI.description: Register Transfer level machine organization; performance; arithmetic; pipelined processors; exceptions, out-of-order and speculative execution, cache, virtual memory, multi-core multi-threaded processors, cache coherence.

CSCI.title: Numerical Methods
CSCI.description: Rounding errors in digital computation; solution of linear algebraic systems; Newton's method for nonlinear systems; matrix eigenvalues; polynomial approximation; numerical integration; numerical solution of ordinary differential equations.

CSCI.title: Foundations of Machine Learning
CSCI.description: Algorithms for learning behavior from data, including both mathematical underpinnings and practical techniques. Covers supervised learning, deep learning, unsupervised learning and reinforcement learning.

CSCI.title: Computer Vision
CSCI.description: Computer vision; image filtering and classification; object detection. Deep learning for computer vision including multi-view reconstruction, visual recognition, visual reasoning and vision-language models.

CSCI.title: Theory of Computation
CSCI.description: History of the theory of computing, foundational theorems and theoretical frameworks of computer science, solvable and unsolvable problems.

CSCI.title: Cryptography: Secure Communication and Computation
CSCI.description: Introduction to modern Cryptography; Mathematical/algorithmic studies of methods for protecting information in computer and communication systems: Public-Key Cryptosystems, zero-knowledge proofs, data privacy. Prerequisites: CSCI 270.

CSCI.title: File and Database Management
CSCI.description: File input/output techniques, basic methods for file organization, file managers, principles of databases, conceptual data models, and query languages.

CSCI.title: Programming Game Engines
CSCI.description: Techniques for building the core components of a game engine; 2-D/3-D graphics, collision detection, artificial intelligence algorithms, shading, programming input devices.

CSCI.title: Directed Research
CSCI.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

CSCI.title: Advanced Game Project
CSCI.description: The practice of design in various areas of game production, iterative stage two prototyping and development of refined videogame.

CSCI.title: Senior Project
CSCI.description: An original project will be constructed applying computer technology (in either hardware or software) to produce a result useful in the physics classroom or laboratory.

CSCI.title: Numerical Analysis and Computation
CSCI.description: Linear equations and matrices, Gauss elimination, error estimates, iteration techniques; contractive mappings, Newton's method; matrix eigenvalue problems; least-squares approximation, Newton-Cotes and Gaussian quadratures; finite difference methods. Prerequisite: linear algebra and calculus.

CSCI.title: Numerical Analysis
CSCI.description: Computational linear algebra; solution of general nonlinear       systems of equations; approximation theory using functional        analysis; numerical solution of ordinary and partial differential  equations.

CSCI.title: Applied Probability
CSCI.description: Markov processes in discrete or continuous time; renewal processes; martingales; brownian motion and diffusion theory; random walks, inventory models, population growth, queuing models, shot noise.

CSCI.title: Research Methods and Analysis for User Studies
CSCI.description: Introduction to research methods and data analysis techniques for human subject research; experimental research design, correlational research, data analysis, ensuring validity and ethics.

CSCI.title: Computer Animation and Simulation
CSCI.description: Fundamental techniques of computer animation and simulation, knowledge and/or experience in the design, scripting, production and post-production stages of computer animation. Prerequisite: CSCI-420 or CSCI-580. Recommendedpreparation: Familiarity with calculus, linear algebra, and numerical computation; C/C++ programming skills.

CSCI.title: Game Engine Development
CSCI.description: The principles of developing game engines targeted at modern PC  and game console hardware.

CSCI.title: Advanced Mobile Devices and Game Consoles
CSCI.description: Explore the complex engineering process required to design and build a real-time graphics engine to support physical realism on mobile devices. Recommended preparation: CSCI 420 or CSCI 580 or an equivalent course in graphics.

CSCI.title: Graduate Advanced Game Project
CSCI.description: The practice of design in various areas of game production, iterative stage two prototyping and development of a refined videogame.

CSCI.title: Applied Cryptography
CSCI.description: Intensive overview of cryptography for practitioners, historical perspective on early systems, number theoretic foundations of modern day cryptosystems and basic cryptanalysis.

CSCI.title: Innovation for Defense Applications
CSCI.description: Development of problem statements and innovative software prototypes for defense, intelligence and homeland security applications; team projects; hands-on experience.

CSCI.title: Algebraic Combinatorics
CSCI.description: Combinatorics motivated by Representation Theory and Algebraic Geometry. Topics may include: representations of the symmetric group, symmetric functions, Young tableaux and plane partitions, permutation enumeration.

CSCI.title: Affective Computing
CSCI.description: Overview of the theory of human emotion, techniques for recognizing and synthesizing emotional behavior, and design application.

CSCI.title: Multimodal Probabilistic Learning of Human Communication
CSCI.description: Principles and techniques to understand, build, and utilize multimodal machine learning algorithms through automatically understanding, recognizing, and analyzing phenomena of human communication. Recommended preparation: CSCI 542 or CSCI 567 or CSCI 573 or equivalent.

CSCI.title: Augmented, Virtual and Mixed Reality
CSCI.description: Technical design and implementation of immersive environments; visual simulations, interactive 3D graphics and games.

CSCI.title: Foundations of Modern Data Management and Processing
CSCI.description: Modern database system architectures; indexing for analytical and transactional workloads, query pipelining; materialization, vectorization, optimization, scheduling; join algorithms, consistency and concurrency control.

CSCI.title: Applied Natural Language Processing
CSCI.description: Introduction to key components of human language technologies, including: information extraction, sentiment analysis, question answering, machine translation.

CSCI.title: Robotics
CSCI.description: Fundamental skills for modeling and controlling of dynamic systems for robotic applications and graphics animations; control theory; kinematics; dynamics; sensor processing; real-time operating systems; robot labs. Recommended preparation: Basic knowledge in linear algebra (matrices and vectors), calculus, programming in C/C++ or any another language or permission of the instructor.

CSCI.title: Distributed Systems
CSCI.description: The theory and practice of distributed systems. Topics include: distributed storage systems, fault tolerance, consensus, consistency, transactions, distributed data processing and efficient cloud computing.

CSCI.title: Advanced Data Stores
CSCI.description: Selected topics on highly available, elastic data stores. Topics  include non-relational data models, simple interfaces and query  languages, weak consistency and benchmarking techniques.

CSCI.title: Advanced Operating Systems
CSCI.description: Advanced topics in operating system research: new OS structures, novel memory management, communication, file system, process management, reliability and security techniques.

CSCI.title: Introduction to Cryptography
CSCI.description: Modern secret codes. Public key cryptosystems of Rivest- Shamir-Adleman, Diffie-Hellman and others. The underlying number theory and computational complexity theory.

CSCI.title: Computer Systems Architecture
CSCI.description: Computer architecture from a design perspective: Pipelined processors, speculative execution, VLIW, vector processors, GPU/GPGPU, memory technology and systems, interconnection networks, shared-memory and message-passing multiprocessors, chip multiprocessors.

CSCI.title: Machine Learning I: Supervised Methods
CSCI.description: Distribution-free and probabilistic methods for supervised classification and regression; learning algorithms; optimization techniques; feature-space transformations; parametric and nonparametric methods; Bayes decision theory; artificial neural networks.

CSCI.title: Foundations of Artificial Intelligence
CSCI.description: Foundations of symbolic intelligent systems, search, logic, knowledge representation, planning, learning.

CSCI.title: Building Knowledge Graphs
CSCI.description: Foundations, techniques and algorithms for building knowledge graphs and doing so at scale. Topics include information extraction, data alignment, entity linking and the Semantic Web.

CSCI.title: Deep Learning and Its Applications
CSCI.description: Deep learning research in computer vision, natural language processing and robotics; neural networks; deep learning algorithms, tools and software.

CSCI.title: Machine Learning
CSCI.description: Statistical methods for building intelligent and adaptive systems that improve performance from experiences; Focus on theoretical understanding of these methods and their computational implications. Recommended preparation: Undergraduate level training or coursework in linear algebra, multivariate calculus, basic probability and statistics; an undergraduate level course in Artificial Intelligence may be helpful but is not required.

CSCI.title: Requirements Engineering
CSCI.description: Techniques for successful requirements analysis and requirements engineering (RE) of software-intensive systems. Systematic process of developing requirements through cooperative problem analysis, representation, and validation.

CSCI.title: Analysis of Algorithms
CSCI.description: Explores fundamental techniques such as recursion, Fourier transform ordering, dynamic programming for efficient algorithm construction. Examples include arithmetic, algebraic, graph, pattern matching, sorting, searching algorithms.

CSCI.title: Web Technologies
CSCI.description: Advanced study of programming languages with application to the Web. Languages for client-side and server-side processing. Examples taken from: HTML, Java, JavaScript, Python, JSON, NodeJS and others.

CSCI.title: Information Retrieval and Web Search Engines
CSCI.description: Examines key aspects of information retrieval as they apply to search engines; web crawling, indexing, querying and quality of results are studied.

CSCI.title: Probabilistic Reasoning
CSCI.description: Reasoning under uncertainty, statistical directed and undirected graphical models, temporal modeling, inference in graphical models, parameter learning, decisions under uncertainty. Recommended preparation: An undergraduate level course in probability theory.

CSCI.title: Multimedia Systems Design
CSCI.description: End-to-end multimedia systems -  content creation, compression, distribution using modern standards, DRM solutions,  Digital-Cinema pipeline, multimedia classification, virtual-augmented reality, natural-language multimedia queries, multimodal media analysis, stereoscopic-holographic  technologies.

CSCI.title: Software Engineering
CSCI.description: A: Software life-cycle processes; planning considerations for      product definition, development, test, implemetation, maintenance. Team project.  Graduate standing.

CSCI.title: 3-D Graphics and Rendering
CSCI.description: Course outlines the process of creating images from 3D models. Includes transformations, shading, lighting, rastorization, texturing, and other topics.

CSCI.title: Geometric Modeling
CSCI.description: Hands-on introduction to modern geometry processing of 3D shapes: surface reconstruction, animation, parametrization, deformation and meshing. Applications in computer graphics and computer-aided fabrication.

CSCI.title: Database Systems
CSCI.description: Database system architecture; conceptual database models; semantic, object-oriented, logic-based, and relational databases; user and program interfaces; database system implementation; integrity, security, concurrency and recovery. Recommended Preparation: Knowledge of relational databases, SQL, relational algebra and physical database design is required. Open only to graduate students.

CSCI.title: Geospatial Data Analysis
CSCI.description: Techniques to efficiently store, manipulate, index, query and analyze geospatial information in support of real-world geographical and decision-making applications.

CSCI.title: Directed Research
CSCI.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

CSCI.title: Computer Science Research Colloquium
CSCI.description: Exploration and critical assessment of research activities in computer science. Course will serve as a forum for current research presentations from academia and industry. Graded CR/NC.

CSCI.title: Master's Thesis
CSCI.description: Credit on acceptance of thesis.  Graded IP/CR/NC.

CSCI.title: Master's Thesis
CSCI.description: Credit on acceptance of thesis.  Graded IP/CR/NC.

CSCI.title: Master's Thesis
CSCI.description: Credit on acceptance of thesis.  Graded IP/CR/NC.

CSCI.title: Advanced Program Analysis and Verification
CSCI.description: Advanced techniques for analyzing and verifying software systems; topics include program analysis, automated verification and software testing.

CSCI.title: Machine Learning for/with Mixed-Integer Optimization
CSCI.description: Using mixed-integer optimization (MIO) to solve problems in artificial intelligence (Al) and machine learning (ML). Leveraging Al/ML to improve MIO solvers.

CSCI.title: Computer Animation and Simulation
CSCI.description: Animation and Simulation techniques for computer games, virtual reality, and film visual effects. Research methods, SIGGRAPH papers. Deformable objects, fluids, sound, collision detection, haptics, rigid bodies, GPUs. Prerequisite: CSCI 420 or CSCI 520 or CSCI 580. Recommended preparation: Familiarity with calculus, linear algebra, and numerical computation and C++ programming skills. Open only to doctoral students.

CSCI.title: Digital Geometry Processing
CSCI.description: Digital geometry processing (subfield of computer graphics), that covers the full pipeline from 3D scanning, processing, to 3D printing. Recommended preparation: Solid background in linear algebra, numerical optimization, and C/C++ programming. CSCI 420 Computer Graphics is recommended. Open only to Computer Science doctoral students.

CSCI.title: Analytics for Social Impact
CSCI.description: Use of analytics to address societal challenges arising in public health, social services and conservation; fairness, interpretability, robustness, optimization, machine learning and causal inference.

CSCI.title: Automata Theory, Logic and Formal Verification
CSCI.description: Omega-Regular Languages, Automata over infinite words and trees, Logic and Automata for timed languages, First-order Logic and MSO, Mu Calculus, Probabilistic Logics and Model Checking.

CSCI.title: Program Synthesis and Computer-Aided Verification
CSCI.description: Introduction to the principles and practices of software verification and program synthesis.

CSCI.title: Privacy in the World of Big Data
CSCI.description: Privacy challenges that arise in the world driven by data. An overview of algorithmic and technical approaches to addressing them.

CSCI.title: Natural Language Dialogue Systems
CSCI.description: Computational models of natural language dialogue; conversational interfaces to artificial systems; dialogue system architectures and applications; Reinforcement learning of dialogue policies.

CSCI.title: Advanced Information Integration
CSCI.description: Focus on foundations and techniques for information integration. Topics include Semantic Web, linked data, data integration, entity linkage, source modeling, and information extraction. Prerequisite: CSCI 561. Recommended preparation: CSCI 585 and programming experience. Open only to Computer Science doctoral students.

CSCI.title: Haptic Interfaces and Virtual Environments
CSCI.description: Introduction to haptics; human haptic sensing and perception, haptic interface design, virtual environment rendering, teleoperation, human subject studies; includes hardware programming and a research-oriented project.

CSCI.title: Advanced Topics in Operating Systems
CSCI.description: Advanced OS architectures; methods in design and evaluation of process management and concurrency; reliable distributed file systems; memory management, for cloud and virtualized environments.

CSCI.title: Networked Systems in Cloud Computing
CSCI.description: Systems and network design and protocols in cloud computing and data centers networks.

CSCI.title: Diagnosis and Design of Reliable Digital Systems
CSCI.description: Fault models; test generation; fault simulation; self-checking and self-testing circuits; design for testability; fault tolerant design techniques; case studies; search techniques; memory testing.

CSCI.title: Introduction to Online Optimization
CSCI.description: Foundation and advances of the theory of online learning/online convex optimization/sequential decision making.

CSCI.title: Advanced Natural Language Processing
CSCI.description: Computational models of natural language. Formalisms for describing structures of human language, and algorithms for learning language structures from data. Recommended preparation: Proficiency in programming, algorithms and data structures, discrete math, probability theory, and calculus. Open only to doctoral students. (Duplicates credit in former CSCI 562)

CSCI.title: Artificial Intelligence for Social Good
CSCI.description: Deployment of artificial intelligence tools in various social good contexts such as health, environmental sustainability, public safety and public welfare.

CSCI.title: Advanced Analysis of Algorithms
CSCI.description: Fundamental techniques for design and analysis of algorithms. Dynamic programming; network flows; theory of NP-completeness; linear programming; approximation, randomized, and online algorithms; basic cryptography. Prerequisite: CSCI 570. Recommended preparation: familiarity with algorithms and discrete mathematics. Open only to doctoral students.

CSCI.title: Structure and Dynamics of Networked Information
CSCI.description: Algorithms for analyzing network data and spreading information over networks. Focuses on broadly applicable mathematical tools and techniques, including spectral techniques, approximation algorithms and randomization.

CSCI.title: Convex and Combinatorial Optimization
CSCI.description: Topics include: Convex sets and functions; convex optimization problems; geometric and Lagrangian duality; simplex algorithm; ellipsoid algorithm and its implications; matroid theory; submodular optimization.

CSCI.title: Advanced Computer Vision
CSCI.description: Fundamental issues in computer vision: theory, algorithms and applications. Image formation, image segmentation, inference and measurement of 3-D, motion analysis, object and activity recognition.

CSCI.title: Seminar in Computer Science Research
CSCI.description: Introduction of Ph.D. students to the broad range of computer science research. Two semesters registration required. Open to Computer Science doctoral students only. Graded CR/NC. Duplicates credit in former CSCI 597.

CSCI.title: Practicum in Teaching Computer Science
CSCI.description: Practical principles for the long-term development of effective teaching in Computer Science. Intended for teaching assistants for classes offered by the Computer Science department. Graded CR/NC. Open only to Computer Science doctoral students.

CSCI.title: Research
CSCI.description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

CSCI.title: Doctoral Dissertation
CSCI.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

CSCI.title: Doctoral Dissertation
CSCI.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

CSCI.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

ASTE.title: Foundations of Astronautical Engineering
ASTE.description: Coordinate systems and transformations. Spherical trigonometry. Filtering and estimation. Spacecraft orbits and orbital maneuvers. Rocket propulsion, spacecraft attitude dynamics, spacecraft communications, and space environment.

ASTE.title: Rocket Laboratory
ASTE.description: Participation in ASTE undergraduate student team projects.   Intended for lower-division students or those with little prior  project experience.  Departmental approval.

ASTE.title: SERC Projects
ASTE.description: Participation in ASTE undergraduate student team projects.   Intended for lower-division students or those with little prior  project experience.  Departmental approval.

ASTE.title: Astronautical Gas Dynamics
ASTE.description: Introduction to compressible and rarefied gas flows with applications to rocket propulsion and the dynamics of supersonic and hypersonic vehicles and spacecraft; ionized gases and plasmas.

ASTE.title: Spacecraft Systems Engineering
ASTE.description: Introduction to spacecraft systems: propulsion, attitude dynamics and control, structures, communications, power, thermal control.  Space environment. Systems engineering as applied to spacecraft.

ASTE.title: Mission Systems Design
ASTE.description: Space systems engineering process: requirements definition; trade studies; system integration; technical reviews; cost and schedule development; case studies; ethics. Capstone design experience.

ASTE.title: Spacecraft Dynamics
ASTE.description: Two-body motion.  Rigid-body motion.  Attitude dynamics and  maneuvers.  Spacecraft stabilization: gravity gradient, reaction  wheels, magnetic torques.  Thruster attitude control.  Senior  standing.

ASTE.title: Directed Research
ASTE.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

ASTE.title: Rocket Laboratory
ASTE.description: Participation in ASTE undergraduate student team projects.   Intended for students with prior project experience.  Departmental  approval.

ASTE.title: SERC Projects
ASTE.description: Participation in ASTE undergraduate student team projects.   Intended for students with prior project experience.  Departmental  approval.

ASTE.title: Safety of Space Systems and Space Missions
ASTE.description: Engineering methodology and analysis techniques for safety certification and mission assurance of robotic and human space systems and space missions by government and commercial industry. Recommended preparation: ASTE 520 or some experience in space engineering. Open only to Engineering graduate students.

ASTE.title: Space Environments and Spacecraft Interactions
ASTE.description: Space environments and interactions with space systems.  Vacuum,  neutral and ionized species, plasma, radiation, micrometeoroids.   Phenomena important for spacecraft operations.

ASTE.title: Human Factors of Spacecraft Operations
ASTE.description: Engineering fundamentals and experimental methods of human factors design and evaluation for spacecraft which incorporate human-in-the-loop control.

ASTE.title: Advanced Spacecraft Propulsion
ASTE.description: Nuclear, electric, sails, and far-term propulsion systems. Overviews of nozzles, heat transfer, electromagnetics, rarefied gases, and plasma physics. Analysis of electrothermal, electrostatic and electromagnetic thrusters. Graduate standing in engineering or science.

ASTE.title: Space Launch Vehicle Design
ASTE.description: Fundamentals, technologies, and design of space launch vehicles. Propulsion, trajectory analysis and optimization, static and dynamic structural loads, stability, control, and safety.

ASTE.title: Rocket and Spacecraft Propulsion
ASTE.description: Space missions, rocket dynamics, and propulsion requirements. Thermodynamics and combustion; compressible gas dynamics in nozzles. Liquid- and solid-propellant rockets; launch systems. Advanced propulsion.

ASTE.title: Orbital Mechanics II
ASTE.description: Theory of perturbations of orbits; numerical methods in orbital    mechanics; satellite dynamics; averaging methods; resonance;       mission analysis.

ASTE.title: Spacecraft Power Systems
ASTE.description: Introduction to solar arrays, batteries, nuclear power sources,  mechanical energy storage.  Application, theory of operation,  practical considerations.  Subsystem topologies and performance.   Design optimization techniques.  Graduate standing in engineering  or science.

ASTE.title: Directed Research
ASTE.description: Research leading to the master's degree.  Maximum units which may  be applied to the degree to be determined by the division.  Graded  CR/NC.

ASTE.title: Master's Thesis
ASTE.description: Credit on acceptance of thesis.  Graded IP/CR/NC.

ASTE.description: Laboratory studies of specific problems by candidates for the  degree Engineer in Astronautical Engineering.  Graded CR/NC.

EIS.title: Information Literacy: Navigating Digital Misinformation
EIS.description: Analyze misinformation and disinformation on digital platforms using library research methodologies and applying information literacy principles. Examine how technology creates and disseminates information in society.

EIS.title: Technology and Society
EIS.description: Exploring and analyzing the ethical and social impact of technological innovation and advancement through humanities-based inquiry.

EIS.title: Ethical Issues in Artificial Intelligence
EIS.description: Ethical issues in artificial intelligence including algorithmic bias and interpretability, data privacy and control, autonomous systems and relationships with AI entities.

EIS.title: Sociotechnical Visions of the Future: Japan's Society
EIS.description: Selected topics in Engineering in Society.

EIS.title: Oral Communication Skills for Engineering PhD Students
EIS.description: Academic and professional presentation skills for PhD students. Preparation for qualifying exams, conference paper presentations and other forms of oral communication. Use of visual aids and poster displays included. Graded CR/NC. Not available for degree credit to master's students.

ISE.title: Solving Engineering Problems using Python
ISE.description: Engineering examples are used as a platform to introduce computer programming skills for problem solving; critical thinking skills.

ISE.title: Foundations of Probability Modeling
ISE.description: Techniques for modeling uncertainty: discrete and continuous random variables, probability distributions, expectations and conditional probability; Poisson processes, Markov chains and queuing decision models.

ISE.title: Foundations of Data Analysis
ISE.description: Sampling distributions; confidence intervals and hypothesis testing; analysis of variance; regression; data aggregation; prediction and classification.

ISE.title: Engineering Project Management
ISE.description: Managing a project intended to create an engineered system.  Methods, processes, tools.  Lessons-learned from actual practice.  Case studies from real projects.  Presentations by student teams.

ISE.title: Optimization
ISE.description: Modeling, solution analysis and applications of complex decision problems using linear, dynamic and integer optimization.

ISE.title: Enterprise Data Analytics
ISE.description: Methodology to store, organize, cleanse, harmonize and stage enterprise data for analytics. Report, visualize, slice and dice, forecast and predict trends.

ISE.title: Principles and Practices of Systems Engineering
ISE.description: Systems as complex collaborative ensembles of interconnected components. Theory and practice of requirements, design, implementation, testing, deployment, operation and disposal. Case studies from real projects.

ISE.title: Systems Thinking for Sustainability
ISE.description: Analysis of the complex interplay of technical, social, psychological, and environmental factors to address real-world sustainability challenges.

ISE.title: Human Factors in Work and Systems Design
ISE.description: Role of humans in technological systems; human-systems integration; ergonomics; anthropometry and workstation design; work methods and measurement; human error, safety and accident analysis.

ISE.title: Database Systems: Storage and Retrieval using SQL
ISE.description: Data models for industry applications. Modeling and designing robust databases. Implementing and querying databases with SQL. Innovations in database applications.

ISE.title: Planning and Scheduling for Production and Supply Chains
ISE.description: Production, resource and service planning, forecasting, scheduling, vendor and location selection, inventory; integrated decision systems for the control of production, services and supply chains.

ISE.title: Discrete Systems Simulation
ISE.description: Modeling of complex discrete event systems, input and output analysis, system evaluation via experimentation on the simulation model, applications to industrial and systems engineering problems.

ISE.title: Socio-Technical Systems and Work Organizations
ISE.description: Design, modeling and analysis of complex systems, challenges they present and methods for resolving those challenges. Impact of technology on work and organizational design.

ISE.title: Engineering Decisions, Economics and Ethics
ISE.description: Principles of economic analysis and decision analysis for engineering systems, including applications in financing, developing and comparing new technologies.

ISE.title: Directed Research
ISE.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

ISE.title: Senior Design Project
ISE.description: Investigate client organization operations, evaluate alternative designs to meet client needs, complete preliminary design review.

ISE.title: Senior Design Project
ISE.description: Develop the detailed design including countermeasures for risks, complete critical design review, implement the project plan, close-out the project.

ISE.title: Innovative Conceptual Design for New Product Development
ISE.description: A logic-based framework for conceptual design, including systematic concept generation and improvement, in innovative product developments.

ISE.title: Construction Accounting, Finance and Strategy
ISE.description: Fundamental accounting principles, financial analysis and financial control, strategic management and a review of alternative project delivery methods.

ISE.title: Health Analytics
ISE.description: Case-study approach to learning descriptive and predictive data analytical tools for health data. Derive inspiring solutions to real-world problems in various health domain applications.

ISE.title: Modeling for Health Policy and Medical Decision Making
ISE.description: Modeling techniques used to inform decisions in public health, disease control, and hospital operations.

ISE.title: Lean Operations
ISE.description: Study of various aspects of integrated manufacturing and service enterprises including management, design and production functions, interfaces and related resources and information systems.

ISE.title: Practicum in Health Care Systems
ISE.description: Application of performance and efficiency tools to streamline hospital operations. Group projects collaborating with hospital staff.

ISE.title: Logistics and Inventory Systems
ISE.description: Practice in inventory management, computerized procedures, materials requirements planning. Deterministic and stochastic demand systems with static/dynamic models.

ISE.title: Advanced Production Planning and Scheduling
ISE.description: Dependencies among long, intermediate and short-range planning and scheduling of production systems considering objectives, technological constraints and solution algorithms.

ISE.title: Engineering Project Management
ISE.description: Methods, processes and tools for managing projects to create engineered systems. Project management; engineering economics; risk management. Industry-drawn large-scale engineering case studies. Team project presentations.

ISE.title: Engineering Management of Systems Integration
ISE.description: Foundations of systems integration; advanced topics in systems integration including generative artificial intelligence (AI); data analytics for predicting and supporting engineering decisions.

ISE.title: Foundations of Analytics
ISE.description: Foundational tools, technologies and methodologies for analytics. The statistical basis of analytics. Understanding and preparing data. Python, SQL and exploratory data analysis.

ISE.title: Design of Experiments
ISE.description: Planning data collection to investigate relationships between product/process design choices (materials, temperatures, etc.) and performance, empirical modeling to predict performance, identification of best design choices.

ISE.title: Quality Management for Engineers
ISE.description: Principles of quality management, quality philosophies and frameworks, role of leadership and strategic planning to improve quality, process management, measurements to improve quality and performance.

ISE.title: Predictive Analytics
ISE.description: Supervised learning. Linear regression, cross validation, ridge and lasso regression, logistic regression, k-nearest-neighbors, decision trees, random forest and gradient-boosting models, support vector machines, neural networks.

ISE.title: Optimization Methods for Analytics
ISE.description: Fundamentals of Linear Programming, Integer Programming, quadratic and nonlinear programming for analytics and data science problems.

ISE.title: Data Analytics Consulting
ISE.description: Consulting project concepts, frameworks, analytical tools and managerial skills with a focus on the use of data analytics, design thinking and insight-driven frameworks.

ISE.title: Data Mining
ISE.description: Data preprocessing, data cleaning, data summarization, dimension reduction, data visualization, anomaly detection, classification and clustering. Modeling dependencies using association rules.

ISE.title: Financial Analytics
ISE.description: Modern portfolio theory and optimal decision-making problems in finance. Market microstructure and high-frequency trading. Machine learning models for quantitative finance.

ISE.title: Text Analytics
ISE.description: Methods and algorithms for automated text analysis; machine learning; predictive web data analytics; information retrieval; social media data; natural language documents and graphs.

ISE.title: Enterprise Cloud Analytics
ISE.description: Project-based course covers developing scalable analytics solutions using major cloud platforms, focusing on data management, machine learning and enterprise applications.

ISE.title: Leading and Managing Engineering Teams
ISE.description: Design and management of engineering teams. Group decision-making, motivation, leadership, infrastructure requirements, performance measurement, team diversity, conflict and integration.

ISE.title: Applied Generative Artificial Intelligence for Enterprises
ISE.description: Foundational concepts and methods in large language models and generative artificial intelligence; fine-tuning and pre-training strategies; applications in dialogue systems and text generation.

ISE.title: Fundamentals of Data Engineering
ISE.description: Essentials of data engineering, focusing on data architecture, data warehousing, ETL processes, big data technologies, and data quality.

ISE.title: Analysis of Algorithms
ISE.description: Explores fundamental techniques such as recursion, Fourier transform ordering, dynamic programming for efficient algorithm construction. Examples include arithmetic, algebraic, graph, pattern matching, sorting, searching algorithms.

ISE.title: Economic Analysis of Engineering Projects
ISE.description: Economic evaluations of engineering systems for both government and private industry; quantitative techniques for evaluating non-monetary consequences; formal treatment of risk and uncertainty.

ISE.title: Decision Analysis
ISE.description: Decisions under uncertainty; utility theory; multiattribute utility; probability elicitation; conjugate distributions; decision analysis applications, framing, modeling using spreadsheets or software; cognitive biases, behavioral decision theory.

ISE.title: Financial Engineering
ISE.description: Concepts underlying the economic analysis of engineering projects; applications to call and put options; utility theory and mathematical optimizations models; simulation.

ISE.title: Machine Learning
ISE.description: Statistical methods for building intelligent and adaptive systems that improve performance from experiences; Focus on theoretical understanding of these methods and their computational implications. Recommended preparation: Undergraduate level training or coursework in linear algebra, multivariate calculus, basic probability and statistics; an undergraduate level course in Artificial Intelligence may be helpful but is not required.

ISE.title: Probabilistic Reasoning
ISE.description: Reasoning under uncertainty, statistical directed and undirected graphical models, temporal modeling, inference in graphical models, parameter learning, decisions under uncertainty. Recommended preparation: An undergraduate level course in probability theory.

ISE.title: Performance Analysis with Simulation
ISE.description: Introduction to modeling and analysis of stochastic systems, with an emphasis on discrete-event simulation of non-Markovian systems.

ISE.title: Enterprise Wide Information Systems
ISE.description: The role enterprise resource planning systems (ERPs) play in organization; integrating and coordinating the many business processes such as demand planning, procurement, production and sales.

ISE.title: Strategic Management of Technology and Innovation
ISE.description: Examine principles, strategies, practices and case studies where new technology and innovation are transforming the traditional business paradigms to identify best practices in real-world implementation.

ISE.title: Directed Research
ISE.description: Research leading to the master's degree; maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

ISE.title: Master's Thesis
ISE.description: Credit on acceptance of Thesis.

ISE.title: Advanced Design of Experiments and Quality Engineering
ISE.description: Methodologies of planning, conducting, analyzing and interpreting controlled physical or computational experiments for causal inference with broad data science and engineering applications.

ISE.title: Machine Learning for/with Mixed-Integer Optimization
ISE.description: Using mixed-integer optimization (MIO) to solve problems in artificial intelligence (Al) and machine learning (ML). Leveraging Al/ML to improve MIO solvers.

ISE.title: Analytics for Social Impact
ISE.description: Use of analytics to address societal challenges arising in public health, social services and conservation; fairness, interpretability, robustness, optimization, machine learning and causal inference.

ISE.title: Foundations of Optimization
ISE.description: Convex sets, convex functions, structures of optimization problems, Lagrangian and conjugate duality. First and second order optimality conditions; applications in engineering and statistics.

ISE.title: Network Flows and Combinatorial Optimization
ISE.description: Combinatorial optimization, particularly graph problems. Shortest paths, max flow, minimum cost flows, Spanning trees, matroids, submodular functions. Bipartite and general matchings, Polyhedral combinatorics, total unimodularity.

ISE.title: Seminar in Industrial & Systems Engineering
ISE.description: Current research, guest speakers in the field; review papers; guidance in preparing research proposals and special projects. Duplicates credit in the former ISE-650abc. Open only to Fifth Year Seniors and MasteraE*s Students.

ISE.title: Advanced Decision Theory
ISE.description: Rational decision making; value and utility functions; distribution theory; invariance relations; copulas; value of information and control; multiattribute utility; decision and game theory; behavioral research.

ISE.title: Advanced Analysis of Algorithms
ISE.description: Fundamental techniques for design and analysis of algorithms. Dynamic programming; network flows; theory of NP-completeness; linear programming; approximation, randomized, and online algorithms; basic cryptography. Prerequisite: CSCI 570. Recommended preparation: familiarity with algorithms and discrete mathematics. Open only to doctoral students.

ISE.title: Research
ISE.description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

ENE.title: Environmental Engineering Principles
ENE.description: Analysis of water, air and land pollution, including hazardous waste; engineering of mitigation measures; water and wastewater treatment systems.

ENE.title: Contaminant Transport in the Environment
ENE.description: Fundamentals of the physical mechanisms controlling solute transport in environmental flows.

ENE.title: Particulate Air Pollutants: Properties/Behavior/Measurement
ENE.description: Particulate air pollutants, their measurement and instrumentation methods and their effects on the environment and human health; optical properties and visibility degradation.

ENE.title: Air Pollution Fundamentals
ENE.description: Quantitative overview of air pollution and the physical and chemical processes that describe its behavior.

ENE.title: Water Supply and Sewerage System Design
ENE.description: Design of water supply systems, storm drains, sanitary sewers, and lift stations.

ENE.title: Environmental and Regulatory Compliance
ENE.description: Federal and state environmental laws; environmental impact assessment techniques; permitting for industrial facility construction and operation.

ENE.title: Environmental Fluid Mechanics
ENE.description: Application of the fundamentals on the physical laws governing fluid flow and analyzing transport of contaminant in the environment and the risks involved.

ENE.title: Applied Air Quality Management
ENE.description: Air pollutants, emission levels, and air borne concentrations; Links between pollutant emissions, air quality measurements and health effects; Environmental management in private or public sectors.

ENE.title: Directed Research
ENE.description: . Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

ENE.description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

MASC.title: Materials Science
MASC.description: Chemical bonding and structure in crystalline, amorphous and       molecular solids; tendency and mechanisms for chemical             change; homogeneous and heterogeneous equilibria.

MASC.title: Materials Behavior and Processing
MASC.description: Mechanical behavior of metals, polymers, ceramics, and composites. Structure-process-property relationships. Mechanical testing, stress-strain relationships, microstructural characteristics and analysis. Material failure (fracture, fatigue, creep) and degradation.

MASC.title: Introduction to Machine Learning for Materials
MASC.description: Introduction to machine learning (ML) for materials applications;  basic concepts of machine learning, statistics and probability.

MASC.title: Directed Research
MASC.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

MASC.title: Solid State
MASC.description: Atomic electronic states, molecular bonding, crystal structures, diffraction, reciprocal lattice, Brillouin zones, crystal binding, lattice vibrations, specific heat, anharmonic effects, energy bands, metals, conductivity.

MASC.title: Diffusion and Phase Equilibria
MASC.description: Phase equilibria, phase diagrams, diffusion, planar defects, nucleation and growth, spinodal decomposition, phase transformation.

MASC.title: Machine Learning in Materials, Chemical and Energy Engineeri
MASC.description: Introduction to machine learning, basics of python programming and data science tools; hands-on projects of materials and process modeling based on machine learning methods.

MASC.title: Materials Science for Energy Transitions
MASC.description: Survey of materials science issues relevant to a zero-carbon energy future; material properties; the influence of extreme environments; manufacturing considerations; and sourcing of materials.

MASC.title: Mathematical Methods for Deep Learning
MASC.description: Understanding deep learning: for students in engineering, physical  and life sciences and computer science with mathematical  background.

MASC.title: Fatigue and Fracture
MASC.description: Behavior of materials under cyclic and static fatigue; plastic instability; life-time predictions; brittle and ductile fracture; crack propagation and plastic blunting.

MASC.title: Molecular Dynamics Simulations of Materials and Processes
MASC.description: Modeling of materials and processes such as mechanical, thermodynamical, and transport properties using Molecular Dynamics simulation, interatomic potentials including long-range coulomb interactions and quantum corrections.

MASC.title: Materials Selection
MASC.description: Materials selection in relationship to design and fabrication, economic considerations, methodology of selection, performance parameters; case studies.

MASC.title: Directed Research
MASC.description: Research leading to the Master's Degree. Maximum units which may   be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.  Graded CR/NC.

ENGR.description: Recent developments in a highly technological society with emphasis on selected topics. Enrollment limited to members of the School of Engineering Honors Program. Graded CR/NC.

ENGR.title: Engineering Honors Colloquium
ENGR.description: Recent developments in a highly technological society with emphasis on selected topics. Enrollment limited to members of the School of Engineering Honors Program. Graded CR/NC.

ENGR.title: Technology Entrepreneurship
ENGR.description: Starting and managing a technological business: developing a viable concept, market and financial planning, product development, organizing the venture, protecting intellectual property rights.

ENGR.title: Cooperative Education Work Experience
ENGR.description: Supervised work experience in a professional environment related to specific degree program, academic level, and career objective. Acceptance into Cooperative Education Program required. Graded IP or CR/NC. Degree credit by departmental approval.

ENGR.title: Dean's Seminar in Entrepreneurship: Disruptive Technologies
ENGR.description: Understand, evaluate and manage disruptive technologies in the context of starting and developing a new business. Lectures and discussions with a diverse array of successful business leaders and entrepreneurs.

ENGR.title: Invention and Technology Development
ENGR.description: Use of creative thought, tools and techniques for engineering designs and research endeavors. Activities required for bringing inventions to production phase.

ENGR.title: Internship in Engineering
ENGR.description: Part-time or full-time, practical work experience in the student's  field of study.  The internship must be located at an off-campus  facility.  Students are individually supervised by faculty.  May  not be taken until the student has completed at least one semester  of enrollment in the graduate program.  Graduate standing in  engineering.  Graded CR/NC.

ENGR.title: Internship in Engineering with Professional      Writing and Communication
ENGR.description: Practical work experience; professional communication and writing skills.

ENGR.title: Professional Internship Experiences
ENGR.description: Part-time or full-time practical work experience in a particular field of study. The internship must be located at an off-campus facility.

ENGR.title: Emerging Technologies for National Security
ENGR.description: Emerging science and engineering technologies relevant to national security and the relationship between such technologies and strategic competitiveness.

SAE.title: Systems Engineering Theory and Practice
SAE.description: Integration of engineering problem solving methodologies based on systems concepts. Application to complex, large scale technical systems and problems faced by engineering managers. Case studies.

SAE.title: Engineering Mission-Critical Systems
SAE.description: Formal methods for the design and analysis of resilient systems and system-of-systems (SoS); Disruption risks as a function of system scale and complexity, management, and architectures.

SAE.title: Systems/System-of-Systems Integration and Communication
SAE.description: Essentials of systems and system-of-systems integration from the perspectives of business, programs, and technology. Process, Legacy, and Systems-of-Systems Integration. Verification and Validation methods. Case studies. Recommended preparation: Bachelor's degree in engineering or physical sciences.

SAE.title: Systems Architecting
SAE.description: Introduction to systems architecture in aerospace, electrical,     computer, and manufacturing systems emphasizing the conceptual and acceptance phases and using heuristics.

SAE.title: Systems Architecting and the Political Process
SAE.description: Analysis of risks inherent in managing high-tech/high-cost  government-funded engineering programs; tools and techniques for  coping with the impacts of politically-driven budgets on the      engineering design process.  Recommended preparation: 2 years of  work experience.

SAE.title: Lean Operations
SAE.description: Study of various aspects of integrated manufacturing and service enterprises including management, design and production functions, interfaces and related resources and information systems.

SAE.title: Economic Considerations for Systems Engineering
SAE.description: Impact of economic factors for systems architects and engineers,  tools for understanding these factors, fundamental quantitative  analysis of cash flow, life-cost estimating for systems and  software engineering.

SAE.title: Invention and Technology Development
SAE.description: Use of creative thought, tools and techniques for engineering designs and research endeavors. Activities required for bringing inventions to production phase.

SAE.description: Research leading to the master's degree.  Maximum units which may  be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.   Graded CR/NC.
