TAC.title: Introduction to Business Information Technologies
TAC.description: Business technologies. Operating systems. Networks. Application software.

TAC.title: Introduction to Web Development
TAC.description: Web publishing using HTML, CSS and other Web technologies. Concepts and theory of Web site creation, page layout and production. Introduction to advanced topics.

TAC.title: Programming in Python
TAC.description: Introduction to Python; intended for students without prior programming experience.

TAC.title: Accelerated Programming in Python
TAC.description: Accelerated introduction to Python; intended for students with prior programming experience.

TAC.title: How Not to Get Hacked -- Personal Cyber Security
TAC.description: Cyber security concepts for personal protection, protecting your devices and information, protecting yourself and your family online, using encryption safely.

TAC.title: From Hackers to CEOs: Introduction to Information Security
TAC.description: Introductory course in computer security. Fundamentals of information security management. Threats to information integrity. Ethical hacking concerns and practice. Policies and Procedures.

TAC.title: Introduction to C++ Programming
TAC.description: Introduction to programming using C++, including variables, operators, conditionals, loops, arrays, vectors, strings, functions, files, structs, pointers, dynamic allocation and an introduction to classes.

TAC.title: Introduction to MATLAB
TAC.description: Fundamentals of MATLAB: a high-performance numeric computation and visualization environment. Overview of linear algebra and matrix manipulation; using 2-D and 3-D plotting routines; programming in MATLAB; basic numerical analysis.

TAC.title: Video Game QA Management
TAC.description: Survey of game software development through quality assurance and in-depth analysis of the development cycle with a focus on bug testing systems, methodologies and QA Management.

TAC.title: Introduction to Adobe Photoshop
TAC.description: Digital tools for image creation, editing, composition, layout, web page development, professional page layout and printing with color accuracy.

TAC.title: Introduction to 3D Modeling, Animation and Visual Effects
TAC.description: An applied introduction to the techniques used for modeling, animating, texturing, lighting, rendering, and creating 3D content for games, cinematics, visual effects, animation and visualizations.

TAC.title: Applied Python
TAC.description: Development of practical Python programming skills through project-based applications; "Pythonic" ways of solving problems in modern computational domains.

TAC.title: Introduction to Data Analytics
TAC.description: Introduction to data analytics. Basics of databases, applied statistics, data visualization. Leverage data to make critical business decisions.

TAC.title: Blockchain
TAC.description: Explore blockchain technology, a secure and immutable way to record transactions. Learn the workings of cryptocurrencies and explore their impact on financial services, business and contracting.

TAC.title: Basics of Artificial Intelligence
TAC.description: Concepts and techniques in artificial intelligence; approaches in artificial narrow intelligence; applications of AI that are already changing society; ethical and social questions in AI.

TAC.title: Object-Oriented Programming
TAC.description: Continuation of the fundamentals of programming; problem solving skills within the object-oriented programming paradigm.

TAC.title: Front-End Web Development
TAC.description: Concepts and technologies used to create front-end for web applications. Introduction to programming and client-side web development. User-driven website manipulation and animation.

TAC.title: Full-Stack Web Development
TAC.description: Modern web development techniques and technologies used to create web applications from ground up. Topics include front-end, back-end and web servers.

TAC.title: Computer-Aided Design for Bio-Mechanical Systems
TAC.description: Concepts of computer-aided design in 2-dimensions and 3-dimensions. Creating advanced parts using extrusions, surfaces, and equation driven sketches. Forming assemblies and sub-assemblies, for motion analysis

TAC.title: Design for User Experience
TAC.description: Fundamental concepts, techniques, practices, workflows and tools associated with the practice of user experience and interaction design in web and mobile applications.

TAC.title: Ethical Hacking
TAC.description: Ethical hacking; penetration testing; vulnerability assessment; red teams; hacker environments, infrastructure and frameworks; lateral movement and data exfiltration techniques; evasion and anti-forensics.

TAC.title: Making Smart Devices: Introduction to Electronics/Wearables
TAC.description: Design of electronic devices that interact with the physical world; electronic interfaces; development of software algorithms; micro-controller implementation.

TAC.title: Enterprise Data Analytics
TAC.description: Methodology to store, organize, cleanse, harmonize and stage enterprise data for analytics. Report, visualize, slice and dice, forecast and predict trends.

TAC.title: Enterprise Networks: Design and Architecture
TAC.description: Network technologies. Routers and managed switches. Integrated operating systems (IOS). Strategies for endpoint management. Subnets and securing subnetworks. Reliability with networks and network infrastructure.

TAC.title: Applied Neural Networks
TAC.description: Design, build, and train applied neural networks to solve real-world problems; implement neural networks for machine vision, image recognition and object detection and tracking.

TAC.title: Character Rigging for Games
TAC.description: Fundamentals of character rigging for video game production and development; optimization of character design, skeleton and mass properties for effective rigging; virtual rigs.

TAC.title: Managing Data in C++
TAC.description: Data structures in C++ including vectors, linked lists, stacks, queues, trees, hash tables, graphs and parallelism.

TAC.title: Blockchain: Advances and Use Cases
TAC.description: Latest advances in blockchain and distributed ledger technologies. Critical analysis of new projects, proposals and protocols. The promise and technical feasibility of use cases.

TAC.title: Cross-Platform App Development
TAC.description: Programming applications with dynamic graphical user interfaces. Topics include events, controls, resources, data bindings, styles and user experience.

TAC.title: Cybersecurity Management and Operations
TAC.description: Cybersecurity project design. Incident response. Teambuilding, management and communications for cybersecurity. Scalable approaches for implementation of Information Security Management Systems.

TAC.title: Digital Forensics and Cybersecurity Investigations
TAC.description: Forensic science techniques. Digital evidence preservation. Processes and methodologies for digital examinations. Cyber crime investigations. Windows file system analysis. Real case scenario analysis and reporting

TAC.title: Video Game Programming
TAC.description: Underlying concepts and principles required for programming video games (topics include vectors, transformations, 3-D math, geometric primitives, matrices).

TAC.title: Database Systems: Storage and Retrieval using SQL
TAC.description: Data models for industry applications. Modeling and designing robust databases. Implementing and querying databases with SQL. Innovations in database applications.

TAC.title: Developing Connected Devices
TAC.description: Design and development of production-ready connected devices; PCB design; micro-controller logic; interfacing with the connected world.

TAC.title: Video Game Project Management
TAC.description: Production and project management of video games from concept to release and beyond.

TAC.title: Advanced Back-End Web Development
TAC.description: Topics include Model-View-Controller (MVC) pattern, RESTful APIs, Object Relational Mapping (ORM), testing and Node.js, an asynchronous server-side alternative using JavaScript.

TAC.title: Advanced Cloud Analytics
TAC.description: Data engineering and machine learning principles; cloud labs, data pipelines, big data and automation; conceptualize, build and deploy natural language processing models at cloud scales.

TAC.title: Web Application Security
TAC.description: Examine web applications from an offensive security standpoint. Topics include information gathering, vulnerability discovery and validation, exploitation and privilege escalation techniques.

TAC.title: Professional C++
TAC.description: Applications of advanced concepts in C++ including lambda expressions, templates, secure coding, parallel programming, writing performant code, CMake and continuous integration.

TAC.title: Malware Analysis and Reverse Engineering
TAC.description: Reverse engineering concepts for malware analysis; debuggers and decompilers; static and dynamic analysis of malicious scripts and binaries; focused on Windows and Windows APls.

TAC.title: Applications of Machine Learning
TAC.description: Hands-on approach to the fundamental modeling techniques and machine learning algorithms that enable students to build robust predictive models of real-world data and test their validity.

TAC.title: Blockchain: Capstone
TAC.description: Use decentralized blockchain technology to propose a use case of trustless peer-to-peer transactions.

TAC.title: Network Security
TAC.description: Network policy and mechanism, firewalls, malicious code; intrusion detection, prevention, response; cryptographic protocols for privacy; risks of misuse, cost of prevention and societal issues.

TAC.title: Applied Natural Language Processing and Generative AI
TAC.description: Applied topics in machine learning, including transfer learning, reinforcement learning, generative adversarial networks and natural language processing using neural networks.

TAC.title: Web Application Project
TAC.description: Skills to plan, analyze, build and launch professional Web sites with actual clients. Includes project management, documentation, technology assessment, security, UI, Q/A and various methodologies.

TAC.title: Building the High Tech Startup
TAC.description: Basic technologies and processes involved in building web and mobile startup; aspects of building a web startup including online business models, product management, agile development processes, technology platforms and operations, customer development and online marketing.

TAC.title: Technology and Applied Computing Practicum
TAC.description: Independent technology project related to specific topics under    the direction of a faculty member.

TAC.title: Consultancy Skills for Cyber Security Risk Management
TAC.description: Development of consultancy skills; cyber risk assessments; policy evaluations; project team development tailored to business objectives and relevant ISO/NIST standards.

TAC.title: Advanced Digital Forensics and Incident Response
TAC.description: Advanced digital forensics; cyber breach investigations; incident response; system triage; advanced Windows file system analysis; trial preparation and testimony.

TAC.title: Technologies for Interactive Marketing
TAC.description: Technologies, concepts and strategies in the emerging online advertising ecosystem; learn to drive traffic to a website and measure efficacy; work with a real client and budget to craft and execute an online marketing plan.

TAC.title: Cyber Law and Privacy
TAC.description: Cyber legal issues, search and seizure, 4th amendment and digital evidence, warrants, private searches, wiretaps, tracking devices, workplace privacy.

TAC.title: Technology and Applied Computing Internship
TAC.description: Practical experience in applying information technology skills in  real-world settings. Supervised internship at companies and        start-ups. Balancing academic rigor with corporate challenges and  deadlines.

TAC.title: Programming Game Engines
TAC.description: Techniques for building the core components of a game engine; 2-D/3-D graphics, collision detection, artificial intelligence algorithms, shading, programming input devices.

CE.title: Introduction to Civil Engineering Graphics
CE.description: Graphic communication and drawing; Free-hand sketching; Use of CAD software; Drawing in 2-D, including lettering, dimensioning, and detailing; Drawing and modeling in 3-D.

CE.title: Programming for Civil and Environmental Engineers
CE.description: Computer programming, organization of problems for computational solution, flow charts, programming; numerical methods; analysis and solution of civil engineering problems.

CE.title: Mechanics of Deformable Bodies
CE.description: Analysis of stress and strain; axial, flexural, and torsional behavior of slender bars; elastic deflections; combined stresses; introduction to elastic stability and energy methods.

CE.title: Fluid Mechanics
CE.description: Fluid statics; relative velocity field; total acceleration; divergence theorem; conservation of mass, energy, and momentum applied to engineering problems in laminar and turbulent flow.

CE.title: Computational Methods in Engineering
CE.description: Application of computer-oriented numerical analysis methods and tools to a broad spectrum of practical science and engineering problems. Use of Python, R and computer algebra.

CE.title: Environmental Chemistry and Analysis
CE.description: Physiochemical characterization of water, soil and air; chemical processes in aquatic, atmospheric, and geospheric environments; air, soil and water pollution chemistry and abatement.

CE.title: Construction Contracts and Law
CE.description: Legal aspects of property development and construction: land use, construction practices and specifications, architecture and engineering contracts, agency, subcontracting, professional registration, liability, insurance, liens, bonds.

CE.title: Water Resources and Coastal Engineering
CE.description: Control and utilization of inland and coastal water, quantitative hydrology, groundwater, probability concepts, extreme events, coastal hydrodynamics, wave-structures interactions, multiple purposes water projects, economic study.

CE.title: Structural Design II
CE.description: Design of structural systems in wood, steel, concrete and masonry, and the performance of structural systems for wind and seismic forces.

CE.title: Computational Structural Analysis
CE.description: Analyze continuous beams, trusses and frame structures using analytical methods and Matlab programming; finite element analysis of plane stress problems, steel beams and concrete beam-column joints.

CE.title: Construction Engineering
CE.description: Introduction to the construction processes; estimating and bidding, construction administration, planning and scheduling, equipment and methods, labor relations, cost control systems, safety and ethics.

CE.title: Construction Estimating
CE.description: Fundamental principles and practices of advanced building cost estimating using Revit Models and industry standard databases.

CE.title: Water Supply and Sewerage System Design
CE.description: Design of water supply systems, storm drains, sanitary sewers, and lift stations.

CE.title: Geotechnical Engineering
CE.description: Fundamentals of the engineering behavior of soil: soil composition and minerology, soil classification, compaction, vertical and lateral stresses, seepage, strength, compressibility; common geotechnical laboratory tests

CE.title: Civil and Environmental Engineering Capstone Design
CE.description: Civil and Environmental Engineering capstone design project incorporating all disciplines of Civil Engineering and Environmental Engineering.

CE.title: Engineering Economics in Civil Engineering
CE.description: Principles of engineering economics; modeling and evaluation of receipts and outlays timing; relevance to and applications within Civil and Environmental Engineering projects.

CE.title: Innovation in Engineering & Design: Global Grand Challenges
CE.description: The innovative and human-centered design of products, services, and technologies to help solve the needs of people affected by global crises

CE.title: Directed Research
CE.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

CE.title: Architecture, Engineering and Construction Practices
CE.description: Systems, processes, and constraints governing the initiation, direction, engineering, and delivery of major construction projects. Professional construction management, responsibilities, and practice.

CE.title: Construction Accounting, Finance and Strategy
CE.description: Fundamental accounting principles, financial analysis and financial control, strategic management and a review of alternative project delivery methods.

CE.title: Data Management for Civil and Environmental Engineering
CE.description: The basics of databases and database management systems as applied to engineering problems. Introduction to data mining concepts, techniques and knowledge discovery in database principles.

CE.title: Game Theory for Interactive Autonomy
CE.description: Game-theoretic modeling of strategic interactions between autonomous systems and humans. Autonomous driving, collaborative robotics, multi-agent decision-making. Nash Equilibrium, reinforcement learning.

CE.title: Data Analytics in Civil Engineering
CE.description: Application of Fourier series, wavelets, auto-regressive models and Markov models to civil engineering systems. Introduction to deep learning methods and applications to time series analysis.

CE.title: Retaining Structures and Slope Stability
CE.description: Principles and practices underlying analysis, design, construction and stability of retaining walls, braced excavations and slopes.

CE.title: Advanced Reinforced Concrete
CE.description: Advanced beam flexural analysis; shear behavior of beams; beam-columns and interaction diagrams; torsion; structural wall design; analysis of D-regions; nonlinear behavior of RC systems.

CE.title: Modeling and Analysis of Tall and Special Structures
CE.description: Integration of structural modeling with the analysis and design of tall and special structures to resist earthquake motion through inelastic response.

CE.title: Dynamics of Structures
CE.description: Forced vibrations of discrete and distributed systems; energy methods; analytical dynamics; computational techniques; approximate methods; random vibration concepts; nonstationary response; structural control; nonlinear system response.

CE.title: Fundamental Concepts of Computing and            Programming in Civil and Environmental  Engineering
CE.description: Concepts of computing and programming related to engineering; Form and operation of modern computational devices; Data structures and algorithms that support CEE software applications.

CE.title: Project Controls
CE.description: Project controls principles including costs and schedules, cost engineering concepts, schedule development, status evaluation, progress monitoring and responses to variances and changes.

CE.title: Invention and Technology Development
CE.description: Use of creative thought, tools and techniques for engineering designs and research endeavors. Activities required for bringing inventions to production phase.

CE.title: Technology-Enabled Architecture, Engineering and Construction
CE.description: Integration of architecture, engineering and construction practices through the development of a construction project.

CE.title: Design of Transportation Infrastructure
CE.description: Planning, design, staging, construction, test and maintenance of the public works and facilities for land, water, and air transportation.

CE.title: Directed Research
CE.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

CE.title: Mechanics of Soft Materials and 3D Printing
CE.description: Course content will be selected each semester to reflect current trends and developments in the field of civil engineering.

CE.title: Methods and Modeling Tools for Transportation Planning
CE.description: Background applications of established urban travel forecasting procedures; land use; trip-generation, trip-distribution, modal-choice, trip-assignment; evaluation; criticisms.

CE.description: Research leading to the Doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

PTE.title: Testing of Wells and Aquifers
PTE.description: Principles of well testing; down hole device; aquifer tests; slug tests; DST; pressure transient modeling in homogeneous and heterogeneous systems; parameter estimation; computer aided techniques.

PTE.title: Mathematical Methods for Deep Learning
PTE.description: Understanding deep learning: for students in engineering, physical  and life sciences and computer science with mathematical  background.

EE.title: Introduction to Electrical Engineering
EE.description: Electrical engineering overview: communications, computers, circuits, components, signals, electromagnetics, microelectronics; data encoding and compression, USPS and UPC product codes, DVDs, semiconductor devices, and integrated circuits.

EE.title: Introduction to Embedded Systems
EE.description: Information representations, embedded programming, digital and serial I/O, analog-to-digital conversion, and interrupt mechanisms. Elementary analog, logic and state-machine design.

EE.title: Linear Circuits
EE.description: Lumped circuit elements; network equations; zero-input and zerostate responses; sinusoidal steady-state analysis; impedance; resonance; network functions; power concepts; transformers; Laplace transforms.

EE.title: Distributed Systems for the Internet of Things
EE.description: Introduction to hardware, operating systems, signal processing and control, network protocols, mobile applications, databases, cloud computing, machine learning and security for the Internet of Things.

EE.title: Linear Systems
EE.description: Representation and analysis of linear time-invariant systems primarily for the continuous time case. Convolution, Fourier series and transform, Laplace transform, controls and communications applications.

EE.title: Physical Electronics
EE.description: Semiconductor device characteristics and applications. Physical models of electronic conduction in solids, p-n junctions, bipolar and field effect transistors and other solid-state devices.

EE.title: Introduction to Digital Circuits
EE.description: Digital system design and implementation; synchronous design of datapath and control; schematic/Verilog-based design, simulation, and implementation in Field Programmable Gate Arrays; timing analysis; semester-end project.

EE.title: Software Design for Electrical Engineers
EE.description: Object-oriented programming techniques, basic data structures, and elementary complexity analysis for the modeling, simulation, and solution of engineering problems.

EE.title: Introduction to Probability and Statistics for   Electrical Engineering and Computer Science
EE.description: Introduction to concepts of randomness and uncertainty: probability, random variables, statistics. Applications to digital communications, signal processing, automatic control, computer engineering and computer science.

EE.title: Introduction to Power Systems
EE.description: Components of power systems; analysis techniques in electrical power generation transmission and utilization; and environmental and economic considerations in system operations and planning.

EE.title: Foundations of Robotics
EE.description: Designing and programming mobile robots; sensors, effectors, basic control theory, control architectures, planning, some advanced topics, illustrations of state-of-the-art. Weekly robot programming labs; final project.

EE.title: Introduction to Computer Networks
EE.description: Network architectures; layered protocols, network service interface; local, wide area, wireless networks; Internet protocols; link protocols; addressing; routing; flow control; software defined network; multimedia networks.

EE.title: Parallel and Distributed Computation
EE.description: Introduction to parallel programming techniques, models and optimization strategies; Application mapping to multi-core, accelerator, GPU and cloud platforms; High Performance Computing and Data Science applications.

EE.title: Introduction to Programming Systems Design
EE.description: Intensive introduction to programming principles, discrete mathematics for computing, software design and software engineering concepts. Not available for credit to computer sciencemajors, graduate or undergraduate.

EE.title: Computer Systems Organization
EE.description: Register Transfer level machine organization; performance; arithmetic; pipelined processors; exceptions, out-of-order and speculative execution, cache, virtual memory, multi-core multi-threaded processors, cache coherence.

EE.title: Embedded Systems Design Laboratory
EE.description: Specification, design, implementation, testing and documentation of a digital system project using embedded processors, programmable logic, analog I/O interfaces and application specific hardware. Capstone design experience.

EE.title: Machine Learning for Engineers
EE.description: Overview of machine learning, regression and classification, clustering and dimensionality reduction, loss-functions, over/under-fitting, cross-validation, kernel machines, decision trees and neural networks.

EE.title: Introduction to Communication Systems
EE.description: Broad treatment of analog and digital communication systems. Modulation and demodulation techniques using a carrier wave's amplitude, frequency, phase. Channel signal and noise. Review current systems.

EE.title: MOS VLSI Circuit Design
EE.description: Analysis and design of digital MOS VLSI circuits including area, delay and power minimization. Laboratory assignments including design, layout, extraction, simulation and automatic synthesis.

EE.title: Control Systems Laboratory
EE.description: Vibration measurement and analysis; simulation, design, and experimental verification of mechanical control systems; system identification; implementation of controllers; performance evaluation via experimentation and stimulation.

EE.title: Introduction to Digital Signal Processing
EE.description: Fundamentals of digital signal processing covering: discrete time linear systems, quantization, sampling, Z-transforms, Fourier transforms, FFTs and filter design.

EE.title: Directed Research
EE.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

EE.title: Undergraduate Thesis
EE.description: For the undergraduate degree. Credit on acceptance of thesis.  IP (EE 494a) or letter grade (EE 494b).

EE.title: Undergraduate Thesis
EE.description: For the undergraduate degree. Credit on acceptance of thesis. IP (EE 494a) or letter grade (EE 494b).

EE.title: Capstone Design
EE.description: Capstone design project for the undergraduate degree. Project topics vary from semester to semester.

EE.title: Solid State
EE.description: Atomic electronic states, molecular bonding, crystal structures, diffraction, reciprocal lattice, Brillouin zones, crystal binding, lattice vibrations, specific heat, anharmonic effects, energy bands, metals, conductivity.

EE.title: Probability for Electrical and Computer Engineers
EE.description: Rigorous coverage of probability, discrete and continuous random variables, functions of multiple random variables, covariance, correlation, random sequences, Markov chains, estimation, and introduction to statistics. Duplicates credit in former EE 464 and EE 465.

EE.title: Hardware Foundations of Machine Learning
EE.description: Introduction to ML accelerators; memory access kernels; parallelization approaches to the design of scalable ML systems; distributed ML; privacy in machine learning.

EE.title: Linear Algebra for Engineering
EE.description: Introduction to linear algebra and matrix theory and their underlying concepts; applications to engineering problems; mathematically rigorous and foundational to other classes in communication, control, and signal processing.

EE.title: Stochastic Processes for Financial Engineering
EE.description: Theory and applications of stochastic processes relevant to  financial engineering. Stochastic processes, Brownian motion, martingales, stochastic calculus, Monte Carlo Simulations with financial application examples.

EE.title: Mathematics and Tools for Financial Engineering
EE.description: Students will build a mathematical background for studying Financial Engineering. Emphasis is on analysis, proofs and examples. Mathworks Financial toolbox will be introduced.

EE.title: Speech Recognition and Processing for Multimedia
EE.description: Speech production, acoustics, perception, synthesis, compression,  recognition, transmission.  Coding for speech, music, and  CD-quality.  Feature extraction.  Echo cancellation.  Audio,  visual synchronization.  Multimedia, Internet use.

EE.title: Power Systems Analysis and Design
EE.description: Power system planning, studies, and design; time-domain modeling and analysis of power-system networks; power flow, stability, fault, and economic dispatch analysis; symmetrical components.

EE.title: Spatial Audio for Real and Virtual Spaces
EE.description: Fundamentals of audio signal processing, acoustics and human perception to understand sound in the real world and create compelling virtual auditory worlds.

EE.title: Advanced Biomedical Imaging
EE.description: Advanced scientific and engineering principles of biomedical imaging including magnetic resonance, X-ray computed tomography, ultrasound and single photon and positron emission tomography.

EE.title: Renewable Energy in Power Systems
EE.description: Renewable energy sources and their integration in electrical networks. Power-flow control from highly variable resources. Cost analysis and planning.

EE.title: Power Electronics
EE.description: Fundamentals of switched-mode power converters operating under steadystate and transient conditions. Feedback control systems. Magnetic circuit design.

EE.title: Nonlinear Optics
EE.description: Theory of nonlinear optical susceptibility and application to self-focusing, harmonic generation, and parametric interactions. Raman and Brillouin scattering. Coherent spectroscopy.

EE.title: Network Processor Design and Programming
EE.description: Design, implementation, and programming of a custom multi-core RISC-V-based network processor and hardware accelerators using reconfigurable hardware in a SmartNIC in a realistic network testbed.

EE.title: Wireless Communications
EE.description: The mobile communication channel; techniques used to combat the channel; cellular communications; multiple-access techniques; example mobile communication systems.

EE.title: Computing Principles for Electrical Engineers
EE.description: Survey of computing principles and practice of software design: object-oriented and non object-oriented, testing, template libraries, time-space complexity, data structures, algorithms, and dynamic programming.

EE.title: A Computational Introduction to Deep Learning
EE.description: Deep learning frameworks for training multilayer perceptrons, convolutional and recurrent neural networks; Python, virtual environments, linux and shell scripting, cloud computing, including GPUs and datasets.

EE.title: Robotics
EE.description: Fundamental skills for modeling and controlling of dynamic systems for robotic applications and graphics animations; control theory; kinematics; dynamics; sensor processing; real-time operating systems; robot labs. Recommended preparation: Basic knowledge in linear algebra (matrices and vectors), calculus, programming in C/C++ or any another language or permission of the instructor.

EE.title: Applied and Cloud Computing for Electrical Engineers
EE.description: Introduction to cloud applications; software development and deployment within cloud platforms; interactive user-facing interfaces; API development; databases, virtualization, asynchronous execution, testing and scalability.

EE.title: Nanotechnology for Materials, Electronics, and Circuits
EE.description: Nanotechnology for advanced nanomaterials, nanoelectronics devices, and circuits, including the rigorous treatment of electronic band structures of carbon nanotubes, graphene, and two-dimensional materials.

EE.title: Computer Systems Architecture
EE.description: Computer architecture from a design perspective: Pipelined processors, speculative execution, VLIW, vector processors, GPU/GPGPU, memory technology and systems, interconnection networks, shared-memory and message-passing multiprocessors, chip multiprocessors.

EE.title: Machine Learning I: Supervised Methods
EE.description: Distribution-free and probabilistic methods for supervised classification and regression; learning algorithms; optimization techniques; feature-space transformations; parametric and nonparametric methods; Bayes decision theory; artificial neural networks.

EE.title: Foundations of Artificial Intelligence
EE.description: Foundations of symbolic intelligent systems, search, logic, knowledge representation, planning, learning.

EE.title: Inference and Estimation: Theory and Algorithms
EE.description: Bayesian and non-Bayesian hypothesis testing and estimation, sufficient statistics, exponential families, expectation-maximization, approximations, Kalman filtering and smoothing, recursive Bayesian tracking.

EE.title: Introduction to Digital Image Processing
EE.description: Image sampling, 2-D image transform, image enhancement, geometric image modification, morphologic processing, edge detection, texture analysis, image filtering and restoration.

EE.title: Advanced Electromagnetic Theory
EE.description: Classical electromagnetic field theory and its usage in understanding and analytically modelling advanced applied electrical engineering devices.

EE.title: Wave Interactions with Random and Inhomogeneous Media
EE.description: Analyses and applications of electromagnetic wave scattering and propagation in inhomogenous media, including random media and periodic structures.

EE.title: Integrated Memory Devices and Technologies
EE.description: Fundamental device physics, integration technology and cutting-edge innovations in integrated microelectronic memory devices and systems, and their applications in data storage and emerging beyond-von-Neumann computing.

EE.title: VLSI System Design
EE.description: MOS logic; system design; memory design; datapath subsystem design; circuit simulation; basic device physics; simple device layout: structured chip design; timing; project chip; silicon compilers.

EE.title: VLSI System Design
EE.description: Semi-custom ASIC VLSI design flow; RTL coding, logic synthesis, automatic placement & routing, memory and interface design, signal integrity solutions, hardware acceleration and approximation

EE.title: Robotic Mobility
EE.description: Robot gait design; the kinematics and dynamics of locomotion; control adaptations for complex terrains.

EE.title: Nonlinear Control Systems
EE.description: State-space Models. Equilibrium points. Limit Cycles. Linearization. Nonlinear Phenomena. Lyapunov Stability. Analysis and Design of Nonlinear Systems. Passivity. Backstepping. Feedback and Input-Output Linearization.

EE.title: Quantum Information Theory
EE.description: Quantum Shannon theory: quantum channels and entanglement; dense coding, teleportation, quantum compression, and quantum capacity theorems.  Open problems in quantum communication.

EE.title: Directed Research
EE.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

EE.title: Magnetic Resonance Imaging and Reconstruction
EE.description: Principles of magnetic resonance imaging. Fourier-based acquisition and reconstruction, tissue contrast, system imperfections, artifact correction, advanced image reconstruction including AI, quantitative biomarkers, laboratory experiments.

EE.title: Computational Methods for Inverse Problems
EE.description: A rigorous description of vector space and functional analysis concepts and tools that are useful for solving inverse problems in real-world applications.

EE.title: Robust Multivariable Control
EE.description: Singular values of the various sensitivity matrices are introduced to quantify the benefits of multivariable feedback systems operating in an uncertain environment and controllers are designed for the worst-case disturbances making them "robust."

EE.title: Master's Thesis
EE.description: Credit on acceptance of Thesis. Graded CR/NC.

EE.title: Master's Thesis
EE.description: For the Master's Degree. Credit on acceptance of Thesis. Graded CR/NC.

EE.title: Master's Thesis
EE.description: For the Master's Degree. Credit on acceptance of Thesis. Graded CR/NC.

EE.title: Wavelets and Graphs for Signal Processing and    Machine Learning
EE.description: Multirate signal processing, wavelets and filter banks. Overcomplete and sparse signal representations. Graph signal processing. Applications to compression, sensing, time-frequency analysis, and machine learning.

EE.title: Wireless Networks
EE.description: Introduction to wireless networking technologies; fundamental architectural and design principles used at all protocol layers; optimization, performance evaluation and implementation using mathematical analysis, simulations, and experiments.

EE.title: Antenna Engineering and Applications
EE.description: The course content will be selected each semester to reflect current trends and developments in the field of electrical engineering.

EE.title: Distributed Systems for Medical Applications
EE.description: The course content will be selected each semester to reflect current trends and developments in the field of electrical engineering.

EE.title: Foundations of Learning to Control
EE.description: The course content will be selected each semester to reflect current trends and developments in the field of electrical engineering.

EE.title: Microelectromechanical Systems
EE.description: Exploration of the technology methods and physical principles of MEMS, and survey various MEMS of current interest.

EE.title: Survey of Energy and Power for a Sustainable Future
EE.description: Power production includes conventional fossil fuels, synthetic fuels, hydroelectric, solar, wind, geothermal, biomass and nuclear. The environmental consequences of various energy sources are discussed.

EE.title: Mixed-Signal Integrated Circuits
EE.description: Fundamentals of sampling and discrete-time signals; analog to digital converters; digital to analog converters; switched-capacitor circuits.

EE.title: Diagnosis and Design of Reliable Digital Systems
EE.description: Fault models; test generation; fault simulation; self-checking and self-testing circuits; design for testability; fault tolerant design techniques; case studies; search techniques; memory testing.

EE.title: Advanced Computer Vision
EE.description: Fundamental issues in computer vision: theory, algorithms and applications. Image formation, image segmentation, inference and measurement of 3-D, motion analysis, object and activity recognition.

EE.title: Computer-Aided Design of Digital Systems
EE.description: A contemporary look at solving VLSI design problems using computer aided design and machine learning, including models, algorithms and techniques for physical design and synthesis.

EE.title: Directed Research
EE.description: Laboratory study of specific problems by candidates for the       degree Engineer in Electrical Engineering. Graded CR/NC.

EE.description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.
