THTE.title: Foundations of Vocal Performance
THTE.description: Exploration of the foundations of vocal technique in a group setting, with an emphasis on musical theatre repertoire.

THTE.title: Acting for Musical Theatre
THTE.description: Analysis and investigation of role interpretation and character development by working on two or more scenes from the same play. Introduction of techniques to unlock objectives based on the text.

THTE.title: Acting for Musical Theatre
THTE.description: Continuation of analysis and investigation of role interpretation and character development by working on two or more scenes from the same play. Introduction of techniques to unlock objectives for character creation.

THTE.title: Speech
THTE.description: A guided study of dialect acquisition.

THTE.title: Movement for Musical Theatre
THTE.description: Introduction to foundational skills in musical theatre movement, including safe alignment and a movement vocabulary.

THTE.title: Movement for Musical Theatre
THTE.description: Introduction to foundational skills for musical theatre movement, including safe alignment and a movement vocabulary.

THTE.title: Musicianship for Musical Theatre Actors II
THTE.description: Continued development of the foundations of musicianship necessary for a career in musical theatre.

THTE.title: The History of Content Creation
THTE.description: An exploration of the evolution of content creation spanning from the ancient multicultural oral traditions to the digital age.  Discover how storytellers and story-sellers have always been influencers in the realms of entertainment, activism and commerce.

THTE.title: Script and Score
THTE.description: Introduction and development of techniques needed to transition from the script to score. Beginning with an exploration of Broadway's "Golden Age" and the examination of Sondheim and his contemporaries.

THTE.title: Script, Score and Choreography
THTE.description: Study of the musical comedy and the connection between script, score and choreography.

THTE.title: Musical Theatre Integration Workshop I
THTE.description: Introduction to the synthesis of emotional life, voice and movement skills as the foundation for an authentic musical theatre performance.

THTE.title: Musical Theatre Individual Instruction
THTE.description: Introduction to foundational healthy vocal performance/singing skills needed to sustain a career in the musical theatre.

THTE.title: Building Your Cabaret
THTE.description: Development of skills needed to create a solo musical cabaret performance.

THTR.title: Introduction to Acting
THTR.description: Study of diverse genres and disciplines of acting; fundamental techniques necessary for performance; scene study from contemporary text.

THTR.title: Introduction to Screen Acting
THTR.description: Introduction to the theoretical and foundational practices, techniques and strategies specific to screen acting in relation to the basic dynamics of acting for the stage.

THTR.title: Acting I
THTR.description: Basic principles and techniques of acting through theatre games and improvisation. Introduction to contemporary texts, basic characterization and cold reading techniques.

THTR.title: Improvisation and Theatre Games
THTR.description: Individual and group exercises to free the actor physically and emotionally and to stimulate creativity, imagination, and  self-expression.

THTR.title: Introduction to Theatrical Production
THTR.description: Introduction to the non-performance areas of theatrical production(administrative, design, and technical fields) through hands-onparticipation in USC productions.

THTR.title: Advanced Theatrical Production
THTR.description: Advanced understanding of non-performance areas of theatrical production (administrative, design, and technical fields) through hands-on participation in USC productions.

THTR.title: Art of Theatrical Design
THTR.description: Development of the artistic process and theatrical design vocabulary of the individual within the environment of collaborative storytelling.

THTR.title: Beginning Voice
THTR.description: Physiological mechanism of voice: breath control, phonation, resonance, articulation of language for the stage; expressive use of stress, intonation and rhythm.

THTR.title: Introduction to Scene Study: Contemporary Plays
THTR.description: Application and consolidation of the skills, knowledge and techniques acquired in the study of fundamentals of acting encountered in THTR 101.

THTR.title: History of Stand-Up Comedy
THTR.description: A comprehensive overview and understanding of how stand-up evolved in the United States, from the mid-1800's to the current touring performers.

THTR.title: Theatre on Film
THTR.description: Introduction to the theater and its relationship to society through major plays in film versions. Separate screenings to be arranged.

THTR.title: Comedy and Performance
THTR.description: Comedy and Performance traces the history of comedy in performance from its earliest incarnations to the present day.

THTR.title: The Fundamentals of Comedy
THTR.description: Introduction to the fundamental elements of comedy and how to apply those elements to create short, original pieces of comedy in performance and writing.

THTR.title: Stardom: Creation, Management and Culture Impact
THTR.description: An exploration of the phenomena of stardom and celebrity across media, entertainment, sports and social influence, ranging from early modern theatre to current day.

THTR.title: Corset Construction
THTR.description: Design and construct period corsets, along with the materials and terminology needed to sew (machine and hand) corsets.

THTR.title: The Actor's Instrument: Voice and Body
THTR.description: A comprehensive exploration of voice, speech and acting to strengthen the actors physical instrument.

THTR.title: Movement for Actors
THTR.description: Training and practice in the coordination of the physical          apparatus of the actor utilizing various movement techniques       through improvisation.

THTR.title: Intermediate Acting I
THTR.description: Continuing development of imagination leading to an increased range of dramatic expression through the formalized text of William Shakespeare.

THTR.title: Stage Make-up
THTR.description: Principles of stage make-up materials and skills allowing the  actors to enhance their features and techniques for moderate and  extreme aging, injuries, and character roles.

THTR.title: Theatre Across History and Cultures
THTR.description: The analysis of a range of plays from different times and cultures with a consideration of the roles of actor, director, dramaturg and designer.

THTR.title: Sports on Stage and Screen
THTR.description: The examination of the intersection between athletes and actors through the study of plays, musicals, feature films and TV series that depict athletic worlds.

THTR.title: Communicating Theatrical Design Concepts
THTR.description: The visualization and communication of design ideas through free-hand and mechanical drawing: orthographics, isometrics,perspective, shades and shadows, plans, sections and elevations.

THTR.title: Stage Lighting
THTR.description: Theory and practice of theatrical lighting design including electricity, radiant energy, refraction, reflection, absorption, chromatic variation and electronic controls.

THTR.title: Methods and Materials
THTR.description: Cutting-edge and traditional methods and materials that enhance both the planning stages and realization of the theatrical design.

THTR.title: Camera and Improvisation
THTR.description: Understanding on-camera acting and improvisation by creating original material both in front and behind the camera.

THTR.title: Intermediate Acting I: Drama/Comedy
THTR.description: Polishing the actor's skills through analysis and performance applied to the arc of a character.

THTR.title: Intermediate Acting I: Drama/Comedy
THTR.description: Polishing the actor's skills through analysis and performance applied to the arc of a character.

THTR.title: Introduction to Medical Clowning
THTR.description: Explores the art of clowning in hospitals for the purpose of improving the well-being of those in need.

THTR.title: Theatre in Los Angeles
THTR.description: Current state of American theatre, through a study of acting, playwriting, criticism, stage design, lighting, and dramatic styles.

THTR.title: Shakespeare in His World
THTR.description: The plays and theatre of Shakespeare, the influences on his work  and his contemporary world. Recommended preparation: THTR 201,  THTR 310, THTR 311

THTR.title: Projection Design I
THTR.description: Investigation of the projection design process, equipment, multi-media, digital technology concepts and related documentation.

THTR.title: Directing
THTR.description: Examination of basic directorial principles. Pre-production analysis and rehearsal procedures; relationship of the director to actor; integration of technical aspects of production.

THTR.title: Directing
THTR.description: Examination of basic directorial principles. Pre-production analysis and rehearsal procedures; relationship of the director to actor; integration of technical aspects of production.

THTR.title: Audio-Drama
THTR.description: Develop a basic understanding of the skills required to effectively develop, create, record, edit and market an audio drama.

THTR.title: Comedy in LA
THTR.description: Experiential and discussion-based; examines Los Angeles-based live comedy as it continues to evolve, both through text and performance.

THTR.title: Programming for Lighting
THTR.description: Strategies and principles in computerized programming for theatrical lighting, emphasizing its applied use in creating kinetic, responsive environments.

THTR.title: LGBTQ Theatre
THTR.description: Explores the range and genealogy of LGBTQ theatre and performance across political, historical, and theatrical contexts.

THTR.title: Comedy of Manners
THTR.description: Study of the development of Comedy of Manners, with primary focus on Restoration Comedy of Manners.

THTR.title: Physical Theatre I
THTR.description: Actor training anchored by rigorous physical movements.   Activities include comedy, clowning, juggling, and mask work.   Open to BFA acting majors only.

THTR.title: Theatre Clown
THTR.description: Introduction to techniques of clown performance and key techniques including complicite, play, looks and drops.

THTR.title: Creating the Hit Podcast
THTR.description: Develops the ability to create a podcast. Focuses on skills to produce, perform, market and monetize a podcast across a variety of genres.

THTR.title: Intermediate Acting II
THTR.description: Further development of range and breadth of performance skills with emphasis on texts of heightened language and style.

THTR.title: Improv 2: Advanced Improv
THTR.description: An in depth study of improvised comedy scene work.  An exploration of the primary tools and structure for creating improvised scenes and developing characters for stage and screen.

THTR.title: Casting for Stage and Screen
THTR.description: Introduction of the casting principles and practices for four of the mediums that dominate entertainment: theatre, film, television and commercials.

THTR.title: Performance Capture
THTR.description: An immersive course exploring Motion/Performance Capture technology, terminology and acting techniques for film, TV and games.

THTR.title: Scenic Construction
THTR.description: Technology, organization, and operation of the theatrical scene shop centered around the proper and safe use of tools, the choosing of materials, and methods of construction.

THTR.title: Introduction to Sound Design
THTR.description: The art and techniques of theatrical sound design. The use of music and ambient sound in theatrical presentations. Design elements as metaphor.

THTR.title: The Actor's Instrument: Voice and Body II
THTR.description: Continued training in the areas of breath awareness, physical awareness, voice, speech work and movement training.

THTR.title: Basic Voice
THTR.description: a: Examination of the individual voice centering on resonance, tone, flexibility, and support through dramatic selections for transmitting meaning and emotion of character.

THTR.title: Basic Voice
THTR.description: Examination of the individual voice centering on resonance, tone, flexibility, and support through dramatic selections for transmitting meaning and emotion of character. Continuation of 342a.

THTR.title: Musical Theatre Audition
THTR.description: Designed to give students confidence and integrity for auditions in musical theatre. Choosing appropriate material and preparation for the audition and performance. Audition required.

THTR.title: Costume Crafts: Armor and Millinery
THTR.description: An overview of costume crafts construction techniques as they relate to the more structured of crafts. Hat, jewelry, shoe and armor construction techniques are explored.

THTR.title: Intermediate Acting II
THTR.description: Building and sustaining character with special focus on stylized realism, subtext and heightened language. Multi-cultural text and methodologies.

THTR.title: Acting Shakespeare
THTR.description: Basic approach to the acting and analysis of the highly formalized texts of William Shakespeare.

THTR.title: Acting for Sitcoms
THTR.description: Provide an understanding as to how to work in half-hour television and streaming media.

THTR.title: Playwriting I
THTR.description: Essential elements of playwriting through weekly assignments, students' initiative, occasional productions of scenes, and extensive classroom analysis.

THTR.title: Playwriting II
THTR.description: Continuation of the work begun in 365.

THTR.title: Drama as Human Relations
THTR.description: A focus on American ethnic and multicultural diversity from the  perspectives of gender, race, and myth as revealed in plays, film,  and other performance media.

THTR.title: Theatre Practicum
THTR.description: Substantive participation in a production sponsored by the School and supervised by the faculty.

THTR.title: Contemporary Theatre in a Changing World
THTR.description: Explores the bold approaches that characterize the best of contemporary theatre, as well as the artists who are groundbreakers in a changing world.

THTR.title: Acting Theory
THTR.description: Examination of the theoretical foundations of acting as an art form through the reading of primary historical texts.

THTR.title: Performing Identities
THTR.description: This course explores the live performance medium as a creative means of social redress and personal expression. Duplicates credit in the former THTR 393m.

THTR.title: Theatre on the Edge
THTR.description: An exploration of the art of theatre at the edge of possibilities.

THTR.title: Drawing and Rendering for the Theater
THTR.description: Drawing and rendering techniques appropriate for theater designers. Drawing and drawing theory.

THTR.title: Dialects
THTR.description: The study of standard American stage dialect using the international phonetic alphabet.

THTR.title: Dialects
THTR.description: The study of accents and regional dialects.

THTR.title: Advanced Drafting: Vectorworks
THTR.description: An exploration of computer aided drafting (CAD) software, including drafting standards as achieved with Vectorworks and related software.

THTR.title: The Digital Actor
THTR.description: Empowers the student to forge a career in acting by managing and utilizing the many facets of social and digital media.

THTR.title: The Business of Acting
THTR.description: Develops the student's ability to connect and combine managerial, economic and business-related skills with the craft and career of acting.

THTR.title: Stage Combat
THTR.description: Introduction to safe and effective portrayals of violence for the stage. Training and practice of unarmed stage combat skills. Recommended preparation: THTR 216.

THTR.title: Alexander Technique for Performers
THTR.description: Training and practice in the work of F.M. Alexander. A clear and systematic look into the underlying principles that govern human movement.

THTR.title: Public Speaking as Performance: A Course for Non-Actors
THTR.description: Public speaking approached as performance, using acting techniques to communicate with confidence, clarity and charisma.

THTR.title: Improv 3 : Long Form Improvisation
THTR.description: Emphasis on  Full Length Improvised Performances including the  styles of various playwrights, genres of films, "the Harold,  "improvised plays and musicals. Building on the groundwork of THTR  122 Improvisation and Theatre Games and THTR 322 Improv 2,  students apply the techniques to long form unscripted performances.

THTR.title: Magic
THTR.description: The dramatic art of making an audience believe something is impossible. the history and performance of magic including illusion, mentalism, vanishing, coin and card tricks.

THTR.title: Creator as Entrepreneur
THTR.description: Explores the tools required to forge a career as a contemporary creator, with an emphasis on producing and monetizing new work through modern platforms.

THTR.title: Dynamics of Technical Theatre
THTR.description: Advanced technical direction topics involving the technical analysis and design of moving scenery and theatrical systems.

THTR.title: Being on Screen: A Class for Presenters, Hosts, and Others
THTR.description: Exploration of on-camera skills required for presenters, hosts, athletes, public speakers, and others whose careers will include on-screen appearances.

THTR.title: Audition Technique for Film, Television and New Media
THTR.description: Develop on-camera auditioning skills for actors at a professional level in a variety of film, television and new media venues.

THTR.title: Stage Management II
THTR.description: Application of stage management procedures required in the professional theatre.

THTR.title: Seminar in Theatre Design
THTR.description: Research into the application of contemporary topics relevant to theatrical design within the diverse cultural environment of the greater Los Angeles area.

THTR.title: Scene Design II
THTR.description: Continuation of THTR 330. Evolution of scene design through  analysis of script, environmental factors, and styles.

THTR.title: Costume Design II
THTR.description: Evolution of costume design through analysis of script,            environmental factors, and styles.

THTR.title: Lighting Design II
THTR.description: Continuation of THTR 332. Evolution of lighting design through    analysis of script, environmental factors, and styles.

THTR.title: Advanced Theatrical Drafting
THTR.description: Drafting style and complex graphic communication. Emphasis on creating professional plates, developing an individual style and graphic problem solving.

THTR.title: Scene Painting
THTR.description: Techniques, materials, and equipment of the scenic artist  including both historic and modern methods. Recommended  preparation: paint and drawing experience

THTR.title: Technical Theatre
THTR.description: Theory and practice of technical theatre. Emphasis is on technical problem solving and graphic solutions to technical theatre.

THTR.title: Advanced Sound Design
THTR.description: Advanced exploration of theatrical sound design theory and related technology; creative uses of music, sound effects, and audio equipment in modern theaters.

THTR.title: Voice-over Acting
THTR.description: Acting techniques, recording studio technology and editing for the field of voice acting and voice-overs.

THTR.title: Developing Your Speaking Voice
THTR.description: Development of resonance, range and clarity. Examination of posture and breathwork.  Applications of voice skills to acting, professional speaking and personal projects.

THTR.title: Fashion Influencing
THTR.description: Analysis of key influencers and aesthetics within relevant digital platforms for the fashion industry.

THTR.title: History of Fashion and the Costume
THTR.description: Introduction to four hundred years of fashion history drawing parallels between the fashion and period that it existed.

THTR.title: Taking it on the Road and Beyond
THTR.description: Specific instruction to prepare Stage Managers for the rigors and processes of Touring and Opera productions as well as other non-theatrical team-based collaborations in entertainment.

THTR.title: Acting Shakespeare II
THTR.description: A continuation and deeper investigation of the analysis and performance of the highly formalized texts of William Shakespeare.

THTR.title: Latinx Theatre
THTR.description: Explores the range and genealogy of Latinx theatre and performance from its origins in the last fifty years to the present.

THTR.title: Film Acting Practicum
THTR.description: Creating a visual narrative story. Gaining a basic understanding of both the visual and technical components of story telling.

THTR.title: Asian and Asian American Theatre: Identity and Aesthetics
THTR.description: Explores Asian and Asian American theatre, from the historical to  the contemporary, with an aim toward understanding issues of  aesthetics, acculturation, and identity.

THTR.title: An Actor's Reel
THTR.description: Using original and existing scripted material for film, television and new media students will act, film and edit scenes to form a professional performance reel.

THTR.title: Playwriting III
THTR.description: Analysis of a full-length play or its equivalent with continued production opportunity.

THTR.title: Going Viral: Performance for New Media
THTR.description: A writing and performance course (partially online) for new media. Students will learn to create original short form and web series content for new media including YouTube, Funny or Die, Periscope and other Internet platforms.

THTR.title: Industry Landscape
THTR.description: Designed to provide the graduating students with opportunity to select, prepare and perform for agents, directors and producers in film, television and theatre. Also includes the study of the business of acting.

THTR.title: Sketch Comedy in Performance
THTR.description: A workshop in the techniques of performing humorous sketches, in collaboration with writers, directors, and technicians in the production of a live sketch comedy show. Recommended preparation: THTR 101, THTR 122, THTR 470.

THTR.title: Introduction to Stand Up Comedy
THTR.description: An introduction to the discipline of conceiving, writing, and creating original Stand Up Comedy routines

THTR.title: Acting on Camera: The Collaborative Process
THTR.description: Acting students will learn to develop on-camera acting skills and to collaborate with student directors and cinematographers from the School of Cinematic Arts.

THTR.title: African American Theatre, Dance, and Performance
THTR.description: A survey of African American theatre and cultural performance traditions as a reflection of both African American culture and American history.

THTR.title: Solo Performance
THTR.description: A writing-performance workshop in which students write, develop,  and rehearse original, autobiographical and character monologues  and perform them at the end of the semester.

THTR.title: Performance for Camera
THTR.description: Structured to address the dynamics of acting in relation to film/television. Refining the students' understanding of the similarities/differences between acting on stage/film.

THTR.title: Performance for Camera
THTR.description: Continued exploration of acting for film/television. Furthering the student's understanding of the similarities/differences between acting on stage/film.

THTR.title: Stand Up 2: Becoming A Pro
THTR.description: Interactive performance and writing intensive focusing on creating professional level comedy material plus onstage performance strategies.

THTR.title: Acting in Television Commercials
THTR.description: An on-camera, workshop-style introduction to techniques, perspectives and theories unique to performing in television commercials.

THTR.title: Theatre in the Community
THTR.description: Research and actively develop the theory of theatre as a movingpolitical, social, economic and spiritual force of change withinthe local community.

THTR.title: Theatre Internship
THTR.description: Practical experience in the entertainment industry.

THTR.title: Directed Research
THTR.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

THTR.title: Periods and Styles
THTR.description: A survey of the influence of historical and cultural events on the evaluation of theatrical styles. Restoration to 20th century.

THTR.title: Advanced Theatre Practicum
THTR.description: Intensive participation in a production sponsored by the school and supervised by the faculty, to increase and develop artistic growth.

THTR.title: Dramaturgical Perspectives and Approaches
THTR.description: Investigates art and craft of dramatic writing initiated/completed in other MFA in Dramatic Writing courses or that was submitted as a sample for program entry.

THTR.title: Poetry and Prose into Drama
THTR.description: Plays for the stage shall be written using public-domain poetry and prose as inspiration and source material, complemented with exploring poetry, prose, and varied dramas as context for the student writer. Students should be well-versed in literature, and have written in one or more genres.

THTR.title: Advanced Creating Characters
THTR.description: An advanced writing workshop that focuses on continuing development of the crafting of character, centering on depth, breadth, dimensionality, and authenticity.

THTR.title: Advanced Movement
THTR.description: Advanced exercises in movement for the use of the body in relation to the stage.

THTR.title: Advanced Movement
THTR.description: Advanced exercises in movement for the use of the body in relation to the stage including a study of Viewpoints and Mask Work.

THTR.title: Advanced Movement
THTR.description: Advanced exercises in movement for the use of the body in         relation to the stage.

THTR.title: Filmmaking for Actors
THTR.description: The execution and breakdown of a film project from ideation to completion.

THTR.title: Advanced Acting
THTR.description: Advanced training in acting skills including camera work; emphasis upon individual needs.

THTR.title: Advanced Acting
THTR.description: Advanced training in acting skills; emphasis upon individual needs.

THTR.title: Advanced Acting
THTR.description: Advanced training in acting skills; includes performing for agents, directors and producers in film, television and theatre.

THTR.title: Textual Studies for Performance
THTR.description: Close textual reading of dramatic texts as a fundamental tool for  rehearsal and performance.

THTR.title: Advanced Voice Diction
THTR.description: Individual work in improving the actor's vocal range.

THTR.title: Advanced Voice Diction
THTR.description: Individual work in improving the actor's vocal range.

THTR.title: Advanced Voice Diction
THTR.description: Advanced individual vocal development and application to a variety of professional and performance circumstances including voice-over work.

THTR.title: Dramatic Writing Studio
THTR.description: Investigates gestalt of the student dramatic writer's professional development from the empty page and writing fundamentals to the first-draft script, business affairs, and dramaturgical advancement.

THTR.title: Professional Seminar
THTR.description: Introduction to the world of the professional actor.

THTR.title: Performance with Camera
THTR.description: Structured to address the dynamics of acting in relation to film/television. Refining the students understanding of the similarities/differences between acting on stage/film.

THTR.title: Dramatic Narrative Design
THTR.description: Continued exploration of the execution and breakdown of a film project, including script development and production techniques, through hands-on collaboration.

THTR.title: Thesis Development and Attainment
THTR.description: Designed to guide the MFADW student toward refinement of thesis including vision, development, and execution.

THTR.title: Theatre Practicum
THTR.description: Substantive participation in productions sponsored by the school and supervised by the faculty.

GERO.title: Gerontology: The Science of Adult Development
GERO.description: Introduction to adult development through the lifespan;  biological, psychological, and social processes; gerontology as a  career for the future.

GERO.title: A Journey into the Mind
GERO.description: Introduction to the brain and mind. A unique multimedia approach to stress how knowledge about the mind is gained from scientific and clinical investigations.

GERO.title: Psychology of Adult Development
GERO.description: How psychologists study thinking, memory, emotions, personality, and behavior, and how people change in these throughout adulthood to old age.

GERO.title: Introduction to Psychology and Aging
GERO.description: An introduction to the core curriculum in the study of Gerontology. Research perspectives on adult development and aging; methodological issues; personality and relationship issues; general mental and emotional components of aging; research methods.

GERO.title: Policy, Values, and Power in an Aging Society
GERO.description: How Americans' political values affect public policy. Studies of landmark legislation to explore the social contract between generations and role of governments in social welfare.

GERO.title: Diversity in Aging
GERO.description: Exploring diversity in the older population and variability in the human aging process.

GERO.title: Physiology, Nutrition, and Aging
GERO.description: Explores nutritional needs and the physiological, psychological, and sociological relationships to nutrition. Laboratory experiments in assessment and evaluation.

GERO.title: Exercise and Aging: Principles and Programs
GERO.description: Physiological, psychological, and sociological aspects of         exercise. Laboratory involvement in assessment and evaluation of   fitness.

GERO.title: Neurobiology of Aging
GERO.description: Age-related changes in nervous system structure and function; relationship of brain changes to changes in cognitive function and perception; Alzheimer's and Parkinson's diseases.

GERO.title: Neuroaffective Disorders of Aging
GERO.description: Methods of studying, evaluating, and treating cognitive, psychiatric, and behavioral problems associated with medical conditions of old age.

GERO.title: Health Issues in Adulthood
GERO.description: Physiological, psychological, and social health problems of adults  as they are impacted by health choices throughout life.

GERO.title: Aging Brain Interventions
GERO.description: Design and write up a proposal for a behavioral intervention with older adults that examines the effects of the intervention on the aging brain.

GERO.title: Women and Aging: Psychological, Social, and      Political Implications
GERO.description: Problems and resources of the middle-aged and older woman in a changing society; including discrimination, stereotypes, employment, social interaction, etc.

GERO.title: Social and Psychological Aspects of Death and Dying
GERO.description: Introduction and critical survey of the current issues, concepts, and research of the social and psychological aspects of death and dying.

GERO.title: Biodemography of Aging
GERO.description: Consideration of the biological and social-cultural factors that govern the evolution of life spans and the life of humans and selected animal models

GERO.title: Biotechnology and Chemical Biology in Modern Biomedical      Research
GERO.description: Topical seminar in molecular and computational biology. Junior, senior or graduate standing.

GERO.title: Food History, Culture and Society
GERO.description: Examines historical, cultural, economic, social and wellness roles of food in society and introduces dietary practices that support healthy aging and longevity.

GERO.title: Directed Research
GERO.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

GERO.title: Practicum
GERO.description: Supervised experience in one or more community agencies.  Graded  CR/NC.

GERO.title: Senior Seminar
GERO.description: An in-depth integration of major research and professional themes  in the study of human development and aging.

GERO.title: Practicum in Geriatric Care
GERO.description: Supervised experience in a geriatric health care setting which  allows students to put theories and ideas into practive.  Graded  CR/NC.  Lecture, discussion, and fieldwork.

GERO.title: Honors Seminar
GERO.description: Advanced study of empirical approaches in gerontology.   Preparation, progress, presentation, and evaluation of Senior  Honors Thesis research.  Standing in Gerontology Honors Program  and departmental approval.

GERO.title: Honors Seminar
GERO.description: Advanced study of empirical approaches in gerontology.   Preparation, progress, presentation, and evaluation of Senior  Honors Thesis research.  Standing in Gerontology Honors Program  and departmental approval.

GERO.title: Honors Seminar
GERO.description: Advanced study of empirical approaches in gerontology.   Preparation, progress, presentation, and evaluation of Senior  Honors Thesis research.  Standing in Gerontology Honors Program  and departmental approval.

GERO.title: Perspectives on a Changing Society: An Introduction to Aging
GERO.description: A web based course analyzing physical, mental, and social age-related changes as well as implications of population aging trends for individuals and society.

GERO.title: Marketing and Shifts in Consumer Decision Making
GERO.description: Branding, marketing, and consumer behavior through examination of  established, transitioning and emerging aging services and  organizations.

GERO.title: Current Issues in Aging Services Management
GERO.description: Basic skills needed for an executive working in an aging services  environment. Recommended for entry level administrators and  managers.

GERO.title: Housing and Community Policies and Programs
GERO.description: Examination of the behavioral and social consequences of design and the environment to create a more satisfying physical environment for both frail and active older adults.

GERO.title: Technological Innovations in Aging (Gerontechnology)
GERO.description: Reflections on shifts in preferences for aging in place and the  market ramifications of innovations in science and technology on  older consumers and service provider.

GERO.title: The Mind and Body Connection through the Lifespan
GERO.description: An introduction to mind-body processes involved in healthy aging. Examines the interplay of emotions, beliefs, and behaviors in shaping health-relevant biological processes.

GERO.title: Physiology of Development and Aging
GERO.description: Examination of lifespan physiology of human development, growth, and aging; major emphasis in the physiology of the later years and implications for health maintenance.

GERO.title: Advanced Therapeutic Nutrition
GERO.description: Application of nutrition science, physiology, biochemistry, and metabolism to evaluate critically ill patients and plan nutrition intervention and monitoring. Open only to graduate students.

GERO.title: Life Span Developmental Psychology
GERO.description: Behavior from adulthood to old age; study of major components of behavior such as perception, cognitive processes, personality, intergenerational relationships, sexuality, and life styles.

GERO.title: Life Span Developmental Sociology
GERO.description: Life-span perspective on the sociological theories of marriage and the family, intergenerational relationships, work and retirement, and other forms of social organization.

GERO.title: Social Policy and Aging
GERO.description: Major legislation and programs; examination and analysis of policy-making and political processes affecting development and implementation of programs for older persons.

GERO.title: Administration and System Management in Programs for Older Adults
GERO.description: Application of theories of administration and system management to public and volunteer programs and services for older adults including residential institutions and community programs.

GERO.title: Human Resources and Aging
GERO.description: Addresses legal issues and liability arising out of the employer-employee relationship, and how to identify and act proactively to minimize such risk.

GERO.title: Evaluation: Incorporating Evidence-Based Practices
GERO.description: Examination of the evaluation of health and service delivery in  aging services industries.

GERO.title: Integrating Gerontology: A Multidisciplinary Approach
GERO.description: Aging (commonalities and distinctions) as addressed by biologists,psychologists, and sociologists. Topics include researchperspectives, normative agings, functional decline and disability,and aging and society.

GERO.title: Fundamentals of Nutrition: Micronutrients
GERO.description: Explore the role of micronutrients, vitamins, minerals and phytonutrients in human nutrition, including digestion, absorption, metabolism, and major biological, physiological and metabolic roles.

GERO.title: Introduction to Aging and Normal Changes with Aging
GERO.description: Introduces medical and health care professionals to the interdisciplinary field of gerontology. Examines the worlds changing demography; effects of aging on physical, psychological and social changes; aging process, ethical issues, aging stereotypes.

GERO.title: Geropsychology
GERO.description: Understanding geropsychology and cognition in advanced age; psychosocial theories of aging and psychodynamic models.

GERO.title: Novel Technologies in Aging and Assisted Living
GERO.description: Focuses on the understanding of technology use with older adults. Examines telemedicine and e-health technologies as well as ethical considerations.

GERO.title: Cognitive Decline: Alzheimer's Disease and Dementia and Adva
GERO.description: Covers cognitive decline for people with Alzheimers Disease or other forms of dementia.  Imaging technology to identify and find treatment options.

GERO.title: Marketing Senior Living
GERO.description: Current practices in marketing senior living and associated services. Examines behaviors and preferences of older adults and their families. Explores new media platforms.

GERO.title: Food Service and Senior Living
GERO.description: Addresses the food services components of senior living. Covers pricing, menu design and nutrition.

GERO.title: Branding Senior Living
GERO.description: Marketing models aimed to provide services for senior living. Analyze various institutions models for marketing, communicating and technological influence to brand a facility.

GERO.title: Case Studies in Leadership and Change Management
GERO.description: Examination of case studies of issues affecting the aging services  industries and the role industry leaders play in reacting to  change.

GERO.title: Directed Research
GERO.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

GERO.title: Field Practicum
GERO.description: Supervised experiential learning in one or more organizations     that serve older adults; includes a regularly scheduled seminar.   Graded CR/NC.

GERO.title: Multidisciplinary Research Seminar in Aging
GERO.description: Multidisciplinary perspectives on current research in Gerontology including physiology, neurobiology, health and medicine, psychology, sociology and public policy. Topics will change each semester.

GERO.title: Research Methods
GERO.description: An introduction to research methods and their application to gerontology including problem formation, research design, data collection, descriptive and analytical statistics, interpretation, and report preparation.

GERO.title: Molecular Genetics of Aging
GERO.description: Explores concepts of molecular and genetic regulation of healthy aging, lifespan, and age-related diseases.

GERO.title: Seminar on Discoveries of Biogerontology
GERO.description: Critical analyses of primary scientific data and interpretations presented in the literature. (Duplicates credit in former GERO 602)

GERO.title: Research and Journal Club Presentation Workshop
GERO.description: Intensive training in journal club and research talk presentations for graduate students in the Biology of Aging Ph.D. program.

GERO.title: Health and Aging
GERO.description: Examination of changes in health related to age, changes in health in populations over time, and the key health issues facing older persons.

GERO.title: Laboratory Rotations in the Biology of Aging
GERO.description: Mandatory organized laboratory rotation. Allows students to participate in laboratory activities. Designed to help select dissertation advisor and research.

GERO.title: Practical Data Science and Stats for Geroscience Research
GERO.description: Holistic training in Geroscience including solid bases in statistics, data analysis and data science for reporting reproducible and robust research results.

GERO.title: Research
GERO.description: Research leading up to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied toward the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

GERO.title: Doctoral Dissertation
GERO.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

GERO.title: Doctoral Dissertation
GERO.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

GERO.title: Doctoral Dissertation
GERO.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

GERO.title: Doctoral Dissertation
GERO.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

GERO.title: Doctoral Dissertation
GERO.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

ACMD.title: Becoming a Leader in Academic Medicine
ACMD.description: Current approaches to leadership within the context of academic medicine and health professions education, leadership styles, emotional intelligence, critical reflection, well-being and personal leadership journeys.

ACMD.title: Leading Change in Academic Medical Centers
ACMD.description: Developing skills for promoting programs within health professions education; teams and teamwork, organizational change, conflict resolution, crucial conversations, non-violent communication, negotiation and teaching leadership.

ACMD.title: Instructional Design in Academic Medicine and Health
ACMD.description: Focuses on Instructional Design for Health Professions Education. Content includes learning principles, teaching methods, session development, assessment techniques and designing curricula (Plan, Implement, Evaluate, Disseminate).

ACMD.title: Competencies in Academic Medicine and Health
ACMD.description: Learning theory, teaching methods, assessment techniques related to acquisition and reinforcement of competencies related to patient care, practice based learning and improvement and systems-based practice.

ACMD.title: Implementing Research on Innovation in Academic Medicine
ACMD.description: Mentored research on an innovation in academic medicine, qualitative and qualitative methods, and producing a formal written research report:

ACMD.title: Fieldwork: Designing Innovations for the Health Professions
ACMD.description: Individual projects designing curricular or other innovations for an individual program or specialty as an extension of program concepts or deepening the capstone experience.

ACMD.title: Capstone Portfolio for the Master of Academic Medicine
ACMD.description: Role of portfolios for teachers and learners; develop a personal capstone portfolio that represents each learners accomplishment of the core competencies of the MACM program.

ADSC.title: Research Methods in Addiction Science
ADSC.description: Real-world implementation of an observational research study in addiction science that teaches subject recruitment, survey administration, data collection and analysis, and dissemination of study results.

ADSC.title: Regulation of Addictive Consumer Products
ADSC.description: Examines regulatory frameworks for addictive products (tobacco, alcohol, vapes, foods) exploring historical approaches, ethical issues, and balancing public health, consumer choice and industry interests.

ANST.title: Advanced Pharmacology of Anesthesia Practice I
ANST.description: Pharmacokinetic and pharmacodynamic principles, uptake and distribution of inhalational anesthetics, and pharmacology of respiratory and cardiovascular drugs. Application of pharmacologic principles to anesthetic management.

ANST.title: Principles of Nurse Anesthesia Practice
ANST.description: Basic theory of anesthesia administration, preanesthetic assessment, physical examination, monitoring. Case management including airway and blood/fluid management, anesthesia machine, and postoperative pain. Lecture/case study format.

ANST.title: Professional Integration to the Clinical Environment
ANST.description: Correlation of techniques of anesthesia administration with application of scientific and pharmacologic theory in the clinical environment with observation and supervised clinical instruction.

ANST.title: Advanced Clinical Residency in Nurse Anesthesia I
ANST.description: Correlating techniques of anesthesia administration with application of scientific and pharmacologic theory expanded to geriatric, obstetrical, and pediatric anesthesia; anesthetic management includes medically compromised patients.

ANST.title: Advanced Clinical Residency in Nurse Anesthesia III
ANST.description: Correlation of techniques of anesthesia administration with application of scientific and pharmacologic theory expanded to neuroanesthesia, cardiac anesthesia, trauma anesthesia, critical care and pain management.

ANST.title: Advanced Clinical Residency in Nurse Anesthesia IV
ANST.description: Correlation of techniques of anesthesia administration with application of scientific and pharmacologic theory expanded to neuroanesthesia, cardiac anesthesia, trauma anesthesia, critical care and pain management.

ANST.title: Clinical Synthesis II
ANST.description: Part two of a four-semester curriculum promoting synthesis and mastery of topics integral to the art and science of nurse anesthesia planning, management and delivery.

ANST.title: PeriOperative Evaluation and Management II
ANST.description: Continuation of ANST-651 with an emphasis on differential  diagnosis, illness management, and perioperative optimization in  patients with multiple health alterations.

ANST.title: Doctoral Capstone Project
ANST.description: Mentored research on an individualized topic of interest leading to the professional doctorate.  The project will culminate in a formal written research paper or presentation.

ANST.title: Doctoral Capstone Project
ANST.description: Mentored research on an individualized topic of interest leading to the professional doctorate. The project will culminate in a formal written research paper or presentation.

CBG.title: Cancer  Biology and Genomics Research Seminar  Series
CBG.description: Cancer biology research seminar for doctoral students enrolled in the CBG program.

CBG.title: Topics in Cancer (Epi)Genomics
CBG.description: Selected topics in Cancer Biology and Genomics including review of contemporary literature and research.

CBG.title: Research
CBG.description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Open only to doctoral students. Graded CR/NC.

CBG.title: Doctoral Dissertation
CBG.description: Credit on acceptance of dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC. Open only to doctoral students.

CBG.title: Doctoral Dissertation
CBG.description: Credit on acceptance of dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC. Open only to doctoral students.

CBG.description: Credit on acceptance of dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC. Open only to doctoral students.

CBG.title: Doctoral Dissertation
CBG.description: Credit on acceptance of dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC. Open only to doctoral students.

IAS.title: Human Skeletal Anatomy
IAS.description: An intensive introduction to the human skeleton and the fundamentals of bone and dental biology. Covers a variety of topics including: skeletal development; functional interpretation of bone and bony processes; osteological and dental pathology; human anatomical variation; laboratory analyses and imaging techniques; methods for estimating age, sex, and stature; and comparative osteology.

IAS.title: Human Development: Clinically Oriented Embryology
IAS.description: System-based course covering the anatomical and molecular processes that shape human embryological development with an emphasis on relevant clinical correlations.  Includes gross anatomy lab component.

IAS.title: Microscopic Anatomy II
IAS.description: Study of microscopic anatomy emphasizing embryonic origin of the body plan, cells, tissues, and organs; ultrastructural and functional correlations. Duplicates credit in former CNB 511b.

IAS.title: Teaching in the Anatomical Sciences: Practicum
IAS.description: Obtain a deeper understanding of clinical anatomy, develop  pedagogical skills in small-group anatomical demonstration, and  learn to prepare practical exams.

IAS.title: Directed Research
IAS.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

IAS.title: Research
IAS.description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

HP.title: Introduction to Health Promotion and Disease     Prevention
HP.description: Introduction to strategies for promoting health and wellness. Includes self monitoring of health risk behavior, goal setting, and behavior changes.

HP.title: Introduction to Research Apprenticeship
HP.description: Individual research apprenticeship in health related fields under  supervision of a departmental faculty member.  Graded CR/NC.   Departmental approval.

HP.title: Principles of Human Behavior
HP.description: Overview and analysis of human behavior and the influences of behavior on health and disease.

HP.title: Biological and Behavioral Basis of Disease
HP.description: Examination of the major systems of the human body; disease  processes and behavioral risk factors.

HP.title: Health Behavior Statistical Methods
HP.description: Intermediate statistics for health behavior studies; topics include descriptive statistics, hypothesis testing, correlation and regression, and use of computer software in data analysis.

HP.title: Health Behavior Research Methods
HP.description: Introduction to the design, conduct and evaluation of health  behavior research studies; quantitative and qualitative approaches  to research and analysis. Recommended preparation: HP 340L

HP.title: Culture, Lifestyle, and Health
HP.description: Comparison of national and international differences in health status as influenced by cultural practices and lifestyles within geographic, economic, and political environments.

HP.title: Sexually Transmitted Diseases: A Global Public Health Priority
HP.description: An overview of the magnitude and impact of STDs including  prevention, diagnosis, and treatment of common STDs, STD/HIV  inter-relationship, global burden, trends, public health  challenges, and STD/HIV prevention and control strategies and  programs worldwide.

HP.title: Environmental Health in the Community
HP.description: Survey of occupational and environmental health. Introduction to  epidemiology, exposure assessment, toxicology, policy development,  risk assessment, and effects of urban development on health.

HP.title: Issues in Prevention and Cessation of Drug Abuse
HP.description: Examination of factors related to drug abuse behaviors; overview  and assessment of drug abuse prevention and cessation programs;  relapse prevention programs. Recommended preparation: HP 300

HP.title: Behavior and Education Strategies for Nutrition and Fitness
HP.description: Examination of dietary intake and exercise behaviors as they  relate to health and illness; methods for measuring diet and  exercise. Recommended preparation: HP 430

HP.title: Global Environmental Changes and Health
HP.description: Discussion of global environmental changes, including climate change, air pollution, water pollution, radiation, and their impacts on human health.

HP.title: Traditional Eastern Medicine and Modern Health
HP.description: Overview of traditional Eastern approaches toward health and  disease; relevance to modern health issues, emphasizing a  comparison between traditional Chinese and modern Western medicine. Recommended Preparation:  Fundamentals of Medicine

HP.title: Case Studies in Global Health
HP.description: Case study examination of programs and organizational structure  underlying current international efforts addressing problems  related to infection disease, chronic disease, global  environmental change, emergencies and emerging disease epidemics.

HP.title: Directed Research
HP.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit. Open to HP majors only. Recommended preparation: HP 350L

INTD.title: Infection and Host Responses
INTD.description: Overview of microbes, their life cycles and the host responses they elicit, evade or exploit, including the manipulation and the malfunction of the immune system.

INTD.title: Pathobiology of Disease
INTD.description: Relationship between histopathological and clinical manifestations of disease and their underlying molecular mechanisms. Topics include inflammatory, developmental, environmental, degenerative, and neoplastic disease processes.

INTD.title: Current Topics in Cellular Homeostasis
INTD.description: Weekly research lectures by leading investigators in the field of homeostatic response to injury such as cell death, inflammation, fibrosis and regeneration.

INTD.title: Medical Biology Seminar
INTD.description: Selected topics in systems biology and disease.

INTD.title: Internship for Curricular Practical Training
INTD.description: Part-time or full-time, practical work experience in the student's field of study. The internship must be located at an off-campus facility. Students are individually supervised by faculty. May not be taken until the student has completed at least one semester of enrollment in the graduate program.

INTD.title: Student Research Presentation
INTD.description: Students prepare and present their own research to an audience of faculty and peers. Graded CR/NC. Open only to graduate students.

INTD.title: Pre-clinical System Block for Health, Technology and Engineering
INTD.description: A three-to-nine week block of lectures and laboratories focused on particular body system (e.g. Cardiovascular, Renal, etc.). Open only to Health, Technology and Engineering students.

INTD.title: Research
INTD.description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Open only to doctoral students. Graded CR/NC.

MPHY.title: Directed Research
MPHY.description: Research leading to the masters degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Open only to master students. Graded CR/NC. (Duplicates credit in former PHBI-590.)

MPHY.title: Masters Thesis
MPHY.description: Credit upon acceptance of thesis. Graded IP/CR/NC. (Duplicates credit in former PHBI-594a.)

MPHY.title: Master's Thesis
MPHY.description: Credit upon acceptance of thesis. Graded IP/CR/NC. Duplicates credit in former PHBI-594b.

MPHY.description: Credit upon acceptance of thesis. Graded IP/CR/NC. (Duplicates credit in former PHBI-594z.)

Students are individually supervised by faculty. May not be taken until the student has completed at least one semester of enrollment in the graduate program.

BIOC.title: Logic and Design of Disease Mechanism Studies
BIOC.description: Experimental logic used to determine the mechanism of disease development, identity and validate therapeutic targets, and design therapeutic approaches.

BIOC.title: Optimal Research Presentations
BIOC.description: Lectures by peers; formal critique; prepare and present own research to faculty and peer audiences.

BIOC.title: Directed Research
BIOC.description: Research leading to the master of science degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree will be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

BIOC.description: Credit on acceptance of Thesis. Graded IP/CR/NC.

Students are individually supervised by faculty. May not be taken until the student has completed at least one semester of enrollment in the graduate program with a cumulative 3.0 GPA.

MDED.title: Narrative Medicine II: Methods and Pedagogy
MDED.description: Advanced study in Narrative Medicine; study current methods and best practices for designing, facilitating and evaluating narrative medicine workshops.

MDED.title: Intersubjectivity:  Lived Bodies/Relational Selves
MDED.description: Introduction to philosophical, anthropological and sociological considerations of intersubjectivity and experience; narrative approaches to intersubjectivity and relational self-making focusing, especially on clinical encounters.

MDED.title: Immigrants, Illness and Narrative Medicine
MDED.description: Apply narrative medicine methods to the study of fictional and non-fictional illness narratives from the immigrant perspective in the United States.

MDED.title: Directed Research
MDED.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

MDED.title: Narrative Medicine Capstone
MDED.description: A summative experience such as a thesis, a clinical practicum or a capstone project; regular meetings with an adviser and a final presentation are required for successful completion.

MEDS.title: Healthcare Foundations: Core Concepts and Terminology
MEDS.description: Introduction to and discussion on clinically relevant topics such as social determinants of health, medical ethics and legal and regulatory aspects, in preparation for experience in the clinical setting.

MEDS.title: Introduction to Data Innovation and Analytics
MEDS.description: Introduction to data innovation and analytics, converting data to knowledge and insights, statistical techniques, analytics models, implementing data analytics through real-world examples and situations.

MEDS.title: Introduction to Machine Intelligence
MEDS.description: Introduction to artificial intelligence and machine learning through programming models, training models with several methodologies, support vector machines, decision trees, ensemble learning and random forests.

MEDS.title: Introduction to Professionalism and the Practice of Medicine
MEDS.description: An introduction to professionalism and skills required in the practice of medicine and careers in health care.

MEDS.title: Introduction to Healthcare Innovation
MEDS.description: Introductions to various health innovations, including pathways, technology, techniques and outcomes. A framework for innovation in healthcare and overview of tools for health innovators.

MEDS.title: Challenges in the Forefront of Biomedical Ethics
MEDS.description: Examination of fundamental ethical concepts and principles in clinical health care and biomedical research. Use of film, case studies and discussion. Recommended Preparation: MDA-110 or MEDS-220.

MEDS.title: Mental Health and Climate Change
MEDS.description: Explores ways that changing climate affects individual and collective mental health, including concepts related to building individual and collective resilience to environmental threats.

MEDS.title: The Science of Altruism
MEDS.description: Explores the science behind altruism, volunteerism, compassion and how helping others impacts individuals physically, psychologically and behaviorally through lectures, projects and experiential learning.

MEDS.title: Human Cadaveric Anatomy
MEDS.description: Anatomical structure and function of the major regions of the human body as related to health and disease, using clinical cases, lectures and cadaveric demonstrations.

MEDS.title: Skeletal Biology and Pathology
MEDS.description: Overview of the cellular make-up of the human skeleton, the functions of bones, clinical application of this knowledge towards bone-related diseases, and introduction to technological advances in orthopedic surgery.

MEDS.title: Bench to Bedside: Application of the Basic Sciences
MEDS.description: A theoretical basis of laboratory approaches that help the biomedical or physician scientist in understanding the etiology of disease and targeting disease processes.

MEDS.title: Organ Failure: Non-Communicable Chronic Disease
MEDS.description: An examination of frequently treated diseases with the greatest impact on society. Involvement of medical specialists as guests.

MEDS.title: Stem Cells: Fact and Fiction
MEDS.description: Exploring how stem cells and regenerative medicine are portrayed in culture, the scientific underpinnings of what is currently possible, and visions into the future.

MEDS.title: Health Care Systems: A Doctor's Perspective
MEDS.description: An examination of the health care system of the United States, from the perspective of the physician and other health professions. Particularly covers health care systems as a workplace and how medical professionals fit into and operate within it.

MEDS.title: Medical Examiner-Coroner: Investigating Death
MEDS.description: Emphasizes the team-based approach used by forensic scientists, medical examiners and coroners to investigate the circumstances and determine the cause/manner of death. Prerequisites: BISC 220 or BISC 221 and MEDS 220. Open only to sophomores, juniors, and seniors.

MEDS.title: Introduction to Surgical Principles
MEDS.description: Introduction to the spectrum of surgical care, taught by surgeons, with the goal of developing an appreciation of the role that surgery plays in society. Prerequisites: BISC 220 or BISC 221 and CHEM 103 or CHEM 105a or CHEM 115a and MEDS 220. Open only to juniors and seniors.

MEDS.title: OB/GYN: The Medicine and Surgery of Reproduction
MEDS.description: An introduction to the practical realities of modern obstetric and gynecology practice from the point of view of practicing surgeon scientists at USC. Prerequisites: BISC-220 or BISC-221 and MEDS-220.

MEDS.title: Directed Research in Biomedical Science
MEDS.description: Individual research and readings.

MEDS.title: Social Emergency Medicine: Practicum with the  CHLA CHAT Team
MEDS.description: Explores the social determinants of health through supervised on-site practicum with the Community Health Advocates Team at Childrens Hospital Los Angeles and didactic sessions.

MEDS.title: Medical Spanish for the Health Professions
MEDS.description: Spanish language course for students planning to enter the health professions. Graded CR/NC.

MEDS.title: Zoonotic Infectious Diseases
MEDS.description: Background information on a group of infections that are transmitted via animal contact. Understanding of the epidemiology, clinical manifestations, treatment, and impact of the diseases on the economies of the countries in which they are found. Recommended preparation: MEDS 500. Open only to graduate students.

MEDS.title: Global Health Modules, Sexually Transmitted Infections
MEDS.description: Examines clinically relevant perspectives from distinguished international authors on STI issues and the devastating effect on particular geographical regions around the world.

MEDS.title: Foundation of Medicine: Anatomy, Physiology, and Pathology
MEDS.description: The basics of human anatomy (gross anatomy, histology, radiographic anatomy), physiology (cellular physiology, organ system areas) and pathology (general, systemic, cellular pathology).

MEDS.title: Non-communicable Diseases
MEDS.description: A conceptual framework for understanding global challenges faced in the management of non-communicable diseases, including heart disease, diabetes, chronic lung disease, and cancer.

MEDS.title: Global Nutrition
MEDS.description: A systematic survey of basic and clinical nutrition that provides an overview of critical public health-nutrition issues in both the developing world and industrial society.

MEDS.title: Maternal and Child Health in South Africa
MEDS.description: Examination of country-specific factors affecting pregnancy, pre-natal care, and childbirth in South Africa, with analysis of factors contributing to health inequality and methods to mitigate healthcare challenges.

MEDS.title: Global Palliative Care
MEDS.description: Exploration of the provision of palliative care and analysis of factors affecting the increased burden of palliative care provision facing developing regions of the world.

MEDS.title: Interprofessional Team Dynamics in Healthcare
MEDS.description: Examination of typical composition and function of interprofessional healthcare teams. Exploration of roles of team members and purview of care issues and common challenges, including medication management, inpatient/outpatient decision making, and care plan implementation.

MEDS.title: Directed Research
MEDS.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

MEDB.description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Open only to doctoral students. Graded CR/NC.

MICB.description: Overview of microbes, their life cycles and the host responses they elicit, evade or exploit, including the manipulation and the malfunction of the immune system.

MICB.title: Animal Virology
MICB.description: Virus structure and chemistry; virus-cell interactions; aspects of virus genetics; molecular biology; pathogenesis, immunology, and evolution of viral infections.

MICB.title: Recent Advances in Microbiology
MICB.description: Intensive examination of selected topics in microbiology. Student presentations and critiques. Required of all graduate students.

MICB.title: Microbiology Research Seminar
MICB.description: Critical discussion of current research topics. Students present   published and unpublished research results for discussion and      critique.

DSR.title: Cell and Gene Therapy Development - From Research to Clinic
DSR.description: Introduces the basic principles processes, and requirements of cell and gene therapy drug development, manufacturing and clinical applications using hands-on and interactive activities.

DSR.title: For PhD Students
DSR.description: Selected topics in Development, Stem Cell, and Regeneration.

DSR.title: Clinical Perspective of Regenerative Medicine
DSR.description: Offers interaction with clinicians in patient-care setting to understand the need and role of regenerative medicine in bedside management. Graded CR/NC.

DSR.title: Stem Cell Biology, Politics, and Ethics.
DSR.description: Selected topics on sub-fields within developmental and stem cell biology including review of contemporary literature and research.

DSR.title: Bioinformatic Methods: Transcriptome and Chromatin Analysis
DSR.description: Principles of bioinformatic and computational analysis methods applicable to genomic, epigenomic and molecular biology studies.

NEUM.title: Advanced Topics in Neuromedicine
NEUM.description: Introduces current research and advances in technologies related to diagnosis and treatment of neurological and neurodegenerative diseases and progress in research projects of student peers.

NEUM.title: Directed Research
NEUM.description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

MBPH.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.
