MBPH.description: Part-time or full-time, practical work experience in the student's field of study. The internship must be located at an off-campus facility. Students are individually supervised by faculty. May not be taken until the student has completed at least one semester of enrollment in the graduate program.

MBPH.title: Research
MBPH.description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

NIIN.title: Experimental Design for Neuroimaging
NIIN.description: Examine experimental design approaches for experimental and clinical neuroimaging investigation. Topics on how to develop rigorous experiments to test theories of cognitive and clinical neuroscience.

NIIN.title: Computational Modeling in Neuroimaging
NIIN.description: Addresses the current neuroinformatics approaches to large-scale data representations, mining, and visualization in brain imaging. Open only to Neuroimaging and Informatics majors.

NIIN.title: Brain Architecture and Neuroanatomic Exploratory Techniques
NIIN.description: Introduction to basic theories and methodological approaches to neuroanatomy in animal models including histology, microscopy, behavioral investigations, and neuroinformatics.

NIIN.title: Neuroimaging Genetics
NIIN.description: Lectures on human genetics and epigenetics. Discuss how applying these concepts to brain imaging advances our understanding of healthy development and neurological disease. Emphasis on critical thinking applied both to designing neuroimaging genetics studies and to constructively assessing peer work and existing neuroimaging genetics literature.

NIIN.title: Introduction to Data Science in Neuroimaging
NIIN.description: Basics of data science as applied to neuroimaging data. Topics include neuroimaging data preparation and quality control, basics of programming and statistical models and machine learning techniques appropriate for the analyses of neuroimaging data.

NIIN.title: Science Communications
NIIN.description: Learn writing and communication elements critical for success in science-related fields, including clear writing, effective presentations and career development skills.

PAIN.title: Where is the Pain: Mind-Body Interface and Pain Physiology
PAIN.description: An introduction to the physiological and psychological components of pain, and pharmacological and non-pharmacological management strategies.  Cultural and social aspects of chronic pain are covered.

PAIN.title: Pain and Society: Epidemiology and Cultural issues
PAIN.description: Explores the societal issues related to pain, including the role of culture, ethnicity, caregiving, social and psychological factors related to pain and pain management.

PAIN.title: Pain Assessment:  History and Physical Examination
PAIN.description: Evaluation of patients suffering from pain, distinguishing between types of pain that may be acute or chronic.

PAIN.title: Musculoskeletal Anatomy and Pathology
PAIN.description: Anatomical survey of the human musculoskeletal system, focused on common pathologies that generate pain.

PAIN.title: Pain Neuroscience
PAIN.description: Anatomy of peripheral and central nociceptors, molecular mechanisms that underlie primary responses, neural networks, and neural mechanisms involved in hyperalgesia and allodynia.

PAIN.title: Pain Medicine Capstone
PAIN.description: Collaborative research project or supervised internship (practicum) incorporating a service learning approach.

PAIN.title: Pain Medicine Capstone
PAIN.description: Collaborative research project or supervised internship (practicum) incorporating a service learning approach.

PAIN.title: Pain Medicine Capstone
PAIN.description: Collaborative research project or supervised internship (practicum) incorporating a service learning approach.

PAIN.title: Case Studies
PAIN.description: Multiple elements including weekly online discussions of cases; learning need assignments; defense of an 18 cases or scenarios e-Portfolio.

PAIN.title: Case Studies
PAIN.description: Multiple elements including weekly online discussions of cases; learning need assignments; defense of an 18 cases or scenarios e-Portfolio.

PAIN.title: Case Studies
PAIN.description: Multiple elements including weekly online discussions of cases; learning need assignments; defense of an 18 cases or scenarios e-Portfolio.

PAIN.title: Public Policy and Legal issues
PAIN.description: Public Policy and Legal Issues in Pain Medicine including the California Medical Board Guidelines for Pain Medication, CURES, and legislation related with the discipline.

PAIN.title: History of Pain:  Theory and Treatment
PAIN.description: Trace through history our collective understanding of pain by examining the people, theories, and technologies which have brought us to our modern understanding.

PAIN.title: Neuropathic Pain
PAIN.description: Focus on pain caused by nervous system dysfunction; assessment, physiology, diagnoses and treatment.

PAIN.title: Psychological Treatments for Chronic Pain
PAIN.description: Information and demonstration on specific psychological treatments to decrease pain levels and manage pain flares.

PAIN.title: Physical and Occupational Therapies
PAIN.description: Physical and Occupational Therapy techniques to assess and treat chronic pain.

PAIN.title: Advanced Therapeutics
PAIN.description: Patients who suffer from chronic pain often fail to respond to basic treatments. Therefore it is crucial for clinicians to be familiar with different treatment options.

PHBI.title: Seminar in Advanced Cellular, Molecular and Systemic Physiology
PHBI.description: Lectures and student presentations on advanced topics in  molecular, cellular and systemic physiology.  Open to Systems  Biology and Disease, Physiology and Biophysics, and Pathobiology  students only.  Graded CR/NC.

OHNS.title: The Practice of Educational Speech-Language Pathology
OHNS.description: Examination of the interprofessional practice of educational speech-language pathologists and the multiple professionals working in the pediatric arena to serve children in schools.

OHNS.title: Telehealth and Assistive Technology in SLP
OHNS.description: Examination of the design and implementation of assistive technology (AT) and telehealth models, tools and service delivery in speech-language pathology working across settings.

OHNS.title: Audiology for Speech-Language Pathologists
OHNS.description: Introduction to the discipline and practice of audiology, including the nature of hearing and balance, how these systems are clinically assessed and impacts of altered function.

OHNS.title: Autism Spectrum Disorder, AAC and Cognitive Communication Di
OHNS.description: Assessment and treatment of Autism Spectrum Disorders and other cognitive disabilities including language, social skills, behavior, consideration for assistive technology and augmentative and alternative communication.

OHNS.title: Voice and Resonance Disorders
OHNS.description: Nature of normal voice production and the assessment and treatment of physiological and other disorders of pitch, loudness, voice quality, including resonance and alaryngeal voice.

OHNS.title: Dysphagia
OHNS.description: Anatomy and physiology of the normal swallow and neurological/oncologic disorders which affect the swallowing process. Current practice for clinical and instrumentation analysis, evaluation and treatment.

OHNS.title: Clinical Practicum in Speech-Language Pathology
OHNS.description: Supervised clinical hours in assessment and treatment of individuals with varying communication disorders at a variety of age levels in educational or medical settings.

OHNS.title: Adult Neurogenic and Related Cognitive Communication Disorde
OHNS.description: Acquired communication disorders including aphasia, right hemisphere disorder, traumatic brain injury, dementia, concussion. Assessment and treatment of these disorders including executive functioning and work/life/family/social implications.

OHNS.title: Externship in Speech-Language Pathology
OHNS.description: Speech-language pathology clinical experience in a supervised school-based, medically-based or private practice setting.

OHNS.title: Professional Issues in Speech-Language Pathology
OHNS.description: Professional issues that affect speech-language pathology in different work settings.  Practice issues, licensing and certification, ethics, reimbursement and funding, national and state practice guidelines.

OHNS.title: Fluency Disorders
OHNS.description: Topics related to assessment and treatment of fluency disorders. Theories, characteristics and behavioral and psychological and psycho-social impact.  Clinical focus, counseling and transitional planning.

OHNS.title: Research Capstone in Communication Sciences and Disorders
OHNS.description: Capstone Research Project addressing a problem in the field of communication sciences and disorders. Students work under the guidance of a faculty member; culminates in a submission for presentation in a poster session at a professional conference.

OHNS.title: Directed Research
OHNS.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may   2e applied to the degree to be determined by the department.  Graded C/NC.

PM.title: Foundations in Health Education and Promotion
PM.description: Overview and application of behavioral theories to the field of  health education and promotion.  Examines the determinants of  health behavior and strategies for change at the individual, group  and community level.

PM.title: Practice of Public Health
PM.description: Introduction to the application of strategies and tools for practice in public health, including policy advocacy, leadership and management, program planning and evaluation, health communication.

PM.title: Quality in Health Care
PM.description: Examines quality assessment at different levels of the health care system including health plans, physicians, hospital and integrated system performance.

PM.title: Health Service Delivery in the U.S.
PM.description: Historical development of the American health care system; determinants of health care utilization; role of health care providers; health policy; public health services; and health care finance.

PM.title: Principles of Biostatistics
PM.description: Concepts of biostatistics; appropriate uses and common misuses of  health statistics; practice in the application of statistical  procedures; introduction to statistical software including EXCEL,  SPSS, nQuery.  Laboratory.

PM.title: Data Analysis
PM.description: Major parametric and non-parametric statistical tools used in biomedical research, computer packages including SAS. Includes laboratory. Lecture, 2 hours; laboratory, 2 hours.

PM.title: Data Analysis
PM.description: Statistical methods for analysis of categorical data including dichotomous, ordinal, multinomial and count data, using Stata package.  Includes laboratory.

PM.title: Principles of Epidemiology
PM.description: Terminology/uses of epidemiology and demography; sources/uses of  population data; types of epidemiologic studies; risk assessment;  common sources of bias in population studies; principles of  screening. Recommended preparation: algebra

PM.title: Experimental Designs
PM.description: Statistical methods for analysis of various experimental designs. Parametric analysis of variance (ANOVA), repeated measures methods, crossover designs, non-parametric ANOVA.

PM.title: Multivariate Statistics in Health Behavior Research
PM.description: Advanced training in multivariate statistical techniques involving general linear modeling, mixed modeling and basic latent variables analysis in health behavior research

PM.title: Biostatistical Consulting
PM.description: An overview of the tools used by statisticians for solving statistical problems. Introduces students to the field of biostatistical consulting.

PM.title: Biostatistical Consulting
PM.description: Reinforce concepts in biostatistical consulting and will expose students to the practice of biostatistical consulting

PM.title: Research Methods in Epidemiology
PM.description: Overview of epidemiologic research in cancer. Selected cancer sites will be covered to highlight study design and conduct, exposure assessment, data analysis and interpretation.

PM.title: Statistical Methods for Epidemiological Studies I, II
PM.description: Principles and methods used in epidemiology for comparing disease frequencies between groups. Restricted to the analysis of binary outcome variables.

PM.title: Moving Toward Health Equity in the United States
PM.description: A thoughtful perspective on U.S. health services delivery while introducing students to social inequalities in health.

PM.title: Advanced Statistical Computing
PM.description: Techniques for the solution of statistical problems throughout intensive computing; iterative techniques, randomization tests, the bootstrap, Monte Carlo methods. Lecture and required laboratory.

PM.title: Introduction to the Theory of Statistics
PM.description: b: Theory of estimation and testing, inference, analysis of variance, theory of regression. Recommended Preparation: college-level calculus and linear algebra.

PM.title: Design of Clinical Studies
PM.description: Design, conduct, and interpretation of results of clinical trials; emphasis on principles affecting structure, size, duration of a trial, and the impact of ethical and practical considerations.

PM.title: Culture and Health: Global Perspectives
PM.description: International variations in health status with a focus on the impact of socioeconomic status, politics, environment, education and gender in etiology of illness, access to health care, progression of disease, and recovery.

PM.title: Communications in Public Health
PM.description: Application of communication theories and methods to community health problems. Includes background assessment, program design, evaluation, social marketing, media advocacy, review of major health campaigns.

PM.title: Epidemiology of Infectious Disease
PM.description: Survey of natural history of infectious disease, methods of disease control and outbreak investigation, and an overview of the epidemiology of injury. Prerequisite: PM-512.

PM.title: Program Design and Evaluation
PM.description: Core concepts, methods and values of public health program planning and evaluation, including community needs assessment, writing objectives, designing health promotion programs, process and outcome evaluation.

PM.title: Social Network Analysis
PM.description: Theory, methods and procedures of network analysis with emphasis  on applications to public health programs.

PM.title: Introduction to Time Series
PM.description: Transfer function models; stationary, nonstationary processes; moving average, autoregressive models; spectral analysis; estimation of mean, autocorrelation, spectrum; seasonal time series.

PM.title: Public Health Policy and Politics
PM.description: Examination of major policy issues in the U.S. health care delivery system to understand policy options in reforming health care and reducing health care disparities.

PM.title: Human Molecular Genetics and Genomics
PM.description: Principles of genetics and genomics as they apply to the study of the molecular basis of human diseases.

PM.title: Environmental Epidemiology: Concepts, Methods, and Practice
PM.description: Examine epidemiologic methods, concepts, and statistical approaches; case-study seminars with structured critiques of current literature on human-environment interactions affecting public health. Recommended Preparation: PM-510 and PM-512.

PM.title: Cancer Epidemiology
PM.description: Explores the fundamental concepts of cancer epidemiology, including the molecular basis, descriptive epidemiology, and historical and groundbreaking studies that have impacted the field.

PM.title: Intervention Approaches for Health Promotion and Disease Prevention
PM.description: Approaches for modifying health behavior in varioius settings and  within diverse populations.  Emphasis on practical considerations  necessary to design and implement interventions with demonstrated  effectiveness.

PM.title: Public Health Leadership and Management
PM.description: Introduction to leadership and management concepts, tools, and practices in the context of domestic and global public health and healthcare delivery settings.

PM.title: Introduction to Global Health
PM.description: Current public health issues and research topics relating to 21st century challenges and threats. Lessons learned and best practices to strengthen public health systems and enhance public health readiness and preparedness.

PM.title: Statistical Methods in Environmental Epidemiology
PM.description: Study designs, exposure time response, longitudinal, spatial, ecologic correlation and mechanistic models, measurement error interactions, measurement error, public policy implications.

PM.title: Global Health Research and Programs
PM.description: Introduction to the core concepts and methods of planning and implementing health-related programs and research in resource-constrained settings.

PM.title: Global Health, Law and Human Rights: Concepts and Methods
PM.description: Highlights the complex interactions between global health, law and human rights, emphasizing the use of human rights in public health thinking and practice.

PM.title: Directed Research
PM.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

PM.title: Machine Learning for the Health Sciences
PM.description: Introduces Masters and Ph.D. students in the Health Sciences to Machine Learning methods and their Biomedical applications.

PM.title: Master's Thesis
PM.description: Credit on acceptance of thesis. Graded IP/CR/NC.

PM.title: Master's Thesis
PM.description: Credit on acceptance of thesis. Graded IP/CR/NC.

PM.title: Master's Thesis
PM.description: Credit on acceptance of thesis. Graded IP/CR/NC.

PM.title: Internship for Curricular Practical Training
PM.description: Part-time or full-time, practical work experience in the students field of study. The internship must be located at an off-campus facility. Students are individually supervised by faculty.

PM.title: Practicum in Public Health
PM.description: Applied practical experience through field placement in federal, state, and/or local public health agencies/organizations, including community-based organizations; research and school-based settings.

PM.title: Capstone in Public Health
PM.description: Provides the culminating, integrative learning experience for students enrolled in the Master of Public Health program.

PM.title: Social Dimensions of Climate Change in a Sustainable World
PM.description: Special topics relevant to the study of selected issues and areas of health behavior research or other aspects of preventive medicine.

PM.title: Social and Behavioral Theories for Health Promotion and Dise
PM.description: Psychosocial basis of health hazardous lifestyle behaviors and preventive strategies.

PM.title: Health Behavior Research Methods
PM.description: Health research/evaluation philosophies, approaches and           development of skills for development and critique of health       behavior research projects/studies. Recommended preparation  PM-511.

PM.title: Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis
PM.description: Theoretical basis and practical approaches for identifying, summarizing and interpreting current bodies of scholarly information addressing a defined research question.

PM.title: Environmental and Genetic/Epigenetic Epidemiology
PM.description: A forum in which students develop speaking and presentation skills while critically evaluating epidemiological methods in epidemiology research.

PM.title: Seminar in Biostatistics and Epidemiology
PM.description: Special topics of current interest to provide background for  research in biostatistics and epidemiology.  Based largely on  student dissertation research.  Graded CR/NC.

PM.title: Clinical Translational Research (CTR)
PM.description: Analysis and interpretation of data to test clinical translational hypotheses.

PM.title: Fellowship Grant Proposal Development
PM.description: Process of applying for research grants in health behavior research, including dissertation grants. Covers the structure of NIH and other grantmaking agencies, the grant review process, tailoring ideas to the grantmaker's priorities, research design, development of training and mentoring plans, and budgeting.

PM.title: Data Science for  Climate Change and Health
PM.description: Introduces fundamental concepts on climate, epidemiology and biostatistics; follows with data science methods to study impacts of climate-related events on human health.

PM.title: Directed Research in Health Behavior
PM.description: Independent research at an advanced level on a problem in the field of Health Behavior. Recommended preparation PM 604.  Graded CR/NC.

PM.title: Directed Research in Health Behavior
PM.description: Independent research at an advanced level on a problem in the      field of Health Behavior.  Graded CR/NC.

PM.description: Independent research at an advanced level on a problem in the      field of Health Behavior.  Graded CR/NC.

PM.description: Independent research at an advanced level on a problem in the field of Health Behavior.

PM.title: Directed Research In Health Behavior
PM.description: Independent research at an advanced level on a problem in the      field of health behavior.  Graded CR/NC.

PM.title: Research Seminar in Health Behavior
PM.description: Short seminar presentations and discussions on issues             accompanying the development of the field of health behavior and   implementation of research in this field.  Graded CR/NC.

PM.description: Research applicable to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

PCPA.title: Behavioral Sciences II
PCPA.description: Psychosocial issues in medical care such as death and dying,  aging, and sexuality are addressed.  Communication skills to  multicultural patient populations are also explored.  Open to  Physician Assistant Practice majors only.

PCPA.title: Clinical Skills II
PCPA.description: Designed to prepare the physician assistant to conduct a complete physical examination.

PCPA.title: Clinical Skills IV
PCPA.description: Laboratory experiences with basic clinical skills essential to  medical practice.  Last of four courses.  Open to Physician  Assistant Practice majors only.

PCPA.title: PA Critical Thinking Course II
PCPA.description: Builds upon PCPA 536; team-based learning to prepare the physician  assistant to learn and practice applying critical thinking in  clinically relevant scenarios.

PCPA.title: Basic Medical Sciences II
PCPA.description: Builds upon PCPA 530; focuses on clinical anatomy, physiology, pathophysiology and pathology, essential to understanding disease mechanisms commonly encountered in medicine.

PCPA.title: Topics in Medicine II
PCPA.description: Basic instruction in normal/abnormal states of organ systems in  the study of human disease.  The second of three courses that  includes instruction in pathophysiology, pharmacology, diagnostic  studies, and medicine.  Open to Physician Assistant Practice  majors only.

PCPA.title: Clinical Assignment I
PCPA.description: One discrete consecutive six-week long, five-day-a-week intensive  field placement under a program approved supervising preceptor in  a program-approved clinical setting.  Requires departmental  approval.  Graded CR/NC.

PCPA.title: Clinical Assignment II
PCPA.description: One discrete consecutive six-week long, five-day-a-week intensive  field placement under a program approved supervising preceptor in  a program-approved clinical setting.  Requires departmental  approval.  Graded CR/NC.

PCPA.title: Clinical Assignment III
PCPA.description: One discrete consecutive six-week long, five-day-a-week intensive  field placement under a program approved supervising preceptor in  a program-approved clinical setting.  Requires departmental  approval.  Graded CR/NC.

PCPA.title: Advanced Topics in PA Studies: Education
PCPA.description: Seminar format: students explore educational theories and methods  used by PAs in variety of settings, including clinical practice,  classroom and community.  Open to Physician Assistant Practice  majors only.  Requires departmental approval.

PCPA.title: Advanced Topics in PA Studies: Research
PCPA.description: Seminar format: students receive an integrated experience in  research methods including methodology, data collection, analysis  and evaluation.  Open to Physician Assistant Practice majors  only.  Requires departmental approval.

PCPA.title: Advanced Topics in PA Studies: Medical Care Organization
PCPA.description: Seminar format: studetns will explore current topics in medical  care organization and physician assistant practice including  administration, financing, changing organizational settings, and  workforce issues.  Open to Physician Assistant Practice majors  only.  Requires departmental approval.

PATH.title: Pathobiology of Disease
PATH.description: Relationship between histopathological and clinical manifestations of disease and their underlying molecular mechanisms. Topics include inflammatory, developmental, environmental, degenerative, and neoplastic disease processes.

PATH.title: Emerging Trends and Methods in Molecular Pathology
PATH.description: Discuss emergent methodologies in molecular pathology with emphasis on applications important for genetics and epigenetics changes in various diseases, Sequencing Technologies, Data Analysis, Forensic Pathology.

PATH.title: Directed Research
PATH.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

PATH.title: Master's Thesis
PATH.description: Credit on acceptance of thesis. Graded IP/CR/NC.

PATH.title: Master's Thesis
PATH.description: Credit on acceptance of thesis. Graded IP/CR/NC.

PATH.title: Master's Thesis
PATH.description: Credit on acceptance of thesis. Graded IP/CR/NC.

PBHS.title: Science and Practice of Building Resilience
PBHS.description: Promotes learning principles and skills that enhance resilience to effectively navigate common stressors throughout a professional career through course lecture, group discussion, reflection and practice.

PBHS.title: Mental Health and Climate Change
PBHS.description: Explores ways that changing climate affects individual and collective mental health, including concepts related to building individual and collective resilience to environmental threats.

PBHS.title: The Science of Altruism
PBHS.description: Explores the science behind altruism, volunteerism, compassion and how helping others impacts individuals physically, psychologically and behaviorally through lectures, projects and experiential learning.

PBHS.title: Identity Development of the Contemporary Male
PBHS.description: Exploration of identity development in terms of social, political and cultural constructs; examination of collegiate athletics and the contributions of men of color.

TRGN.title: Advanced Human Genomic Analysis Methods
TRGN.description: Molecular biotechnology, genomics, next-generation sequencing,  epigenomics, drug discovery, biomarkers, microarrays, analytical  validation, pipelines, molecular analysis.

TRGN.title: Translational Genomics, Applied Databases and Datastructures
TRGN.description: Genomics, bioinformatics resources, NCBI, portals, databases, datastructures, NoSQL, SQL, big data.

TRGN.title: Translational Biomedical Informatics Capstone Portfolio
TRGN.description: Portfolio, translational biomedical informatics, bioinformatics, genomics, application development, web-based application.

TRGN.title: Applied Data Science and Bioinformatics
TRGN.description: Data science and bioinformatics tools in the study of human health and disease using R and Bioconductor for students from non-quantitative backgrounds.

TRGN.title: Pathway and Target Discovery
TRGN.description: Exploration of the process of discovering and developing novel therapeutic treatments.

TRGN.title: Seminar in Translational Biotechnology
TRGN.description: Series of seminars that provide updated views on various sub-specialties in biotechnology.

TRGN.title: Translational Biotechnology Practicum
TRGN.description: Experiential training based on a project in a biomedical, biotechnology or pharmaceutical setting.

TRGN.title: Translational Biotechnology Capstone Defense
TRGN.description: Finalization and defense of capstone project.

TRGN.title: Biotechnology Entrepreneurship and Commercialization II
TRGN.description: Advanced discussion: global biotechnology industry, idea generation, business plan formulation, intellectual property protection, funding, personnel management including board composition, regulatory body interaction, company exits.

TRGN.title: Exploring Chemical and Biological Therapeutic Modalities
TRGN.description: Turning molecules into drugs and cells into therapeutics. Emphasizing selection, development and optimization of appropriate modalities to target specific key defects in diseases.

TRGN.title: Directed Research
TRGN.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

SCRM.title: Stem Cells: Fact and Fiction
SCRM.description: Exploring how stem cells and regenerative medicine are portrayed in culture, the scientific underpinnings of what is currently possible, and visions into the future.

SCRM.title: Gene Editing and Gene Therapy
SCRM.description: Overview of gene editing technologies and their applications in vitro and in vivo to advancements in disease modeling and clinical therapies for patients.

SCRM.title: Directed Research
SCRM.description: Individual research and readings under the guidance of a faculty member.

SCRM.title: Bringing Stem Cells to the Clinic
SCRM.description: Lectures addressing the business, legal, ethical, manufacturing and regulatory aspects involved in moving stem cells or related product into clinical practice.

SCRM.title: Cell and Gene Therapy Development - From Research to Clinic
SCRM.description: Introduces the basic principles processes, and requirements of cell and gene therapy drug development, manufacturing and clinical applications using hands-on and interactive activities.

SCRM.title: Historical and Contemporary Stem Cell Research
SCRM.description: Historical and contemporary stem cell research using hematopoietic stem cells as a model system.

SCRM.title: Historical and Contemporary Research: Neural Stem Cells
SCRM.description: Focuses on historic achievements in stem cell research and how contemporarily, research and its related technological advances have fostered breakthroughs the understanding of NSCs.

SCRM.title: Historical and Contemporary Research: Tissue Development Eng
SCRM.description: Focuses on the components of cell, molecular biology, and basic tissue development to comprehend its uses within the realm of synthetic biology and cellular/tissue engineering.

SCRM.title: Data Analysis in Stem Cell Biology
SCRM.description: Training in the analytical tools needed to assess data-sets typically acquired during stem cell biology research.

SCRM.title: For PhD Students
SCRM.description: Selected topics in Development, Stem Cell, and Regeneration.

SCRM.title: SCRM External Speaker Seminar Series
SCRM.description: Reading and discussion of recent papers by the SCRM speaker of the week, and attendance at the speaker's seminar. Open only to Stem Cell Biology and Regenerative Medicine majors.

SCRM.title: Independent Research
SCRM.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of faculty in the Department of Stem Cell Biology and Regenerative Medicine.

SCRM.title: Master's Thesis
SCRM.description: Credit on acceptance of Thesis. Graded IP/CR/NC.

SCRM.title: Master's Thesis
SCRM.description: Credit on acceptance of Thesis. Graded IP/CR/NC.

SCRM.title: Stem Cell Biology, Politics, and Ethics.
SCRM.description: Selected topics on sub-fields within developmental and stem cell biology including review of contemporary literature and research.

LAW.title: Law and the U.S. Constitution in Global History
LAW.description: By examining key constitutional moments involving race, rights, and revolutions, students will explore how legal meaning changes over time.

LAW.title: Law and Politics
LAW.description: Examination of the rules and realities of American politics, and the role politics plays in American life and culture.

LAW.title: Introduction to Criminal Law
LAW.description: Provides a comprehensive analysis of the criminal justice system and an overview of the fundamentals of substantive criminal law.

LAW.title: Fundamentals of the U.S. Legal System
LAW.description: Introduces the U.S. legal system and its relationship to basic principles of the rule of law. Examines lawmaking institutions, judicial processes and contemporary legal issues.

LAW.title: Intellectual Property and Technology
LAW.description: Examines how American law protects and facilitates intellectual property and its modern utility. Provides a practical understanding of laws regulating patents, copyrights and trademarks.

LAW.title: Immigration Law for a New America
LAW.description: Examines current immigration law in America, the normative debates over immigration policies and the role the government plays in expanding or limiting immigration rights.

LAW.title: Interdisciplinary Perspectives on the Law
LAW.description: Examines law and the legal system from different disciplinary perspectives. It explores how various disciplines provide different insights to the legal regime.

LAW.title: Exploring Courthouses in Los Angeles
LAW.description: Gain hands-on experience by observing the inner workings of the criminal and civil law system through lectures and courtrooms visits.

LAW.title: Current Court Cases
LAW.description: Exposes students to the impact of legal decisions on society through analysis of pending and recent cases on the courts docket.

LAW.title: Concepts in American Law
LAW.description: The main concepts and topics in American law, in the historical, economic and cultural contexts in which they have developed.

LAW.title: Global Justice for Mass Atrocities and Genocide
LAW.description: Learn about international law and courts trying these cases, while also reflecting on whether criminal trials are the best response to bringing healing and reconciliation to affected societies.

LAW.title: Fundamentals of Entertainment Law
LAW.description: Examines key legal principles governing the entertainment industry by exploring legal challenges faced by professionals in music, film, sports, gaming and other areas of entertainment.

LAW.title: Law, Enslavement and Race
LAW.description: Studies how law, politics and culture interacted to shape the institution of enslavement and the development of modern conceptions of race.

LAW.title: Sports Law
LAW.description: Examines the relevance and application of legal structures to all participants in the sports enterprise by providing an overview of legal and ethical issues.

LAW.title: Law and Entrepreneurship
LAW.description: Examines areas of the law that impact entrepreneurs, starting, operating and financing businesses. Topics include: selection of business entities; securities laws and issues that arise in fundraising; employment law; contracts; torts; intellectual property; global expansion; mergers and acquisitions; and IPOs.

LAW.title: Law and Homelessness
LAW.description: Examines the current housing crisis by interweaving tenant/landlord law, local ordinances, historical exclusionary policies and reviewing current reporting and scholarship.

LAW.title: Mental Health Law
LAW.description: Foundational legal and practice concepts at the intersection of law and psychology through three intersecting systems: the mental health, the criminal and the immigration systems.

LAW.title: Individual Rights in U.S. Constitutional Law
LAW.description: Explores the U.S. Bill of Rights and the limits that the Constitution imposes on the state majoritys ability to impose its will on an individual.

LAW.title: Regulatory Law
LAW.description: Introduces legal and social ideas and issues surrounding regulatory law - how and why regulations are developed, along with the accountability and enforcement of regulations.

LAW.title: Undergraduate Law Review
LAW.description: Introduces students to the basics of legal writing and research, with a focus on legal scholarship and law review-type journal articles.

LAW.title: Legal Studies Capstone Project
LAW.description: A cumulative experience demonstrating a student's depth of knowledge in applying research and writing skills on examining the legal system.

LAW.title: Law Internship
LAW.description: Intensive experience with a law-related non-profit organization, or public agency.

LAW.title: Criminal Law
LAW.description: The crime problem and the legislative response to it through substantive criminal law; administration of criminal justice through police, prosecutorial, sentencing, and penological discretion.

LAW.title: Legal Profession
LAW.description: Functions of the lawyer in modern society; history and organization of the legal profession; the adversary system; equal access to justice; other problems of ethics and professional responsibility.

LAW.title: Property
LAW.description: The idea of property as understood through economic and philosophical concepts. Rights in land, water and other natural resources. Forms of shared ownership (e.g., landlord and tenant), and a survey of mechanisms for controlling land use.

LAW.title: Constitutional Law: Structure
LAW.description: Considers the delineation of spheres of responsibility between the judiciary and legislature, the nation and the state, and the government and the individual.

LAW.title: Torts I
LAW.description: Individual's obligation not to harm others; bases for compensating persons who are harmed, either by holding responsible whoever is at fault or by invoking other principles of liability, including the efficiency of resource allocation and the spreading of losses.

LAW.title: Legal Research, Writing, and Advocacy II
LAW.description: Continuation of LAW 515.  Development of legal research, writing,  and advocacy skills.  Emphasis on persuasive legal writing,  including appellate briefs, and researching statutory and  administrative law.  Participation in a moot court program.   Registration restricted to Law students.

LAW.title: Ethical Issues for Nonprofit, Government and Criminal Lawyer
LAW.description: Covers legal ethics issues with an emphasis on access to justice, nonprofit practice settings and duties of prosecutors and defense attorneys. Fulfills Legal Profession requirement.

GRSC.title: Studies for the Qualifying Examination
GRSC.description: Studies for the Qualifying Examination. Students may enroll in GRSC 800, once they have completed all other degree requirements, to prepare for their Qualifying Examination.

MUCM.description: An introduction to the many facets of choral music. Grounding in the intellectual and practical issues of choirs, singing, and choral literature. Recommended Preparation: Ability to read music.

MUCO.title: Basics of Music Theory
MUCO.description: Introduction to music theory; scales, intervals, principles of common practice and popular music harmony; melodic, harmonic, and structural analysis; 20th-century developments. Not available for credit to BM majors.

MUCO.title: Basics of Music Theory
MUCO.description: Introduction to music theory; scales, intervals, principles of common practice and popular music harmony; melodic, harmonic, and structural analysis; 20th-century developments. Not available for credit to B.M. majors.

MUCO.title: Harmony in Popular Music
MUCO.description: Study of harmony used in the popular music idiom, as well as diminished chord patterns, modulation techniques, basic modal theory, and principles of melodic construction.

MUCO.title: Aural Skills I
MUCO.description: Sight-singing, dictation, related keyboard application.

MUCO.title: Theory I
MUCO.description: a: Notation, scales, intervals; introduction to counterpoint;harmonic principles of the common practice period; analysis,written work. b: Continuation of 133a; elements of form;application of analysis to performance. Concurrent registration inAural Skills required.

MUCO.title: Composition I
MUCO.description: Beginning exercises in composing, initial composition projects, study, lectures and class discussions of selected compositions from the repertory.

MUCO.title: Aural Skills II
MUCO.description: Continuation of MUCO 132ab.

MUCO.title: Theory II
MUCO.description: a: Analysis of representative pieces from the classic and romantic periods; exercises in composition. b: Survey of 20th century developments; composition utilizing 20th century techniques.

MUCO.title: Counterpoint II
MUCO.description: Studies in tonal counterpoint; two-, three-, and four-part  counterpoint in 18th century style; polyphonic variations,  inventions.

MUCO.title: Composition II
MUCO.description: Composition in shorter forms, continuation of score analysis and listening assignments.

MUCO.title: Theory Review
MUCO.description: Review of materials covered in Theory I and II. For students whose entrance examination in music theory indicates the need for further study.

MUCO.title: Composition for Non-Majors II
MUCO.description: Individual instruction in composition for non-composition majors. Continuation of MUCO 221abx. Not open to B.M. in Composition majors.

MUCO.title: Aural Skills Review
MUCO.description: Review of the materials covered in Aural Skills I, II, III. For students whose entrance examination in aural skills indicates the need for further study.

MUCO.title: Composition III
MUCO.description: Individual instruction in composition; preparation for the senior recital.

MUCO.title: Orchestration Review
MUCO.description: Review of materials covered in elementary orchestration; for students whose entrance examination in orchestration indicates a need for further study.

MUCO.title: Analytical Techniques
MUCO.description: Selected analytical topics.

MUCO.title: Composition IV
MUCO.description: Individual instruction in composition; preparation for the senior recital.

MUCO.title: Choral Arranging
MUCO.description: Arranging and composing for chorus.

MUCO.title: Intermediate Programming for Digital Media & Computer Music
MUCO.description: Visual-based programming language Max is further investigated to use the computer as a tool for generative and interactive multimedia performance, composition and improvisation environments.

MUCO.title: Directed Research
MUCO.description: Individual research and readings. Not avaliable for graduate credit.

MUCO.title: Introduction to the Analysis of Tonal Music
MUCO.description: Survey of common practice period (1650-1900) approaches to phrase  design, tonal organization and type-forms (binary, ternary, rondo,  sonata.)

MUCO.title: Introduction to the Analysis of Post-Tonal Music
MUCO.description: Introductory survey of 20th/21st century approaches to the  organization of pitch (serial, modal, extended tonal, etc.),  rhythm, texture and form.

MUCO.title: Composition for Non-Majors III
MUCO.description: Individual instruction in composition.  Not open to graduate  students in composition.  Prerequisite: submission of portfolio of  musical compositions.

MUCO.title: Advanced Orchestration I
MUCO.description: Continuation of Orchestration III with emphasis on contemporary techniques.

MUCO.title: Advanced Composition I
MUCO.description: For graduates with evidence of preparation for advanced work.

MUCO.title: Special Studies in Contrapuntal Music
MUCO.description: In-depth analytical and historical study of contrapuntal techniques and styles. Emphasis to be determined by the department. Recommended preparation: MUCO 501.

MUCO.title: Directed Research
MUCO.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

MUCO.title: Writing about Analysis
MUCO.description: Seminar on analytical writing through examination of varied analyses of single works, interrogation of method, style and effectiveness; mentored writing.

MUCO.description: Continuation of Advanced Orchestration with emphasis on historical survey of orchestral compositions and advanced orchestration projects.

MUHL.description: A study of the musical styles and genres in the late modern and contemporary eras within their historical context. Detailed analysis of selected works.

MTAL.title: Sociological Foundations of Music Teaching and Learning
MTAL.description: Study of interdependent relationship between society, music and music education.

MTAL.title: Coaching the Popular Music Ensemble
MTAL.description: Conceptual and practical strategies used towards teaching a wide range of popular music ensembles that are culturally responsive and student centered.

MTAL.title: Directed Research
MTAL.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

MTAL.title: Final Project

MTAL.title: Foundations of Community Music
MTAL.description: Exploration of community music programs in the U.S. and beyond with emphasis on philosophical, sociological, structural and cultural bases for the diverse programs.

MTAL.title: World Music Pedagogy
MTAL.description: Introduction to the pedagogy of world music cultures, including both sonic and sociocultural dimensions of music-in-culture, through the World Music Pedagogy approach.

MTAL.title: Research
MTAL.description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

MTEC.title: Music Production I
MTEC.description: Introduction to studio recording systems, headphone cues and recording session procedures and techniques.

MTEC.title: Fundamentals of Audio Recording
MTEC.description: Introduction to the principles and techniques of audio recording. Students will gain a basic understanding of signal flow, gain structure, microphones, monitoring systems, signal processing, mixing. Duplicates credit in former MTEC 275a.

MTEC.title: Critical Listening
MTEC.description: Introductory course where students will develop an understanding of audio quality, the musical aspects of audio production and the vocabulary necessary to offer audio critique. Recommended preparation: MTEC-175. Duplicates credit in former MTEC 275a.

MTEC.title: Music Production II
MTEC.description: Study of large ensemble (rhythm section, vocal, background vocal with horn section and or strings) music production in a variety of popular music styles.

MTEC.title: Introduction to MIDI Sequencing
MTEC.description: Introductory course where students will learn to use professional MIDI sequencing software to sequence, edit, and realize music compositions.

MTEC.title: Introduction to Audio Recording and Editing
MTEC.description: Introduction to the techniques and applications of recording, editing and mixing sound on personal computers.

MTEC.title: Fundamentals of Audio Engineering
MTEC.description: Fundamentals of Audio Engineering is an intermediate course in the principles and techniques of professional audio production as related to music. Recommended preparation: MTEC-175 and MTEC-176. Duplicates credit in former MTEC 275b.

MTEC.title: Introduction to Music Technology
MTEC.description: A survey of the technology used to create, prepare, perform, and distribute music, with an emphasis on recording, MIDI, music production, mastering and Internet technologies. Not available for major credit to B.M. and B.S., Music Industry majors. (Duplicates credit in former MUIN 277.)

MTEC.title: Individual Instruction
MTEC.description: Intermediate and advanced instruction in the applications of technology to the creation and performance of music. Recommended preparation: Experience with audio recording and synthesizers.

MTEC.title: Music Production III
MTEC.description: Small group instruction to develop the student's arranging, production and project management skills as related to medium budget music and multimedia projects.

MTEC.title: Introduction to Mixing and Mastering
MTEC.description: Fundamental principles and techniques used to fuse multiple audio elements into clear, comprehensive final products.

MTEC.title: Advanced Instrumental Recording
MTEC.description: An in-depth study of the standard practices and techniques used in contemporary multi-track recording.

MTEC.title: Advanced Music Production for Non-Majors
MTEC.description: The study of small music production in a variety of popular music styles with the goal of developing the students arranging, production and project management skills.

MTEC.title: Introduction to Sound Reinforcement
MTEC.description: An overview of the acoustic, technical and musical aspects of amplifying audio for live performance.

MTEC.title: Desktop Music Production
MTEC.description: Intermediate course where students will learn to use professional MIDI sequencing and digital audio software to compose, edit, and mix songs and other music compositions. Recommended preparation: MTEC-245. Duplicates credit in former MUIN 305.

MTEC.title: Non-Linear MIDI Sequencing
MTEC.description: An in-depth course focusing on the principles and techniques of sequencing and performing musical compositions using a non-linear sequencer. Recommended preparation: MTEC 245.

MTEC.title: Advanced Desktop Music Production
MTEC.description: Students will learn to apply their musical and technical skills to create professional quality computer-based arrangements in a variety of musical styles. Recommended preparation: MTEC 443 or MTEC 444 and MTEC 474a.

MTEC.title: Computer Assisted Recording and Editing
MTEC.description: Techniques and applications of recording and editing sound on personal computers. Hardware, software, editing for song, sound effects and dialog for film. (Duplicates credit in former MUIN 446a.)

MTEC.title: Computer Assisted Recording and Editing
MTEC.description: Techniques and applications of recording and editing sound on personal computers. Hardware, software, editing for song, sound effects and dialog for film. (Duplicates credit in former MUIN 446b.)

MTEC.title: Performance Technology
MTEC.description: In-depth course focusing on the concepts, principles and techniques of performing music using audio and MIDI technology.

MTEC.title: Electronic Synthesizer Techniques
MTEC.description: Electronic music procedures in a multi-track studio. Duplicates credit in former MUEA 474ax.

MTEC.title: Remote Recording Techniques
MTEC.description: Special problems of location recording; specialized equipment; microphone design and operation. Prerequisite: MTEC 275. (Duplicates credit in former MUIN 477.)

MTEC.title: Audio Mastering
MTEC.description: A survey of the final creative steps of an audio CD. Concepts of acoustics, mastering suite design, critical listening, frequency, dynamics and sequencing. Prerequisite: MTEC 275. Recommended preparation: MTEC 446a. (Duplicates credit in former MUIN-479)

MTEC.title: Immersive Audio Mixing
MTEC.description: An advanced course focusing on the concepts, principles and techniques of mixing music for immersive audio master recordings and broadcast media.

MTEC.title: Computer-Assisted Music Editing for Picture
MTEC.description: Techniques and applications of recording, editing and synchronizing music and sounds to film, video or games, using time code and personal computers. Prerequisite: MTEC 446b. (Duplicates credit in former MUIN 486.)

MTEC.title: Directed Research
MTEC.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit. Duplicates credit in former MUEA 490x.

MTEC.title: Senior Project
MTEC.description: Culmination of the four-year course of study intended to afford students the opportunity to pursue a mentored project to advance their future careers. Graded CR/NC.

MTEC.title: Stockholm Maymester
MTEC.description: Selected topics of current interest.

MTEC.title: Individual Instruction
MTEC.description: Intermediate and advanced instruction in the applications of technology to the creation and performance of music. Recommended preparation: Experience with audio recording and synthesizers.

MTEC.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC. Duplicates credit in former MUEA 590.

ARTL.title: Issues in the Arts and the Contemporary World
ARTL.description: Examination of major environmental trends including changing demographics, new business models, rapidly developing technology and globalization, and understanding their implications for the arts.

ARTL.title: Arts and the Community: Current Practice and New Visions
ARTL.description: Exploration of a range of ideas, ideologies and strategies that have historically been used to connect arts organizations to their communities.

ARTL.title: Arts Leadership Practicum
ARTL.description: Year-long practicum which puts ideas and concepts into practice. Each student will conceptualize, develop, and complete an arts project of his/her own choosing.

MPPM.description: Study of popular music repertoire from the 1970s to the present. Students will learn, rehearse and perform in a collaborative, interactive environment.

MUIN.title: Introduction to the Music Industry
MUIN.description: A survey of the music business with emphasis on distribution of recorded music, music publishing, performance rights societies, record companies, agents, personal managers and contracts. Open to  music majors (B.M. and B.S. degrees) only.

MUIN.title: Basics of the Music Industry
MUIN.description: Introductory survey of the music business. Topics include: copyright, record companies, contracts, music publishing, performance rights societies, managers, agents, and other artist team/income considerations. Not for major credit for Music Industry Majors. (Duplicates credit in former MUIN 372ax.)

MUIN.title: Communications in the Music Industry
MUIN.description: A comprehensive course on communications specific to the music industry with a focus on press and publicity for artists.

MUIN.title: Introduction to Music Law
MUIN.description: A study of entertainment law with a focus on the music industry.Areas of study include contracts, domestic practices,international practices, copyright protection, trademarks. Prerequisites: MUIN 270.

MUIN.title: Music Publishing and Licensing
MUIN.description: A contemporary survey of the methods used to monetize music through licensing/media placement, covering music publishing, songwriter agreements, performance rights and licenses for traditional/new media. Prerequisites: MUIN 270 or MUIN 272x.

MUIN.title: Business and Legal Aspects of the Music Industry
MUIN.description: An intermediate/advanced-level survey of music copyright law, artist contract analysis, infringement case studies as they affect modern/emerging business models and global music licensing.

MUIN.title: Marketing, Branding and Strategic Alliances in Music
MUIN.description: An in-depth study of music marketing, non-traditional revenue streams for artists, musicians, and labels including artist endorsements, artist tour sponsorships, digital music programs, music licensing, merchandise, and a primary focus on brand partnership deals in the music space. Prerequisites: MUIN 270 or MUIN 272x.

MUIN.title: DIY Music Marketing
MUIN.description: An exploration of the most current and effective marketing strategies and online branding tools for promoting, monetizing, and sustaining the career of the independent creative artist. Prerequisites: MUIN 270 or MUIN 272x.

MUIN.title: Live Music Production and Promotion
MUIN.description: A survey of the presentation of the live musical experience. Both classical and popular concert presentation will be examined including venue selection, promotion and security.

MUIN.title: Artist Management and Development
MUIN.description: A study of issues relating to the personal management of music artists including negotiating contracts, image, career development, agents, touring, merchandizing, fees and duties.

MUIN.title: Practicum in Music Industry Issues (Internship)
MUIN.description: Field application of music industry theories and practices; part-time employment. Project jointly defined by student, employer and professor.

MUIN.title: Streaming Economy in the Music Industry
MUIN.description: Focus on identifying the economic impact current music streaming models have on artists, record labels, publishing and consumers.

MUIN.title: Music Festival Design and Management
MUIN.description: Focus on planning, booking, marketing, promoting, ticketing and operating a festival in an ever-changing marketplace.

MUIN.title: Technology, Big Data and Marketing in the Music Industry
MUIN.description: Analyzing technologys relationship to the music industry. Use of data and analytics to develop successful strategies for new and existing artists.

MUIN.title: Artist and Repertoire
MUIN.description: In-depth study of the functions of an A&R professional as they guide the record label and artist from acquisition to release.

MUIN.title: Public Assembly Venue Management
MUIN.description: Review and examination of the principles and practices associated with managing theaters, arenas, stadiums and all other public assembly venue types.

MUIN.title: Ethics in the Music Industry
MUIN.description: Focus on the intellectual/philosophical foundations of the modern interpretation and application of ethics within the music industry.

MUIN.title: DIY Touring
MUIN.description: A "hands-on" approach to learning the essential components of a successful small-market tour through the DO IT YOURSELF artist lens.

MUIN.title: Advanced Concert Management
MUIN.description: Application of theories, technologies, and practices of the live  music industry.  Focus on the business, management, marketing,  promotion, and production of professional concert events.

MUIN.title: Directed Research
MUIN.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

MUIN.title: Artificial Intelligence in the Music Industry
MUIN.description: Exploration of emerging topics and trends in business and technology in the music and entertainment industries. Prerequisites; MUIN 270 or MUIN 272x.

MUIN.title: High Level Digital Advanced Data Analysis
MUIN.description: Exploration of emerging topics and trends in business and technology in the music and entertainment industries. Prerequisites; MUIN 270 or MUIN 272x.

MUIN.title: Music and Mindfulness: Strategy and Practice for an Ever     Changing Field
MUIN.description: Exploration of emerging topics and trends in business and technology in the music and entertainment industries. Prerequisites; MUIN 270 or MUIN 272x.

MUIN.title: Music Industry Tool-Kit
MUIN.description: Exploration of emerging topics and trends in business and technology in the music and entertainment industries. Prerequisites; MUIN 270 or MUIN 272x.

MUIN.title: The Intersection of Music and Sports
MUIN.description: Exploration of emerging topics and trends in business and technology in the music and entertainment industries. Prerequisites; MUIN 270 or MUIN 272x.

MUIN.title: Final Capstone Project
MUIN.description: Culmination of the four-year course of study. Affords students the opportunity to experience guided work to meet the professional demands of the industry.

MUIN.title: Final Capstone Project
MUIN.description: Culmination of the four-year course of study. Affords students the opportunity to experience guided workto meet the professional demands of the industry. Graded CR/NC.

MUIN.title: Professional Music Capitals of the World-Maymester- Stockholm, Sweden
MUIN.description: Selected topics of current interest.

MUIN.title: Music Industry History: Entrepreneurs, Moguls and Catalogs
MUIN.description: Focus on recorded musics sounds and innovators. Includes in-depth research, discussion, presentations and memorization for greater cultural context.

MUIN.title: Artist Management: Campaign Planning, Pitching, Partnerships
MUIN.description: Lecture and experiential learning focused on the role of an artists personal manager including developing their story, assets and strategy for various product release campaigns.

MUIN.title: Music Industry/Producers Forum
MUIN.description: Student-driven discussion, networking and Q&A; with guest industry leaders and role models, including producers, artists, music supervisors, concert promoters, agents, label executives, managers and attorneys.

MUIN.title: Survey/Analysis of Music Agreements
MUIN.description: Focus on demystifying legalese" and music industry standards by assessing actual contract examples for context, including recording, songwriter, producer, media licensing, sponsorship and band partnerships.

MUIN.title: Concert Promotion, Venue Management and Event Planning
MUIN.description: Overview of the three areas that comprise most of the live performance spaces, and focuses on the artist, promoter and venue (Circle of Live) and the roles they play in the performance.

MUIN.title: Music Supervision, Production and Creative Licensing
MUIN.description: A comprehensive look at contemporary music supervision for all visual media. Students will creatively apply guided lessons using real world example cases and projects.

MUIN.title: Directed Research
MUIN.description: Research leading to the Master's Degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

MUIN.title: Internship
MUIN.description: Students gain insight, experience and networking opportunities within the industry areas they wish to consider as a career.

MUIN.title: Research
MUIN.description: Research leading to the doctorate.  Maximum units which may be  applied to the degree to be determinedd by the department.  Graded  CR/NC.

MUSC.title: World Music
MUSC.description: Exploration of music and cultures of the world. Engagement with international musicians, global issues, field work and musical diasporas in Los Angeles.

MUSC.title: Exploring Our Musical Campus
MUSC.description: Exploration of musical styles and elements, creative process and social context through active listening and engagement with live performances on the USC campus.

MUSC.title: Western Music as Sounding History
MUSC.description: An introduction to Western art music and culture from the Medieval, Renaissance, Baroque, Classical, Romantic and Modern eras through reading, listening, analyzing and writing about music.

MUSC.title: The Broadway Musical: Reflections of American Diversity
MUSC.description: A uniquely American genre, the Broadway musical serves as a catalyst for inquiry into human diversity, cross-culturalism, and significant social and political issues.

MUSC.title: Electronic Music and Dance Culture
MUSC.description: The origins and development of EDM and its relatives such as disco, house, techno, rave and electronica, focusing on cultural and technological influences.

MUSC.title: Music, Mind and the Brain
MUSC.description: An interdisciplinary approach to music, mind and brain. Explores music as an object with its own properties and as a form of human behavior.

MUSC.title: The Music of Black Americans
MUSC.description: A chronicle of the musical contribution of Africans and African Americans to American society and to the foundations of musical genres and styles throughout the world.

MUSC.title: Songwriting I
MUSC.description: Development of musical and lyrical skills, composing, listening, analysis, and critiques of popular original music.

MUSC.title: Hip-hop Music and Culture
MUSC.description: A history of hip-hop music from its inception to the present: its musical processes and styles, as well as attendant social, political and cultural issues.

MUSC.title: Songwriting II
MUSC.description: Continuation of Songwriting I; particular emphasis on the analysis of the techniques of important popular songwriters and the application of these techniques to original songs.

MUSC.title: Music, Turmoil and Nationalism
MUSC.description: An exploration of musical practices and styles which reflect and shape national identities and which focus on those created in response to political turmoil in many forms.

MUSC.title: Beatles, Stones, Bowie: Empire and Masculinity
MUSC.description: Historical survey of the Beatles, the Rolling Stones and David Bowie that explores their contributions to contemporary notions of "masculinity," "Empire," and "classic rock."

MUSC.title: Songwriting III: The Performing Songwriter
MUSC.description: Continuation of Songwriting I and II with emphasis on the development of performance skills of original popular music in preparation for songwriting showcases.

MUSC.title: Musicians Health and Wellness
MUSC.description: Interactive exploration of injury prevention, body awareness disciplines, effective practice strategies, warm-ups and stretches, performance anxiety, hearing protection, and other pertinent wellness topics for musicians.

MUSC.title: Young Artist Project I
MUSC.description: Ideation and development of plans for unique individualized, mentored projects related to students' diversified and often hybrid work as classical musicians.

MUSC.title: Careers in Music
MUSC.description: A study of the practical aspects of the music business, including the history, procedures, standard practices, economics and technologies employed by the music industry.

MUSC.title: Internship in Music
MUSC.description: Practical work experience in the student's field of study, at an  off-campus location.  Students are individually supervised by   faculty.  Open only to Bachelor of Music and Bachelor of Arts,  Music majors only.  Not available for graduate credit.  Graded  CR/NC.

MUSC.title: Internship in Music
MUSC.description: Practical work experience in the student's field of study, at an  off-campus location.  Students are individually supervised by  faculty.  Open only to music majors.  Graded CR/NC.

MUSC.title: Internship in Music
MUSC.description: Practical work experience in the student's field of study, at an  off-campus location.  Students are individually supervised by  faculty.  Open only to doctoral students in music.  Graded CR/NC.

MUSC.title: Studies for the Qualifying Examination in Music
MUSC.description: Studies for the Qualifying Examination. Duplicates credit in GRSC-800.  CR/NC.

SCOR.title: Introduction to Scoring Movies and Television
SCOR.description: Practical composition course covering the unique art, craft, and technology involved in writing and integrating music for animated and live-action visual media.

SCOR.title: Introduction to Scoring Video Games
SCOR.description: Practical composition course covering the unique art, craft, and technology involved in composing and integrating video-game music.

SCOR.title: Directed Research
SCOR.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

SCOR.title: Screen Scoring
SCOR.description: Secondary instruction for graduate music majors or instruction for graduate non-music majors.

SCOR.title: Individual Instruction in Advanced Screen Scoring
SCOR.description: Individual instruction and review of students work. Selected composers, orchestrators, filmmakers, and other important industry collaborators offer their insights on scoring and career building.

SCOR.title: Advanced Scoring for Motion Pictures and Television
SCOR.description: Scoring principles involved in designing, timing, and composing scores for video projects, including documentaries, animated, and live-action projects. Will also include composing for live recording sessions.

SCOR.title: Orchestral Scoring
SCOR.description: Explores the sounds of and notations for the major orchestral instruments; provides instruction on implementation of those instruments in scoring and orchestrating for the screen.

SCOR.title: Advanced Game Scoring and Integration
SCOR.description: Explores more sophisticated principles and techniques involved in the unique aspects of composing and integrating music for video games.

SCOR.title: Music Editing and Spotting for Media Productions
SCOR.description: Processes and techniques used for the planning and workflow of a score within a media production.

SCOR.title: History of Film Scoring
SCOR.description: Examines the evolution of movie music from 1920s to present. Includes recorded interviews with the most significant film composers and film clips of their work.

SCOR.title: Entrepreneurialism for the Screen Composer
SCOR.description: Addresses challenges facing emerging screen composers, including negotiating deals; establishing a studio, production budgets, and a publishing business; tracking royalties; licensing music; and engaging representation.

SCOR.title: Recording, Mixing and Editing for the Screen Composer
SCOR.description: Addresses the need for modern-day screen composers to produce and digitally record, sweeten, mix, and edit much of their own music.

SCOR.title: Advanced Screen Scoring Technology
SCOR.description: Explores sophisticated principles and applications of technologies for screen scoring, including the use of synthesizers, samplers, and sequencers.

SCOR.title: Directed Research
SCOR.description: Research leading to the Master's Degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

SCOR.title: Research
SCOR.description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

MUCD.title: Choral Conducting
MUCD.description: Intermediate and advanced instruction (secondary emphasis) for  music majors and minors.  Open only to music majors and minors.

MUCD.title: Instrumental Conducting
MUCD.description: Intermediate and advanced instruction (secondary emphasis) for  music majors and minors.  Open only to music majors and minors.

MUCD.title: Choral Conducting I
MUCD.description: Basic conducting techniques; score analysis; conducting patterns; problems of tempo, dynamics, articulation and text.

MUCD.title: Instrumental Conducting I
MUCD.description: Communicating musical ideas to instrumental ensembles; reading and conducting from full score of orchestral compositions. Laboratory, 3 hours. Prerequisite: ability to read a music score.

MUCD.title: Instrumental Conducting and Orchestration
MUCD.description: Reading and conducting from scores, communicating musical ideas to instrumental ensembles, arranging for small and large ensembles, notation, playing techniques, timbre, rhythm and intonation.

MUCD.title: Choral Conducting II
MUCD.description: Refinement of techniques developed in MUCD 340; study of styles and interpretations of choral music from the Renaissance to the present.

MUCD.title: Instrumental Conducting II
MUCD.description: Principal composers and representative instrumental works since the eighteenth century; studies of styles and interpretations based on scores and the performance of works in class.

MUCD.title: Directed Research
MUCD.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

MUCD.title: Choral Conducting
MUCD.description: Secondary instruction for graduate music majors or instruction for  graduate non-music majors.

MUCD.title: Instrumental Conducting
MUCD.description: Secondary instruction for graduate music majors or instruction for  graduate non-music majors.

MUCD.title: Choral Conducting III
MUCD.description: Problems of preparing and conducting contemporary choral music    and major choral-orchestral works from full score; special         projects according to student's development and interests.         Laboratory, 3 hours.

MUCD.title: Directed Research
MUCD.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

MUCD.title: Choral Conducting IV
MUCD.description: Continuation of MUCD 541, including choral conducting pedagogy.
