BPMK.title: Biopharmaceutical Advertising and Communication
BPMK.description: Understand product positioning, timing and market opportunities. Key message development and communication pathways including digital advertising. Write and integrate an advertising and marketing plan.

BPMK.title: Market Access and Reimbursement Strategy
BPMK.description: Comprehensive analysis of the payer environment and health technology assessment bodies and strategies and brand planning activities to enhance product uptake, value and formulary coverage.

BPMK.title: Biopharmaceutical Product Pricing and Competition
BPMK.description: Hands-on development of a competitive value-based pricing model for a biopharmaceutical product from initial global commercial launch and throughout the product lifecycle.

BPSI.title: CPT Internship in Biopharmaceutical Sciences
BPSI.description: Cooperative education providing international undergraduate pharmacy students opportunity to enhance biopharmaceutical sciences curriculum through practical, industry appropriate, work experience.

BPSI.title: Biopharmaceutics II
BPSI.description: Comprehensive overview of early drug discovery and medicinal product development; in vitro and in vivo assays simulations/modeling, biopharmaceutical classification system, drug delivery science and technology.

BPSI.title: Drug Safety Pharmacology and Toxicology
BPSI.description: Toxicology and safety pharmacology principles that guide the clinical development of safe and efficacious drugs and biologics.

BPSI.title: Biologics and Vaccines
BPSI.description: How biologics and vaccines are researched, designed and used to treat and prevent diseases; regulatory and ethical issues surrounding these therapeutics.

BPSI.title: Biopharmaceutical Marketing Analysis and Strategy
BPSI.description: Introduces marketing analysis and strategy for biopharmaceutical drugs. Learn to conduct analysis to develop integrated marketing strategies and to execute on marketing and promotion plans.

BPSI.title: Pharmacoethics
BPSI.description: Ethics as a challenge in the pharmaceuticals industry. Organizational ethics and bioethics related to research, development and marketing across the public and healthcare professional groups.

BPSI.title: Science Talk
BPSI.description: Students will learn to present science to others using techniques of storytelling, informative, commemorative, persuasive speeches, interviews and scientific presentations; strategies to reduce speaker apprehension.

BPSI.title: Directed Research
BPSI.description: Individual research, reading, writing and project development.

BPSI.title: Senior Honors Seminar I
BPSI.description: Exciting and challenging opportunity to marshal and deploy research, analysis, interpretation and writing skills learned in their major.

BPSI.title: Senior Honors Seminar II
BPSI.description: An independent study course for students undertaking the research and writing of an Honors thesis.

HCDA.title: Foundations of Product Development and Commercialization
HCDA.description: Introduction to product development and commercialization of new healthcare technologies. Principles of clinical development, regulatory pathways, market access, reimbursement, pricing, and commercial product launch strategies.

HCDA.title: Business Implications of Healthcare Policy
HCDA.description: Overview of healthcare policies that impact payers, employers, healthcare industry, state/federal agencies and consumers.

HCDA.title: Healthcare Decision Analysis and Modeling
HCDA.description: Quantitative methods of evaluating business, policy, pharmaceuticals, medical care resource allocations. Budget Impact Models, Decision Trees, Sensitivity Analysis tradeoffs between treatment strategies, interventions, risks, outcomes.

HCDA.title: Healthcare Literature Analysis and Applications
HCDA.description: Conduct literature evaluations using practical approaches to analyze and critique medical and health economic literature with the aim of optimizing health policy and business decisions.

HCDA.title: Healthcare Data Analytics II
HCDA.description: Develop an analytical plan and conduct analysis of health-related datasets using RStudio and design data visualizations to summarize findings to support healthcare decision makers.

HCDA.title: Seminars in Healthcare Decision Analysis
HCDA.description: Weekly seminar and literature series, review and discuss policy, biopharmaceuticals, insurance, global healthcare access issues. Student lead discussions, expert guest speakers, group projects, critical thinking.

HCDA.title: Healthcare Consulting Enterprise Team Project
HCDA.description: Work as a consultant to conduct market research and apply decision analysis methods to design strategies for healthcare products and services or company pipelines.

RXRS.title: The History and Geography of Drugs
RXRS.description: Global perspectives; discovery and use of drugs (legal/illegal); poisons. How they helped shape, modify or change history as described in classical literature through present day.

RXRS.title: Comparative Neuropharmacology: A Kaleidoscope of Experiences
RXRS.description: How drugs impact culture in individual, society and global communities

RXRS.title: CPT Internship in Pharmacology and Drug Development
RXRS.description: Cooperative education providing international undergraduate pharmacy students opportunity to enhance pharmacology and drug development curriculum through practical, industry appropriate, work experience.

RXRS.title: Introduction to Pharmacology and Therapeutics
RXRS.description: Drug/Receptor interactions, pharmacodynamics, pharmacokinetics. Safe and effective drug administration; differences in pediatric and geriatric populations. Current therapies, adverse effects and drug interactions.

RXRS.title: Neuropharmacology in Health and Disease
RXRS.description: Neuropharmacological treatments of brain disorders including neurodegenerative disorders, injury, and disease; influence of environment and experiences on neuroplasticity and brain development; drug discovery.

RXRS.title: The Discovery, Development and Marketing of Medicines
RXRS.description: Principles, concepts, challenges and short comings of modern day drug discovery and development of medicines. Inter-relationships with regulatory, ethical and societal sectors presented.

RXRS.title: Arming the Immune System for Novel Therapies
RXRS.description: Principles of human immunological responses to maintain wellness and perturbation in disease. Focus on discovery, development and use of therapeutic strategies targeting immune mechanisms.

RXRS.title: Globalization of the Biomedical Industry
RXRS.description: Globalization; pharmaceuticals, biologics, medical devices, and combination products in advanced, emerging, and developing markets; regional and national regulations, global and regional harmonization efforts, ethical considerations.

RXRS.title: Buzzed: Modern Substances of Abuse and Addiction
RXRS.description: Modern perspectives; discovery and use of legal and illicit drugs including alcohol and opioids. How drugs have helped, shaped, modified or changed individuals and society.

RXRS.title: More than Prescriptions: An Integrative Approach to Modern H
RXRS.description: Integrative medicine; dietary supplements; plant medicines; pharmacology, toxicity and human disease

RXRS.title: Management and Operation of Clinical Trials
RXRS.description: Clinical Trials management and operations are vital aspects in the design, planning, conduct and reporting of successful research projects and portfolios.

RXRS.title: Introduction to Patient Care and Clinical Therapeutics
RXRS.description: Pharmacy practice. Cultural humility in healthcare. Public health principles.

RXRS.title: Pharmacy Undergraduate Maymester
RXRS.description: Global Perspectives Maymester - Medicines, Geography and History through immersive travel.

RXRS.title: Directed Research
RXRS.description: Individual research, reading, writing and project development.

RXRS.title: Senior Honors Seminar I
RXRS.description: Exciting and challenging opportunity to marshal and deploy research, analysis, interpretation and writing skills students learned in their major.

RXRS.title: Senior Honors Seminar II
RXRS.description: An independent study course for students undertaking the research and writing of an Honors thesis.

PMEP.description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be      applied to the degree to be determined by the department.  Graded  CR/NC.

PMEP.title: Doctoral Dissertation
PMEP.description: Credit on acceptance of dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC.

PMEP.title: Doctoral Dissertation
PMEP.description: Credit on acceptance of dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC.

PMEP.title: Doctoral Dissertation
PMEP.description: Credit on acceptance of dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC.

PMEP.title: Doctoral Dissertation
PMEP.description: Credit on acceptance of dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC.

RSCI.title: Quality Assurance for Drugs and Biologics
RSCI.description: Design and implementation of a quality system assuring the quality and safety of pharmaceuticals and biologics, according to relevant FDA and international regulations and guidance documents.

RSCI.title: Quality Assurance, Medical Devices and Combination Products
RSCI.description: Design of systems according to FDA and international regulations and guidelines to ensure the quality and safety of medical devices and combination products.

RSCI.title: Introduction to Medical Product Regulation
RSCI.description: Introduction to regulatory environments surrounding medical product development, manufacturing and marketing; operation of federal, state and international regulatory bodies.

RSCI.title: Regulation of Medical Devices and Diagnostics
RSCI.description: Development and testing of new medical products according to U.S. and international regulatory requirements.

RSCI.title: Global Regulation of Medical Products
RSCI.description: Regulatory requirements governing medical products in European Union, Asia and other global markets.

RSCI.title: Introduction to Risk Management for Health Care  Providers
RSCI.description: Historical development, formal language and theoretical approaches  to risk management in health care and medical product environment;  policies, regulations, standards; liability prevention and loss  control.  Recommended preparation: undergraduate degree in  pharmacy, medical or independent health sciences, engineering or  equivalent mix of post-secondary training and industry  experience.  (Duplicates credit in MPTX 520.)  Recommended  preparation: undergraduate degree in pharmacy, medical or  independent health sciences, engineering or equivalent mix of  post-secondary training and industry experience, enrollment in  M.S., Regulatory Science.

RSCI.title: Seminars in Regulatory Science
RSCI.description: Current problems in regulatory affairs, legal management, preclinical and clinical testing, scientific evaluation and quality assurance. (Duplicates credit in former MPTX 521.) Graded CR/NC. Recommended preparation: undergraduate degree in pharmacy, medical or independent health sciences, engineering or equivalent mix of post secondary training and industry experience; enrollment in MS Regulatory Science program.

RSCI.title: Introduction to Clinical Trial Design and Statistics
RSCI.description: Clinical designs and statistics commonly used to test medical products in general populations and special patient groups.

RSCI.title: Industrial Approaches to Drug Discovery
RSCI.description: Examines the process of drug discovery from selection of disease and therapeutic target to characterization and validation of lead drug candidates. Recommended preparation: undergraduate degree in pharmacy, medical or independent health sciences, engineering or equivalent mix of post-secondary training and industry experience; enrollment in M.S., Regulatory Science, certificate in Preclinical Drug Development.

RSCI.title: Clinical Trial Project Management
RSCI.description: Clinical Trials management and operations are vital aspects in the design, planning, conduct and reporting of successful research projects and portfolios.

RSCI.title: Directed Research
RSCI.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

RSCI.title: Internship for Curricular Practical Training in  Regulatory Science
RSCI.description: Part-time or full-time practical work experience in Regulatory Science. The internship must be located at an off-campus facility. Students are individually supervised by faculty. Graded CR/NC. Recommended preparation: Undergraduate or professional degree in pharmacy, medicine or independent health sciences, engineering or equivalent mix of post-secondary training and industry experience; enrollment in MS (Regulatory Science).

RSCI.title: Biomedical Commerce
RSCI.description: Introduction to business principles appropriate to medical  products, including: supply and demand, product entry-exit  strategies, financing, reimbursement, marketing and pricing in  global marketplace.  Recommended preparation: undergraduate degree  in pharmacy, medical or independent health sciences, engineering  or equivalent mix of post-secondary training and industry  experience; enrollment in M.S., Regulatory Science.

RSCI.title: Directed Field-Research Project
RSCI.description: Research/policy analysis conducted under preceptor supervision in an industrial or governmental setting.

RSCI.title: Directed Research
RSCI.description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied towards the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC

PHRD.title: Physiology, Biopharmaceutics and Medicinal Chemistry II
PHRD.description: Explores proteins involved in drug absorption, distribution, metabolism and elimination (ADME), organ physiology, pharmacokinetics, drug interactions and the relationship between plasma drug levels and pharmacological effects.

PHRD.title: Clinical Skills and Professional Development II
PHRD.description: Equips pharmacy students with clinical skills, patient-centered care, medication therapy management, physical assessment and interprofessional education, fostering communication, clinical decision-making and ethical healthcare practice. Builds upon prior knowledge from the Clinical Skills and Professional Development course series.

PHRD.title: Pharmacogenetics
PHRD.description: Principles of gene expression and the influence of genetics on the effectiveness of drug therapy. Open to Doctor of Pharmacy students only. (Duplicates credit in former PHRD-505)

PHRD.title: Scholarship I
PHRD.description: Equips pharmacists with essential drug information, literature evaluation and research skills to support evidence-based decision-making, formulary management and quality improvement in various health care settings.

PHRD.title: Integrated Science and Clinical Therapeutics II
PHRD.description: Covers endocrine disorders, including diabetes, thyroid disease, reproductive health and osteoporosis, integrating pathophysiology, pharmacology and clinical management for patient care applications.

PHRD.title: Pharmacy Career Pathways II
PHRD.description: First-year seminar introducing pharmacy students to four Trojan Areas of Concentration, aligning education with career goals through expert-led sessions, some leading to academic certificates.

PHRD.title: Case Conference 2
PHRD.description: Case conferences and seminars focusing on contemporary pharmacy practice.

PHRD.title: Therapeutics: Central Nervous System
PHRD.description: Integration of biomedicinal chemistry, pharmacology, pharmacokinetics, and therapeutics with emphasis on the central nervous system. Open to Doctor of Pharmacy students only. (Duplicates credit in PHRD 560)

PHRD.title: Therapeutics: Endocrine System
PHRD.description: Integration of biomedicinal chemistry, pharmacology, pharmacokinetics, and therapeutics with emphasis on the endocrine and reproductive system.

PHRD.title: Introductory Community Pharmacy Practice Experience 1AB
PHRD.description: The P1 Community IPPE provides 15 days of hands-on experience, introducing student pharmacists to community pharmacy operations and their role in patient care.

PHRD.title: Community Pharmacy Practice
PHRD.description: Exploration of the various roles pharmacist play in the community-based pharmacy practice setting. Includes emphasis on fundamentals and ongoing changes in community practice, advance pharmacy practices, and patient care services, including (but not limited to) international travel health.

PHRD.title: Longitudinal Elective Pharmacy Practice
PHRD.description: For Year 2 pharmacy (P2) and Year 3 pharmacy (P3) students who are assigned to an Elective Introductory Pharmacy Practice Experience (IPPE) after registering for PHRD 627a. The P2 and P3 Elective IPPE provides the student with 80 hours of experiential learning to develop skills related to various aspects of the pharmacy profession in a variety of settings.

PHRD.title: Longitudinal Community Pharmacy Practice
PHRD.description: For Year 2 pharmacy (P2) and Year 3 pharmacy (P3) students who are assigned to a Community Introductory Pharmacy Practice Experience (IPPE). The P2 and P3 Community IPPE provides the student with 80 hours of experiential learning to develop skills related to aspects of the pharmacy profession in the Community pharmacy setting.

PHRD.title: Longitudinal Community Pharmacy Practice
PHRD.description: For Year 2 pharmacy (P2) and Year 3 pharmacy (P3) students who are assigned to a Community Introductory Pharmacy Practice Experience (IPPE) after registering for PHRD 629a. The P2 and P3 Community IPPE provides the student with 80 hours of experiential learning to develop skills related to aspects of the pharmacy profession in the Community pharmacy setting.

PHRD.title: Longitudinal Institutional Pharmacy Practice
PHRD.description: This course is for Year 2 pharmacy (P2) and Year 3 pharmacy (P3) students who are assigned to an Institutional Introductory Pharmacy Practice Experience (IPPE) after registering for PHRD 631a. The P2 and P3 Institutional IPPE provides the student with 80 hours of experiential learning to develop skills related to aspects of the pharmacy profession in the institutional pharmacy setting.

PHRD.title: Acute Care Clinical APPE
PHRD.description: Application of pharmaceutical care principles to the adult patient population in an acute care environment. Clinical application and disease state management will be emphasized. Open only to Doctor of Pharmacy students.

PHRD.title: Primary Care APPE
PHRD.description: Disease state management and a primary care setting. Modification and design of drug therapy regimens and primary patient care using a team based approach. Open only to Doctor of Pharmacy students.

PHRD.title: Community Pharmacy APPE
PHRD.description: Pharmaceutical care principles applied in a community pharmacy environment. Participating in the development, implementation and outcome evaluation of patient care services in the community. Open only to Doctor of Pharmacy students.

PHRD.title: Nuclear Pharmacy APPE
PHRD.description: Provides practical and theoretical aspects of radiopharmacy services delivery.

PHRD.title: Hospital Pharmacy Practice APPE
PHRD.description: Practical experience in the practice of hospital pharmacy. Administrative, practice-based and therapeutic competencies emphasized.

PHRD.title: International Pharmacy Practice Experience
PHRD.description: Practical experience in the practice of pharmacy in the international setting. Students will visit an international pharmacy practice setting and complete a project.

PHRD.title: Advanced Geriatrics APPE
PHRD.description: Directed projects/practical experience in geriatric drug therapy.

PHRD.title: Pharmaceutical Industry APPE
PHRD.description: Practical experience within a pharmaceutical company may include: clinical affairs, drug development, research and/or marketing process.

PHRD.title: Advanced Pharmacy Practice Elective (APPE)
PHRD.description: Pharmacy practice experience (internship) course in a health care  setting.

PHRD.title: Non-traditional Advanced Pharmacy Elective (APPE)
PHRD.description: Pharmacy practice experience (internship) course in a              non-traditional or emerging setting.

PHRD.title: Directed Research
PHRD.description: Research leading to doctorate in Clinical and Experimental  Therapeutics.

PHRD.title: Doctor of Pharmacy Capstone
PHRD.description: Capstone course required for completion of Doctor of Pharmacy degree.

OT.title: THRIVE: Foundations of Well-Being
OT.description: Exploration of themes of thriving including well-being, self-care and connection. Application to university life, building community, developing identity and integrating learned topics into everyday life.

OT.title: Caring For Your Self: Engaging in Healthy Habits and Routines
OT.description: Application of self-care, lifestyle, and behavior change principles in occupational science and occupational therapy to students own lives, through self-analysis and learning through doing.

OT.title: Culture, Medicine and Politics
OT.description: Survey of the impact of public institutions, private interests and cultural practices on health and the delivery of health care.

OT.title: Medical Terminology for Health Professions
OT.description: Foundation of medical terminology and hospital abbreviations useful for practice in health care.

OT.title: A Life of Play
OT.description: Exploration and incorporation of play as a meaningful activity to promote healthy living; emphasis on the importance of play in human development throughout the lifespan.

OT.title: Lifestyle Design: Self-Analysis of Activities for Health
OT.description: Introduction to theoretical concepts concerning the relationship of engagement in activities, or occupations, to health and well-being. Application of these perspectives to students' own lives.

OT.title: Introduction to Occupational Science and         Occupational Therapy
OT.description: Exploration of occupations, or meaningful activities, and how they may promote health and wellness, and the science behind why occupations are powerful tools for healing.

OT.title: Across the Lifespan: Occupations, Health and Disability
OT.description: Innovative team-based learning to explore theories and stages of development throughout the lifespan, as manifested in activity; representation of diverse contexts, perspectives, and abilities.

OT.title: Human Functional Anatomy for Allied Health Professions
OT.description: Lecture and cadaver lab-based, human anatomy course focused on the interaction of anatomical systems relative to functional activity, health and wellness.

OT.title: Essential Occupations of Emerging Adulthood
OT.description: Examination of challenges associated with the emerging adulthood stage of development through an occupational science lens; strategies to promote health and well-being for this population.

OT.title: Occupational Expressions of Diverse Identities and Lifestyle
OT.description: Exploration of the diverse ways occupational practices become central to identity, reify standard social ideologies, and are manipulated to redress conventional standards.

OT.title: Exploring Creative Occupations
OT.description: Examination of theories and practices of the creative process in varied mediums; exploration of the relationship between creative occupation, identity, health, and quality of life.

OT.title: Living a Sustainable Life
OT.description: Exploration of relationship with nature in daily life, including impact on mental health, nutrition, and built environments; includes hands-on activities at USC Peace Garden.

OT.title: Animal and Human Interconnections in Daily Life
OT.description: Exploration of the vast and evolving relationships between animals and humans; how animals expand human capacity for action and contribute to health, well-being and participation.

OT.title: Disability, Occupations, and the Health Care System
OT.description: Exploration of the ways in which able-bodyism, sexism, racism,  classism and homophobia contribute to occupational opportunities  or barriers and weave their way into health care.

OT.title: Understanding Autism and Neurodiversity: Participation Acros
OT.description: Introduction to autism from a neurodevelopmental and neurodiversity-positive perspective; occupational participation of individuals who identify as neurodivergent; strategies to promote acceptance and inclusion for all.

OT.title: Directed Research
OT.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

OT.title: Clinical Problems in Occupational Therapy
OT.description: Specific applications of occupational therapy practice in varied clinical/health settings. Seminar to integrate theory with application of treatment principles for various dysfunctional conditions. Graded CR/NC.

OT.title: Clinical Problems in Occupational Therapy
OT.description: Specific applications of occupational therapy practice in varied clinical/health settings. Seminar to integrate theory with application of treatment principles for various dysfunctional conditions. Graded CR/NC.

OT.title: Clinical Problems in Occupational Therapy
OT.description: Specific applications of occupational therapy practice in varied clinical/health settings. Seminar to integrate theory with application of treatment principles for various dysfunctional conditions. Graded CR/NC.

OT.title: Practice Immersion: Adult Physical Rehabilitation
OT.description: Scientific and theoretical underpinnings and knowledge and skills necessary for occupational therapy evaluation and intervention in adult rehabilitation and geriatrics; incorporates related Level I Fieldwork. Duplicates credit in former OT 401. Open only to Occupational Therapy majors.

OT.title: Practice Immersion: Mental Health
OT.description: Scientific and theoretical underpinnings and knowledge and skills necessary for occupational therapy evaluation and intervention in mental health practice; incorporates related Level I Fieldwork. Duplicates credit in former OT 402. Open only to Occupational Therapy majors.

OT.title: Practice Immersion: Pediatrics
OT.description: Scientific and theoretical underpinnings and knowledge and skills necessary for occupational therapy evaluation and intervention in pediatrics; incorporates related Level I Fieldwork. Duplicates credit in former OT 403. Open only to Occupational Therapy majors.

OT.title: Practice Immersion: Productive Aging and Geriatrics
OT.description: Examination of the aging process and introduction to the role of occupational therapy in working with older adults in a variety of settings.

OT.title: Seniors Rising:Occupational Foundations for Graduate Success
OT.description: Overview of individualized goals necessary for graduate school success using occupational therapy frameworks and assessment measures.

OT.title: Foundations of Occupation: Sensory Processing in Daily Life
OT.description: Comprehensive overview of the basic neurobehavioral principles underlying sensory processing and sensory integration theory and their relationship to everyday occupations.

OT.title: Communication in Practice
OT.description: Strengthening therapeutic communication skills to develop collaborative relationships and manage challenging clinical encounters through motivational interviewing and the application of therapeutic modes.

OT.title: Practice Scholar: Applying Quantitative Evidence
OT.description: Introduction to concepts of practice scholarship; emphasis on applying quantitative research evidence to clinical questions and appraising quantitative research evidence.

OT.title: Practice Scholar: Applying Qualitative Evidence
OT.description: Development of skills to find, appraise, synthesize and communicate qualitative evidence and the integration of multiple types of evidence to inform practice decisions.

OT.title: Leadership Capstone
OT.description: Building professional leadership capacity through personal reflection and leadership skills development, fostering professionalism, engaging in advocacy efforts, and applying ethical reasoning in occupational therapy practice.

OT.title: Directed Research
OT.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

OT.title: Master's Thesis
OT.description: Credit on acceptance of thesis.

OT.title: Master's Thesis
OT.description: Credit on acceptance of thesis.

OT.title: Master's Thesis
OT.description: Credit on acceptance of thesis.

OT.title: Internship for Curricular Practical Training
OT.description: Part-time or full-time, practical work experience in the student's field of study. The internship must be located at an off-campus facility. Students are individually supervised by faculty. May not be taken until the student has completed at least one semester of enrollment in the graduate program with a cumulative 3.0 GPA.

OT.title: Advanced Applications: Functional Cognition and Occupation
OT.description: In-depth exploration of foundational knowledge pertaining to both the nature of cognitive capacities and issues surrounding potential compromise in daily living contexts.

OT.title: Advanced Applications: Medical Complexity and Occupation
OT.description: Exploration of human physiology, pathophysiology, and occupational performance across the lifespan; Integration of a medical systems perspective applicable to various practice settings.

OT.title: Researching Occupation: Engagement, Meaning, and Society
OT.description: Approaches to studying social contexts, structures, processes, discourses, practices and meanings of everyday life concerning people as occupational beings, emphasizing qualitative and mixed methods.

OT.title: Research Practicum
OT.description: Experiential learning through immersion in one or more externally funded research groups in the Division, enabling intense participation in multi-skilled research groups.

OT.title: Focused Applications of Occupational Science
OT.description: Identification, analysis, critique and application of current occupational science research and themes to topic of relevance to post-professional occupational therapy education.

OT.title: Research
OT.description: Research leading to the doctorate, maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

OT.title: Doctoral Dissertation
OT.description: Credit on acceptance of dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC.

OT.title: Doctoral Dissertation
OT.description: Credit on acceptance of dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC.

OT.title: Doctoral Dissertation
OT.description: Credit on acceptance of dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC.

OT.title: Doctoral Dissertation
OT.description: Credit on acceptance of dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC.

OT.title: Doctoral Dissertation
OT.description: Credit on acceptance of dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC.

AEST.title: Aerospace Studies I (Air Force Mission and Organization)
AEST.description: Organization and function of NORAD; Tactical Air, Military Airlift, Systems, Logistics, Air Training, and Communications Commands; Army, Navy, Marines; Reserves; Separate Operating Agencies.

AEST.title: Leadership Laboratory I
AEST.description: Introduction to the military experiecne focusing on customs and courtesies, drill and ceremonies, and the environment of an Air Force Officer. Graded CR/NC.

AEST.title: Aerospace Studies II (Air Force History)
AEST.description: Development of aerospace power since WWII; emphasis on international confrontations involving the U.S.; communications skills.

AEST.title: Leadership Laboratory II
AEST.description: Introduction to the military experience focusing on customs and courtesies, drill and ceremonies, and the environment of an Air Force Offficer. Graded CR/NC.

AEST.title: Aerospace Studies III (Air Force Management and Leadership)
AEST.description: Air Force management fucusing on the new manager in the Air Force milieu. Emphasis on communication skills peculiar to the Air Force.

AEST.title: Leadership Laboratory III
AEST.description: Practical introduction to Air Force leadership focusing on military communicative skills, group dynamics, and application of theories of leadership and management. Graded CR/NC.

AEST.title: Aerospace Studies IV (National Security Forces in Contemporary American Society)
AEST.description: (AEROSPACE STUDIES IV - NATIONAL SECURITY FORCES IN CONTEMPORARY AMERICAN SOCIETY - Military professionalism and the context in which defense policy is formulated and implemented; national security policy, political/social constraints, and military justice.

AEST.title: Leadership Laboratory IV
AEST.description: Advanced Air Forcer leadership experience forcusing on the practical development of the Air Force officer through command and staff positions within the Cadet Corps. Graded CR/NC.

AEST.title: Leadership Laboratory V
AEST.description: Advanced leadership experiences for AFROTC continuing cadets. Graded CR/NC.

HMGT.title: Information Technology and Patient Engagement
HMGT.description: Strategic management and utilization of healthcare information technology in the delivery of healthcare; patient engagement and the use of technology to facilitate participation in their own care. Open only to Executive Master of Health Administration students.

HMGT.title: Health Economics, Financing and Reimbursement
HMGT.description: Provides a framework for the economic analysis of health care issues and provides students with an opportunity to apply economic methods to a number of actual health care problems.

HMGT.title: Strategic Management
HMGT.description: Provides skill development and application in the integrative  discipline of strategic management including assessment, strategy  formulation implementation and control.  Open to MHM students only.

HMGT.title: Operations Management for Accountability
HMGT.description: Hospital operations in the inpatient/outpatient setting; special emphasis on the growing requirement to more effectively manage across the continuum of care while assuming greater accountability in the delivery of care. Open only to EMHA students.

HMGT.title: Operational Efficiency Processes in Health Care  Organizations
HMGT.description: Improving productivity and efficiency of health care organizations combining the application of key operational analysis principles to improve quality, speed and productivity in the delivery of health care. Open only to EMHA students.

HMGT.title: Developing & Monitoring of Quality & Patient Safety Outcomes
HMGT.description: Overview of contemporary methods used to develop and monitor patient quality and safety outcomes; develop skill in data collection and analysis of clinical care outcomes; focus on operationalizing outcomes that matter to payers, organizations, and clinicians. Open only to EMHA students.

PPDE.title: Professional Workshop in Public Administration
PPDE.description: Evidence-based argumentation, written reporting and communication  in public administration;  research skills for effective stakeholder engagement.

PPDE.title: Professional Residency in Public Administration
PPDE.description: Skills in written reporting, professional briefings and social media for public administrators; effective engagement for stakeholders and constituencies; research, analysis and reporting on current policy or management cases

PPDE.title: Social Innovation
PPDE.description: Strategies and processes of social innovation in the context of economics, institutional, and innovation theory. How social innovation materializes across all sectors, including the government, nonprofit, and for-profit spheres. Critical thinking and practical application development to solve social problems.

PPDE.title: Analytics and Operations for Healthcare Management
PPDE.description: Integrates data, analytics and operational management concepts through cross-functional case studies and in-depth analysis principles and tools.

PPDE.title: Methodology, Methods and Tools for Urban Sustainability
PPDE.description: Methodology, assessment and planning methods for urban sustainability and land use planning; how the choice and use of theory and methods impact the planning process; systems and spatial analysis

PPDE.title: Housing and Land Use in Rapidly Urbanizing Regions
PPDE.description: Interdisciplinary approach to conceptualize urban land and property rights; property rights strategies; design and policy interventions; the struggle for rights to space in the city

PPDE.title: Art and the City
PPDE.description: Role of art in modern society with a particular emphasis on the urban context including public spaces, the process of gentrification, and redevelopment; theoretical and research approaches.

PPDE.title: Planning for Resilience
PPDE.description: Key concepts in planning for resilience and risks. Unequal distributions of risks, including social vulnerabilities and equity considerations. Topical issues in resilience planning.

PPDE.title: Land Use and Transportation Planning
PPDE.description: Key theories of land use - transportation interactions; understanding of land markets and derived-demand approach; use of evidence for information; travel data collection methods; application of land use

PPDE.title: Methods for Equity Analysis
PPDE.description: Techniques to measure inequality and segregation. Policy evaluation using techniques for casual inference. Prerequisites: PPD 558.

PPDE.title: Seminar in Social Justice and Public Policy
PPDE.description: Major theories of social justice in the US and globally; how theories of social justice influence policy, urban planning, and public administration; how to bridge theories about justice for professional practice.

PPDE.title: Applied Econometrics for Program Evaluation
PPDE.description: Application of econometric methods for causal inference. Production and evaluation of empirical estimates of causal relationships to inform evidence-based policy decisions.

PPDE.title: An Exploration of the Intelligence Community -  from Policy to Cyber Espionage
PPDE.description: Introduction to the intelligence community with an emphasis on public policy and open source intelligence (OSINT); analysis of US and foreign intelligence communities and sources, collection methods and analysis techniques; policy considerations.

PPDE.title: Foundations of Environmental Policy
PPDE.description: Introduction to environmental policy; the evolution of regulatory institutions - local, state, federal and global; use of economic analysis and empirical methods; practical applications in the field

PPDE.title: Board Governance and Leadership
PPDE.description: Governance of nonprofit organizations; responsibilities and expectations of boards; board effectiveness; and changes in governance as a result of recent federal and state legislation.

PPDE.title: Fund Development for Nonprofit Organizations
PPDE.description: Key aspects of the fundraising process for nonprofit organizations; theoretical foundations and general fundraising principles; techniques sources of donations; key aspects of managing the process

PPDE.title: Capstone in Nonprofit Leadership and Management
PPDE.description: Mission-mandated accountable and ethical practice, individually and organizationally; applications of core competencies; practical inquiry, analysis, systems; comparative frameworks; strategic leadership and management of public value production.

NAUT.title: Seamanship and Navigation
NAUT.description: An experiential approach to sailing and seafaring, introducing offshore sailing theory and techniques, navigation, and basic oceanography as relevant to seamanship, leadership and communication skills.

NAUT.title: Seamanship and Navigation
NAUT.description: An experiential approach to sailing and seafaring, introducing offshore sailing theory and techniques, navigation, and basic oceanography as relevant to seamanship, leadership and communication skills.

NAUT.title: Advanced Seamanship and Navigation
NAUT.description: Responsibilities and operations commanding an offshore sailing vessel including sailing theory and advanced techniques, advanced navigation, ships engineering and oceanography relevant to seamanship.

NSC.title: Seapower and Maritime Affairs
NSC.description: Analysis of U.S. Navy development and campaigns; evolution of strategic, tactical and maritime doctrines; interaction of naval affairs with national security and domestic policies.

NSC.title: Navigation
NSC.description: Purposes, methods, and instruments of navigation; terrestrial and celestial navigation and nautical astronomy; time diagrams; lines of position by observation of celestial bodies.

NSC.title: Evolution of Warfare
NSC.description: Causes and practice of warfare from ancient times; impact of changes in strategy, tactics, and technology; modern revolutionary warfare, global conflict, and politico-military relationships.

NSC.title: Naval Ships Systems II (Weapons)
NSC.description: Systems approach to naval weapons; linear analysis of ballistics; weapons control systems configurations and dynamics. Field trips.

NSC.title: Leadership and Ethics
NSC.description: Introduction to primary duties of junior naval officers; counseling and interviewing techniques; review of basic administrative responsibilities at the division officer level.

PPD.title: Solving Public Problems
PPD.description: Develops a framework for understanding public policy and its role in solving current complex issues. Theories, processes and institutions that shape policymaking and professional development for policymaking. Course sections may vary in policy subject emphasis.

PPD.title: Citizenship and Public Ethics
PPD.description: Review of legal and ethical traditions of citizenship withemphasis on the latter; consideration of implications for currentpractice of public policy-making and management.

PPD.title: The Urban Context
PPD.description: The urban context for planning and policy decisions. Socioeconomic, physical and spatial structure of cities; and the underlying demographic, economic and social processes that drive their ongoing transformation.

PPD.title: Social Justice Issues in Public Policy and Urban Planning
PPD.description: Social justice issues through the lens of public policy and urban planning with main focus on Los Angeles; critical thinking skills about the fields and their relevance to social justice.

PPD.title: PPD Practices: Internship Seminar
PPD.description: Policy, planning, and development skills for practice; internship seminar; leadership, group dynamics and presentation skills; application of management; organizational diversity; reflection on experiences.

PPD.title: Statistics for Policy, Planning, and Development
PPD.description: Statistical applications applied to the real world; techniques including probability, sampling; hypothesis formation and testing; correlation, and linear regression.

PPD.title: Public Policy and Law
PPD.description: Institutional foundations and analysis of public policy issues; policy formulation and implementation; application of theories; case analyses.

PPD.title: Analytic Foundations for Public Policy
PPD.description: Qualitative methods of analysis; ethical and political implications of policy choices; issue diagnosis and policy design skills; critical reasoning and ethics; policy leadership.

PPD.title: Fundamentals of Health Policy and Management
PPD.description: Learning the institutions of health care delivery and financing; evaluating key health policy issues; understanding and using economic, statistical and mathematical tools as ways to inform health policy issues.

PPD.title: Introduction to Health Care Systems
PPD.description: Concepts and determinants of health and illness; health care delivery organizations and programs; the role of the administrator; issues in health care financing and access; quality evaluation; future trends.

PPD.title: AI and Urban Planning
PPD.description: Exploration of the core concepts and use of AI in urban planning; developments in the field; urban applications; assessment of AI's ethics, equity and impact

PPD.title: Government and Business
PPD.description: Interrelated roles of business and public institutions; effects of public policies and laws on business sector; incorporates public and business perspectives.

PPD.title: Sustainable Communities, Policy and Planning
PPD.description: Policy and planning as shaped by sustainability theories;          sustainability indicators; topics include water resources, air     quality, land use regulations, environmental design, carrying      capacity, ecological footprint analysis. Duplicates credit in  former PPD 461.

PPD.title: The Nonprofit Sector and the Public Interest
PPD.description: Theories of the voluntary nonprofit sector in society and its relationship to government and business; public policies toward the sector.

PPD.title: Topics in Public Policy and Urban Studies
PPD.description: Seminar in cross cutting topics in public policy and urban studies that engages students with faculty and scholars in                 interdisciplinary research and analysis of key problems and issues in the fields.

PPD.title: Management of Public and Nonprofit Organizations
PPD.description: Contemporary management theory; the nature of complex  organizations' organizational and intergovernmental arrangements;  roles and responsibilities of managers; managerial and  organizational effectiveness; organizational structure and  dynamics.

PPD.title: Financial Management of Public and Nonprofit Organizations
PPD.description: Time value of money, risk, government bonds and tax-exempt  financing, cost of capital, budgeting, financial statement  analysis, and working capital management.

PPD.title: Comparative Urban Development
PPD.description: Urbanization and urban development and growth through an international scope; globalizing cities.

PPD.title: Geodesign Practicum
PPD.description: Application of design concepts, planning protocols and spatial analysis skills to a complex planning or design problem sponsored by a local public, private or not-for-profit client in a studio setting.

PPD.title: Community Health Policy and Planning
PPD.description: Historical perspectives on and the contemporary practice of community health planning; impact of culture, socioeconomics, and environment; policy dimensions; urban plannings role in enhancing and sustaining health.

PPD.title: Health Policy
PPD.description: Health policy analysis and challenges; price of health; structure of major sectors in health care; role of insurance in policy debates; trade-offs with policy decisions.

PPD.title: Transportation Data and Automation
PPD.description: Introduction of the role that technology will play in facilitating shared mobility, disrupting transportation markets, and reshaping multi-modal urban transportation systems; analyses of governance issues; the interaction between private markets and regulators; changes in the nature of infrastructure and urban planning that will be required to accommodate the wired future of transportation.

PPD.title: Geographic Information Systems and Planning      Applications
PPD.description: Basic GIS concepts, ArcView and other GIS software, planning  applications and databases, basic cartography; students select,  research and prepare a planning GIS analysis project.

PPD.title: Undergraduate Policy, Planning, and Development Studio
PPD.description: Application of methods in the exploration of a specific project, policy, or organization from the multiple perspectives of the five tracks in the undergraduate program.

PPD.title: Social Innovation
PPD.description: Strategies and processes of social innovation and change; examination of social change in the market, government, and within the nonprofit sector; dynamics; civic action and activism

PPD.title: Directed Research
PPD.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit. Departmental approval.

PPD.title: Senior Thesis
PPD.description: Writing of the honors capstone project in an area of interest related to the track of study; research and writing skills.

PPD.title: Behavioral Insights for Policy Makers: Overcoming Barriers   to Behavior Change
PPD.description: Selected topics in Public Policy, Management and Planning.

PPD.title: Collaborative Environmental Management and Conflict          Resolution
PPD.description: Selected topics in Public Policy, Management and Planning.

PPD.title: Washingtong DC Internship and Policy Research Seminar
PPD.description: Selected topics in Public Policy, Management and Planning.

PPD.title: Economics for Policy, Planning and Development
PPD.description: Microeconomic theory as applied to policy, planning, and development; concepts of efficiency; macroeconomic issues.

PPD.title: Economics for Public Policy
PPD.description: Economic theory as applied to public policy. Concepts of efficiency and equity, analysis of market failure and policy interventions.

PPD.title: Essential Statistics for Public Management
PPD.description: Essential statistics for public managers and administrators; application of statistical methods in addressing public policy and management questions.

PPD.title: Modeling for Health Policy and Medical Decision Making
PPD.description: Modeling techniques used to inform decisions in public health, disease control, and hospital operations.

PPD.title: Financial Management of Health Services
PPD.description: Accounting principles, financial reports, managerial finance, financial planning, capital investments, working capital analysis; elements of budgeting and reimbursement; performance standards; reporting; developing a management system.

PPD.title: Health Administration Residency Seminar
PPD.description: Supervised study of health care administration, governance, professional staff relations, internal operations and controls, legal and regulatory requirements, management policy and strategy.

PPD.title: Economic Concepts Applied to Health
PPD.description: Relationships between economic characteristics and health status; impact of economy on health services industry; demand and resources for health services; utilization, prices, costs, health insurance.

PPD.title: Strategic Management of Health Organizations
PPD.description: Application of principles of health administration in several practice settings. Decision-making; strategic management; organizational performance; communication; provider comparisons.

PPD.title: Quality of Care Concepts
PPD.description: Quality issues and complexities affecting healthcare; fundamentals of quality improvement programs; examination of quality issues and improvement programs in various health care venues; strategies

PPD.title: Urban Economics with International Applications
PPD.description: Fundamentals of urban development including role of land markets, externalities, economic analysis of market failures; regulations and stakeholders. Applications to U.S. and international contexts.

PPD.title: Physical Planning: Urban and Community Design
PPD.description: Exploration of the theories and concepts of livable communities and good city form. Introductory basics of design and city form. Case studies of historical and current best practices.

PPD.title: Planning Law and Legal Frameworks of Planning
PPD.description: Understanding of the legal system and its processes and laws applicable to land use and development and the legal nature of powers of public and private entities.

PPD.title: International Planning and Development Laboratory Workshop
PPD.description: Application of planning principles and methods to specific urban  planning problems abroad; involves preparation in the Spring  semester and an overseas field visit and a collaborative practicum.

PPD.title: Fundamentals of Public Administration
PPD.description: Administrative concepts, institutions, legal systems, and practices; values; facilitation of responsibilities and rights; professional applications for personal, private sector and public achievement.

PPD.title: Public Financial Management and Budgeting
PPD.description: Financial management applied to public and nonprofit organizations; financial valuation, financial markets, budgeting, tax administration, debt financing, cost-benefit analysis and financial analysis. Duplicates credit in PPDE 645.

PPD.title: Policy and Program Evaluation
PPD.description: Methods and models for policy and program evaluation; methods of collecting and analyzing evaluation data; processes for linking evaluation to policy formulation and program management.

PPD.title: Internship Seminar
PPD.description: Supervised study of management, analytical, or other professional activities in government; integration of theory, practice and      relevant literature.

PPD.title: Public and Nonprofit Organizational Behavior
PPD.description: Behavior in organizations; focus on personal, interpersonal, and group level factors that influence such behavior.

PPD.title: Capstone in Public Administration
PPD.description: Constitutionally accountable and ethical practice, individually and organizationally; applications of core competencies; practical inquiry, analysis, systems; comparative frameworks; citizenship and public service.

PPD.title: Foundations of Policy Analysis
PPD.description: Introduction to public policy analysis; issue diagnosis and policy design; analytic reasoning and argumentation; the role of the public policy professional; ethical issues in policy analysis.

PPD.title: Public Policy Formulation and Implementation
PPD.description: Political and organizational perspectives on policy making process; agenda setting, policy design, adoption, implementation, evaluation, modification or termination. Policy leadership skills: negotiation and strategic mapping.

PPD.title: Multivariate Statistical Analysis
PPD.description: Applied multivariate statistics in support of policy, management, and planning problem solving. Includes regression analysis, logit models, and an introduction to time-series models and multi-equation estimation.

PPD.title: Methods for Policy Analysis
PPD.description: Examination of methods used in the analysis of policy methods, including cost benefit analysis, decision and risk analysis, and applied social science methods.

PPD.title: Policy Analysis Practicum
PPD.description: Application and integration of the knowledge and techniques of     analytic, quantitative, managerial, political, and ethical         analyses to specific public policy problems.

PPD.title: Special Issues in International Public Policy
PPD.description: Current international public policy on issues such as governmental  reform, regulation, social welfare, poverty alleviation and  international aid.  Policy framework and in-depth analysis of  specific topics of relevance to government agencies and  international organizations.

PPD.title: Directed Research
PPD.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may  be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.       Graded CR/NC.

PPD.title: Internship for Curricular Practical Training
PPD.description: Part-time or full-time, practical work experience in the students field of study. The internship must be located at an off-campus facility. Students are individually supervised by faculty. May not be taken until the student has completed at least one semester of enrollment in the graduate program with a cumulative 3.0 GPA.

PPD.title: Management of Managed Care Organizations
PPD.description: Managed care arrangements, interorganizational relations, management practices and controls, medical staff relations, strategic planning, marketing, utilization review, quality assurance, outcomes measures.

PPD.title: Seminar in Hospital Administration
PPD.description: Hospital systems and functions; managerial processes, theory, and practice; governance structures; legal, regulatory, administrative, and professional requirements; medical and professional staff; multi-institutional arrangements; controls.

PPD.title: Planning and Economic Development Finance
PPD.description: Fundamentals for economic development professionals and policy     makers including feasibility analysis and the financing of         facilities, social services, and community-based enterprises.

PPD.title: Design Skills for Urban Planners
PPD.description: Develop observation, description, analysis, and conceptualization  skills related to urban spatial conditions; advance professional   communication proficiencies.

PPD.title: Capstone in Urban Planning
PPD.description: Successful completion of a comprehensive written and oral project-oriented assessment; analysis, interpretation, and solution of a real-world planning problem.

PPD.title: Geographic Information Systems for Policy, Planning, and Development
PPD.description: Introduction to GIS systems and usage in the public sector;  spatial data; understanding software and the application of  technology; analysis of data using GIS.

PPD.title: Methods and Modeling Tools for Transportation Planning
PPD.description: Background applications of established urban travel forecasting procedures; land use; trip-generation, trip-distribution, modal-choice, trip-assignment; evaluation; criticisms.

PPD.title: Seminar in the Administration of Local Government
PPD.description: Intensive consideration of the functions of the municipal         executive and his environment. Research preparation and discussion of cases.

PPD.title: Contemporary Issues in Philanthropy
PPD.description: Motivations and strategies of philanthropists; philanthropic  foundations and emerging institutions for philanthropy; issues of  philanthropic stewardship, public policy and public accountability.

PPD.title: Public Ethics
PPD.description: Following an introduction to the study of ethics, relationships    among administrative, political, and policy ethics are examined,   emphasizing the ethics of the administrative role.

PPD.title: Collaborative Governance
PPD.description: Theory and practice of collaborative policy and planning processes involving stakeholders from public, private, and nonprofit sectors. Leadership skills in the design and facilitation of multi-party negotiations and consensus-building.

PPD.title: Strategic Planning in the Public Sector
PPD.description: Analysis/field application of action research models for          strategic planning in public agencies; design of effective public  systems; citizens/administrators' roles in strategic               decision-making.

PPD.title: Nonprofit Management and Leadership
PPD.description: Issues in nonprofit management and leadership including: the role of boards; strategic planning; marketing and fundraising; financial management; and volunteer and human resource management. Recommended preparation: PPD 689.

PPD.title: International Development Administration
PPD.description: Development of theories; role of international institutions in    resource exchanges; foreign investment and trade policies;         national planning and allocation systems; development and          modernization strategies and implementation.

PPD.title: Health Care Venture Development
PPD.description: Focuses on developing the resourcefulness, know-how and decision  support skills needed to identify, assess and develop new health  ventures.  Includes business planning, financing, strategy,  entrepreneurship.  Recommended preparation: PPD 510a or HMGT 565.

PPD.title: Cultural Proficiency in Health Management and    Policy
PPD.description: Provides an understanding of what social factors contribute to   racial/ethnic, socioeconomic, and gender disparities in health and  the culturally proficient provision of health care.

PPD.title: Teaching Seminar
PPD.description: Pedagogy: learning objectives, curriculum design, teaching methods, evaluation. Graded CR/NC. (Duplicates credit in former PPD-700ab)

PPD.title: Research Seminar
PPD.description: Research fields and design; literature reviews; critical reading and critiquing; project development

PPD.title: Theoretical Foundation of Public Management
PPD.description: Theories of the role, structure, and growth of the public sector;  political economy of public bureaucracies; the voluntary nonprofit  sector.

PPD.title: Econometrics for Policy, Planning and Management II
PPD.description: Identification of a significant and innovative empirical research question; production of a dissertation chapter or draft manuscript for publication in policy, planning or management.

PPD.title: Research
PPD.description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

PPD.title: Doctoral Dissertation
PPD.description: Credit on acceptance of dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC.

PPD.title: Doctoral Dissertation
PPD.description: Credit on acceptance of dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC.

PPD.title: Doctoral Dissertation
PPD.description: Credit on acceptance of dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC.

PPD.title: Doctoral Dissertation
PPD.description: Credit on acceptance of dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC.

PPD.title: Doctoral Dissertation
PPD.description: Credit on acceptance of dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC.

MS.title: Basic Leadership
MS.description: Establishes foundation of basic leadership fundamentals such as problem solving, communications, briefings and effective writing,  goal setting, techniques for improving listening and speaking  skills and an introduction to counseling.

MS.title: Leadership and Teamwork
MS.description: Study examines how to build successful teams, various methods for  influencing action, effective communication in setting and  achieving goals, the importance of timing the decision, creativity  in the problem solving process, and obtaining team buy-in through  immediate feedback.

MS.title: Leadership and Ethics
MS.description: Examines the role communications, values, and ethics play in  effective leadership.  Topics include ethical decision-making,  consideration of others, spirituality in the military, and survey  Army leadership doctrine.  Emphasis on improving oral and written  communication abilities.

MS.title: Leadership and Management
MS.description: Study includes case study analysis of military law and practical  exercises on establishing an ethical command climate.  Students  must complete a semester long Senior Leadership Project that  requires them to plan, organize, collaborate, analyze, and  demonstrate their leadership skills.

PLUS.title: Place, Institutions, and Governance
PLUS.description: Concept of place; investigation of the problems and issues confronting metropolitan communities; how the actions of public, private and nonprofit sectors can effect various areas including economics, health, civic life, and the environment; contemporary issues in policy, planning and development; theoretical frameworks for solutions.

PLUS.title: Planning, Design and Development Professional Dissertation
PLUS.description: Credit on acceptance of Planning, Design and Development Professional Dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC.

PLUS.title: Planning, Design and Development Professional Dissertation
PLUS.description: Credit on acceptance of Planning, Design and Development Professional Dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC.

PLUS.title: Planning, Design and Development Professional Dissertation
PLUS.description: Credit on acceptance of Planning, Design and Development Professional Dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC.

PLUS.title: Planning, Design and Development Professional Dissertation
PLUS.description: Credit on acceptance of Planning, Design and Development Professional Dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC.

PLUS.title: Planning, Design and Development Professional   Dissertation
PLUS.description: Credit on acceptance of Planning, Design and Development Professional Dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC.

RED.title: Introduction to Real Estate
RED.description: Basic understanding of the real estate industry, the process of real estate development and investment, and the key players involved.

RED.title: Real Estate Career Seminar
RED.description: Career assessment and preparation; real estate industry overview; reflection on experiences.

RED.title: Real Estate Internship Seminar
RED.description: Real estate development skills for practice; internship seminar; leadership, group dynamics and presentation skills; application of management; organizational diversity; reflection on experiences.

RED.title: Introduction to Finance in Cities
RED.description: Basic understanding of public finance, public debt, public-private joint ventures, time value of money, present value, risk and return, discounted cash flows, leverage and taxes.

RED.title: Real Estate Development Fundamentals
RED.description: Real estate overview; evolution of cities and neighborhoods; product types; introduction to valuation.

RED.title: Real Estate Development Analysis
RED.description: Real estate development feasibility and analysis; underwriting local fundamentals including neighborhood and city change, real estate capital flows.

RED.title: Residential Properties
RED.description: Cities and urban form created through various real estate product types. Case studies and site visits.

RED.title: Retail Properties
RED.description: Cities and urban form created through various real estate product types. Case studies and site visits.

RED.title: History of Planning and Development
RED.description: Historical evolution of planning and development. How changing modes of planning and development have shaped the built landscape throughout the century.

RED.title: Designing Livable Communities
RED.description: Theories and concepts of livable communities and good city form; case studies of historical and current best practices; field visits; collaborative design project.

RED.title: Analyzing Real Estate Markets
RED.description: Macro and micro-analysis of urban property markets; demographics; location choice; regulation

RED.title: Advanced Finance and Investment for Real Estate  Development
RED.description: Advanced real estate principles. Underwriting property valuation and deal structure including risk and return. Debt and equity markets; difference between development and existing assets.

RED.title: Mixed Use Development Process
RED.description: Design, financial, legal and management challenges of mixed use real estate development; field project.

RED.title: Directed Research
RED.description: Individual research and readings.

RED.title: Real Estate Practice and Principles
RED.description: Fundamental principles of real estate analysis; economics; capital markets; development decision making; relationships between real estate markets and federal, state and local government policies; property value.

RED.title: Applications of Real Estate Finance to Problems of Developme
RED.description: Advanced topics in finance applied to cases and problems of real estate development; emphasis on structuring, finance and evaluation of various types of development projects.

RED.title: Legal Issues in Real Estate Development
RED.description: Ownership and transfer of real estate; formation and enforcement  of contracts; business associations; environmental regulation;  taxation of property transfers; acquiring, financing, leasing of  commercial property.

RED.title: Community Design and Site Planning
RED.description: Physical implementation of development projects. Students will develop concept plan, preliminary design and marketing plan for selected domestic and/or international development sites.

RED.title: Comparative International Development Workshop
RED.description: Comparative study tour focused on understanding international real  estate development practices and markets, site visits and meeting  with principals.

RED.title: Directed Research
RED.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

RED.title: Affordable Housing
RED.description: An evaluation of various real estate development product types. Case studies and site visits.

RED.title: Hotel/Resort Development
RED.description: An evaluation of various real estate development product types. Case studies and site visits.

RED.title: Multi-Family Development
RED.description: An evaluation of various real estate development product types. Case studies and site visits.

RED.title: Retail Development
RED.description: An evaluation of various real estate development product types. Case studies and site visits.

RED.title: Urban Infill
RED.description: An evaluation of various real estate development product types. Case studies and site visits.

BKN.title: Neurobehavioral Basis of Movement
BKN.description: Introduction to the neurobehavioral and neurobiological basis of  movement.  Review of information processing, neural basis of  perception/action, motor systems, and higher cognitive function  and behavior.  Recommended preparation: biology and physiology

BKN.title: Physiological Basis of Voluntary Movement
BKN.description: Consideration of the neuromuscular and musculoskeletal physiology  of voluntary movement.

BKN.title: Readings in Biokinesiology
BKN.description: Independent review and synthesis of papers appearing in the current literature.

BKN.title: Movement Analysis for Sport
BKN.description: Perform systematic quantitative biomechanical analyses of common movements in sport and exercise using a variety of motion analysis techniques.

BKN.title: Advanced Dissection Anatomy
BKN.description: Advanced analysis of systems or structures with dissection.  Emphasis on correlations with function.

BKN.title: Directed Research
BKN.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be  applied to the degree to be determnined by the department.  Graded  CR/NC.

BKN.title: Sports Science Internship
BKN.description: A combination of observation, participation (testing/assessments, training) and analysis and interpretation of data. Supervision and guidance from the internship mentor will vary depending on the setting and credit hours. Allows students a progressively increasing amount of responsibility with respect to athlete/subject and/or data involvement.

BKN.title: Technology in Sport: Field Assessment of Athlete Performance
BKN.description: Introduction of topics related to assessments of athlete performance on the field or in the sports setting. Focus on understanding and applying available technology to athlete field assessments. Overview of the techniques and hardware used to assess athlete performance outside of a laboratory setting.

BKN.title: Technology in Sport: Physiological Assessments
BKN.description: Introduction to the physiological assessment of athlete performance. Focus on understanding, performing and interpreting physiological assessments such as metabolic testing (VO2max), hydration, oxygen saturation, body composition, lactate threshold, heart rate, core body temperature.

BKN.title: Advanced Independent Study in Biokinesiology
BKN.description: Examination of selected mechanisms underlying normal movement and  pathological movement.  Study of methods used to investigate these  mechanisms.  Doctoral students only.

BKN.title: Introduction to Data Science for Biomedical and Movement Res
BKN.description: For students in biomedical, biological and movement sciences who want to learn modern advanced statistical learning methods and to improve R programming.

BKN.title: Research
BKN.description: Research leading to doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

SWKC.title: Systemic Challenges and Social Change in the United States
SWKC.description: Historical and philosophical foundations of social conditions in the United States and their implications for public policy.

SWKC.title: Juvenile Justice in America
SWKC.description: The historical and current context of America's juvenile justice system and its influence on children, youth and families.

SWKC.title: Adolescent Gang Intervention
SWKC.description: The incidence of gangs (particularly in the Los Angeles area),  gang interventions, and policies developed to address the growing  gang situation.

SWKC.title: National Military Immersion in Washington, DC: Military and
SWKC.description: A short study at the campus, online, and in Washington, DC addressing policies and programs for military members, veterans, and their families. Priority enrollment given to currently enrolled MSW students.

SWKC.title: Policy Analysis and Advocacy in a Comparative Social Policy Context
SWKC.description: Examination of the evolution of American and other welfare states  in selected nations.  Analysis of global welfare institutions.   Engaging in policy analysis in a comparative context.

SWKC.title: Theories for Practice with Small Systems
SWKC.description: Early practice theories and their historical roots are examined. Implications for evolving current practice theories with individuals, families, and groups are discussed.

SWKC.title: Multiple Regression for Social Work Research
SWKC.description: Multivariate statistical methods including descriptive and inferential statistics, parametric and non-parametric tests of hypotheses; correlation, analysis of variance, multiple regression, and factor analysis; utilization of computer programs for statistical analysis.

SWKC.title: Social Work Research Methods II: Issues in Research for Social Work Practice
SWKC.description: Research methods to provide students with advanced methodological knowledge in two areas related to social work practice: psychotherapy outcome research, and program research.

SWKC.title: Writing Successful Dissertation Research Grants
SWKC.description: Prepares doctoral students to write and submit applications to obtain extramural funding to support their dissertation research. Students will learn about opportunities and eligibility requirements for federal and foundation supported dissertation research grants, how grants are reviewed and scored once submitted, and how to write successful proposals. Recommended preparation: Completion of a qualitative or mixed methods course is preferred.

SWKC.title: Introduction to Qualitative and Mixed Research Methods
SWKC.description: Overview of the use of qualitative and mixed methods in social,  clinical and health services research.

SWKC.title: Research
SWKC.description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.
